From Al Capone to Joe Bonanno, godfathers have turned grandfathers while behind bars. The heads of four of the city's five organized crime families were convicted and sentenced to 100 years in prison each in 1986. The fifth - Paul Castellano - never heard those verdicts. He was gunned down months earlier in Gotti's alleged grandstand play for control of the Gambino family. But claiming Gotti killed Castellano is one thing; proving it is another. He has never been charged in the killing, although a much-rumored racketeering indictment including the hit is reportedly due this month. Three times Gotti has appeared in New York City courts on other charges, and three times he has walked outaa free man, earning the nickname ``The Teflon Don.'' The acquittals, combined with his reputation for violence and fine clothing, have given Gotti national notoriety. Yet that image may bring his downfall, experts say. Castellano's approach - described by one as ``much more sophisticated racketeering than Gotti's'' and therefore harder to detect and prosecute - is more conducive to a lengthy stay at the head of an organized crime family, they believe. Unless, of course, somebody inside the organization decides to kill you nine days before Christmas. ``Paul Castellano was a class act. He was the emerging racketeer of the '90s. There's a great variance between Mr. Gotti and Mr. Castellano,'' said Fred Martens, director of the Pennsylvania Crime Commission. ``One was a businessman racketeer, the other is a plain old-fashioned gangster, right out of the '20s. That's the difference.'' Castellano's style, which included the creation of citywide concrete scam that netted millions and an aversion to drug trafficking, was in marked contrast to the Gambinos under Gotti, investigators say. ``Castellano seemed shrewder. He kept a low profile, and he also bridged the legitimate and illegitimate worlds, which gave him a little more freedom,'' said Michael Chertoff, acting U.S. attorney in Newark. Chertoff was prosecuting Castellano and the heads of the four other mob families when the reputed Gambino boss and bodyguard Thomas Bilotti were gunned down Dec. 16, 1985, outside a midtown Manhattan steakhouse. Gotti's attorney, Bruce Cutler, noted his client is often linked to the slaying, but asserted Gotti's innocence. ``Take this poor Mr. Castellano who was killed. How many times have the newspapers said my client had something to do with this? He didn't,'' said Cutler. Chertoff believes ``Big Paul,'' in some ways, wielded more power than Gotti. ``Gotti seems powerful, but that may be because the other bosses are gone,'' said Chertoff. ``Gotti is high profile, he has an aura, but that's media stuff. That doesn't translate into real power.'' Real power is cash and soldiers. Gotti has plenty of both; he has increased the number of ``made'' - or initiated - family members since taking over, said Bonalovonta. Most of the new members deal drugs, he said. The Gambino forces now number about 500 made members, he estimated. The Gambinos' other sources of income remain the same: gambling, extortion, loan-sharking, union control, airport rip-offs and dominance of the garment district. Although the Gambino family is the strongest financially, Gotti's reign has seen its share of problems. Thomas Gambino, son of late family boss Carlo, has been indicted for allegedly controlling the garment district through extortion and coercion. Gene Gotti, John's brother, is doing a 50-year stretch for heroin trafficking. And Frank De Cicco, a trusted Gotti underboss, was killed by a car bomb. The same fate could await the man his friends call Johnny Boy. Gotti has twice been targeted for hits: once in a bungled attempt outside the boss's Queens hangout, the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club, and once by the Genovese family in a dispute. The gunman responsible for the first attempt was later found on Staten Island with five bullets in his head; the second bid was undercut when FBI agents got wind of the plans and warned Gotti. The brutal retaliation for the first attempt added to Gotti's reputation, as did his three acquittals - on an assault case, a racketeering trial and the shooting of a union official.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Exports More Than Make Up For Domestic Sales Drop
DOC.TEXT: Overseas sales of U.S. cigarettes have risen dramatically the last five years, more than offsetting a decline in domestic use by health-conscious Americans, an Agriculture Department report says. Cigarette output dropped 20 percent from 1981 to 1985. This year, the report said, production may be up 3 percent from the 1985 level. Domestic use has dropped 12 percent since 1985, the report said. ``The continued decline in U.S. cigarette consumption is due to rising prices and taxes, slipping social acceptance, health concerns, and restrictions on where people can smoke,'' the report said. Further, analysts expect the decline in domestic cigarette use to continue in the 1990s, perhaps by 3 percent or more each year. The report, by Verner N. Grise of the department's Economic Research Service, is in the December issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine, published by the agency. In 1985, sales abroad totaled 59 billion cigarettes. That is down 29 percent from the peak of 83 billion ``pieces'' set in 1981. ``In 1990, the U.S. is probably exporting 160 billion cigarettes, almost three times the 1985 mark,'' the report said. ``The phenomenal growth partly reflects lowered trade barriers in Japan, Taiwan and South Korea.'' Other factors have been the high quality of U.S. cigarettes, rising incomes in importing countries, and the weakening of the dollar against foreign currencies. Recent moves in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union toward market-oriented systems also have spurred increased interest in U.S. cigarettes. The Soviet Union has agreed with U.S. manufacturers to buy more than 35 billion cigarettes over the next two years, with further sales expected. The Soviets will swap goods for part of the cigarettes, but the report said some analysts are concerned that Moscow will have trouble finding hard currency to pay for the rest. Another indication of the growing foreign markets is a decision by some U.S. companies to set up manufacturing plants in what was East Germany, ``a strong sign of the region's hunger'' for American cigarettes, the report said. Still another example is Thailand's agreement to abide by a recent ruling by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade against Thailand's 10-year ban on cigarette imports. ``Efforts to open the Thai market were hampered by an unusual alliance between U.S. anti-smoking groups and the Thai tobacco industry,'' the report said. At home, U.S. cigarettes are finding a tough market outlook. The report cited a Gallup poll survey in July that indicated a growing anti-smoking sentiment among Americans. ``Smoking restrictions have increased markedly and smoking is now banned on all continental U.S. airline flights and all flights to and from Alaska and Hawaii that last less than six hours,'' the report said. Despite the tighter restrictions and declines in tobacco use, Americans will spend a record $44 billion on tobacco products this year, the report said. About 95 percent of that will be for cigarettes. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Gross farm receipts from crop sales in 1991 could exceed $80 billion, up by as much as $5 billion from this year's forecast, according to Agriculture Department economists. ``Pushed by low stocks and pulled by a strong livestock sector, feed grain sales could increase as much as $3 billion,'' an outlook conference report said last week. ``Corn receipts are likely to be up 10 percent, while soybean receipts are expected to rise above $11 billion.'' Corn production in 1991 is expected to increase, if the government's acreage reduction requirements are trimmed from this year's 10 percent level, the report said. ``Some producers may opt not to participate in the government program (in 1991), expanding their planted acreage, and increasing their future base,'' it said. Soybean prices are anticipated to be stable but could be dampened by large plantings on ``triple base'' acres, a feature of the 1990 farm law that gives farmers more choice on using land. Direct payments to farmers in 1991 under the new law are expected to drop 10 percent to 15 percent from this year. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Turkey production almost doubled during the 1980s and is headed for another gain next year, according to Agriculture Department projections. Total 1991 output is forecast at around 4.8 billion pounds. That represents an increase of 5 percent to 7 percent from this year. The 1990 increase was 9 percent. ``Average wholesale prices in 1991 are expected to remain nearly the same as in 1990, with slight increases likely early in the year,'' an outlook report said last week. ``Continued high prices for red meats will help turkey prices, as will the support to the market provided by the continued growth in purchases of processed turkey meats.'' Per capita consumption of turkey is expected to rise to more than 19 pounds next year, up one pound from the 1990 average.

DOC.HEAD: Priest With Messianic Appeal Leads Presidential Race in Haiti
DOC.TEXT: Church bells peal and a man with a megaphone mimics a crowing rooster as the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide rides into town on horseback to be greeted by thousands of adoring supporters. The fiery leftist priest, revered by the masses as a prophet, is taking his remarkable quest for the presidency across Haiti in a campaign imbued with messianic symbolism and patriotic fervor. He calls the campaign Operation ``Lavales,'' or Torrent, a biblical flood to cleanse Haiti of corruption and tyranny; its emblem is the fighting cock, representing Haiti's coming sunrise. ``With Aristide, Lord, there will be no dishonesty,'' the people chant as the slight, bespectacled cleric nicknamed ``Titid'' appears in their midst. Aristide, 37, has survived at least three assassination attempts and was expelled from his Roman Catholic order in 1988 for preaching revolution. He is widely regarded as the frontrunner among 11 candidates in the Dec. 16 election. Supporters say the charismatic priest offers the best hope of giving the impoverished Caribbean nation not only the first democratically elected president in its turbulent 186-year history, but the stability of a government with huge popular support. Critics accuse Aristide of demagoguery and say his a presidency based on emotional mass appeal would pose the threat of a theocratic dictatorship. That appeal has been evident on campaign stops across the country, from the slums of Port-au-Prince, the capital, to the northern city of Cap-Haitien, where an estimated 60,000 people took part in what was probably the biggest demonstration in the city's history. In Jacmel, a crumbling port on the southern coast, perhaps 5,000 people, including hundreds of students in brown and blue school uniforms, poured into the town square for a recent Aristide rally. Dismounting a horse he rode from the outskirts of the city, Aristide plunged into one of his trademark question-response orations in which the distinctions between national pride and Christian love are blurred. Aristide: ``Young people, you know what it is to be lovesick?'' Crowd: ``Yes!'' Aristide: ``Are you in love with Haiti?'' Crowd: ``Yes!'' All sing the lilting ``Haiti Cherie,'' or ``Darling Haiti,'' which is to Haitians what ``America the Beautiful'' is to Americans. Then Aristide: ``We are going to do away with injustice - totally.'' Together: ``Totally, totally, totally, totally, totally, totally.'' Aristide unexpectedly entered the presidential race in mid-October after Roger Lafontant, reputed former head of the Duvalier dictatorship's infamous Tonton Macoute militia, declared his candidacy. Lafontant was later disqualified on a technicality. Although no opinion polls have been published, the consensus among political observers is that Aristide commands much wider support than any of Haiti's veteran politicians. ``Aristide is the figurehead of a messianic movement, the incarnation of a collective dream,'' says Laennec Hurbon, a specialist on religious movements in the Caribbean. ``His responsibility to his following is not the same as that of a politician to his constituency.'' Aristide gained a nationwide following largely from radio broadcasts of his electrifying sermons in which he railed against successive military regimes that have ruled Haiti since the February 1986, when Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier was driven into exile. He is an adherent of liberation theology, which promotes political and social awareness among the poor. In September 1988, thugs armed with guns, machetes and spikes burst into Aristide's St. Jean Bosco Church during Mass, killing at least 12 parishioners and wounding 70. Three months later, Aristide, was expelled from the conservative Salesian Order for refusing to tone down his rhetoric. The only other presidential candidate whose appeal approaches Aristide's is the moderate Louis Dejoie Jr., who drew thousands of supporters on a recent campaign swing of the southern peninsula. Marc Bazin, a former World Bank official frequently mentioned as a favorite of the U.S. Embassy, which denies any preference, is also seen as running strongly. Bazin's National Alliance for Democracy andPProgress, the country's best-funded political machine, is expected to dominate Parliament after the election. If Bazin fails to win the presidency, he could still become prime minister since the president must chose a prime minister from among the majority party. Under Haiti's constitution, the president is head of state but the prime minister runs the government. Aristide has said he would ``embrace'' the next prime minister, but many Haitians see the potential for conflict. Voter registration has reached 3.3 million, or 92 percent of the electorate, according to election officials - a phenomenon largely attributed to Aristide's candidacy.

DOC.HEAD: Report Urges End to Pro-IBM Bias in Computer Purchases
DOC.TEXT: Computer purchasing officials in the Navy and possibly in other government agencies have too cozy a relationship with private-sector contractors such as IBM Corp., says a congressional report issued today. The House Government Operations Committee report says there should be stronger regulations and better oversight to eliminate bias in awarding computer contracts. The report follows a year-long probe touched off by complaints in 1988 from six IBM competitors who said they had been frozen out of the Navy's multibillion-dollar computer market. ``Through a combination of agency malfeasance and the dominance of one vendor, the fair and open system contemplated by Congress has been torpedoed in Navy (computer) procurement,'' the report says. It details ``a tangled web of agency and contractor abuse, improprieties, and illegalities,'' said Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., the committee chairman. ``It's an old story that when the rule of law breaks down, it is the strong who benefit.'' The committee said its investigation had been broadened to include other agencies, including the National Institutes of Health, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Treasury Department. All have large, complex computer systems and are major computer equipment buyers. The report says IBM ``appears for the most part not to be responsible for the bizarre Navy ... acquisition system, but merely its willing beneficiary.'' Former naval officer John Cahill testified during one hearing that his commanding officer, while attending a free IBM promotional training seminar, telephoned Cahill and ordered him to ``change our procurement strategy to go after'' a new IBM technology, the report said. Cahill said he refused and awarded the contract to another company. The report described the officer's participation in the IBM program as ``clearly improper.'' At least 128 Navy officials were trained by IBM in San Jose, Calif., between 1985 and 1987. Navy Undersecretary J. Daniel Howard, in a Sept. 7 letter to Conyers, said IBM's training of Cahill's superior was not an illegal gratuity because IBM did not win the contract it sought. But Howard acknowledged there was an ``appearance of impropriety.'' The General Services Administration, the agency responsible for overseeing government purchases of automated data processing equipment, should take the lead in fixing the system to eliminate bias, the report said. It said the GSA should review training programs and seminars offered by computer contractors to determine whether they are proper for government employees, and should issue clear guidelines on contacts between federal buyers and contractors. GSA should review government computer purchases more frequently and carefully, the report said. ``Agencies cannot be trusted to follow the rules and regulations governing (computer) acquisitions,'' it said. Navy spokesman Lt. James Wood would not comment beyond saying that the Navy had cooperated with the committee during the investigation. IBM spokesman Mark Holcomb said the company endorsed the proposed review of policies on relations between the government and private-sector computer companies. But he said it would be unfair if Congress, in ordering such a review, implied that IBM's dealings with the Navy had been improper. ``We did not do anything wrong,'' Holcomb said. ``If they want to change the regulations after the fact, we will comply. But we're in complete compliance with (existing) regulations and have been all along.''

DOC.HEAD: Students Help Create Civil Rights Museum at Lincoln Memorial
DOC.TEXT: The teen-agers listened spellbound as Rachelle Horowitz recalled the sweltering day when Martin Luther King Jr. stood just a few feet away down the steps of the Lincoln Memorial. For these budding historians, children of the me-decade '80s, the civil rights movement had been an abstraction in a textbook. But the 17 students from high schools in 15 states and the District of Columbia walked away from the memorial with a sense of awe that they can convey to the millions of tourists who climb the same steps each year. ``It's more exciting here than learning it in school,'' said Barbara Burnette, a 19-year-old senior at Edison High School in Minneapolis. ``With books, you're like, right, oh yeah. You've got to be there to really get into it.'' The students were selected to help the National Park Service plan and raise money for a new museum inside the Lincoln Memorial to honor the legacy of Lincoln, King and the nation's other leaders in civil rights. ``I used to think Lincoln was just a great man who was tall and wore a hat,'' said Maureen May, 17, of Copley, Ohio. ``But now I want his ideals to come alive. I want everyone to know about his legacy and to use it.'' The students spent the past week in the Washington area talking to park service planners, touring historic sites and listening to people like Horowitz, who participated in the 1963 March on Washington and other major demonstrations. Horowitz, then 23, was the transportation director for the March on Washington. She pointed around the corner inside the memorial where U.S. Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., a black student protest leader at the time, hurriedly rewrote one of the opening speeches. She pointed down the steps to the very spot where King stood and told the world, ``I have a dream.'' ``He silenced a quarter of a million people on a hot August day,'' she told the students. Horowitz provided the students with the sights, sounds and the sense of the throng spread out before King. The National Park Service has involved the students in planning the Lincoln Memorial museum in a way that it has never used the public before, said Jane Radford, a park service planner. ``This is not done in the museum business,'' she said. ``This was particularly appropriate and very exciting because Lincoln's legacy is often carried on by the youth of this country in protest and demonstration.'' The proposed museum capped a two-year effort begun by a Scottsdale, Ariz., high school history class. The students were upset that their state wouldn't honor King with a holiday. The students were picked by the American Federation of Teachers and other organizations to represent a cross-section of ethnic backgrounds. Their selection was based on a demonstrated interest in Lincoln and good communication and leadership skills. Later they will coordinate a student drive to raise $300,000 for the exhibit by collecting pennies. The students visited the park service's interpretative design center in Harpers Ferry, W.Va., where they submitted their proposal for an exhibit featuring interactive videos, continuous films, computer quizzes, artifacts and recordings. The students came from high schools in Alabama, Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, the District of Columbia, Florida, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Missouri, Nevada, New Mexico, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Utah and Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Records Produced For WWII-Era Servicemen Now Available to All
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: The recording sessions were held in Quonset huts, on movie sets, in night clubs after hours. Some of the biggest names in show business, from old-timers like Al Jolson to newcomers like Frank Sinatra, performed. But the records, produced in a six-year period during and after World War II, were heard only by American servicemen overseas. Now, through the efforts of a retired Navy officer who helped oversee their production, they are on the U.S. market. Nearly 920 12-inch, 78-rpm records were produced by the Army and Navy from 1943 through 1949 as morale boosters. They were called V-Discs. The records - 8 million copies altogether - were accompanied by 125,000 spring-operated windup phonographs, each with 100 steel needles. ``They were played on ships, in foxholes, in trenches, on airplanes, in hospitals,'' said Edmond P. DiGiannantonio. Digi, as he is known, ran the Navy's part of the program and keeps a well-preserved copy of each record in a closet in his lakeside home here. One serviceman wrote a letter saying he and his buddies were playing a V-Disc as they headed to the D-Day invasion of Normandy, DiGiannantonio said. The program was started after an Army musical branch captain named Bob Vincent suggested to Army officials in Washington that they get popular band leaders like Benny Goodman and Artie Shaw to record for the troops. The colonel, Vincent's superior, said, ``Look, these guys don't want to hear any swing music or any jazz; they want marching music,'' DiGiannantonio recalled. The colonel's reluctance was overcome and ``we went on to include all types of music in all releases,'' said DiGiannantonio. ``From Toscanini to Spike Jones. All the way.'' When the Navy started looking for an officer to run the Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard part of the program, DiGiannantonio was in a hospital in Boston, recovering from wounds he suffered when his ship, the heavy cruiser Vincennes, was sunk off Guadalcanal. He had played violin, piano and saxophone in high school in Boston and at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, held a broadcast engineer's license and had recorded Shaw, Glenn Miller, Goodman and other band leaders when they came to town. So he got the job. Along with each box of 20 or 30 records went copies of a questionnaire asking the servicemen to say what kind of music they wanted. ``White Christmas'' was the most requested piece. About 60 percent wanted jazz or swing, 20 percent or so classical and some country and western or others. Marches didn't make it. Some of the music came from movie film tracks and transcriptions of radio broadcasts, but many were live recordings by artists donating their services. During the early years, they were the only records made. The American Federation of Musicians, at odds with the recording companies over royalties, had banned all recording until the dispute was settled. Union President James Caesar Petrillo waived the ban to permit the recordings for the troops. ``We recorded in night clubs, hotel ballrooms, movie studios, Quonset huts, Army bases, Navy bases, wherever the artists were,'' said DiGiannantonio, now 73. ``In those days when you went on a job you traveled by bus all night. They'd do a session and wind up at one or two in the morning, and then come to a studio and lug all the instruments and record for us.'' The services had tried sending shellac records overseas earlier, but found that most of them were broken before they arrived. The V-discs were recorded on more durable vinylite. When vinylite became scarce because it was critically needed for insulation, they switched to Formvar, a product developed in Canada. Instructions on changing needles were often ignored, so many of the records wore out overseas. Others were left behind when the war ended. DiGiannantonio said that when the V-disc program ended, officials ordered the remaining disks destroyed to prevent commercial use. Nevertheless, the Library of Congress has a nearly complete set. Their quality ``ranges from very good to poor, depending on the source,'' said music librarian Sam Brylawski. ``Remember how heavy those old needles were,'' said Brylawski. ``That would gouge a record like a V-disc. If we got one from someone who really liked their recording a lot, it could very well be beat up.'' DiGiannantonio took good care of his. They have been transferred to cassettes and compact discs, with no adjustment of the original sound. ``Some people said let's enhance it, and do this or this,'' said DiGiannantonio. ``But we said this is the way it was, and we are going to do it that way.'' DiGiannantonio said he has clearance from the Defense Department to market the recordings, and is working with the American Federation of Musicians and Broadcast Music Inc. about payment of royalties. He said much of the profit will go to the musicians' union retirement fund, or to the artists, their families, or their estates. The first installment is a three-cassette set with 37 numbers including Glenn Miller playing ``Chattanooga Choo Choo,'' Jolson singing ``Mammy'' and Connie Boswell crooning ``Good Night, Sweetheart.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - The first V-disk installment is available for $24.95 in cassette or $29.95 in compact disc from V-Disc, P.O. Box 6, Springfield, Va. 22150, toll-free telephone 1-800-323-3808.

DOC.HEAD: Selective Service Ready To Turn on the Tap - If Needed
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Also in Monday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Seventeen years after the government's authority for a military draft expired, the Selective Service System is alive and well - and on standby. But if President Bush and Congress gave the order, the Selective Service could start issuing draft notices within days and supply up to 100,000 young men within a month. Bush has said as recently as last week that he doesn't want to see the draft reactivated, but it's the job of the Selective Service to be ready - just in case. The agency has 270 fulltime employees, 2,000 local draft boards and a entire system for resuming the draft if ordered to do so. ``It's business as usual because that is our mission - to be ready,'' Selective Service spokeswoman Barbi Richardson said. ``We were ready a year ago, and we'd be ready tomorrow.'' However, Selective Service Director Samuel K. Lessey Jr. said ``our agency has had no indication that a draft is needed in response to the Middle East crisis.'' Still, the buildup of U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf has led to growing public concern and debate about the draft, which was one of the most divisive issues of the Vietnam War. Former Navy Secretary James Webb last week questioned Bush's buildup of the troops in the gulf, but said ``if the president is serious about going on the offensive, he should call for an immediate resumption of the draft'' to avoid troop shortages. The president's authority to draft men into the armed forces, which had been routinely renewed by Congress every four years, expired on July 1, 1973, three months after the last U.S. soldiers left Vietnam. The military then began depending only on voluntary enlistments. Even if the draft were reinstated quickly, there would be a significant time lag before conscripts reached the gulf. By law, draftees may not be sent oversees for three months after induction. Lawrence Korb, a Brookings Institution analyst who was assistant secretary of Defense for manpower until 1985, said it would take a year to get conscripts trained and over to the gulf. ``I don't think it (the draft) is likely,'' Korb said. ``Militarily, it doesn't make sense.'' Martin Binkin, another Brookings Institution analyst, said ``I do not think that the average American kid has to worry about conscription.'' Many are worried nonetheless. ``We receive calls from mothers ... from the young men, their wives, their girlfriends, their grandmothers, their grandfathers,'' the Selective Service's Ms. Richardson said. ``We let them know there is no draft and we do not anticipate one.'' David Treber of the National Interreligious Service Board for Conscientious Objectors said his organization also is getting more calls. ``We've even had mothers who have 14-year-old sons wanting to get information,'' Treber said. Other calls come from college students who say ```I registered for the draft a couple years ago and never thought it would amount to anything and now I'm worried,''' Treber said. James Blackwell of the Center for Strategic and International Studies said the need for a draft may increase as voluntary enlistments drop off due to concern about a possible war in the Persian Gulf. ``The longer it lasts and the closer it comes to a shooting conflict, the closer we come to a draft,'' he said. The Selective Service insists it is doing nothing unusual in response to the troop buildup in the gulf. Should Congress authorize a return to the draft, the Selective Service within hours or days could hold a lottery, based on dates of birth, to determine the order in which men would be inducted, Ms. Richardson said. Top priority for the draft would be young men who turned 20 during the same calendar year as the lottery. Young men already are required to register with Selective Service when they turn 18. Once draft notices were issued, draftees would have 10 days to report to a military processing station for examination and, perhaps, immediate induction. Only after a young man got a draft notice could he file a request to postpone or avoid military service. Reasons for a delay might include an emergency such as serious illness or a death in the family. Others might request classification as conscientious objectors who oppose participation in war. They would be required to serve either in a non-combat position or in a civilian job that benefited the nation. Under one change that took effect near the end of the Vietnam War, young men no longer can defer military service for years because they are in college. Deferments now last only until the end of the current semester. Requests to delay or avoid military service are considered by local draft boards made up of trained volunteers. The five-member boards meet yearly to consider sample cases - draft or no draft.

DOC.HEAD: Conference On Blacks and Jews Looks to Build Coalition
DOC.TEXT: Blacks and Jews, who marched shoulder to shoulder during the civil rights movement of the 1960s, have often feuded since, but leaders of both groups are hoping an institute founded here will help heal the rift. ``There is a need for a coalition of blacks and Jews,'' said Dillard University President Dr. Samuel Dubois Cook, the man behind the National Center for Black-Jewish Relations. ``We can do so many things together - fighting poverty, working for social justice, getting blacks into the mainstream, improving education and fighting common enemies.'' More than 200 people were invited to the center for a two-day conference titled ``Healing the Broken Community,'' which ended Wednesday. ``This center is not only important, it's a model for the future of our society,'' said Rabbi Robert J. Marx of Congregation Hakafa in Glencoe, Ill., co-chairman of the Black-Jewish Dialogue in Chicago and a speaker at the conference. Dillard, a predominantly black, nonsectarian liberal arts and sciences college, gave $100,000 to the center when it was founded this year and plans to raise up to $10 million for it. The program has been needed for a long time, said A.I. Botnick, executive director of the South Central Region of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith. ``I went through the period of close coalition and common goals the two communities shared in the 1960s,'' Botnick said. ``When that fell apart, nothing was done to heal it. While some individuals made attempts to find solutions, what were to be major remedies became Band-Aids. This institute is the first effort of its kind and it has great prospects for the entire nation.'' While blacks and Jews during the 1960s were united in their support for integration and voting rights, economic and ethnic issues helped divide them over the next 20 years. For instance, former New York City Mayor Edward Koch was an active supporter of the civil rights movement but later angered blacks with his stiff opposition to hiring quotas and accusations of anti-Semitism. In 1984, relations became especially tense after a Washington Post reporter revealed the Rev. Jesse Jackson had referred to Jews as ``hymie'' and New York City as ``Hymietown.'' A conference in April 1989 examined the root causes of the near-collapse of the alliance and revealed a widespread desire for reconciliation, Cook said. ``It's criminal,'' Cook said. ``If there are any natural allies in history, it should be blacks and Jews. For them not to be wrings my heart. During the 1960s, the two groups played key roles in the civil rights movement. We have been separated by a number of things including some people in both groups who have said things that have hurt us.'' Most of last week's sessions were closed so that participants could discuss issues frankly, Cook said. Workshops were set up on economics, education and the role of the media and others in pitting blacks and Jews against each other, Cook said. One man who may help unify the two groups is David Duke, the Republican state representative and former Ku Klux Klan leader who ran for the U.S. Senate. ``There are people and groups in this country who would like to see the Jews and blacks wiped out. In addition to the positive things that can flow from this conference, we can work together against our common enemies like David Duke,'' Cook said.

DOC.HEAD: Results of German Elections
With PM-Germany-Elections, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a breakdown of nearly complete official results of Sunday's general elections, the first free all-German vote since 1932. A total of 77.8 percent of eligible voters cast ballots. The governing coalition: Christian Democrats - 36.7 percent of the vote, 262 seats in Parliament. Christian Social Union (CDU Bavarian sister party) - 7.1 percent, 51 seats. Free Democrats - 11 percent, 79 seats. Opposition parties: Social Democratic Party - 33.5 percent, 239 seats. Party for Democratic Socialism, (former East German Communists) - 2.4 percent (9.9 percent in East Germany) 17 seats. Greens-Alliance 90 - 1.2 percent (5.9 percent in East German), 8 seats. he rest of the vote went to smaller parties that did not gain seats in Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: American Indians to Offer Peace Pipe to Saddam
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A delegation of South Dakota Indians prayed on the lawn of a downtown Baghdad hotel and said they would offer their sacred peace pipe to the Iraqi president. ``When President Saddam Hussein has prayed for peace the Teton will return to the land of their ancestors and ask President Bush to pray for peace also,'' Arvol Looking Horse said Sunday. He leads a seven-member delegation representing the elders of the traditional Teton Sioux tribes, on a visit at the invitation of the Iraqi government. After praying at the al-Rashid Hotel, Looking Horse said he wanted the Iraqi government to organize the peace pipe ceremony. Smokers of the pipe experience their true feelings, he said. ``The Teton believe that if all humans can speak the truth of their hearts together all things are possible,'' said Garfield Grass Rope, another member of the delegation. The delegatation leaves for home Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Dizzy Gillespie, Katharine Hepburn Among Honorees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS WASHINGTON-dated item in AM-Washington in Brief, a0455, to CORRECT spelling of Lemmon in 7th graf, ``At the Kennedy ...''
DOC.TEXT: The work of five performers and musicians who received the 1990 Kennedy Center honors has been characterized by President Bush as emphasizing the ``crucial role'' the arts play in American society. During a star-studded, black-tie White House reception Sunday night, Bush honored jazz musician Dizzy Gillespie, actress Katharine Hepburn, composer Jule Styne, director Billy Wilder and opera singer Rise Stevens. The president paid personal tribute to each award winner, describing Gillespie as a ``magician of the musical form,'' and remembering Hepburn for her originality. The awards highlight the ``crucial role that art must play in the fabric of our society,'' he said. Guests circulated at a cocktail party before leaving for a Kennedy Center gala. Bush, meanwhile, left for a five-nation trip to Latin America. At the Kennedy Center, the five received stage tributes from - among others - actors Bill Cosby, Jack Lemmon, Walter Matthau and opera singer Marilyn Horne during a show taped for television broadcast Dec. 28. The show, hosted by television newsman Walter Cronkite, included film clips of the lives and achievements of award recipients. Other personalities appearing in the show included columnist Art Buchwald, and actors Glenn Close, Angela Lansbury and Hal Linden. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan and White House chief of staff John Sununu were among the government officials in the audience.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Relishing Newly Found Confidence and Popularity
With PM-Germany-Elections, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Helmut Kohl's re-election campaign showed the German chancellor in a new, self-assured style: more elegantly dressed, relaxed, a better speaker. And the crowds were bigger, too, giving Kohl more enthusiastic receptions than ever in his eight years as chancellor. Having delivered the unification of East and West Germany in record time, Kohl had been heavily favored all along to win a third four-year term. But in the last four weeks of the campaign, the 60-year-old Kohl still made 28 campaign appearances, doing what he likes the best: working the crowds and winning elections. One of the last was in southern Germany in Offenburg, pushing his wheelchair-bound interior minister, Wolfgang Schaeuble, onto the podium. Schaeuble barely survived an assassination attempt in October and the gesture was vintage Kohl, a move that would strike the hearts of ordinary Germans. But it was not only electioneering. Kohl was deeply moved by Schaeuble's ordeal and had tears in his eyes when he had visited the bedside of his trusted minister and possible successor. In Chemnitz, in former East Germany, before speaking at a campaign rally, Kohl stopped at a local inn to have coffee and banter with the owners. These are the times he says he likes the best, mingling with ordinary people, when he feels like a ``farmer at the plough. You can smell the earth.'' According to nearly complete official returns, Kohl's center-right governing coalition won 54.8 percent of the vote Sunday, to 33.5 percent for the main opposition Social Democrats, led by Oskar Lafontaine. Kohl became chancellor in October 1982, when a switch of coalition alliances enabled him to form a government at the head of his Christian Democratic Union. He was confirmed in national elections in 1983 and 1987. At first he was regarded as a blunder-prone provincial politician who spoke with a distinct local accent. But Kohl has risen to the status of a respected international statesman, leader of a country that will play a political role finally equal to its economic might. ``In many fields of politics, we are in a leading position in Europe and in the world,'' Kohl said recently. Often said in the past to be slow in making decisions, Kohl seized the historic opportunity presented with the collapse of East Germany's Communist government and the fall of the Berlin Wall a year ago. ``I like to be underestimated. I've managed very well for 30 years by being underestimated,'' Kohl likes to say. His whirlwind, relentless drive to achieve quick unification paid off when Germany became one fully sovereign state, on Oct. 3, with Kohl as chancellor. His new image is reflected by trendier, double-breasted suits and the virtual disappearance of Kohl jokes. Cartoons used to depict Kohl floating in outer space while aides grappled with problems, or flipping coins to make decisions. Now the 6-foot-5 chancellor is more likely to be depicted as a smiling figure towering over the German landscape, as the newsweekly Der Speigel showed him in a pre-election cover story on ``the lucky giant.'' Kohl was born on April 3, 1930, in Ludwigshafen, a southwest German industrial city in a wine-growing region of the Rhine River. His father was a minor revenue official and his mother a teacher. He earned a doctorate in political science from Heidelberg University in 1958 and devoted his entire adult life to politics. He joined the Christian Democratic Union in 1947 at the age of 17. Kohl served in various Rhineland-Palatinate state party posts. He was elected governor in 1969 and took over as his party's national chairman in 1973. The chancellor has been staunchly pro-American and went ahead with the deployment of U.S. nuclear missiles in the 1980s despite widespread popular opposition. He survived several scandals that shook Bonn - such as an espionage affair in 1985 and a political payoffs scandal - and some notorious gaffes. Kohl once compared Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's public relations skills to those of Nazi propaganda minister Joseph Goebbels. Now he is said to be on first-name terms with Gorbachev, whom he constantly praises as the man who made unification possible. The chancellor and his wife, Hannelore, have two sons, Walter and Peter. He is a staunch Roman Catholic who often stresses family values. Kohl is said to feel uncomfortable abroad, but goes to Austria for his annual slimming cure. He is not fluent in any foreign language, but has been heard using some English. Kohl has said this may not be his last election and that his goal remains the complete unification of Europe by the year 2000.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says `Real Dialogue' Could Lead to Peace
With PM-Gulf-Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from a French television interview with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, recorded Saturday and broadcast Sunday. Saddam spoke in Arabic, and the French transcript was translated into English by The Associated Press: Q: Do you accept the dialogue proposed to you by President Bush? A: If President Bush wishes to establish a balanced dialogue, such a dialogue must not get under way on the basis of preconditions. ... President Bush has proposed two meetings. ... We have accepted. Q: What gesture are you ready to make to convince the world of your good will as you begin this dialogue? A: There is no proposition more important than a dialogue that reaches a solution to all the problems of the region, and at their head the Palestinian problem. ... We have taken a series of initiatives (regarding the hostages) and we have even fixed a date, March 25, as the last date for all of them to go home if nothing happens to disturb the peace. This is not a tactic to sow discord in the ranks of whomever, but it is one of the means which we think is capable of preventing war. Such a method has perhaps proven its effectiveness, because so far there has been no war. ... We will free them (the hostages) ... as soon we have the assurance that President Bush will not attack the Iraqi people between now and March 25. If, after March 25, he still has the devil in his head, we will rely on God in order to face any eventuality. Q: Now that President Bush has proposed dialogue, and you can save face to an extent, why not open up some possibility regarding Kuwait? A: Our face is saved. We don't need Bush for that. Our face is saved because we are believers. ... You know that Bush has not taken the same measures vis-a-vis the Israeli occupation of Palestine and doesn't even lift his little finger when he sees on the television screens women, children and old people being killed, humiliated and tortured in Palestine by the Israelis. The problem is that President Bush and the other Western heads of state have two United Nations charters ... a criteria based on evaluations of their own needs and interests and a criteria for the oppressed peoples of the Third World - oppressed by the policies of the Western bloc and by the United States in particular. Q: Is it necessary for a country like Iraq to provide itself with a nuclear capability? The Americans say this will happen in a year or two. A: I speak of the present. If we had nuclear weapons, we wouldn't have any problem saying so. ... But we don't possess a nuclear weapon ... Why doesn't the West protest and worry at the destructive capabilities of Israel? Q: And this evening, are we closer to war or to peace? A: Fifty-fifty. If they want to make this meeting a real path toward dialogue, then we are closer to peace. But if they want to make this meeting nothing other than a formal exhibition for Congress or international public opinion, simply to give themselves good conscience to say, `There, we've tried dialogue with Iraq, without Iraq renouncing its positions.' In that case, we're closer to war.

DOC.HEAD: Affirmed As Chancellor, Kohl Moves To Enhance Germany's Standing
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's victory in all-German elections gives him both the mandate to guide Germany to a stronger role in world affairs and the burden of assimilating his nation's troubled eastern lands. One of his first priorities, he indicated during the campaign, will be to have Parliament consider changing the constitution to permit sending troops to the Persian Gulf. At home, Kohl must focus on building up the former East Germany and raising the living standards of its inhabitants, a process that will cost hundreds of billions of dollars. After leading his Christian Democrat-led coalition to victory on Sunday, Kohl predicted it will take jst three to four years to develop the industrially backward eastern lands into a ``thriving region.'' ``We will achieve that,'' he told a television interviewer. Expanded influence in Eastern Europe and greater aid to the Soviets also top the issues list for Kohl and the new 656-member Parliament that links lawmakers from the eastern and western parts of the country. An expanded international agenda and Kohl's confidence with it signal another departure from the past. Previously, West Germany hid cozily behind its NATO allies, following their lead on international events. Even before Kohl led his country to unification with East Germany two months ago, demands were growing for a united Germany to take on greater international responsibilities. In September, Secretary of State James A. Baker III told Kohl that ``being more means doing more,'' and there were suggestions of giving Germany a permanent seat in the U.N. Security Council. The Germans politely turned down that suggestion, but the international agenda is full as the 60-year-old Kohl heads into his third four-year term. Kohl several times during the election campaign backed a constitutional change that would allow German troops take part in such missions the U.S.-led multinational force arrayed against Iraq. He promised the new Parliament will consider the change soon. Such a constitutional amendment would be momentous in a country still saddled by the murderous legacy of the Nazi past. Kohl says the current constitution forbids German military missions outside NATO areas. ``The united Germany is faced with a growing responsibility in the community of nations, including the preservation of world peace,'' Kohl said in a speech on Oct. 3, unification day. Germany already has promised to provide more than $2 billion ollars in support for the campaign to drive the Iraqis from Kuwait, although many in the U.S. Congress say that is far too little. Breaking ranks somewhat with other Western leaders, Kohl last month proposed solving the Arab-Israeli conflicts and the Lebanese civil war along with the Persian Gulf stalemate. In the closing days of the election campaign, he suggested ``regional security organizations'' to keep the peace in the Middle East. Meanwhile, Germany's influence is likely to grow throughout Eastern Europe as the new democracies there seek help in rebuilding their own economies. And Germany is likely to stay at the forefront of international support for the Soviet Union, for several reasons. Not the least is the desire to prevent Soviets from going hungry and causing a tide of refugees to head west. Germany already is a magnet for tens of thousands of foreign refugees who sap the country's resources. The government plans to start sending many of the refugees to the underdeveloped eastern part of the country, a move that could make Germany less attractive to the newcomers. Along with his detente-minded Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the German chancellor also will be seeking abolition of chemical weapons and further curbs on nuclear arms. Kohl told voters he will push even more for the decades-long dream of a United States of Europe linking European Community countries, predicting it could come about by the turn of the century. At the same time, Kohl has promised to remain committed to helping solve Third World economic woes. Germany, with 78 million people, is Europe's No. 1 economic power.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Climbs Further, Stocks Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against the Japanese yen for the third consecutive trading day today, and Tokyo share prices closed higher. The dollar closed at 133.00 yen, up 0.25 yen from Friday's 132.75 yen finish. It opened at 132.02 yen and ranged between 132.00 yen and 133.30 yen. Some $11.44 billion changed hands in spot trading. The dollar now has gained 4.10 yen in the last three trading days. ``There is little reason to buy the dollar now considering the slowdown in the U.S. economy, but investors find less reason to buy the yen,'' said Naohiko Yasuda, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. Dealers said the dollar's low start today was in reaction to President Bush's proposal Friday for talks with Iraq. It quickly climbed again as investment trust firms bought dollars to correct oversold positions since Friday, they added. The dollar shot up 2.60 yen Friday after the U.N. Security Council adopted a resolution approving the use of military force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait. The dollar tends to rise in times of international tension because it is seen as a safe investment, while speculation of war in the Persian Gulf usually weakens the yen because Japan imports nearly all of its oil, and 70 percent comes from the Middle East. ``But the dollar failed to keep rising because of lingering uncertainties over the Middle East,'' Yasuda said. He said the yen also weakened today against such major European currencies as the German mark and British pound, mainly because of the generally falling Tokyo stock market. On the stock exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rose 271.36 points, or 1.21 percent, closing at 22,725.99. It lost 257.97 points Friday. Today's trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 250 million shares, down from Friday's 350 million. The index, which was up almost 480 points at the end of the morning session, fell back as early optimism about the gulf crisis soured and the yen weakened, traders said. ``Also, poor performances in the futures market kept investors from arbitrage buying in the spot market,'' said Kazuhiro Nomura, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co. Traders said the Nikkei's morning gains followed Friday's news that Secretary of State James A. Baker III would be sent to Iraq for high-level talks. They said optimism that a diplomatic solution might be reached boosted buying. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds stood at 86.81 points, up from Friday's 86.31-point finish. Their yield fell to 7.315 percent from 7.425 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Germans Peer Past The Politics
With PM-Germany-Elections, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The winners held victory parties, the losers post-mortems. Former East Germans held their breath, waiting for the promises of four straight elections to be delivered. After what has seemed like a single, year-long campaign, voters in what had until October been a Communist country joined Germans to the west on Sunday and elected Chancellor Helmut Kohl to lead the united nation. The election followed East Germany's first free elections in March, its local elections in May, and state elections in October. Kohl's Christian Democrats dominated each. Along the way, questions of ideology began to shrink into the shadow of stark reality for many former East Germans. ``I care about my house. I care about my job, about clean air, a playground for my children,'' Hiltrud Kluger, 36, said after voting Sunday. ``I don't care about a market economy.'' Sunday's balloting was the last of the nationwide races until 1994. The newly elected German Parliament, now free of the hyperbole-filled rhetoric of successive campaigns, faces the task of dispassionately fixing the broken eastern sector of the nation. Mrs. Kluger, a mother of two, lives in the depressed factory town of Delitzsch, in the heart of the former nation's heavily industrialized southern region. She would not say who she voted for, other than to say it was a mainstream party. But her reasons for choosing a party were the same as many other eastern Germans: to quickly improve the quality of life. Eastern Germany is expected to face a sharp rise in joblessness in the first quarter of next year. Many former Communist subsidies that kept rents, energy costs and mass transit fees low will be lifted on Jan. 1. But optimistic economic forecasts also predict new investment that could begin creating new jobs in the middle of next year. Many eastern Germans believe Kohl's conservative, free market-oriented party is best able to deliver that investment. Hildegard Neumann, 66, also a Delitzsch resident, voted for the Christian Democrats in all four eastern elections. ``We think that the Christian Democrats are the capitalists,'' she said. ``They are also Christians, and we need that.'' After World War II, Mrs. Neumann worked briefly for the U.S. Army in West Germany as a telephone operator, but came back to the East to be with family. She worked as a schoolteacher for 40 years and said she fought efforts by authorities to get her to join the Communist Party. ``Once I was fired for three years because I said I believed in God,'' she said. ``I stayed at home. Then they came back and said they needed school teachers.'' Despite the delicate financial condition of a pensioner in a changing, depressed society, she said she is confident the Christian Democrats will improve her living standards. ``I know we've had four elections, but it's very good indeed that we can finally vote for the people we want in our government,'' she said. Although Kohl's party buried the opposition, more than half of the nation's voters on Sunday chose somebody else. Angelika Bobbe, a 35-year-old Berliner, supported Alliance 90, a minor party that includes the intellectuals and pacifists who led last year's revolt against Communism. She was laid off last summer from a government agency that refurbished old buildings. She has been taking retraining courses under a program paid for by Kohl's government. ``There is absolute chaos in this land,'' she said. ``Extremism, greed. Joblessness was never a problem. People don't know how to react.'' The winners and losers knew how to react after the tentative results were in. In Bonn, Kohl's supporters sipped German sparkling wine and gulped chilled German beer. The triumphant chancellor sat with his wife, Hannelore, on a large pedestal at the front of the hall. At the headquarters of the opposition Social Democrats, solemn organizers spoke about mounting a new charge in 1994.

DOC.HEAD: Aaron Copland, `The Dean of American Music,' Dead at 90
LaserPhotos NY10, NY11
DOC.TEXT: Aaron Copland, the immigrants' son from Brooklyn who used jazz rhythms of the South, folk songs of Appalachia and cowboy tunes of the prairie to create classical music that was unmistakably American, has died at 90. The composer, who lived in Peekskill, died Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown of pneumonia. He had suffered two strokes recently. The ``dean of American music'' created such classics as ``Appalachian Spring,'' ``Rodeo,'' ``Billy the Kid'' and ``Lincoln Portrait.'' Leonard Bernstein once called Copland's 1942 orchestral composition ``Fanfare for the Common Man'' the ``all-time top of the hit parade in American music.'' The son of Eastern European immigrants, he strove to be more American than most Americans and sought to focus the international spotlight on his fellow American composers. ``He put American music on the map. He decided that there should be an American sound, a place for the American composer,'' Vivian Perlis, who collaborated with the composer on his 1984 memoir, ``Copland,'' said Sunday. Copland wrote two operas, six ballets and eight film scores, including his Oscar-winning music for William Wyler's ``The Heiress'' in 1948. He won a Pulitzer Prize in 1945 for the ballet ``Appalachian Spring,'' based on a Shaker melody played by a clarinet. It was choreographed by Martha Graham. His ballets ``Billy the Kid'' in 1938 and ``Rodeo'' in 1942 make use of cowboy tunes and folk songs. Other works included the score for ``The Red Pony,'' the 1949 movie based on the novel by John Steinbeck, and ``Lincoln Portrait,'' music performed with narration inspired by the writings of Lincoln biographer Carl Sandburg. The Jewish boy from New York who learned to write cowboy-inspired classical music didn't even travel to the West until he was 28. ``I preferred to imagine being on a horse without actually getting on one!'' he once said. William Schuman, who with Bernstein and Copland formed what Schuman called a triumvirate of American composers, said, ``Copland believed in the validity of American music, that we were not inferior to our European cousins.'' ``He created the American sound in symphonic music,'' said Schuman. Both Bernstein and Copland ``wanted to incorporate popular music into concert music. They always wanted the music to be in contact with people,'' said composer Elliott Carter. Copland's storekeeper parents initially were reluctant to pay for music lessons. ``My parents were of the opinion that enough money had been invested in the musical training of the four older children, with meager results,'' he recalled. But his persistence prevailed, and Copland eventually studied in Paris with Nadia Boulanger and sold a composition, ``The Cat and the Mouse,'' for $32.50. ``To finally see my music printed means more to me than any debut in Carnegie Hall,'' he wrote home. In 1925, Boulanger, on organ, premiered ``Symphony for Organ and Orchestra'' in New York as part of her U.S. debut. Afterward, Copland recalled, conductor Walter Damrosch addressed the audience: ``Ladies and gentlemen, I am sure you will agree that if a gifted young man can write a symphony like this at 23 ... within five years he will be ready to commit murder.'' With such jazz-inspired creations as ``Piano Concerto'' in 1926, Copland once recalled, ``I felt I had gone to the extreme of where jazz could take me, the audiences and critics in Boston all thought I had gone too far.'' During a trip to the West, Copland heard the piece being hissed during rehearsal and again in concert at the Hollywood Bowl. But he forged on, experimenting with even more complex rhythms. ``Symphonic Ode,'' which premiered in 1932, was so difficult conductor Serge Koussevitzky told Copland it took an hour to rehearse three bars. Then, in 1936, Copland did a musical about-turn - to a simpler, folk-based style in ``El Salon Mexico,'' inspired by a visit to Mexico City. The work was followed in 1942 by ``Rodeo,'' which launched Agnes DeMille's dancing career. Copland, who never married, is survived by several nieces and nephews. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Aaron Copland: A Down-to-Earth Musical Genius
DOC.TEXT: With PM-Obit-Copland, Bjt

Leonard Bernstein's visit to Aaron Copland's studio a half century ago opened the door on a friendship between two composers who helped helped put American classical music on the world map. On Sunday, Copland joined Bernstein in death. In life, they had created what a composer called ``the American sound.'' ``They were made for each other,'' said the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer David Del Tredici. ``Aaron wrote the music, and Lenny was its wonderful interpreter. Aaron was the Moses, and Lenny was the Aaron.'' William Schuman, who with Bernstein and Copland formed what Schuman called a triumvirate of American composers, said, ``Copland believed in the validity of American music, that we were not inferior to our European cousins.'' Copland and Bernstein first met when the young ``Lenny,'' in his 20s and fresh from Harvard, showed up at Copland's New York studio door opposite Lincoln Center. ``Copland opened the door, Bernstein introduced himself and then he just sat down and played `Variations,''' a work by Copland, said Del Tredici, who claims Copland as his mentor. Del Tredici recalled weekends 20 years ago spent at Copland's home near New York, which he described as ``a very `Copland' kind of place, spacious, comfortable.'' ``There was no vanity in him, he was very endearing,'' he said, adding that Copland ``didn't care much about food, or a fancy home.'' ``He was generous to everyone around him and under him, and uncomplicated,'' said Del Tredici. ``Usually geniuses are self-centered, and I thought, `How can a man be a genius and still be so nice?''' The down-to-earth approach translated into musical artistry that drew on American folk tunes and jazz. ``Like most sons of immigrants, he wanted to be more American than the Americans,'' said Del Tredici. At Copland's last birthday celebration two weeks ago, he ate apple pie, which he preferred to cake. Surrounded by old friends, Copland read messages from young people, from fifth-graders in Arkansas to teen-agers in Arizona. ``He was not the least pretentious. If you didn't know he was one of the greatest artists of the century, you would never suspect it, with his wonderful, ruddy laugh,'' said Schuman. ``He had a uniquely American voice and was able to express in his music particularly American sensibilities using substantially the language of European serious music,'' said Kenneth Haas, managing director of the Boston Symphony. Copland taught at the orchestra's Tanglewood music school in Lenox, Mass., for 25 years and was head of the faculty there when he stepped down in 1970. ``He lived a very productive 90 years,'' Haas said. ``Happily, we will have his music to appreciate even though we don't have him any more.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Soldiers Seize Two Army Buildings in Argentina
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with additional details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Nationalist officers seized army headquarters and an infantry regiment early Monday and President Carlos Menem immediately declared a state of seige, a presidential spokesman said. Radio stations reported firefights in front of the seized Patricios Infantry Regiment in Palermo, on the eastern side of the capital. They said loyal officers were battling to retake the building. The uprising occurred just two days before the planned arrival of President Bush on his South American tour. The presidential spokesman, Humberto Toledo, said information linked the mutineers to Col. Mohammed Ali Seineldin, who was cashiered and jailed after leading a failed military uprising in December 1988. Toledo said Menem was in his office in the Government Palace, two blocks from army headquarters, which was captured by a group of about 50 officers. The officers, their faces covered in war paint, raided the building around 4 a.m. (2 a.m. EST) and told journalists the attack was ``to fulfill the fourth stage of Operation Dignity,'' a movement of nationalist officers opposed to the government's prosecution of officers for human rights abuses. An army communique said the situation in the rest of the country ``is normal.'' ``The four army corps are still under the control of their commanders, except for small outbreaks that are being controlled,'' said the communique, signed by Gen. Martin Bonnet, the military chief of staff, who remained loyal to Menem. It was the first military uprising under the government of Menem, who took office in July. Three previous uprisings occurred in 1987 and 1988 under President Raul Alfonsin. Bush arrived at dawn Monday in the Brazilian capital of Brasilia and was proceeding to talks with President Fernando Collor de Mello and a speech to a joint session of the Brazilian Congress. He was to fly to Buenos Aires on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Designers Put Their Egos Aside in Sale Benefiting AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Few people recognized Calvin Klein as he quietly re-hung dresses during a sale of $4 million in merchandise donated by fashion designers to benefit the fight against AIDS. The clothes donated by Klein and more than 100 other U.S. designers brought in more than $3.5 million by the end of the three-day sale Sunday and surpassed the goal of $1 million. In an industry where huge egos are legendary, what stood out was that the fashion leaders were able to put their rivalry aside and work together on a cause close to many in the clothing business. Many in the fashion industry - including Perry Ellis - have died of AIDS. ``With a hundred diverse souls like this, it's a miracle,'' said one organizer. ``I think I can see something clicking with the shoppers as they see us, our camaraderie, and see this - what the industry has wanted to do together for a long time,'' said Patricia Underwood, a hat designer who's had her own label for 14 years. ``I think AIDS is starting to mean something to them.'' For many designers, it was the first time in years they had been face-to-face with the public. Most of them stood by unnoticed as shoppers hunted down designer merchandise at huge discounts. ``That's definitely a 39-long,'' designer Jeffrey Banks told a shopper who held up a shirt to her husband's back. Marc Jacobs, the Perry Ellis designer, helped tear open a carton of sweaters as the crowd ignored him and looked at a mannequin instead. Nevi Sicetola, 22, who bought a pair of jeans and a cashmere sweater, said the sale was ``chaos.'' But she added, ``It's a very good cause.'' A spokesman for the Council of Fashion Designers of America, which sponsored the event with Vogue magazine, said the money will be distributed by the New York City AIDS Fund, which gives grants to AIDS-related causes. Socialite Blaine Trump, wearing a baseball jacket with a logo for an AIDS support group, looked for Christmas presents. William F. Buckley's wife, Pat, came back for a second day. New York Daily News gossip columnist Liz Smith sifted through sports shirts. Men's designer shirts that normally sell from $80 to $200 went for $25 and sweaters selling anywhere from $150 to $500 were $50. Norma Kamali socks were selling two pair for $1. Dresses that normally go for thousands of dollars were half-price. The spirit of cooperation even seemed to infect the shoppers, who had to buy $10 tickets in advance to get in. Groups of 1,500 waited happily for an hour before being let in for their 2{-hour shop-a-thon. Shoppers were let in in shifts to control crowding and to give designers a chance to restock their tables. The event was staffed by volunteers - some of whom have AIDS - ranging from retailers and backroom assistants to fashion students. Klein even seemed to think the event could be repeated elsewhere. ``I don't see why it couldn't happen in Paris, London or Milan,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hospital Offers Free Tests to Patients of Doctor Who Died of AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of people called Johns Hopkins Hospital in response to its offer to test for AIDS about 1,800 patients who were operated on by a surgeon who died of the disease. The hospital said it would send a letter this week to all patients Dr. Rudolph Almaraz had operated on since joining its staff in 1984. The breast cancer specialist died Nov. 16 at age 41 of what his family's lawyer, Marvin Ellin, said was AIDS. Ellin said the letter will generate ``nothing but panic'' among Almaraz's former patients. ``Every ache and every pain they experience is going to cause them to wonder if they have AIDS,'' he said. The hospital received dozens of calls Sunday as a result of a story in The Sun in which Ellin said Almarez had died of AIDS. Documents that would confirm his illness, including the death certificate, are confidential under Maryland law. Johns Hopkins said in its letter that the possibility that the AIDS virus was transmitted to any person during surgery is remote. Ellin said Almaraz told him he was exposed to AIDS when blood from an AIDS patient squirted into his eyes and mouth during an operation in New York about seven years ago. Suzanne Raussenbert, a spokeswoman for Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York where Almaraz was on a fellowship, on Sunday said the hospital had no records that would indicate Almaraz contracted AIDS there. He practiced at the hospital in 1983. Almaraz also had privileges at Children's Hospital, where a spokeswoman said Almarza never operated, and Homewood Hospital South. Homewood spokesman Larry Wilson said the hospital will consider sending letters to the surgeon's patients. Almaraz was surgeon-in-chief of surgical oncology and endocrinology at Hopkins until 1985, when he started his private practice. Almaraz sold his practice March 1 and resigned from the Johns Hopkins staff June 30. Dr. Timothy Townsend, senior director for medical affairs at Johns Hopkins, said the hospital made repeated efforts, starting in late summer, to determine the nature of Almaraz's illness amid rumors that he had AIDS. While Johns Hopkins could not give the exact number of patients Almaraz operated on, Townsend estimated the figure at 300 a year. At that rate, he could have operated on more than 1,800 patients while on the staff. AIDS most commonly is transmitted through sexual contact or the sharing of needles by intravenous drug users or exposure to tainted blood or other bodily fluids. Dr. Gregory B. Bulkley, a professor of surgery at the Hopkins Medical School, said a study has found that a doctor who pricks himself while operating on a person with AIDS has a 0.2 percent chance of picking up the virus. The risk of a doctor transmitting AIDS to a patient is so small as to be immeasurable, he said. There is only one case in which a patient is believed to have contracted the disease from a health-care provider. In that case, David J. Acer, was a Stuart, Fla., dentist, who died of AIDS on Sept. 3. Nine months earlier, one of his patients, Kimberly Bergalis, 22, was told she had AIDS after being hospitalized for a form of pneumonia.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Radiation Danger Found in Oil Fields
DOC.TEXT: Decades of oil drilling have brought so much radium to the surface that radioactive contamination in oil fields sometimes exceeds by five to 30 times the level permitted at nuclear plants, The New York Times said today. The newspaper said environmental officials have found radium, a naturally occurring radioactive material, in every oil-producing region in the country from Alaska to the Gulf states. They found low levels of radiation in pumps, pipes and storage tanks from radium that leaches from mineral deposits into water that comes to the surface with oil, the Times said. The federal government has no regulations to deal with oil field radiation, the paper said. The extent of the health risk to oil workers who handle drilling equipment contaminated by radium or to people exposed to radium-contaminated water and soil is unknown. But health officials worry that exposure may raise the risk of cancer and other illnesses, the Times said. Oil industry representatives say the risk is minimal or nonexistent, the paper said. The contamination is worst in the South and along the Gulf Coast where radium concentrations in the water are much higher than in other regions. Oil companies for years in the South have routinely poured billions of gallons of contaminated water into thousands of unlined ponds before pumping it back into the ground or releasing it into wetlands, the Times said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Journalist's Space Flight Seen With Pride, Skepticism
LaserPhoto BAIK1 of Dec. 2
DOC.TEXT: Japan's first space voyage has generated pride along with broadsides about the blatant commercialism of the venture, which cost the nation's largest private broadcasting company $37 million. Toyohiro Akiyama, the first Japanese and first journalist in space, was orbiting the Earth today with two Soviet cosmonauts in a Soyuz space capsule, a day after their blast-off from the steppes of Soviet Central Asia. The rocket carrying Akyiyama into space was plastered with the logos of nine Japanese corporate sponsors, including a manufacturer of diapers and sanitary products, a toothpaste company and a solar heater maker. Japanese newspapers praised the mission, but gently prodded Tokyo Broadcasting System, which footed the bill, for commercializing the final frontier. Asahi Shimbun, Japan's largest newspaper and linked to a media group in competition with TBS, described the mission as an advertising ``sales blitz.'' ``This flight is supposed to be a practice for allowing other laymen into space, but it also gives the impression that space travel is a business,'' said Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a major economic newspaper. TBS is spending $37 million to launch Akiyama, 48, and broadcast his coverage live for the duration of the eight-day trip. The network hopes to arrange a telephone call Dec. 7 between Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the cosmonauts. The commercial contract with TBS boosted the Kremlin's drive to cash in on its Soyuz space program in the face of critical economic problems. Cosmonauts Viktor Afanasyev and Musa Manarov will link the Soyuz capsule with the space station Mir. They will switch places with cosmonauts Gennady Manakov and Gennady Strekalov and spend the next six months orbiting the earth. Soviet officials and TBS executives have held out the hope that the flight could improve ties between the two countries, which never officially ended their World War II hostilities. Japanese newspapers also focused on the human-interest aspects of the flight, the first layman's venture into space since New Hampshire schoolteacher Christa McAufiffe and six astronauts died in the 1986 Challenger explosion. ``A regular guy becomes a middle-aged star,'' trumpeted the Sankei Shimbun. ``Prayer, smiles and then tears,'' it said of Akiyama's wife, Kyoko, who watched her husband disappear into space from the Baikonur Cosmodrome, 1,310 miles east of Moscow. Kyoko called the blastoff ``beautiful,'' although she earlier said she was nervous. ``But when I saw their faces on the television screen, I calmed down and felt happier,'' she said. Akiyama is to spend six days aboard Mir. In addition to his live reporting he will carry out experiments to seek how tree frogs react to a gravity-free environment.

DOC.HEAD: Hearin's Death Ends Years of Wondering About Missing Wife
DOC.TEXT: Robert Hearin paid almost a million dollars hoping to ransom his wife of 50 years. But her kidnappers were unyielding and the 73-year-old multimillionaire died without ever seeing her again. Hearin's heart gave out Wednesday, two years after Annie Laurie Hearin was kidnapped from their Mississippi home. Hearin, one of the state's most powerful and wealthy men, paid $931,000 in ransom, but his wife was never freed. Authorities believe she is dead. ``My one regret is I couldn't give him back his wife,'' said FBI agent Wayne R. Taylor. ``We continue to do everything we can that might lead to her.'' The Hearins met while they were students at the University of Alabama and married in 1940. They had two children, Robert Hearin Jr., a lawyer in New Orleans, and Laurie McRee of Jackson. ``We've had a terrible loss. I think all along there has been a real mix of sadness and anger,'' said the son. Hearin was worth an estimated $200 million. He controlled Mississippi's largest gas distribution company, Mississippi Valley Gas Co.; its second-largest bank, Trustmark National Bank, and its second-largest insurance company, Lamar Life Corp. Hearin avoided the news media after his wife was kidnapped, but did appear on the TV show ``Unsolved Mysteries.'' He never gave up hope of finding his wife, although authorities believe she died long ago. Last year, he moved out of the brick Georgian house they shared. ``I'm pretty sure she was dead within the first month. I am absolutely sure she is dead,'' said Dr. Rodrigo Galvez, a Jackson psychiatrist and pathologist who analyzed the ransom note. Mrs. Hearin, 72 when she was kidnapped, suffered from ileitis, a chronic intestinal disease that could cause death in days without daily medication. About three weeks after she was kidnapped, her husband received a letter in her handwriting urging him to pay off 12 disgruntled investors named in a rambling letter left in the house the day she disappeared. FBI officials said Hearin paid a total of $931,000. Those named were investors in a school picture company of which Hearin was the largest shareholder. Among them was Newton Alfred Winn, a St. Petersburg, Fla., lawyer. He was sentenced in February to 19 years in prison for conspiring to kidnap Mrs. Hearin, mailing a threatening communication and lying to a federal grand jury. No one was ever charged with the actual kidnapping. The younger Hearin said he and his sister hold out hope their mother will return, but ``the passage of time leads one not to be optimistic.''

DOC.HEAD: Major Winter Storm in Midwest, Great Lakes Region
DOC.TEXT: A major winter storm hit the upper Midwest and Great Lakes region early today, and rain fell ahead of a cold front in the eastern third of the nation. A winter storm warning was posted for today in Michigan, Illinois and Wisconsin. Southern Wisconsin was expected to get up to a foot of snow in spots. Freezing rain fell in Illinois today, and sleet and rain were expected to leave roads slick across many areas of the Midwest. Snow fell early today in North Dakota, Minnesota, Nebraska, Iowa and Kansas. Snow also fell in the Great Lakes region at Detroit and Cleveland. Rain fell today in the Ohio Valley, Pennsyvania, Tennessee and Kentucky. Rain also fell in southern Florida and thunderstorms hit New Orleans.
