The cold front extended from just south of Chicago in a slight curve to just west of New Orleans. The weather was expected to be mild and humid ahead of the front. Thunderstorms were expected to develop in the wake of the front, which was likely to dump up to 2 inches of rain in places. The high temperature for the nation on Sunday was 89 degrees at Harlingen, Texas. DOC.HEAD: More Violence in News Strike
DOC.TEXT: Two Daily News replacement drivers were charged with possessing a loaded, unlicensed gun, a pipe bomb was found near the paper's Brooklyn plant and a striker was charged with assaulting a News hawker. Meanwhile, Publisher James Hoge, fearing a fight over subway newspaper sales today, said the Metropolitan Transit Authority should seek an injunction if transit workers threaten to walk out in solidarity with Daily News strikers. A 6-inch pipe bomb was found Sunday on a ramp leading to a truck parking area at the News' Brooklyn printing plant, police said. Nearby were two unexploded, M-80 firecrackers taped to boxes of nails, authorities said. Police had gone there to investigate 12 explosions, apparently caused by firecrackers, said Sgt. Tina Mohrmann. The News said about 200 strikers threw cherry bombs and M-80 firecrackers. Sgt. Peter Sweeney, another police spokesman, said one man was arrested for throwing a bottle that hit an officer. In addition, four demonstrators were arrested for disorderly conduct, he said. In a separate incident, two News replacement drivers were charged with weapons possession after a loaded .25-caliber handgun was found in the front seat of their truck early Sunday, police said. Also on Sunday, a striking News pressman was charged in the assault of a Daily News hawker. Hoge sent MTA chief Robert Kiley a letter Saturday saying that it is illegal for transit workers to strike. The letter followed a temporary court order issued Friday that allows hawkers to sell the Daily News in train and subway stations as long as they stay within 10 feet of newsstands or vending boxes that don't carry the News. Strikers have said they would picket the hawkers and some transit workers have indicated they would not cross picket lines to go to work. Newspaper management turned to hawkers after many newstands refused to sell the News. John Cunningham, an MTA spokesman, declined to comment on Hoge's letter. The strike by some 2,100 workers began Oct. 25.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were lower. Dealers said the market's main preoccupation continues to be U.S. moves to get Iraqi occupation forces to leave Kuwait. A new U.S. diplomatic effort could reduce the risk of war slightly, traders said, but they added that the tense situation in the Gulf continues to prop up the dollar. The dollar is considered a safe haven currency in crisis situations. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.25 yen to a closing 133.00 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 134.12 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with Friday: -1.5035 German marks, up from 1.4990 -1.2870 Swiss francs, up from 1.2760 -5.0810 French francs, up from 5.0630 -1.6877 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6910 -1,130.25 Italian lire, up from 1,122.00 -1.1648 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1640 In London, the British pound was quoted at a lower rate of $1.9315, compared with $1.9400 Friday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $381.75 per ounce at midmorning, down from $382.25 bid per ounce late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $381.75, down from $385.00 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 4.95 to close at a bid 380.06. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.14 a troy ounce, up from Friday's $4.11.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Fears Send Residents Away, Bring Visitors In
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6-7th grafs, `Residents of...;' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with school held in Illinois county. Picks up 8th graf pvs, , to `Gullick said...'.
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of schools along the New Madrid Fault canceled classes today just in case the earth rumbles as forecast. And farm animals will decide whether classes should be held in one Illinois county. Judy Byrd of Evansville, Ind., gave in to her 11-year-old son's request to stay home even though she doesn't believe earthquakes can be forecast. ``At this age, they really worry about everything. War. An earthquake. Water. The environment,'' Mrs. Byrd said. ``I figured if he really was that worried about it, it should be up to him.'' The nervousness was prompted by New Mexico climatologist Iben Browning's forecast of a 50-50 chance for a major earthquake along the fault this week. Schools were closed today and Tuesday in more than a dozen districts in Arkansas and Missouri. Classes were also canceled in at least three districts in Tennessee and several in Kentucky and Illinois. Residents of Illinois' St. Clair County were watching cats and dogs as well as farm animals for signs of nervousness, and had considered canceling school today if there seemed to be a problem. But schoolchildren had their hopes of a day off dashed this morning. ``We have a special monitoring committee that's been watching the animals,'' said Bill Gullick, superintendent of Marissa Community Unit School District 40. ``One of the people on the committee is a farmer. He was the last person we checked with early this morning, and everything was OK.'' Gullick said many people claim animals seem to sense earthquakes, and the method has been used in China for more than 1,000 years. In Marked Tree, dozens of people in the community of 3,200 left town just in case. Not Sterling Ivy. ``I wouldn't go two steps to try to get away from an earthquake, because if your time comes, you're going to go,'' Ivy said outside St. John Missionary Baptist Church in Marked Tree. Marked Tree lies at the southern end of the New Madrid Fault, which runs northeast through New Madrid, Mo., up to Cairo, Ill. Browning bases his theory on the gravitational pull of the sun and moon, which he says will be particularly strong during the 48-hour period on either side of Sunday. Many scientists say that the theory is nonsense and that no one can predict earthquakes accurately. In New Madrid, many residents watched the media circus on Main Street. ``I knew there would be a lot of press here, but I never had a clue it would be like this. It's just amazing,'' said Virginia Carlson, director of the New Madrid Historical Museum, where reporters, photographers and the curious traipsed in and out. Outside the museum, which documents huge earthquakes along the fault in 1811 and 1812, onlookers took pictures of photographers taking pictures of them. Traffic crawled through jam-packed streets. Many people bought T-shirts with the slogans ``It's Our Fault,'' and ``The Biggest Earthquake that Never Happened.'' ``The third biggest industry in town is picking up aluminum cans alongside the road,'' said Leland Phillips. ``But now the T-shirt business has zoomed by the can business.'' In Memphis, Tenn., 40 miles southeast of Marked Tree, earthuake awareness was also high. ``I had one guy call and ask if Monday's earthquake had been canceled,'' said Judy Drawdy of the Memphis-Shelby County Emergency Management Agency. ``Like this Iben Browning had called off the earthquake. I thought that was rather humorous.'' The Center for Earthquake Information and Research at Memphis recorded a small quake in Arkansas on Sunday, but it was not along the New Madrid Fault and caused no reported damage. The temblor, measuring 2.0 on the Richter scale, was centered in the Ozark Mountains, director Arch Johnston said. He said dozens of people called the center, including one woman who said she planned to wear a hard hat to bed. Retailers said items such as bottled water, first aid supplies, flashlights, batteries, radios, sleeping bags, blankets and tents sold briskly. Arkansas officials took advantage of the earthquake concerns to hold a drill using a worst-case scenario: an earthquake measuring a catastrophic 7.6 on the Richter scale occurring Friday afternoon along the fault. By Sunday, officials said the imaginary toll in a 17-county area of the state had reached 4,950 dead, 25,097 seriously injured and 98,020 homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov Requests Postponement of Next Game Of Championship
DOC.TEXT: Today's 17th game of the Garry Kasparov-Anatoly Karpov world chess championship has been postponed until Wednesday at Kasparov's request. The two Soviet grandmasters are scheduled to resume the 16th game on Tuesday. That game was contested for five hours Saturday and nearly six hours Sunday without a result after 88 moves. Through the 15 completed games, the players are tied with 7.5 points each. They have had three draws in the French portion of the championship. They had 10 draws in the 12 games played at New York between Oct. 8 and Nov. 7. The first player to reach 12.5 points wins the championship, but Kasparov would retain the title in the event of a 12-12 draw. Each player is allowed to request up to three postponements during the championship. The postponement requested by Kasparov today was his second. Karpov has used one timeout.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Investigates Contracts for Pope Visit
DOC.TEXT: A judge is investigating whether corruption was involved in the awarding of contracts for Pope John Paul II's visit to Naples last month, newspapers reported. Assistant prosecutor, Oberdan Forlenza, opened the probe on Tuesday. An opposition leader in Naples, Amedeo Laboccetta, has charged the city government wasted money on the construction of altars and platforms for papal ceremonies. He criticized the city for awarding the contract for a large platform in downtown Naples to a company in northern Italy, instead of a local business. Laboccetta also assailed the lack of open bidding on the project. ``A lot of money was wasted to let who-knows-who earn a few million (lire), profiting ignobly from a papal visit,'' he said, according to a report Wednesday in the Milan-based Corriere della Sera. The head of the city economic office, Diego Tesorone, was quoted as saying he awarded the contract without bidding because it was urgent. He said he chose a company outside Naples to avoid involving the Camorra, the Neapolitan Mafia, which traditionally is influential in local construction. ``The Camorra was trying to infiltrate itself in the operation and I, choosing a company that had worked on other papal trips, ruined their intervention,'' Tesorone told Corriere della Sera. Labocetta also charged that the city had rented hundreds of plastic chairs for a papal Mass, paying $4 for each one, when they could have been purchased for $1 less. Hundreds were reported stolen before a papal Mass. The city government spent $1.4 million to build structures and rent chairs for the papal visit Nov. 9-11, the reports said. The pontiff visited neighboring towns Nov. 12-13. The five-day trip was his longest papal journey in Italy and was seen as a symbol of the Vatican's faith in the region, despite all its troubles. Italian government leaders bluntly acknowledge that they have lost control of large segments of the country's southern regions to Mafia clans.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Said Ready Use Its Oil Reserves to Maintain Prices
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The United States will use its nearly 600 million barrel petroleum reserves to stabilize oil prices in the event of war in the Persian Gulf, a U.S. Embassy official said today. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, commented after U.S. Energy Secretary James Watkins met Sunday with his Saudi Arabian counterpart, Hisham Nazer. Watkins arrived Saturday for talks on the oil market situation in light of Iraq's 4-month-long occupation of Kuwait. Saudi Arabia controls more than a quarter of the world's known oil reserves. By overtaking Kuwait, Iraq increased its share of the world's oil reserves to 20 percent. Saudi official statements only mentioned that the two men discussed the world oil market and means of stabilizing it as well as bilateral cooperation in the oil industry. No details were given. The U.S. Embassy official said that Watkins and Nazer talked about the effect of the Persian Gulf crisis on the world oil market, as well as U.S.-Saudi relations. ``They discussed U.S. plans to use strategic petroleum reserves in case hostilities broke out and a real shortage emerged,'' said the diplomat. ``People tend to panic when a conflict breaks out, but we'll do whatever we can to maintain stability.'' The United States, Germany, and Japan together have about 1 billion barrels of oil in reserve. Saudi Arabia's reserves stand at approximately 260 billion barrels. Two months ago, President Bush said the United States would sell 5 million barrels of the 590 million stored in 65 salt-dome caverns in Texas and Louisiana in an attempt to stabilize prices. Before heading to the United Arab Emirates today, Watkins visited Saudi Aramco, the world's largest oil-producing company. Informed sources said on Sunday that discussions by Watkins and Nazer included expansion of Saudi Aramco, an oil contingency plan in case of war, and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, has played a prominent role in almost doubling its oil output to meet the shortage on the world market precipitated by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The move, along with additional production by other OPEC members, have helped stabilize oil prices. They doubled to around $40 a barrel at one point, and now are about $30 dollars per barrel. War could push oil prices as high as $100 per barrel, according to some estimates.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Explode Bombs to Protest Bush Visit
With PM-Bush, PM-Argentina-Military
DOC.TEXT: Bombs exploded in a Mormon chapel and in the offices of two right-wing political parties, causing minor damage and no injuries, police said today. Authorities blamed a small radical leftist guerrilla group. An anonymous caller told a news agency that the blasts Sunday were ``an offensive'' to protest a visit by President Bush. Bush began a five-nation South American tour in Brasil today, and is scheduled to arrive here Thursday. Police said the bomb at a Mormon chapel in Conchali, a northern Santiago working-class suburb shattered windows. Similar attacks occurred at the offices of two right-wing political parties in La Florida and San Miguel, two working-class districts south of the capital city. Police said the attackers were members of the Lautaro Front.

DOC.HEAD: Omaha Car Dealerships Lose Bid To Escape Iowa Lawsuits
DOC.TEXT: Four Omaha, Neb., automobile dealerships seeking to escape lawsuits charging them with violating Iowa's consumer fraud laws lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The justices, without comment, left intact an Iowa Supreme Court ruling that forces the dealerships to defend themselves in Iowa courts. The dealerships had argued that Iowa's courts have no authority over them. Iowa's highest court said such authority stems from the dealerships' placing newspaper advertisements in the Omaha World-Herald, which is circulated in Iowa. The state court noted that the dealerships also placed ads in a telephone directory for Council Bluffs, Iowa, which is located just across the Missouri River from Omaha. The lawsuits, filed in 1987 by Iowa Attorney General Thomas J. Miller, allege that the ads placed by the dealerships - Baxter Chrysler Plymouth, Markel Ford, John Kraft Chevrolet-Isuzu and Olsen Auto World - were false and misleading. The suits seek a halt to such advertising practices, and restitution for any Iowa residents who lost money because of the challenged ads. A fifth suit had been filed against Dean Rawson Nisson of Omaha, but that dealership entered into a consent agreement with Iowa officials. The Constitution's due-process protections, as interpreted in a series of past rulings by the nation's highest court, bar a state court from hearing any lawsuit filed against non-residents unless they have ``certain minimum contacts'' with that state. The Iowa Supreme Court ruled last May that the car dealerships' advertising efforts ``are sufficient to render them amenable to suit here in an action which seeks to halt that advertising on the ground that it is unlawful.'' The state court added that the ads also make the dealerships vulnerable to those portions of the lawsuits seeking other sanctions. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for the dealerships argued that the May ruling went far beyond established boundaries of state court authority. ``This case is an attempt by the Iowa attorney general to impose Iowa law against Nebraska retailers who advertise their product in a Nebraska newspaper, which ads comply with both Nebraska and federal law,'' the appeal contended. The case is Baxter Chrysler Plymouth vs. Iowa, 90-583.

DOC.HEAD: Ireland's First Woman President Takes Office
DOC.TEXT: Ireland's first woman president, Mary Robinson, was inaugurated today at Dublin Castle, and she extended a hand of friendship to both Protestants and Catholics in strife-ridden Northern Ireland. ``I will seek to encourage mutual understanding and tolerance between all the different communities sharing this island,'' Mrs. Robinson said in her acceptance speech, delivered in English and Gaelic. A 21-gun salute echoed across the Irish capital as Mrs. Robinson was sworn in by Chief Justice Thomas Finlay, following an interdenominational service at the medieval, turreted castle. About 500 church and state dignitaries and Dublin-based foreign diplomats looked on as Mrs. Robinson, wearing a purple jacket, took the oath of office. Schools throughout the republic were given the day off to watch the ceremony televised live in Britain and in the Irish Republic, where Ireland's tricolor flags flew against cloudy skies. The president, a 46-year-old feminist lawyer, campaigned for the largely ceremonial post on a liberal platform of change and a more involved presidency. She won the Nov. 9 election with 52.8 percent of the vote. She invited Irish descendants around the world to visit their native island. Mrs. Robinson said she would continue Ireland's long tradition of promoting international human rights, particularly in Latin America and Africa, during her seven-year term in office. After her victory, Mrs. Robinson thanked the women of Ireland who voted for her and ``instead of rocking the cradle, rocked the system.'' The president and mother of three children aged 9 to 18 addressed Irish women in her acceptance speech. ``As a woman I want women who have felt themselves outside history to be written back into history ... finding a voice where they have found a vision.'' In 20 years in the Irish senate and as a lawyer, Mrs. Robinson battled church and state in efforts to legalize divorce and contraception. She won court cases to permit women to serve on juries, to overturn laws criminalizing homosexuality, to restore inheritance rights for illegitimate children and to give women legislators the same pension rights as their male colleagues. Mrs. Robinson succeeds Patrick Hillery, who is stepping down after the maximum 14 years in office.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Proposes $6 Billion Takeover of Unwilling NCR
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `AT&T chairman...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with today's early trading, add that $85 offer had been rejected Friday. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `An AT&T-NCR...'. A version has moved on the financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. moved to become a major player in the computer industry by offering $6 billion for the NCR Corp., the nation's fifth-largest computer maker. NCR chairman Charles E. Exley Jr. reacted negatively to the offer of $90 worth of AT&T stock for each share of NCR and criticized AT&T for making the takeover discussions public Sunday. In early trading today, NCR shares shot up $24.75 to $81.50 after a delayed opening on the New York Stock Exchange. AT&T shares fell $2.25 to $29.87{ in heavy trading. AT&T chairman Robert E. Allen said AT&T decided to go public so NCR stockholders could make their own decisions. NCR, formerly National Cash Register, rejected a bid valued at $85 per share as too low on Friday. An AT&T-NCR merger would be the second-largest takeover of 1990 after Matsushita Electric Industrial Co.'s $6.13 billion merger with MCA Inc., which was announced last week. It would represent AT&T's largest-ever acquisition. The merger would greatly increase the presence of the long-distance phone service giant and telecommunications equipment maker in the computer industry, which it entered six years ago with the breakup of the Bell System. Some observers had long predicted AT&T, which has made alliances with and acquired other hardware and software makers in recent years, would become one of the major computer makers. NCR also is a leading maker of automated teller machines and cash registers. AT&T said the two companies and their boards have exchanged letters and presentations on the proposed acquisition but that talks had broken down. ``Although AT&T said it is willing to negotiate all aspects of its proposal, including price, NCR has since repeatedly refused to meet with either AT&T or its advisers,'' AT&T said. AT&T said its $90 offer amounted to 88 percent more than the $48 NCR stock traded for on Nov. 7, the day before reports of a rumored AT&T bid surfaced in the media. But Exley said the $90 offer was only 25 percent more than the highest price his company's stock had reached in the past six months. NCR stock traded for $56.75 Friday on the New York Stock Exchange. In a statement Sunday night, Exley said AT&T cannot hope to achieve the merger ``without the support and confidence of NCR management in AT&T's integrity and sense of honor.'' ``No ultimatum or demand will likely win that support or confidence. And no ultimatum or demand will intimidate the board of directors of NCR into doing a disservice to the company, its customers, shareholders and employees,'' he said. AT&T said its offer would remain open until the end of business Wednesday. It said its purchase of NCR would be particularly beneficial in selling computers and other equipment to industries such as retailing and banking, where NCR has its strength. AT&T said such uses of computers require extensive communications know-how that the company can provide. Under a merger, AT&T's computer line would be combined with NCR's, and NCR would continue to operate under its own name from its Dayton, Ohio, headquarters, AT&T said. AT&T said that it did not expect to close any NCR facilities and that it wanted NCR's management to run the combined operation. NCR, which has about 56,000 employees, announced in September it will replace its proprietary computers with so-called open systems, which adhere to computer-industry standards and can work easily with models made by other companies. NCR earned $412 million on overall revenue of $5.96 billion last year. AT&T, with about 279,000 employees, earned $2.7 billion on overall revenue of $36 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: Court Shields Businesses from Some Suits in Pension Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today shielded businesses from some big-money lawsuits filed by employees who claim they were fired so their employers would not have to pay pension benefits. The court ruled unanimously that fired employees may not sue in state courts over such allegations. The state suits are pre-empted by a federal law protecting pensions, the court said. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is aimed at assuring workers will get their retirement pay. But state lawsuits had loomed as potentially far more lucrative because fired employees could win punitive damages that greatly exceed lost pay. Writing for the court today in a case from Texas, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said Congress clearly intended to preclude state lawsuits over firings motivated by efforts to avoid paying pension benefits. ``The goal was to minimize the administrative and financial burden of complying with conflicting directives among states or between states and the federal government,'' O'Connor said. The decision is a victory for the Ingersoll-Rand Co., which was sued by Perry McClendon after firing him in 1982. McClendon had been transferred by the company from San Antonio to Dallas in 1979 to develop a sales market for construction equipment there. He was fired four months before his 10th anniversary with the company. A worker with 10 years experience is entitled to have his pension vested, which meant Ingersoll-Rand would have to contribute to McClendon's retirement benefits. McClendon sued in Texas state courts, accusing his former employer of firing him to avoid paying pension benefits. The company said he was fired to reduce the workforce and save money. McClendon did not sue for lost pension benefits. In fact, shortly after he sued the company agreed to vest his pension. Instead, McClendon's suit sought a potentially big-money judgment for lost wages, mental anguish and punitive damages. The Texas Supreme Court ruled that McClendon's lawsuit was not precluded by ERISA, the federal law, but today's decision reversed the state court ruling. The case is Ingersoll-Rand vs. McClendon, 89-1298.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Stands On Arizona Air Pollution Controls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 4th graf, The deadline, to show extension not yet expired.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact a ruling that gave federal officials a deadline for approving tougher air pollution controls for two metropolitan areas in Arizona. The justices, without comment, rejected Bush administration arguments that a federal appeals court ruling improperly limited the government's power in developing plans for improving regional air quality. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last May gave the Environmental Protection Agency six months to adopt a new plan for reducing carbon monxide in Phoenix and Tucson and surrounding areas in Maricopa and Pima counties, respectively. The deadline was to expire Nov. 26, but federal officials were granted a two-month extension. Justice Department lawyers said the appeals court exceeded its authority and may be in conflict with a Supreme Court ruling issued last June. In that decision, the justices reinforced the EPA's power to seek fines against air polluters even when federal officials have been slow to approve plans for cleaning up the atmosphere. The June decision permitted EPA enforcement when the agency arguably has missed its own deadlines for adopting new rules. The appeal acted on today said the Arizona case should be restudied in light of that ruling. But state residents seeking stricter pollution controls said the June decision is irrelevant to the case. The residents sued the EPA, claiming pollution control plans it approved for the two metropolitan areas are inadequate. The agency required gas stations to sell high oxygen content fuel during winter months when carbon monoxide levels are highest; large employers to limit commuting by employees driving to work alone; and upgraded testing of car-exhaust emissions. The plans' challengers said additional measures are needed, including expanded mass transit, parking controls, bus and car pool lanes, reduced bus fares and reduced truck travel during peak periods. The 9th Circuit court said the EPA violated federal law by arbitrarily lifting from state officials the burden of proving the additional measures would not speed up the attainment of cleaner air. ``Arizona has made no claim that any of the measures ... is impracticable or unreasonable in either Maricopa County or Pima County,'' the appeals court said. ``The EPA cannot extract leeway from a statute that Congress explicitly intended to be strict.'' President Bush signed a new clean air law in November, but the Arizona residents seeking tougher controls in the two counties said the new law appears to have no bearing on their case. The case is Reilly vs. Delaney, 90-456.

DOC.HEAD: West Africans Impose Cease-Fire in Monrovia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to CORRECT that army troops, not rebels, going to barracks east of city. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `In one incident..''
DOC.TEXT: West African troops have forced an end to fighting between rival factions, and relief workers prepared to distribute food today to starving people in the capital as tensions relaxed. The five-nation West African army turned its guns on rebel leader Prince Johnson for the first time Sunday when his fighters refused to halt their fire. Johnson ended nearly two months of relative peace in the Liberian capital and broke a cease-fire signed last week by the three warring factions by attacking remmants of slain president Samuel Doe's army on Friday. The mercurial rebel leader told reporters he had become impatient with the slow pace of a promised resettlement of the discredited government soldiers outside the capital, where they had been harassing civilians. A spokesman for the West African intervention force said Johnson's attack was ill-considered, but ``it has provided a good opportunity for us to demilitarize Monrovia and sort out these two factions.'' Nkem Agetua, press secretary to army commander Gen. Joshua Dogonyaro of Nigeria, told The Associated Press today that remnants of the Liberian army remaining in Monrovia had indicated they were ready to go to an army barracks 15 miles east of the city, and that the West Africans intended to help them move soon. Many of Johnson's men had to be forced back to a base at Caldwell, eight miles northeast of Monrovia, he said. In one incident, the West Africans were seen arresting more than 50 rebels outside the U.S. Embassy. No shots were fired then, but there was a shootout when the West Africans forced Johnson's men to disarm at a bridge linking the city to Monrovia's port. Agetua said more than 40 Johnson fighters were detained Sunday. Independent observers put the number at nearer to 200. The spokesman said no force had to be used against the soldiers because they retreated to their barracks. Agetua put the death toll from the fighting at about a dozen fighters in all from both sides. He said there were no civilian casualties. At least one civilian died during the weekend in an unrelated incident. Johnson's men shot Moses Willi, a part-time guard at the British Embassy, at his home in a northern suburb after neighbors denounced the man as a former Doe soldier. Friends said he was a former policeman. All three warring sides have indiscriminately killed civilians. At least 10,000 people have been slain. But people in Monrovia said they feared the soldiers more than the rebels and sympathized with Johnson's wish to get them out of Monrovia. Monrovia's first food distribution in months was stopped last month because soldiers immediately stole the food from civilians. The last distribution - except for supplementary feeding for children near death - took place three weeks ago. People in the street beg for food, mothers pleading their children have had nothing to eat in days. Dozens of articles are on sale in the city, from running shoes and T-shirts to buttons and batteries. But what little food is available is too expensive for more people. The outbreak of fighting in Monrovia has diverted attention from the main rebel faction of Charles Taylor, which has overrun the capital and until signing the cease-fire agreement Wednesday was the only faction blocking peace. Agetua said U.S. Ambassadors Peter De Vos was acting as an intermediary, arranging a meeting among all the warring factions and leaders of an interim government chosen by Liberian exiles, which Taylor does not recognize. He said he hoped the meeting would be held within two days, either in Monrovia or the neighboring state of Sierra Leone. The meeting is to organize modalities of a cease-fire, such as a camp to which Taylor's men could be confined, and to negotiate an interim government agreeable to all parties.

DOC.HEAD: Weak Support for Extreme-Right Republican
With PM-Germany-Elections, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The far-right Republican Party suffered a major setback in the German election, capturing only 2.1 percent of the vote nationwide, final results indicated today. The results wiped out any chance of the party gaining seats anywhere and ended fears that voters in former East Germany could swing to the far right after more than 40 years of Communist rule. In the five new eastern states, the Republicans received only 1.3 percent of the vote, while in the western region they received 2.3 percent, for a nationwide average of 2.1 percent. The ultrarightist party shocked the nation in January 1989 by getting 7.5 percent of the vote to gain 11 seats in the legislature of former West Berlin. But on Sunday, the Republicans dropped to 2.4 percent of the vote in a united Berlin, eliminating any chance of them retaining seats in the city's legislature. The party still holds a few seats in some local city councils in western Germany and the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, but the election results indicated their influence was eroding.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislative Leader Gives Stern Warning to Baltics
DOC.TEXT: A top Kremlin official warned the Baltic republics today that even if they refuse to sign a new Union Treaty, they must remain in the Soviet Union until they follow procedures established by national law. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has proposed the treaty to hold the 15 Soviet republics together in a federation. The Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia refused to participate in drafting the document and have said they will not sign it. Rafik Nishanov, chairman of the Council of Nationalities, one of the two chambers in the Supreme Soviet legislature, formally submitted the treaty to lawmakers today. ``If the Baltic republics don't accept such a treaty, in my opinion, they will remain in the Soviet Union on the basis of the documents with which they joined the union,'' Nishanov told the legislature. He said that under the Soviet Constitution, the Baltic republics have a right to secede, but only if they first hold referendums and then follow procedures established by Soviet law. Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia were occupied by the Soviet army at the start of World War II and were annexed in 1945. The Kremlin has refused to recognize their declarations of independence this year, saying they violate the Soviet Constitution. The Baltic republics contend they were occupied by force and that their annexation is invalid. The parliaments of all three republics, meeting in joint session in Vilnius last week, called for the removal of Soviet ``occupation'' forces and international recognition of their independence. Nishanov's speech indicated the Gorbachev government is maintaining a hard line on the issue of secession and will not allow the Union Treaty to become an easy way out for republics seeking independence. Gorbachev sat on the rostrum during the legislative session but did not speak. The new Union Treaty, replacing one signed in 1924, would give the restive republics more economic and political autonomy. But a strong central government in Moscow would retain control over defense, foreign policy, taxation, monetary policy, electric power and transportation. In addition to the Baltic republics, Armenia, Georgia and the Ukraine have said they will not sign the Union Treaty in its current form. Georgia's parliament has declared that it wants full independence, and there are also strong independence movements in Armenia and the Ukraine. Without mentioning Russian republic President Boris N. Yeltsin by name, Nishanov attacked Yeltsin's proposal for bilateral treaties between republics. Forming ``a union without a center ... would be a step backward'' after centuries of cooperation between the ethnic groups in the Soviet Union, he said. Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, the Soviet Army chief-of-staff, told the legislature that defense had to remain a function of the central government. He noted that defense installations and academies were spread across the country, and said nuclear weapons should remain under the control of only a few top officials. ``No other way (of handling nuclear weapons) is possible,'' Akhromeyev said. ``That's how it's done both here and in the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Strengthens Right of Criminal Suspects in Mississippi Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 4-9, In other action, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today strengthened the right of criminal suspects to have lawyers present when they are questioned by police. By a 6-2 vote, the justices overturned the murder conviction of Mississippi death row inmate Robert S. Minnick, who confessed when he was questioned without his lawyer present. The court said Minnick's rights were violated even though he earlier had consulted with his lawyer and agreed to talk to authorities. Unless the suspect initiates such a talk with police, the court said, he may not be questioned outside the presence of his lawyer once he has invoked his right to a lawyer. In other action, the court: - Left intact a lawsuit settlement that eased restrictions on abortion clinics in Illinois. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by two nurses and two expectant fathers who said the settlement does not adequately protect women or fetuses. - Refused to kill a lawsuit against a California community college's officials accused of unlawful censorship for blocking the on-campus performance of a racially charged play. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by the college officials. - Shielded businesses from some big-money lawsuits filed by employees who claim they were fired so their employers would not have to pay pension benefits. The court ruled unanimously that fired employees may not sue4 in state courts over such allegations. The state suits are pre-empted by a federal law protecting pensions, the court said. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, writing for the court in the confession case, said, ``There can be no doubt that the interrogation in question was initiated by the police. It was a formal interview which (Minnick) was compelled to attend.'' ``Since (Minnick) made a specific request for counsel before the interview, the police-initiated interrogation was impermissible.'' In a dissenting opinion, Justice Antonin Scalia said the majority was ``misguided'' to discourage ``an honest confession.'' He said the ruling undermines a ``belief in either personal responsibility or the moral claim of just government to obedience.'' He was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. Justice David H. Souter did not take part in the case. Minnick and James ``Monkey'' Dyess escaped from Clarke County, Miss., jail in April 1986 and went looking for guns, authorities said. Police said the two men fatally shot Donald Ellis Thomas and Lamar Lafferty when the victims returned to Thomas's mobile home to find Minnick and Dyess there. Minnick was arrested in Lemon Grove, Calif., on Aug. 22, 1986. FBI agents ended their questioning of him when he asked for a lawyer. Minnick then met with an attorney who advised him not to answer any more questions. A few days later, Deputy Sheriff J.C. Denham of Clarke County flew to California and questioned Minnick. The suspect confessed, saying he shot Lafferty because Dyess was threatening to kill Minnick if he did not. Minnick was convicted in Mississippi and sentenced to death. The Mississippi Supreme Court, in upholding his conviction, said Denham's questioning of Minnick did not violate a rule the U.S. Supreme Court established in 1981. The high court barred police from questioning a suspect who has asked for a lawyer unless the suspect initiates the conversation. Today the high court extended that ruling to instances in which a suspect already has conferred with an attorney. Kennedy said the 1981 ruling is designed to prevent police from badgering a defendant into giving up the right to a lawyer provided by the court's famous Miranda ruling in 1966. The threat of badgering is no less after the suspect has talked to his lawyer, Kennedy said. ``A single consultation with an attorney does not remove the suspect from persistent attempts by officials to persuade him to waive his rights or from the coercive pressures that accompany custody and that may increase as custody is prolonged,'' he said. The case is Minnick vs. Mississippi, 89-6332.

DOC.HEAD: Wintry Storm Sweeps Through Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Much of the Midwest and Great Lakes region received an early jolt of wintry weather today, as snowfalls of up to 10 inches closed schools, toppled power lines and snarled travel. A blizzard warning was posted in parts of Wisconsin. In hard-hit Iowa, Iowa State and Drake universities were among among scores of schools and businesses that closed their doors or delayed opening today as high winds and heavy snows brought much of Iowa to a standstill. The Dubuque Regional Airport was closed, with snowdrifts of 2 to 3 feet. Forecasters said the storm was caused by an intense low pressure system that was moving across central Illinois into northern Indiana this morning, and that the East would begin to feel its effects later in the day. National Weather Service meteorologist Dan Ferry in Des Moines, Iowa, said the combination of snow and wind was the most severe in central Iowa in five years. Up to 10 inches of snow fell in central and southeast Iowa by midmorning and the wather service said up to a foot of snow could be on the ground by tonight. Winds gusting up to 56 mph whipped the snow, leaving cars and trucks stranded along roadways. On Sunday afternoon, a teen-ager was killed near Numa in southeastern Iowa when the car he was riding in slid off an icy road and into a ditch. The storm knocked out power to 45,000 customers in the Chicago area, as freezing rain and high winds snapped power lines. ``The outages are scattered all over. There's not too many places that are immune,'' Commonwealth Edison spokesman John Hogan said. By midmorning, about half the customers had power restored, he said. In Wisconsin, the weather service said blizzard conditions had developed in the southern part of the state this morning, and it issued blizzard warnings for some areas. Madison had 7 inches of snow by 6 a.m. The storm was accompanied by strong winds, gusting up to 54 mph at Milwaukee, causing blowing and drifting snow. That knocked down power lines in some scattered areas of southeastern Wisconsin. The Milwaukee and Madison school systems were among those canceling classes. Schools also were closed in Michigan, where the storm dumped up to 3 inches of snow by the morning rush hour. The snow was expected to turn to rain during the day in southern Michigan, but more snow was expected in the northern half of the state. State police said at least 45 schools and school districts in southern lower Michigan called off classes today. Elsewhere, the storm dumped up to 8 inches of snow in Southern Minnesota and forced some schools to close or open late. As the storm moved eastward, Buffalo, N.Y., reported its first major snowstorm of the season. Two inches of snow fell in two hours this morning, with up to 6 inches expected by the afternoon, according to the weather service. Dozens of fender-benders, but no major accidents were reported on the slick Buffalo roads. ``The first day like this, everybody has to learn to drive all over again,'' said Jerry Hooven, an American Automobile Association spokesman. To the West, another storm was blowing into Washington state, which suffered tens of millions of dollars in damage from two bouts of record flooding last month. Heavy rain was falling along the coast this morning in advance of a warm front. Parts of the coast received more than 1{ inches since Sunday evening, and winds of 20 to 35 mph were forecast.

DOC.HEAD: Honecker Maintains His Innocence; Hospitalized in Cardiology Unit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Honecker maintaining his innocence, translator's name, other details. ADDS byline. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Germany-Elections, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former East German leader Erich Honecker said today that he is not guilty of personally issuing shoot-to-kill orders at the Berlin Wall, the ADN news agency quoted his lawyer as saying. Wolfgang Ziegler, the lawyer, said the ousted Communist party boss claimed he is not guilty according to criminal codes that existed when he was ruling what was then East Germany, the agency reported. Ziegler said it was important to determine whether Honecker violated firearms laws of former East Germany, what the laws said, and how they fit in with the current penal code in effect in a united Germany. The lawyer said, however, that Honecker should answer politically and morally for acts committed as Communist leader. Honecker, 78, is wanted by German police on charges he signed the shoot-to kill orders. Soviet military officials have prevented German police from serving an arrest warrant to Honecker, who is at a Soviet military hospital outside Beelitz, in former East Germany 20 miles south of Berlin. Earlier today, Soviet military doctors ordered Honecker into a cardiology unit at the Red Army hospital, German radio reported. The Sender Freies Berlin radio station quoted a Soviet interpreter as saying Soviet doctors considered Honecker's condition ``serious.'' Honecker sought refuge at the hospital in April. A Soviet military doctor with the rank of colonel diagnosed Honecker as having high blood pressure, the ADN news agency quoted Igor Molotkin, the interpreter, as saying. The agency said Honecker's wife, Margot, called the doctor early this morning and the ousted party boss was carried on a stretcher to a cardiology department for treatment. German police need permission from Soviet authorities to enter the hospital complex. A Soviet diplomat said Sunday that the decision on whether Honecker can be turned over to German authorities would have to be made at the highest level, presumably in Moscow. A Soviet official at the embassy in Bonn refused to comment on a report that talks were under way between German and Soviet officials on handing over Honecker, whose testimony could be potentially damaging to Moscow. Berlin justice officials issued the warrant on Friday, just two days before the first free elections in a united Germany in 58 years. They based the warrant on new documents recently uncovered that incriminate Honecker. Honecker's lawyers maintain he is too sick to stand trial. The arrest warrant charges Honecker with personally signing shoot-to-kill orders to guards at the Berlin Wall - the border between former East and West Germany. The warrant also links Honecker directly to the deaths of several people killed while trying to flee the repressive East German regime before it was toppled in last year's peaceful revolution. Some 200 people died trying to escape from East Germany during the 28-year existence of the Berlin Wall and the barbed wire barrier that separated the two German states. Honecker also rejected ``responsibility'' for issuing the shoot-to-kill orders in comments published Nov. 1 in the London-based weekly newspaper, The European.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Presidential Hot Line, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0451,0724
DOC.HEAD: $4.7 Million Upgrade Completed On U.S.-Soviet Hot Line
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with rededication of hot line and quote from Army official. Picks up 3rd graf pvs., `Could we ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Russians asking questions about basketball over the Moscow-to-Washington hot line? The Cold War really must be over. Experts manning the hot line, which was rededicated today after a $4.7 million upgrade, see evidence of glasnost in test transmissions from the Soviets. ``The project has helped keep the peace all these years and this upgrade allows us to have state-of-the art communications,'' Lt. Gen. Jerome B. Hilmes, director of information systems in the office of the Secretary of the Army, said at a ribbon-cutting ceremony today. Routine, maintenance-related dispatches have actually become chatty. ``Could we ask an unofficial question about basketball?'' the Soviets asked last February over the communications link set up after the Cuban missile crisis to avert the accidental outbreak of war. ``Could you please tell us how our Kurtinaitis performed against your snipers?'' The Soviets were referring to Rimas Kurtinaitis, a 6-foot-5 star from Lithuania. The National Basketball Association had invited Kurtinaitis to challenge eight NBA stars in a three-point shooting contest in Houston. ``Snipers'' apparently was the Soviets' translation of long-range basketball shooters. ``We'd like to know how he feels in the NBA,'' the Soviets asked. ``Friends,'' the Americans technicians and linguists on the hot line replied, ``in the local newspaper it says that Kurtinaitis is feeling fine, but there are no results from the competition. They'll probably be in tomorrow's paper.'' ``Several years ago,'' said Tom Brothers, manager of the hot line station at Fort Detrick, ``you would have never seen that.'' Technicians working at Fort Detrick in Frederick make sure the emergency communications link is available to President Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev. The hot line, established in 1963, allows the superpower heads of state to circumvent normal diplomatic channels and exchange written messages. There never was a red phone in the Oval Office, an image popularized in many movies. The modernized operation includes updated transmitters and receivers, control consoles and two new saucer-shaped satellite dishes. Replacement parts were becoming scarce for the old dishes. ``At this station we never know when the president is using it. What we do is make sure the hot line is available to him,'' Brothers said. ``Our checks are to make sure the Earth station-to-Earth station link is OK.'' This is the line's third upgrade. The first hot line, a trans-Atlantic teletype cable, was prone to interruptions, including one caused by a Finnish farmer who cut a cable with his plow the very first year. In the 1970s, a manhole fire north of Baltimore cut off the cable's primary circuit. About the same time, American telephone workers accidentally cut the line's cables. Today, each hot line message goes to the Soviet Union three different ways - over a land cable and through two satellite systems. The duplication ensures messages arrive at the Kremlin, or the White House, during a crisis. Any message Bush sends to Gorbachev is encoded and taken to an undisclosed terminal point in Washington. It is transmitted to the Fort Detrick Earth station, 50 miles northwest of the nation's capital, where the signal is enhanced and relayed to two Soviet satellites. The satellites, 22,300 miles above the equator, beam the message to antennae south of Moscow. The message is also sent to Moscow via Intelsat, an American-owned commercial satellite system based in Etam, W.Va. Since 1986, the presidents have been able to accompany their written messages with maps, charts or other graphics. ``It takes a matter of seconds for our communications to reach the Soviet Union,'' said Brothers, one of 13 Field Engineering Corp. employees who work at the Fort Detrick station. Presidents have used the hot line more than 15 times in its 27-year history, said Norm Covert, a spokesman for Fort Detrick. One of the most notable uses was during the six-day Arab-Israeli war in 1967. President Lyndon B. Johnson advised the Soviet Union of U.S. ship and aircraft movements in the Mediterranean following an Israeli attack on the USS Liberty.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves First Over-the-Counter Drug for Yeast Infections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 7-8, In a small, on minimal risk
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the first non-prescription drug to treat vaginal yeast infections, which afflict nearly three-fourths of all women at least once in their lifetimes. Availability of the drug, clotrimazole, for non-prescription sales will spare many women the inconvenience and expense of going to a doctor to get a prescription to treat the common infections, the FDA said. ``Clotrimazole is highly effective and carries a minimal risk,'' said Dr. Carl Peck, director of the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, adding that it has a 10-year history of safe prescription use. ``FDA has concluded that the switch of this drug to non-prescription sale will benefit women - especially those with recurring infections,'' who will be able to treat themselves, he said. Peck said that as long as the infection is initially diagnosed by a doctor, a woman can recognize the symptoms and treat herself without needing a prescription. Labeling on the drug's package will say: ``If this is the first time you are suffering from vaginal itch and discomfort, please consult your physician.'' In a small number of cases, use of the drug can cause allergic reactions, including burning and a rash. More rarely, it has caused abdominal cramps and bloating, the FDA's Cruzan said. Women who are pregnant are advised not to use the product except under a physician's supervision. Vaginal yeast infection, or candidiasis, is an overgrowth of a naturally occurring fungus called Candida. The overabundance occurs when the body's natural balance of bacteria is upset. This often occurs with antibiotics or birth control pills. When the yeast overgrows, the resulting infection causes itching and burning, sometimes with a discharge and soreness. However, other conditions, including sexually transmitted diseases, can cause similar symptoms, which is why a woman should get an initial diagnosis by a physician, said FDA spokeswoman Susan Cruzan. A brochure that will be sold with the product will advise women to continue treatment for seven consecutive days, even if the infection appears to have cleared up before then. If signs of the infection do not clear up in three days, the brochure advises, the woman should see a physician. The drug, which will be available as a vaginal suppository or as a cream, is made by Schering-Plough in Kenilworth, N.J., and will be sold under the trade name Gyne-Lotrimin. Nearly 22 million cases of vaginal yeast infections are reported annually, the company said, and nearly 75 percent of all women will experience at least one infection.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules on Phony Mileage Reading Case from Virginia
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled today that a federal anti-counterfeiting law may be used to crack down on the sale of used cars with phony mileage readings. By 5-3 vote, the court upheld the conviction of Raymond J. Moskal, manager of a Pennsylvania car dealership sentenced under the law to six months in prison. Moskal was convicted of taking part in a scheme in which car odometers were turned back and ownership titles listing the lower mileages were obtained in Virginia. That process - called ``title washing'' - is covered by a 1939 federal law that makes it a crime to ship ``falsely made'' documents across state lines, said Justice Thurgood Marshall for the court. ``Our conclusion that `falsely made' encompasses genuine documents containing false information is supported by Congress' purpose in enacting'' the law, he said. ``Title washes involve precisely the sort of fraudulent activities that are dispersed among several states in order to elude state detection.'' Justice Antonin Scalia, in a dissenting opinion, said the ruling creates a dangerous precedent because the court is interpreting a law in a way that seems to conflict with the dictionary meaning of words. Falsely made is not the same thing as false, he said. ``A forged memorandum is falsely made,'' Scalia said. ``A memorandum that contains erroneous information is simply false. The temptation to stretch the law to fit the evil is an ancient one, and it must be resisted.'' He was joined by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justice David H. Souter did not take part in the ruling. Moskal was convicted with Al Davis, owners of the wholesale car dealership in Manheim, Pa., that Moskal managed, and Dennis Smith, owner of a dealership in Chesapeake, Va. Davis and Smith did not appeal to the high court. Prosecutors said the ownership certificates from Davis' dealership were shipped to contacts in Virginia who applied for titles in that state with the phony lower mileage figures. The Virginia titles then were sent back to Davis and he distributed them to area dealers to sell with the used cars. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the convictions of the three men. But federal appeals courts elsewhere in the nation have struck down similar convictions on grounds the federal law did not cover odometer tampering. The case is Moskal vs. U.S., 89-964.

DOC.HEAD: Army Deploys in Greater Beirut
DOC.TEXT: The Lebanese army began deploying in both Moslem and Christian sectors of Beirut today, in the first phase of a plan to end the country's 15{-year-old civil war. About 8,000 troops moved in to replace the rival armed militias that completed their withdrawal today. People lined the streets in the Christian, eastern sector of the capital, to cheer the government troops. Women showered the soldiers with flower petals, rice and scented rose water. The restitution of state authority is seen as a major achievement in the government's efforts to end the civil strife that has left more than 150,000 people dead. The first phase of the plan went into effect with the completion earlier today of the withdrawal of all warring militias from the greater Beirut area. This extends along a 15-mile coastal strip between the Kelb River in the north and Damour River in the south. The army started moving in after the 6,000-strong Lebanese Forces militia led by Christian warlord Samir Geagea withdrew from eastern Beirut to positions in the Christian hinterland of Kesrouan province. The last remaining 2,000 Lebanese Forces troops rumbled out of the neighborhoods of Ashrafiyeh, Karantina and Nabaa in a convoy of 400 military vehicles. The convoy included 30 tanks decorated with colored portraits of Geagea and the militia's flag of a green cedar tree on a white background. Some trucks towed Soviet-made 130mm howitzers and twin-barrelled anti-aircraft guns. About 1,660 tons of ammunition were taken from the city over the previous week. ``Today we complete our withdrawal from Greater Beirut which will come under the protection of the Lebanese army. We hope the army will soon be in control throughout the nation,'' said the militia's Voice of Free Lebanon radio. Lebanese army troops of the mainly Christian 5th Brigade moved into areas evacuated by the Lebanese Forces. Soldiers of the predominantly Moslem 6th and 12th Brigades were deployed along the five-mile Green Line, which had split Beirut into Moslem and Christian sectors since the outbreak of the civil war in 1975. Army troops also started deploying in the Moslem western and southern sectors of the capital and in the predominantly Druse mountains east and southeast of Beirut. The main Moslem Shiite and Druse militias announced last month they had completed the withdrawal of their militias from Greater Beirut. Withdrawal of the rival militias was part of an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end the civil war. Subsequent phases envisage the complete disbandment of the rival militias.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Seal Homes of Arab Teen-Agers Involved in Stabbing
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers sealed the homes of three Arab teen-agers arrested in a weekend stabbing attack on a Tel Aviv bus in which an Israeli and one of the assailants were killed, the army said today. Moslem fundamentalist leaders of the 3-year-old Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories put out leaflets praising the stabbings. ``We will continue our revolution with knives,'' said the Jihad Islami, or Islamic Holy War, faction. The Hamas, or Zeal, movement urged ``using all means'' to escalate attacks on Israelis. It was the bloodiest incident in greater Tel Aviv, Israel's most populous area, since Arabs began a wave of stabbing attacks on Jews in October. The attacks followed the police slaying of Arabs on Jerusalem's Temple Mount. Police announced that in the wake of Sunday's attack they would tighten controls on Palestinians entering Israel from the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Radio stations reported increased checks this morning on Palestinian-owned vehicles entering the Tel Aviv area from the West Bank. In the attack Sunday, three Palestinian youths from the West Bank boarded a bus bound for Tel Aviv then later stood up and knifed four passengers shouting ``Allahu Akbar!'' Arabic for ``God is great.'' A 24-year-old Jewish seminary student, Baruch Heisler, died of throat and chest wounds suffered in the attack. Three other Israeli passengers, all teen-agers, were also wounded. A police officer who helped subdue the attackers, shot and killed one of them, 17-year-old Jafaar Omar Fares Dawikat. The other two assailants were injured. One was shot in the hand, and the other was beaten by passersby, Israeli reports said. They were later identified as Mohammed Abdul Majid Sawalha, 19, and Munir Hussein Ahmad Sawalha, 17. Soldiers sealed the home of Dawikat's family in the area of Nablus and the two Sawalha family houses in nearby Azmut this morning, the army said. Army radio mentioned the sealings, which are done routinely to the homes of Arabs suspected of participating in attacks. The three suspects were all from large families and the sealings put 37 people out on the street. A military court, meanwhile, sentenced 12 Palestinian guerrillas to 30 years in prison for an aborted seaborne attack six months ago aimed at the U.S. Embassy and Israeli civilians. The attempted raid on May 30 was claimed by the Palestine Liberation Front, a PLO faction headed by Mohammed Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Here are some quotes from the testimony of Secretary Cheney on the Persian Gulf situation.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Airlines Files For Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13-15th grafs, bgng `We entered...', with 3 grafs to UPDATE with quote from news conference, CORRECT 2nd reference to Harris sted Hollis in 15th graf pvs. Picks up 16th graf pvs, `Raymond E...'. Version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. filed for protection from creditors under federal bankruptcy laws today, blaming the move on a stunning rise in fuel costs and heavy debts accrued in the free-spending 1980s. It was the first bankruptcy-court refugee in the airline business since the dramatic leap in fuel prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis, and underscored the financial beating taken by all airlines because of a weakening economy, with fewer passengers flying and booking tickets. The move also marked a rapidly deteriorating situation for Continental, once the nation's biggest airline operator, which only a few weeks ago rejected the bankruptcy-court option. Based in Houston, Continental is best known as the child of one-time airline entrepreneur Frank Lorenzo, who built it into a major force in the airline industry through aggressive price-cutting and debt-financed expansion after a previous stint in bankruptcy court seven years ago. Continental officials said they expected to operate normally through the holiday season and passengers would notice no difference in service. ``Essentially, we're allowed to treat the traveling public, travel agents, tour operators, just as if the bankruptcy hadn't occurred ...,'' said Paul P. Welsh, a Continental attorney. ``There will not be anyone stranded.'' The airline filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws in Wilmington, Del., where it is incorporated. Under Chapter 11, a company gets a reprieve from debts while it works out a way to pay the bills and tries to re-emerge from court protection as a healthy business. As part of the bankruptcy filing, Continental said it agreed to sell its prized Seattle-to-Tokyo route to American Airlines for $150 million, pending approval of the court. Today's filing marks the second bankruptcy-court stint for Continental. In 1983, amid a bitter labor dispute with the airline's unions, then-chairman Frank Lorenzo plunged the airline into bankruptcy court, scapped union contracts and hired low-cost replacements for workers striking at the time. The incident eventually led to changes in the law to limit companies' right to abrogate union contracts by bankruptcy filing. In today's statement, Continental, the nation's fifth-largest airline, said the latest financial woes were brought on by high jet fuel costs and a high debt load, which have ``created a temporary cash shortage for the airline.'' The airline listed total assets of $4.77 billion and liabilities of $5.85 billion. ``Continental has made these decisions reluctantly,'' Hollis Harris, chairman, president and chief executive of Continental, told a news conference in Wilmington. ``We couldn't handle the debt and the cost of fuel at the same time. Fuel is our highest item of operating costs.'' Harris said that since July, Continental was paying $70 milion per month more in jet fuel because of the recent runup in oil prices. He said fuel costs made up about a quarter of its operating costs. Continental lost $88.3 million in the third quarter of this year, compared with a loss of $158 million in 1989. For the first nine months, losses totaled $97 million, compared with a $522.8 million loss last year. Harris said he forsaw no need for layoffs, pay cuts or reductions in benefits to the airline's 37,000 employees as a result of the bankruptcy-court move. Raymond E. Neidl, an airline analyst with Dillon Read & Co. in New York, said if Continental's creditors agree to a reorganization plan early on, ``they still have chance of survival'' because ``they have a good, solid domestic system and they have a low operating cost structure.'' Continental, which was known as Texas Air Corp. until this summer, is the parent of Continental Airlines and Eastern Airlines. Eastern filed for bankruptcy protection in 1989 and has been run by a government-appointed trustee since April 10. Continental had been rumored to be considering filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy for the past several weeks. As recently as late October, the company said its board of directors, including Lorenzo, unanimously rejected a proposal to file, saying it would consider possible asset sales, cost controls or seek new investors. Continental sold a 16.8 percent stake to Scandinavian Airline System in August and Lorenzo stepped down as chairman, although he remains on the board.

DOC.HEAD: Foundation Raises Money for Monument to Military Women
DOC.TEXT: When Mary Hoffman joined the Army during World War II, she was a serious young woman who thought she'd already missed her chance for a full life. But the Women's Auxiliary Army Corps changed everything. ``I thought I was going to be a spinster,'' she recalled 47 years later. ``Instead, I married my first bedside patient.'' Mrs. Hoffman is one of the 350,000 women who served in World War II. She is also the largest single donor to the foundation that's trying to build a memorial to America's women veterans. Mrs. Hoffman has contributed more than $60,000 to the project, all from disability payments she received after breast cancer forced her to leave the service in 1945. Mrs. Hoffman, now an 83-year-old widow, says women veterans need their own memorial. Male war veterans have their monuments and memorials, but ``we are the last group to unite,'' she said from her home in Hyattsville, Md. ``I do feel it's so well worth it.'' Mrs. Hoffman spent two years in the WAC as an occupational therapist, stationed at Woodrow Wilson Hospital in Staunton, Va. Her job was to go from bedside to bedside, helping injured soldiers make wallets or belts or teaching them to type or knit. ``I didn't have a sense of humor when I first went into the military,'' she remembered. ``I was a little old-fashioned, wearing my hair up. But the Army made me over, believe me.'' Mrs. Hoffman's small story is one of almost 50,000 collected so far for a databank that will be part of the memorial, said retired U.S. Air Force Brig. Gen. Wilma Vaught, president of the Women in the Military Service of America Foundation. Vaught is delighted with Mrs. Hoffman's generosity. But she needs a total of $25 million for the memorial and at the moment, she's about $22.5 million short. ``There are over 1.2 million living women veterans and 400,000 women on active duty and in the Guard and reserve'' who are potential donors, Vaught said in a recent interview at the foundation's Arlington, Va., offices. Part of Vaught's problem is finding those women, as well as the descendants of the thousands of American women who served in every war since the Revolution - as nurses, scouts, suppliers, soldiers and saboteurs. Privacy laws prevent Vaught from getting the addresses of veterans or active-duty military women from the government. She has been relying on some 450 volunteers to find them. The Women in Military Service Memorial also suffered a fund-raising setback this year. The foundation tried to raffle a $1 million house in suburban Centreville, Va., only to see ticket sales fall far below target. ``We saw this as a mechanism that in a really short period of time we could raise a lot of money,'' Vaught said. But the kickoff coincided with the drug trial of D.C. Mayor Marion Barry, and media attention was nominal, she said. When the date for the drawing approached in early November, the foundation had sold only about 24,000 of the one million raffle tickets printed. Vaught was forced to postpone the drawing until Feb. 23. There's been progress in other areas. The site has been chosen: the ceremonial entrance gate to Arlington National Cemetery. The foundation conducted a design competition last year and selected a concept by Marion G. Weiss and Michael Manfredi, partners in a New York architecture firm. Their design sets 10 39-foot glass spires into the top of the semicircular gate, known as the Hemicycle. Inside the entrance walls will be a museum portraying the history of women in the U.S. military, a 225-seat auditorium, and the databank. At night, the spires will be gently lit, giving the effect of candles against the Virginia hillside. Vaught is very conscious that time is essential. Under the law authorizing the memorial, Vaught has until November 1991 to raise the $25 million. ``That date may be a little optimistic,'' she said, adding that she is prepared to go back to Congress to ask for more time. Meanwhile, as she travels the country meeting women veterans and promoting the memorial, she is most impressed by the World War I veterans. ``We still have a few World War I women left who can make it to the dedication,'' she said. ``If we're going to do something to say thank-you to them, it's got to be now.''

DOC.HEAD: Ireland's First Woman President Takes Office
DOC.TEXT: Ireland's first woman president, Mary Robinson, was inaugurated Monday and extended a hand to both Protestants and Catholics in troubled, British-ruled Northern Ireland. In her acceptance speech, delivered in English and Gaelic, the 46-year-old lawyer said she would represent a ``new Ireland.'' ``I want to do this with no hidden agenda, no strings attached,'' said Mrs. Robinson, a Roman Catholic who married a Protestant. ``As the person chosen by you to symbolize this republic ... I will seek to encourage mutual understanding and tolerance between all the different communities sharing this island.'' A 21-gun salute echoed across the Irish capital as Mrs. Robinson was sworn in by Chief Justice Thomas Finlay following an interdenominational service at the medieval, turreted Dublin Castle. About 500 government and church dignitaries and Dublin-based foreign diplomats looked on as Mrs. Robinson took the oath of office. The ceremony was televised live in Britain and in the Irish Republic, where schools were closed for the day. Mrs. Robinson extended an invitation to Irish descendants worldwide to visit the republic. ``There are over 70 million people living on this globe who claim Irish descent and I will be proud to represent them,'' Mrs. Robinson said. ``And I would like to see ... my official residence to serve on something of an annual basis as a place where our immigrant communities could send representatives for a get-together of the extended Irish family abroad.'' Mrs. Robinson said that in her seven-year term she would continue Ireland's tradition of promoting international human rights, particularly in Latin America and Africa. She campaigned on a platform of change and a more involved presidency, winning the Nov. 9 election with 52.8 percent of the vote. After her victory, Mrs. Robinson thanked the women of Ireland who voted for her and ``instead of rocking the cradle, rocked the system.'' In her acceptance speech, the president and mother of three addressed Irish women. ``As a woman I want women who have felt themselves outside history to be written back into history ... finding a voice where they have found a vision,'' she said. Britain sent troops to Northern Ireland in 1969 to end sectarian and political violence. Nearly 2,900 people have died in bombings and assassinations since. The Irish Republican Army is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland and wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic republic of Ireland under Socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Satanists Scatter Remains From 21 Coffins
DOC.TEXT: Vandals pillaged a mausoleum and scattered remains from 21 coffins during what appeared to be satanic rituals on the French island, police reported Monday. No suspects had been arrested. The vandals wrote ``Satan worshipers will destroy you'' on the walls of the mausoleum over the weekend, police said. They also killed several chickens and threw them on a fire. Police said only one coffin was left untouched. The mausoleum recently has been a hangout for young people taking drugs and drinking, new problems on the traditionally Roman Catholic island, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Oceanographer's Wife Dies In Monaco
DOC.TEXT: Simone Cousteau, who accompanied her husband, Jacques-Yves Cousteau, on hundreds of voyages aboard the marine research ship Calypso, has died at her home in Monaco, the Cousteau Foundation said Monday. She was 72. Mrs. Cousteau died Sunday. The cause of death was not given. Married in 1937, the Cousteaus for many years spent most of their time aboard the Calypso, sailing throughout the world to study marine biology, conduct underwater explorations, make films and promote conservation. Known by the Calypso's crew as ``the shepherdess,'' Mrs. Cousteau served as nurse and purser, and sometimes participated in underwater missions. She is survived by her husband and a son, Jean-Michel. A second son, Philippe, died in an airplane crash in 1981. Funeral arrangements were not announced.

DOC.HEAD: Royal Regalia Stolen, Sultan Says
DOC.TEXT: Selangor state's royal ruler said Monday that thieves have stolen his ceremonial golden belt, which was studded with dozens of diamonds and rubies. ``I am very sad over the theft,'' Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah said. ``This is the third time such a thing has happened, the first being the theft of the state ceremonial mace two years ago and the attempted theft of my car. I don't know what else will go missing next.'' The sultan told a news conference at his palace in Klang, 21 miles west of here, that the Pending Emas Bertahta Berlian, a ceremonial golden belt worn by him at official functions, was stolen from the state museum on Nov. 27. It had been on exhibit to mark the silver jubilee of his reign. The belt, inlaid with 45 diamonds and 25 rubies, was made on the orders of his late father, Sultan Hisamuddin Shah, in 1950 and cost $31,500. The mace also had precious stones on it. The sultan said he believed the belt was stolen by the same person or group that stole the mace, but he did not elbaborate. He offered an $11,100 reward to anyone who helped arrest those responsible, the National News Agency Bernama reported from Klang. The sultan blamed the theft on carelessness by police and museum officials and said he had ordered that all Royal regalia be kept in a bank vault. The 64-year-old sultan is the constitutional monarch of Selangor state, which surrounds Kuala Lumpur.

DOC.HEAD: Hanoi Disciplines 1,246 Cadre, Party Members for Corruption
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have disciplined 1,246 people in Vietnam's capital in a 2-month-old crackdown on corruption, state radio said. Radio Hanoi said authorities will bring more people to trial, including Hanoi's deputy director of police. It did not give his name. Officials in the capital also ``have initially detected signs of financial, economic and managerial violations by 140 targeted primary installations,'' the broadcast last Thursday said. A transcript of the broadcast was seen Monday in Bangkok. It said Hanoi authorities had disciplined 1,246 cadre and members of the ruling Communist Party, including 558 who have been expelled from the party. It did not elaborate. Since the crackdown began, there have been numerous reports of high-ranking officials tried for corruption.

DOC.HEAD: French Prize to Mubarak for Championing Human Rights
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak on Monday received a French prize for upholding peace and human rights, and said he would continue to champion the rights of Kuwaitis and Palestinians. Mubarak said Egypt's belief in human rights and democracy explained its rejection of the Aug. 2 Iraqi conquest of Kuwait. ``We call for concerted international efforts after the end of the gulf crisis to achieve a legitimate solution to the Palestinian issue,'' Mubarak said after accepting the prize in a nationally televised ceremony. The ceremony was attended by Alain Poher, president of the French Senate. He is honorary chairman of the French Institute of Advanced Political and Social Studies, which awarded Mubarak the Louise Michel Prize for Human Rights, Democracy, Dialogue and Peace.

DOC.HEAD: Seamen Executed for Mutiny
DOC.TEXT: Two seamen were executed Monday on charges of killing their captain and three other crewmen in a mutiny aboard a Taiwanese trawler last year, prison officials reported. Hsu Guohsin, 29, from the Chinese province of Fujian, and Taiwanese Yu Tien-shou, 36, were executed after the Supreme Court upheld the death penalty imposed by the Taipei District court last year, the officials said. The men were shot in the back. The seamen were convicted of killing crewmen of the trawler Tung Chung in June last year while it was fishing near Indonesian waters. The two said they mutinied because the captain abused them and gave them too much work to do.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnappers To Be Sentenced To Death By Hanging
DOC.TEXT: The government on Monday decided to stiffen the punishment of kidnappingsffor ransom, raising the sentence from life in prison to death by hanging to try to halt the rising number of abductions. Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz told reporters the decision was taken at a Cabinet meeting. ``There has been a rising tide of kidnappings,'' Aziz said. ``Strictest punishment is needed.'' Pakistan's criminal law called for life imprisonment and forefeiture of property for kidnapping, but that will be amended to include the death penalty, Aziz said.
