Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif announced the plan three weeks ago, prompting speculation that the harsher punishment was aimed at Asif Ali Zardari, the husband of ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. Zardari is in jail in Karachi for his alleged role in the kidnapping and extortion of a Pakistani-born British businessman. Zardari twice has been refused bail. The government denies anyone is the target of the new law. Aziz said the amendment will be introduced before the National Assembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament, for ratification later this month. Kidnappings for ransom has increased dramatically in the past two years in southern Sindh province, especially in Karachi, the country's largest city and its financial and industrial center. Scores of wealthy businessmen and their familes have been the main targets. Most have been released after their families paid huge ransoms. Politicians had blamed the crime on what is popularly known as the ``Kalashnikov and heroin culture,'' a referrence to the automatic rifle that has flooded Pakistan during the war in neighboring Afghanistan and the drug industry it spawned.

DOC.HEAD: Court Resolves Deadline for Job-Bias Suits in Texas Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today resolved conflicting rulings by federal appeals courts around the country over the deadline federal employees face when suing over alleged on-the-job bias. The court, by a 6-2 vote, said such suits against federal employers sometimes may be allowed even if the 30-day deadline is missed. Some appeals courts had disallowed such waivers for suits against the federal government while allowing more deadline flexibility in suits against private employers. But by a separate 7-1 vote, the court ruled that the 30-day deadline begins when the office of the suing person's lawyer receives a right-to-sue letter from the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. There had been some confusion in lower courts about whether the 30-day period began to run only when the suing persons themselves or their lawyers, not their lawyers' office, received notice of the right to sue. Writing for the high court in a Texas case, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said federal courts need not throw out all such bias lawsuits filed past the deadline. But Rehnquist added that no waiver is required when the delay was caused by a lawyer's absence from the law office where the right-to-sue notice was received. The decision killed a suit by Shirley W. Irwin, a handicapped former employee of the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Waco, Texas. Irwin's suit said the VA fired him illegally in 1986. Justices Byron R. White and Thurgood Marshall voted to make the 30-day deadline apply to all suits by federal employees, regardless of the reason for delay. Justice John Paul Stevens voted to have the 30-day deadline begin to run only when the suing employees themselves receive notice of their right to sue. The case is Irwin vs. VA, 89-5867.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Arrives in Brazil as Trouble Erupts in Argentina
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 8-10 to UPDATE with Fitzwater comments on Argentina situation.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today hailed ``extraordinary political and economic change'' in the Western Hemisphere as he kicked off a five-nation South American visit. He vowed not to let his tour be interrupted by military turmoil in Argentina. In an appearance before a joint session of the Brazilian Congress, Bush praised Brazil for being among the first countries to impose economic sanctions against Iraq. He said the high oil prices resulting from the Persian Gulf crisis are costing Brazil $5 billion annually. However, local experts said Bush's figure seemed excessive. ``I realize the sacrifices that Saddam (Hussein's) brutality has caused this nation,'' Bush siid, departing from his prepared text. As the president arrived in Brazil at dawn, nationalist officers seized army headquarters at Buenos Aires and President Carlos Menem declared a state of siege, a presidential spokesman said. Bush, scheduled to visit Argentina and hold talks with Menem on Wednesday, told reporters, ``I have no thoughts of changing my plans. I have great confidence in the security there.'' Bush's top State Department aide on Latin America, Bernard Aronson, said the situation in Argentina was ``all right.'' ``I don't know if it's entirely over but it doesn't sound too serious. There's a small group in the military that has certain grievances and every once in while something like this happens,'' said Aronson, who was traveling with Bush. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, accompanying Bush on his trip, telephoned the U.S. Embassy in Argentina and was told that rebel forces were in three locations in Buenos Aires. Government forces were en route to talk them into giving up, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Fitzwater added that it seems likely the incident was intended to embarrass Menem before Bush's visit. ``It's also the reason we want to make clear our support for democracy and President Menem,'' Fitzwater said. In another development, police said bombs exploded Sunday in a Mormon chapel and in the offices of two right-wing political parties in Chile, another country on Bush's travel schedule. Authorities blamed a small radical leftist guerrilla group. An anonymous caller told a news agency that the blasts were ``an offensive'' to protest Bush's visit to Santiago on Thursday. Bush seemed in good spirits as he arrived at a military air base here. Bush and President Fernando Collor de Mello opened their meeting by talking about the impact on world oil prices and the global economy of Iraq's takeover of Kuwait. Bush mentioned the figure $1.5 billion, presumably talking about the impact that President Vaclav Havel told him the occupation was having on Czechoslovakia. ``That's why, when people say to me that this can go on and on, I say, `No!,' Bush said. Later, in his speech to Congress, Bush hailed the ``extraordinary political and economic change that is transforming the face of this hemisphere.'' He described Brazil as a leader in this effort, citing Collor's efforts at reducing the size of the state, privatizing enterprises, combatting inflation and liberalizing trade. These steps, he said, ``are the keys to growth and prosperity in the global economy of the 21st Century.'' He added: ``Our thinking must be bold, our will resolute. Our challenge now is to hew out of a wilderness of competing interests a new kind of opportunity in the Americas. ``To fulfill the new world's destiny, all of the Americas and the Caribbean must embark on a venture for the coming century: To create the first fully democratic hemisphere in the history of mankind,'' Bush said. There were no urgent issues to be discussed on Bush's agenda, but he wants to associate himself with what he sees as a rare opportunity in hemispheric relations. The first four countries on Bush's itinerary - Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina and Chile - all were under military rule within the last few years and now have elected governments. The fifth country, Venezuela, has been democratic since 1958. Bush is making the trip at a time of unusual harmony in U.S.-Latin American relations. The South American tour was to have taken place in September but was postponed because of the Persian Gulf crisis. Secretary of State James A. Baker III stayed behind in Washington to deal with that issue. The centerpiece of Bush's policy toward Latin America is the Enterprise for the Americas Initiative, which is designed to achieve economic growth through expanded trade and investment and reduced debt. Bush's goal is a hemisphere-wide free trade area. Just a week ago, Bush was in Mexico to push for a bilateral free trade agreement with that country. Although military rule gave way to elected government in much of the hemisphere during the 1980s, the decade was a disaster economically. Production, investment and consumption all fell sharply. Collor is part of a new generation of Latin leaders who have moved aggressively to reduce the state role in the economy and to reduce inflation through spending cuts. Inflation dropped dramatically shortly after Collor took office in March but is now again on the rise. Brazil's foreign debt is $112 billion, the largest in any developing country. The country is almost $10 billion in arrears on debt repayments and is negotiating a new repayment schedule with creditors. In what the administration sees as a breakthrough in its goal of nuclear non-proliferation, Brazil and Argentina last week agreed to renounce the manufacture of nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Wins Elections; Economics Minister Quits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 1 graf each for 6th, `He has...' and 11, `The Greens...' to fix typos. Pickup 12th, `Kohl's center-right...'
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who triumphed in the first free all-German elections in 60 years, began talks today on forming a new coalition and discussed the new Germany's role in the Persian Gulf. ``On international levels, one is conscious of a special responsibility,'' he told reporters a day after his center-right coalition rode to victory, buoyed by his own popularity as a champion of quick unity. But Kohl indicated Germany would probably not be able to quickly make a constitutional change that would be needed to allow the deployment of German troops in the Persian Gulf or elsewhere outside NATO areas. ``We will discuss this within the coalition ... I don't see this situation at the moment,'' he said. Kohl himself proposed the amendment, but many of the opposition Social Democrats have criticized it. Kohl said he had already begun initial talks on forming a new coalition with his Christian Democratic Union's current governing partners, the Christian Social Union and the Free Democrats. He has indicated he wants to have his Cabinet in place by Christmas, but his coalition colleagues are pressing him for instant decisions on his next Cabinet. One decision was made for him when Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said he was quitting the Cabinet amid what German television claimed was growing criticism over Haussmann's handling of the economy. Haussmann was a major force in putting together the economic and monetary union of West Germany and East Germany in July, a crucial step toward full unification Oct. 3. He gave no reason for quitting. But Stern magazine released an interview with central bank chief Karl Otto Poehl, who criticized Kohl's plans to borrow up to $100 billion next year to finance unification. Poehl's comments were confirmed by the Bundesbank's press office. The big losers in Sunday's elections were the leftist Social Democrats, the main opposition party, and the far-leftist Greens. Both parties had criticized Kohl's rapid pace of unification and accused his Christian Democrats of underplaying the cost of bring the east up to the standard of the west. The Greens, Europe's most-established ecology movement, lost most of their seats in parliament, receiving only 3.9 percent of the vote in western Germany. The Social Democrats, led by Oskar Lafontaine, polled 33.5 percent. Kohl's center-right governing coalition won 54.8 percent of the vote. The government put turnout at 78.5 percent of 60 million eligible voters. Berlin - the united Germany's designated capital - held its first combined city elections in 44 years Sunday. The conservative slate won the most votes but appeared to lack the majority needed to unseat Mayor Walter Momper's Social Democrat-led administration. The Christian Democrats were projected to win 40.1 percent of the vote in Berlin, compared to 30.3 percent for the Social Democrats. Sunday's elections marked the first free balloting in a united Germany since Adolf Hitler's rise to power ended in the devastation of World War II, and capped a year of political victories for Kohl. The 60-year-old chancellor, who championed the swift merger of the two Germanys and now begins a third four-year term, was jubilant and confident after his victory. But he conceded difficult challenges lie ahead, especially restructuring the economy in eastern Germany. ``I have never kept secret the problems that we have,'' Kohl said in a televised panel discussion that included Lafontaine. ``It is a difficult transition period.'' He predicted, however, that within four years prosperity will exist across all of Germany, that ``the strengths of the social market economy, reasonably applied, will create a huge, united, flourishing landscape.'' Lafontaine acknowledged his party had misjudged the popularity Kohl won in uniting the two Germanys. He also conceded that ``in the long term people will be better off'' in what was East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: COfficial Expresses Concern About Trump Taj Mahal's Financial Stability
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with hearing under way. Picks up 5th graf pvs `The commission had...'. A version also moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: State casino investigators today expressed concern about the financial stability of Donald Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort but said it was still too early to accurately predict the gambling hall's fate. In a statement before the state Casino Control Commission, Deputy Attorney General Thomas Auriemma said the Taj Mahal's slot machine performance continues to lag and that a debt restructuring agreement reached with bondholders on Nov. 16 fails to reduce the gambling hall's $675 million debt. ``The Taj Mahal is not reducing its overall debt,'' Auriemma said. Auriemma and Trump attorney Nicholas Ribis agreed that the commission can examine the restructuring agreement although its exact terms have yet to be finalized. Auriemma also said it was it was too soon for state gaming regulators to gauge whether the agreement would stabilize the casino. He spoke as the casino commission opened a hearing to examine the financial stability of the Taj, which opened last spring and is undergoing restructuring that will temporarily throw it into bankruptcy court. If they conclude that the casino is financially unstable, the commission members could lift its license and appoint a conservator to operate it. Trump himself was not at the hearing this morning. It is expected to last at least two days. The flamboyant developer, author of the best seller ``The Art of the Deal,'' has battled financial and marital problems for most of the year. Since gambling came to the Boardwalk in 1978, only one of 13 casinos - Elsinore's Atlantis Casino Hotel - has lost its license because of financial problems. The commission had planned to evaluate all three Trump casinos - the Trump Castle, Trump Plaza and Taj Mahal - after giving its approval in August to a $65 million emergency bank loan in June that allowed Trump to make an overdue payment to Trump Castle bondholders. Trump put up his casinos as collateral for the new loans. Commission spokesman Tom Flynn said the regulatory panel will look only at the Taj Mahal for now but may check the Trump Castle and Trump Plaza later. ``It would have been too cumbersome to look at all three,'' Flynn said. Among the evidence at today's hearing is an August report on the casino issued by the state Division of Gaming Enforcement that accurately predicted Trump would miss a $47.3 million interest payment to Taj Mahal bondholders Nov. 15. That report concluded, ``Simply put, the (Trump) organization is in dire financial straits.'' An updated report on the casino's status will also be submitted, said gaming division spokesman Wayne Marlin. He would not comment on the contents of that report. Marlin said the division, an arm of the attorney general's office, would not take a position on whether the Taj Mahal should keep its license. Stephen Bollenbach, chief financial officer of the Trump Organization, said the commission would find the restructuring for the Taj Mahal leaves the casino in sound shape despite a weakened economy. ``Based on the revised deal with bondholders, there's no doubt we're financially stable,'' Bollenbach said. ``Nothing in the world we live in today looks like it did six months ago.'' Trump, who is restructuring $675 million in Taj Mahal bonds, will enter into a ``prepackaged'' bankruptcy filing that allows the casino to emerge quickly from court protection. He made the deal shortly after missing the Nov. 15 interest payment. The agreement cuts the bonds' interest rate from 14 percent to 12 percent and gives bondholders half the stock in the Taj Mahal. The Taj Mahal set city records for gross gaming revenues, or ``win,'' but still reported losing $11 million during the third quarter of this year. The casino said its gross profits were dragged down by $26.51 million in interest payments.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Charged in Death of Woman Who Used Suicide Device
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with background. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A doctor whose device was used by a woman to commit suicide was charged today with murder. Dr. Jack Kevorkian was charged in the death of Janet Adkins, 54, who traveled to suburban Detroit last June to use an apparatus he devised. He hooked her up to the intradvenous device, then she pushed a button that triggered a flow of coma and death-inducing drugs into her bloodstream. Mrs. Adkins f Portland, Ore., had been diagnosed a year earlier with Alzheimer's disease, a degenerative brain and nerve disorder. ``Janet Adkins was not terminally ill. She was not suffering any pain,'' Oakland County Prosecutor Richard Thompson said today at a news conference to announce the murder charge. ``For me not to charge Dr. Kevorkian would turn Oakland County into the suicide mecca of our nation.'' If convicted, Kevorkian could be senteced to life in prison. He has contended that assisting suicide is not a crime under Michigan law. Michigan now has no specific law against suicide or assisting it. Mrs. Adkins' family said she wanted to end her life before her condition worsened. The device was used in Kevorkian's van in a park about 40 miles north of Detroit. Thompson had delayed filing charges, saying he was awaiting autopsy results to determine whether Mrs. Adkins had a terminal illness. Kevorkian, 63, a retired pathologist and advocate of doctor-assisted suicide, said Sunday he expected to be charged in the case. ``How could he claim murder? I didn't kill anybody,'' Kevorkian said. ``It wasn't malicious disregard for life.'' Prosecutors obtained a temporary injunction against Kevorkian to keep him from using the machine, which they seized, and from aiding other suicides. A hearing had been set for Tuesday to determine whether Kevorkian could have his machine back. State police and the Michigan State Medical Society have said they also were investigating Mrs. Adkins' death, but have issued no formal findings.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Prepare to Storm Rebel-Seized Base; Bush Visit Still On
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 17 grafs to UPDATE with troops surrounding all installations rebels seized, report that exits at tank factory mined and troops blocking rebel column, increases casualties and number of rebels involved, U.S. comment. Pickup 14th graf pvs, `All of...' TRIMS thereafter to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Bush, Bjt
LaserPhoto NY21
DOC.TEXT: Government troops today surrounded bases and buildings seized before dawn by mutinous soldiers in an uprising two days before President Bush was scheduled to visit. President Carlos Menem declared a state of siege, suspending constitutional guarantees and giving his government sweeping powers to ensure public order. His government demanded that the rebels surrender unconditionally. Bush, in Brazil, indicated he had no plans to cancel his visit to Argentina, and the military said the situation was being brought under control. The rebels said they were not trying to overthrow the government, but were trying to force changes in the way the military was run. The uprising, the fourth military revolt in Argentina in four years, began when insurgent soldiers seized part of the downtown army headquarters, several coast guard buildings nearby, a tank factory 16 miles to the northwest and infantry base five miles to the north. Loyal troops tried to retake the installations, but by afternoon the rebels were still holed up in the buildings they seized. The army said at least three loyal soldiers were killed and 14 wounded in the fighting. Police sealed off major roads in Buenos Aires, a city of 10 million people. Federal police banned public gatherings, and the Economy Ministry declared a bank holiday. The army said a total of 200 rebel soldiers were involved, but rebels claimed 700 followers at several bases, including a tank batallion in Entre Rios Province, north of Buenos Aires Province. The private news agency Noticias Argentinas said government troops were mining the exits from the tank factory to prevent the rebels from driving tanks out. It also said the government troops had dynamited a bridge and blocked a tunnel that cross the Parana River north of the capital to prevent a column of rebel tanks and armored vehicles from leaving Entre Rios Province. The army chief of staff, Gen. Martin Bonnet, said in a communique that the army is ``under the orders of their commanders, except for small groups that are being put under control.'' In the capital, rebels fired at and hit a helicopter carrying Vice President Eduardo Duhalde as it landed on the roof of Government House, two blocks from the downtown army headquarters. Duhalde was unhurt. Gunfire was heard in the port zone two blocks to the other side of Government House, where Menem and Duhalde have their offices. Bush, who arrived in Brazil today, said his visit was still on. ``I have no thoughts of changing my plans. I have great confidence in the security there,'' he told reporters in Brazil. Bush's top State Department aide on Latin America, Bernard Aronson, said the situation in Argentina was ``all right.'' ``I don't know if it's entirely over, but it doesn't sound too serious. There's a small group in the military that has certain grievances and every once in while something like this happens,'' said Aronson, who was traveling with the president. White House spoksman Marlin Fitzwater added that it seemed likely the incident was intended to embarrass Menem before Bush's visit. ``It's also the reason we want to make clear our support for democracy and President Menem,'' Fitzwater said. The insurrection was the first in Argentina since Menem took office in July 1989. He is the country's second civilian president since the military ceded power in 1983. All of the previous insurrections have been by officers who declare themselves nationalists and demand pay increases, pardons for rights abuses during the 1976-83 military regime, and changes in the military high command. Military pay - like the pay of most Argentines - has been severely reduced by hyperinflation and government budget cuts. A spokesman for the rebels, an unidentified lieutenant, said, ``This is not a coup. We recognize the authority of President Menem as commander-in-chief.'' But, he told reporters: ``Our generals don't represent the sentiment nor the thought of our army.'' A rebel spokesman, retired Maj. Hugo Abete, said the plotters were followers of Col. Mohammed Ali Seineldin, who was cashiered after he led the previous military uprising, in December 1988. Seineldin has been under military arrest for several weeks for delivering a letter critical of the high command to Menem. He is held at a base in San Martin de los Andes, about 1,000 miles south of the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Former South Carolina Legislator Sentenced In Sting Case
DOC.TEXT: Former state Sen. Rick Lee was sentenced today to a six-month term in a halfway house and five years' probation for accepting a cash bribe made during a federal ``sting'' operation. Lee is the first lawmaker sentenced in the FBI probe of corruption in the Statehouse. U.S. District Judge Falcon Hawkins said the light sentence was given to the Boiling Springs Republican because of his cooperation in the FBI sting. Hawkins could have sentenced Lee to up to 27-months in prison under federal sentencing guidelines. ``I'm very appreciative of the judge's sentencing and the work my attorney did,'' said Lee, 37. Ex-Rep. Luther Taylor, snared in the FBI probe ``Operation Lost Trust,'' was scheduled to be sentenced later today. Taylor, D-Columbia, faced a maximum 120 years in prison and $1.5 million fine. U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel, in court papers filed last week, recommended that Lee get a lighter sentence than federal guidelines mandated because he has cooperated with the government in the continuing probe of corruption. Daniel asked for harsher treatment of Taylor, arguing that Taylor's crimes were so severe that he warranted extra punishment. He did not recommend a sentence. The federal probe has led to bribery charges against nine lawmakers and drug charges against a tenth lawmaker and a Statehouse lobbyist. Lee and three other former legislators pleaded guilty to accepting money from a lobbyist, working undercover for the FBI, to support a bill legalizing betting on horse racing and dog racing in South Carolina. The four all had resigned from the legislature when they were indicted in August. A fifth ex-legislator pleaded guilty to a cocaine charge and also awaits sentencing. Taylor, meanwhile, contested the bribery charges; a jury convicted him in October. Four other House members await trials later this month and in January. Three won re-election to the House in November; the fourth decided not to run.

DOC.HEAD: 12 People Killed in Soviet Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Five soldiers and three civilians died in the Uzbekistan city of Namagan over the weekend during several hours of violence touched off by a clash between youths and troops returning from leave, Tass said today. Elsewhere, four Azerbaijani policemen were killed, three wounded and two reported missing on Sunday in the troubled border region between the republics of Azerbaijan and Armenia, Tass reported today. It said the policemen were attacked by Armenian fighters, three of whom were killed and two wounded. In Uzbekistan, Namagan Mayor Erkin Mamakulov said six soldiers returning to their unit on a city bus Sunday night were harassing young women passengers and demanding the bus change its route. He said the soldiers were drunk. Tass said the bus driver agreed to change routes, but was stopped by a crowd which surrounded the bus and began to beat the soldiers. Four of them died, the official Soviet news agency said. When news of the incident reached the soldiers' battalio in the Central Asian republic, its commander, Maj. V. Tezikov, set off for the site with a group of unarmed soldiers, Tass said. The crowd, which Tass said had swollen to more than 3,000 people, set the bus of fire and threw stones and metal rods. The troops, unable to reach the bus, called for armed reinforcements who were backed up by 700 policemen, some of whom were forced to use their weapons, it said. A fifth soldier was killed along with three civilians, Tass said. Twenty-nine soldiers and 22 policemen were injured, some seriously, it said. Regarding the other unrest, Tass said Interior Ministry troops were sent today to the scene of the violence, the village of Martunashen in Azerbaijan's Khanlar district northwest of the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region. Armenians and Azerbaijanis have been clashing for nearly three years over control of Nagorno-Karabakh, a predominantly Armenian region inside Azerbaijan's borders. More than 220 people have been killed. Armenian has demanded control, but Azerbaijan has refused, prompting intermittent strikes, boycotts and violence. Interior Ministry troops have repeatedly been dispatched to restore order.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Says U.S. Cannot Trust Saddam; Palestinian Question Raised By Saddam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs third to the last graf ``The plane...'' to say plane has again left Amman.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. defense secretary today told lawmakers that Kuwait would not satisfy Saddam Hussein's ``appetite for conquest.'' The Iraqi president again linked the Palestinian question with Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said in Washington that the United States could not wait indefinitely for economic sanctions to drive Iraq out of Kuwait. ``Despite the pain he is inflicting on his own people, there is no indication that Saddam Hussein is open to a peaceful resolution of the problem he has created,'' Cheney told the Senate Armed Services Committee. The United States cannot trust Saddam when ``he tells us his intentions are benign,'' Cheney said. ``If he gets away with swallowing Kuwait, his appetite for conquest will hardly be satisfied.'' His testimony followed statements from former U.S. military officials and several U.S. lawmakers urging that the United States give economic sanctions against Iraq more time to take effect. Meanwhile, U.S. and British military officials said Iraq tested surface-to-surface missiles on Sunday. The missiles, which have a range of 400 miles, were fired and landed within Iraqi territory. Cheney said Iraq fitted similar missiles with conventional warheads during its war with Iran, but the missiles also could carry chemical warheads. In an interview broadcast Sunday by a French television network, Saddam said the chances of war in the Persian Gulf stand at ``50-50,'' with the outcome depending on the discussions between his government and Secretary of State James A. Baker III. President Bush, in the latest initiative to end the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, offered on Friday to send Baker to Baghdad and the Iraqis accepted. Saddam did not respond to the French reporters' questions about the possibility of an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. But he said the ``dialogue'' with Baker would have to deal with Israel's withdrawal from the territories occupied by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war - lands where most residents are Palestinians. The United States has rejected any such linkage. ``If they want to make this meeting a real path toward dialogue, then we are closer to peace,'' Saddam said. ``But if they want to make this meeting nothing other than a formal exhibition for the American Congress, the American people or international public opinion, simply to give themselves good conscience to say, `There, we've tried to dialogue with Iraq, without Iraq renouncing its positions' - in that case, we're closer to war.'' Some U.S. observers have said Bush's offer to hold talks with Iraq was lip service for critics who say his administration is moving too quickly toward war. The U.N. Security Council, in a resolution Thursday, authorized force against Iraq if Saddam does not withdraw his troops from Kuwait by Jan. 15. The United States has about 240,000 troops among the 350,000-strong force in the gulf region. By next month, the number of U.S. soldiers in the force assembled against Iraq is expected to swell to around 400,000. U.S. Marines began a four-day amphibious exercise Sunday, the fourth since Operation Desert Shield began after the occupation of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Military officials refused to dislose the location of the practice landings, the number of Marines involved or whether forces from other countries took part. Also Sunday, U.S. Energy Secretary James Watkins met with Saudi Arabian Oil Minister Hisham Nazer in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, to discuss plans to expand Saudi oil production and to keep prices from skyrocketing in the case of war. A U.S. Embassy official in Riyadh said today that the United States will use its nearly 600 million barrel strategic petroleum reserve to stabilize oil prices in the event of war. ``They discussed U.S. plans to use strategic petroleum reserves in case hostilities broke out and a real shortage emerged,'' said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``People tend to panic when a conflict breaks out, but we'll do whatever we can to maintain stability.'' Crude oil prices doubled to around $40 a barrel soon after Iraq's invasion, but have fallen to as low as $29 since. If war breaks out, they could shoot up as high as $100 a barrel, according to estimates by oil officials. The plane carrying former heavyweight boxing champion Muhammad Ali and 17 former hostages made an emergency landing in Amman, Jordan, today after developing technical problems shortly after takeoff. The jet departed for New York again after about seven hours on the ground. A spokesman said Ali plans to return to Baghdad on Christmas Eve to seek freedom for other hostages. The 15 American hostages and two Canadian hostages with Ali left Iraq on Sunday. The Americans had been among those foreigners held at strategic sites in Iraq to deter an attack by the U.S.-led multinational force.

DOC.HEAD: Five Guerrillas Killed in Clash with Israeli-Backed Militia
DOC.TEXT: Israeli-allied militiamen today killed five Lebanese guerrillas in a firefight in Israel's self-proclaimed security zone in southern Lebanon, army officials said. There were no casualties among fighters of the Israeli-financed South Lebanon Army militia, army officials said. The guerrillas first fired a number of rocket-propelled grenades at a position of the militia 1,000 yards northwest of Alman, which is five miles northwest of Israel. The Israel-backed fighters returned fire and began a three-hour chase up the Litani River estuary that ended in a battle in which four of the guerrillas were killed and a fifth died later of wounds, military sources said. The guerrillas were armed with the Soviet-designed Klashnikov assault rifles and two rocket-propelled grenade launchers, the army officials said. Artillery duels rocked the region during the chase, the officials said. They said the guerrillas apparently belonged to a Lebanese branch of the Baath party and the Lebanese Resistance Front, which was responsible for several suicide attacks against Israeli forces in 1985 aimed at pushing them out of Lebanon. Last week, five Israeli soldiers and two Palestinian guerrillas were killed in a clash on the eastern sector of the buffer zone. The army said those guerrillas belonged to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a PLO faction led by George Habash. Israel carved out the 440 square mile security zone as a buffer protecting its northern border against guerrilla raids in 1985, when it withdrew the bulk of its forces from Lebanon after a three-year occupation. The zone is jointly patrolled by Israeli soldiers and some 2,700 members of the mostly Christian South Lebanon Army.

DOC.HEAD: House Republicans Re-Elect Leadership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, And in, with Vander Jagt vote.
DOC.TEXT: House Republicans re-elected their leadership team today in voting marked by the deep divisions and frustrations that come from being the minority party for more than three decades. House Minority Leader Robert Mchel of Illinois and Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia were re-elected to the No. 1 and No. 2 jobs without opposition when the 167 Republicans assembled in the cavernous Cannon Caucus Room. The terms last two years. Then, in a toughly fought contest for Republican Conference chairman, the No. 3 leadership post, incumbent Jerry Lewis of California defeated challenger Carl Pursell of Michigan, 98-64. And in a bitter contest for chairman of the party's House campaign arm, National Republican Congressional Committee Chairman Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan survived a challenge by Rep. Don Sundquist of Tennessee, 98-66. It has been 36 years since any Republican in the House of Representatives could call a hearing to order, preside over the chamber, or take primary credit for a piece of legislation. House Republicans suffered an additional indignity and stepped up their renewed infighting when their already small numbers were reduced further by last month's elections. ``There is a big feeling that we just have to get a broom in there and sweep the place out,'' said one six-term Republican, speaking only on condition of anonymity. ``But there are others who feel a bloodletting is not what we need.'' The two hotly fought contests are symptoms of ``the same mood which gripped the electorate (in this year's campaign) - throw the rascals out,'' said another senior GOP lawmaker. Few Republicans wanted to be interviewed on the subject, and those who did insisted on anonymity. Both contests also pointed out a deeper division within the party, one that splits House Republicans from the White House. When Bush wants to win a fight on Capitol Hill, he most often goes to the Senate, where the numbers are less stacked against him. ``They see themselves manipulated and taken advantage of by their own White House, and condescended to by the Democrats,'' said Norman Ornstein, a longtime Congress-watcher at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative Washington think tank. The split with the White House widened in the year's battles over the federal budget. Many House Republicans felt left in the lurch by Bush when he abandoned the no-new-taxes pledge that helped elect him in 1988. Gingrich led a group of renegade House Republicans against the president. The congressional committee's chief political operative, Ed Rollins, advised candidates to run against Bush's budget. Lewis stuck with the White House, but Pursell did not. Those familiar with the Byzantine world of House party politics say White House anger over that move along with a number of rivalries were at work in today's contests. Others pointed to the relatively poor performance of Vander Jagt's committee over the past decade. Despite GOP domination of the White House and the expenditure of millions of dollars, Republicans have won more than 50 House seats that they have later lost back to the Democrats. This year, the GOP lost a net of eight seats, giving the Democrats a 100-member majority. Coupled with mixed results in governor's races and in state legislatures, the result was disappointing in a year when the party had hoped for gains that would give them an advantage when House seats are reapportioned before the 1992 elections.

DOC.HEAD: President Offers to Resign, Lift State of Emergency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with opposition demanding Ershad step down now. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Ershad, who...'
DOC.TEXT: President Hussain Muhammad Ershad, beset by increasingly violent opposition protests, offered today to resign before presidential elections next year and to lift a state of emergency. The 60-year-old former army general said on state-run television he was willing to resign 45 days before the election, scheduled for June. The opposition demanded that he step down immediately instad. ``He has not announced any time frame for the elections and thus he intends to buy time to hoodwink the opposition. This is not acceptable,'' said Kamal Haider, spokesman for the country's major opposition alliances. The opposition had said previous elections were rigged and had demanded that Ershad quit to allow a caretaker government to supervise the balloting. The president said in his television address that he would revoke the 6-day-old state of emergency on Dec. 16. Under it, civil liberties have been suspended, including the right to assemble in public places. He said also he was willing to dissolve Parliament, now dominated by his party, and hold elections when the presidential vote is held. Ershad, who seized power in a 1982 coup, had denounced the campaign against him as an ``attempt to destroy the national economy.'' His surprise offer to step aside came hours after security forces in Bangladesh's second-largest city, Chittagong, opened fire on students hurling homemade bombs. Reporters in the port city said at least 50 people were hurt in the clash. The government says six people have died throughout the country since the state of emergency was imposed, but opposition leaders put the death toll at 75. They say 3,000 people have been wounded and 5,000 arrested. In the past, some opposition claims have been exaggerated, while some government tolls have been understated. Because of chaos and poor communications, independent verification has not been possible. Earlier today, the government lifted censorship that was imposed with the state of emergency, the Information Ministry said in telexes sent to news offices. It said the move was due to ``the improvement of overall situation in the country.'' All newspapers, including those owned by the government, stopped publishing when the state of emergency was declared because journalists refused to work under censorship. There was no immediate word on when they would resume publication. On Sunday, censorship was eased for four international news agencies, including The Associated Press, but correspondents were cautioned to remain objective. The curfew ordering people to stay indoors was imposed in Chittagong, Dhaka, Khulna and Rajshahi when the state of emergency was declared. Chittagong, whose population is about 2 million, was a frequent flashpoint between Ershad's supporters and opponents. The injured in Chittagong, 125 miles southeast of Dhaka, included a policeman who lost both eyes in a bomb blast and five other members of the security forces, reporters said. Today's riot began when about 1,000 students set off crude bombs and attacked vehicles in a shopping district. The trouble occurred during a 15-hour break in the curfew imposed as part of the state of emergency. In Dhaka, a city of 7 million people, shops opened and traffic returned to the streets with the lifting of the curfew today. Government offices and banks lso resumed business. The opposition parties had called for 6 a.m. to 2 p.m. nationwide strike every day beginning Tuesday to maintain the pressure against Ershad. The two main opposition leaders, Sheik Hasina and Khaleda Zia, called on government employees to resign and for non-cooperation with Ershad's government. The two rival opposition leaders combined forces in October in an attempt to oust Ershad.

Here are the quote candidates. Sri to have been tardy getting them punched into the system. On other year-end stuff: Mike Robinson is looking for a couple of unsung heroes, but he's on the desk this week and next and that is slowing his search somewhat. I've asked him to let to know who he's thinking about as soon as he can so you're assured we're not duplicating other efforts. Also, our numbers people are compiling stuff for Ms. Noble today and Friday. I understand Randy Schmid already has given her some stuff. Lastly, I hope to give you by Monday or Tuesday of next week, a line on some kind of Washington year end story. If Bush would just come home, we could dismantle the trip desk and all go back to our real jobs. Have a happy Thanksgiving. WX CARROLL ----
Defeated Texas Gop Gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams' infamous comment-in-jest likening bad weather and rape: ``If it's inevitable, just relax and enjoy it.''
``Seven million albums? Embarrassing?'' asked Roy Lott, vice president for operations of Arista Records, Milli Vanilli's label. ``I don't mean the end justifies the means. But we sold 7 million albums.'' Lott was reacting to a report that the purported singers of Milli Vanilli, Fab and Rob, had not in fact been involved in recording their hit songs.
At a German Embassy lunch Nov. 1, 1990, honoring a new German agreement to support European studies programs at U.S. universities, J. O'Donovan, S.J., president of Georgetown University, said he would use a toast his grandmother taught him: ``Here's champagne for our real friends, and real pain for our sham friends.''
The Kuwaiti newspaper Al-Seyassah reported that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein told top aides that he dreamed Mohammed appeared before him and told him: ``I see your rockets deployed wrongly.'' The dream could be an attempt to prepare Iraqis psychologically for a pullout from Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2.
WX CARROLL

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Warns of `Consequences' of Waiting Too Long in Gulf
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 3 grafs after 15th graf pvs, bgng, Cheney's testimony... with comment from Byrd, Glenn; INSERTS 2 grafs after 26th pvs, bgng, Bush announced... with details from State Department on talks
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee clashed today over whether economic sanctions will force Iraq to withdraw its army from Kuwait. Cheney, testifying at Senate hearings on the Bush administration's Persian Gulf policy, said he saw ``no indication'' that Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein is willing to settle for a peaceful withdrawal. ``There is no guarantee that sanctions will force him out of Kuwait,'' Cheney said. He insisted the United States could not ``wait indefinitely'' for the embargo to work while Saddam uses the time to prepare for an attack. Cheney's comments prompted Committee Chairman Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat and critic of Bush's gulf policy, to question the administration's attitude toward sanctions. ``If we have a war, we're never going to know whether they would have worked, would we?'' he asked Cheney. ``That's the major point here. The way you find out if sanctions are going to work is to give them enough time to work,'' Nunn said. Cheney said Nunn was assuming that sanctions will work if given enough time. ``That's a big assumption,'' Cheney said. ``There's a big difference between saying we know if we use military force we can achieve our objectives (and) it may be, if we wait a year or two, economic sanctions will get him out of Kuwait as well.'' Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, were the first administration officials to appear before the committee following President Bush's dramatic announcement Friday that he was sending Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Bagdad to meet with Saddam. Cheney, responding to Democratic pleas to give the sanctions more time to work, said ``there are consequences, costs to our coalition partners and to the country. ``It isn't a clean, clear-cut choice,'' Cheney said. He said the United States cannot trust Saddam when ``he tells us his intentions are benign.'' ``Despite the pain he is inflicting on his own people, there is no indication that Saddam Hussein is open to a peaceful resolution of the problem he has created,'' Cheney told the committee. ``If he gets away with swallowing Kuwait, his appetite for conquest will hardly be satisfied,'' Cheney said. Cheney's testimony came on the heels of statements from former U.S. military officials and several lawmakers that Bush should allow the United Nations sanctions more time to take effect before opting for war. The same fears were expressed today. ``I'm concerned that we don't have a consensus here in this country that would support a war,'' said Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., a member of the panel and president pro tem of the Senate. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, voiced misgivings about the ``Chicken Little approach to our policy. The sky is falling and the only option is war.'' The defense secretary defended Bush's decision to send an additional 200,000 troops to the gulf region last month to supplant the more than 240,000 in the area. He also said additional deployments are possible and the question of troop rotation has been put aside for now. ``We have not put any upper limit on deployments and we are basing our strength in the region on the advice of the commanders on the scene and the ever increasing size of Iraq's forces in Kuwait,'' Cheney said. Nunn said the question is whether Iraq will leave without a war or following a war. ``The real debate in Congress and the country is whether to punish Iraq slowly'' or with military action, Nunn said. Cheney refused to back down from his position that sanctions alone is not the answer. ``Such a policy would give Saddam a long breathing space in which he could concentrate his efforts,'' the defense secretary said. ``Because he could ignore the possibility of military option, he could use the breathing space to work around the embargo, break up the alliance, enhance his military strength in Kuwait and move ahead on his nuclear weapons program.'' The United Nations has called for Iraq to leave Kuwait, restore the legitimate government to that oil-rich emirate and free all Western hostages. Baker plans to travel to Baghdad between now and Jan. 15 to meet with Saddam. On Friday, Bush announced his latest initiative aimed at finding a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis before Jan. 15, the deadline the U.N. Security Council has set for Iraq to leave Kuwait. After that the U.N. resolution grants the right to use force against Iraq. Bush announced Baker's trip to Iraq and invited Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to Washington to meet with the president. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said today that plans are going ahead to arrange the meetings although the United States still does not have an official reply from Iraq about whether it accepts the proposal. Nonetheless, preliminary, informal talks are under way to discuss scheduling. Ms. Tutwiler said negotiators have agreed that any talks will be bilateral discussions between the United States and Iraq without the participation of other U.S. allies. As he left Washington Sunday evening for South America, Bush declined to respond directly to reporters' questions about details of pending talks. ``I'm very pleased with the way it's going, but we'll see,'' was his only response.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Ground Controllers Have Trouble With Telescope Pointing System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with problem still unsolved; add quote from scientist, clarify description of system to be used as backup. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Columbia blasted...'.
DOC.TEXT: Trouble with the $150 million Astro observatory today delayed Columbia astronauts' scientific research, and as the hours ticked by scientists said some planned observations would not be made. ``There's a definite loss as we go,'' said mission scientist Ted Gull. ``Some objects are just going to slip off the list.'' Despite hours of efforts that stretched into early afternoon, NASA officials had trouble calibrating the observatory's instrument pointing system, which affects all three ultraviolet telescopes. Another problem, involving a computer that controls the movements of one telescope, was solved, however. Mission manager Jack Jones said another star tracker on board, attached to one of the telescopes, will be used to point the telescopes if the main pointing system continues to malfunction. The instrument is more awkward to operate, however, since it is desigened for another purpose. ``Whichever one of these we demonstrate can work first, our plan is to immediately go into that mode of operation and start gathering science,'' he said. The Astro had been expected to look at about 250 high-energy objects, including stars, quasars, galaxies, Jupiter, a supernova and Comet Levy. The ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted from these objects cannot be seen by ground-based instruments because they are unable to penetrate the Earth's atmosphere. Because at least half a day of work has now been lost, that number will be trimmed, officials said. ``Sure we're disappointed, but we knew this was a crucial step and might go slower than we planned,'' said Arthur Code, a University of Wisconsin scientist who helped design one of the telescopes. Columbia blasted into orbit early Sunday on a mission that was originally scheduled to fly in 1986 but was postponed by the Challenger explosion. Hydrogen leaks forced three launch delays earlier this year, and a telescope problem halted a fourth countdown. Columbia's crew, finally in orbit after a six-month delay, spent most of the day Sunday testing the hhree ultraviolet telescopes that will be aimed at quasars, stars and other high-energy objects during the 10-day mission. Although the astronauts hoped to make their first scientific observations today, NASA ground controllers first had to fix the instrument pointing system. The main problem was that the star trackers were over-sensitive to light. University of Wisconsin scientists and engineers, meanwhile, activated a spare on-board computer that controls the movements of the school's ultraviolet telescope, and the computer was working well. The primary experiment computer crashed Sunday while software was being loaded. The mission is the first shuttle flight in five years dedicated solely to scientific research. Columbia's flight also is the third mission in as many months - a pace the shuttle program has not achieved since 1985. ``We were so used to not getting it off, the idea that it's actually been launched and it's up there orbiting the Earth is amazing,'' said Arthur Davidsen of Johns Hopkins University, principal investigator for one of the telescopes. The brilliant night liftoff also was a boost to NASA, which has endured a year of problems with leaky shuttles and the flawed Hubble Space Telescope. ``It sure goes a long way to erase the disappointments we had this summer,'' launch director Bob Sieck said. During the mission, the seven-member crew is working in shifts so the observatory can be manned continuously. An X-ray telescope is being operated by computer commands relayed from Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. Using one of the ultraviolet telescopes during a test Sunday night, the crew focused on the ``first light'' - a star called Beta Doradus that was selected for testing purposes, not scientific observation. ``That is a real star folks,'' astronaut Samuel Durrance reported to scientists at Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala. Scientists will use the observatory to measure ultraviolet and X-ray radiation. Meanwhile, a computer terminal in the flight deck was turned off Sunday after Columbia commander Vance Brand smelled something burning. It was believed to have overheated. Also on Sunday, a Soviet rocket blasted into space with two cosmonauts and a Japanese journalist who will join two other men at space station Mir. That puts a total of 12 people in space, the most at one time. Columbia's astronauts hope to communicate with the Soviet crew by ham radio.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Comedians Chevy Chase and Steve Martin took turns holding down a giant Casper the Friendly Ghost balloon as the pair helped singer Paul Simon make a new music video. The 4{-minute video filmed Saturday will feature the comics clowning amid the floats and baton twirlers in the Jaycees Christmas parade. The video will accompany a single from Simon's latest album, ``Rhythm of the Saints.'' Martin signed just one autograph, to Carrie Cheeley, an 8-year-old baton twirler. ``This certifies that you have had a personal encounter with me and that you found me warm, polite, intelligent and funny,'' Martin wrote. The trio marched a few blocks through downtown with the Shriners' Acca Temple Oriental Band, then rode a float the remainder of the parade. Simon's album is No. 5 on Billboard magazine's album chart. --- BRISTOL, England (AP) - Actor Paul Newman will provide the initial funding for a British summer camp for children with cancer, a charity official said Monday. Bob Woodward, chairman of the Cancer and Leukaemia in Childhood Trust, said the project would cost up to $15.5 million. Newman would provide a large undisclosed cash sum through his gourmet food company, Newman's Own Foods, which gives all profits to charity, said Woodward. The balance of the money needed would be raised through a national appeal. In the United States, Newman has established a similar camp at Ashford, Conn. The camp is called the Hole-in-the-Wall Gang, named after a gang of outlaws from the film ``Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid,'' in which Newman starred with Robert Redford. It provides short holidays for 600 youngsters a year, offering a range of activities, including canoeing, fishing, horse riding and dancing. Woodward said Newman was planning similar camps in Texas and in Florida. --- BIRMINGHAM, Ala. (AP) - Joe McIntyre of the singing group New Kids on the Block fulfilled the fantasy of a 10-year-old heart transplant patient by hugging her, posing with her for pictures and signing her autograph book. ``My stomach feels funny,'' Nichole Duncan told her mother while waiting for McIntyre to visit her backstage prior to a Saturday night concert. Nichole, who underwent the transplant in August, wore two buttons with McIntyre's picture and earrings that read ``I love Joe.'' She was taking her anti-rejection medicine when McIntyre appeared. ``I love you, too,'' he told her. Nichole was diagnosed with heart problems as an infant and had undergone corrective surgery and had two pacemakers before the August operation. Her doctors told her the excitement of meeting McIntyre would not hurt her heart. --- AUSTIN, Texas (AP) - Residents pulled out their wallets - and their best dance steps - at a lively fund-raiser to help country singer Willie Nelson pay some of his back income taxes. About 300 people attended the benefit Sunday night at the Broken Spoke nightclub, where Nelson began his climb to international stardom in the late 1960s and early '70s. Nelson was not present at the country dancehall. ``He's done a lot of things for a lot of people. I think it's great that people want to help him,'' said Will Light, a Nelson fan. But while the event was expected to raise a tidy sum, with those attending paying $10 apiece for admission, it will not cut too deeply into Nelson's enormous tax bill. Internal Revenue Service officials say Nelson owes them $16.7 million. Nelson has won five Grammys. His platinum-selling albums include ``Stardust, ``Poncho and Lefty'' and ``Red-Headed Stranger.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Chief Dissolves Parliament, Suspends Constitution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with constitution suspended, parliament dissolved, Libyan prisoners flown home. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Rebels in...'
DOC.TEXT: The rebel leader who overthrew President Hissene Habre dissolved Chad's parliament and suspended the consitution, a day after his victorious entry into the capital, Radio Chad reported today. Idriss Deby, who has promised to establish a democratic government, drove into the capital aboard a black Mercedes on Sunday, Habre having fled after a series of military debacles. The announcement after a meeting of the executive committee of Deby's Popular Salvation Movement denounced the ``economic, moral and political chaos'' of the previous government. The radio spoke of the ``fictive and inoperant character'' of the institutions being dissolved or suspended. Earlier in the day, Deby freed at least 450 Libyan prisoners of war. A Libyan plane left N'Djamena in late afternoon to ferry the thin and ragged-looking prisoners home. Libya fought a series of wars with Habre's government before being driven off Chadian territory in 1987. Habre apparently fled to Cameroon. The official Libyan news agency, JANA, claimed Sunday that Habre had been killed. But the state radio in Cameroon, Chad's western neighbor, reported Monday that Habre and eight of his ministers had taken refuge in northern Cameroon. French government officials also said they had information that Habre was alive. Deby, 38, was Habre's chief aide in a 1982 coup but broke with him last year and formed a rebel movement. Habre claimed that Libya funded Deby's rebellion, but the Libyans and Deby denied it. Before dissolving the National Assembly, Deby met with Alingue Bawayeu, president of the body, who acts as interim president according to the constitution, adopted Dec. 10, 1989. Members of the rebels' Patriotic Salvation Movement received other high-ranking officials of the deposed government. Sources close to the talks said Deby hoped to calm fears of a purge and instill confidence in the future. He has promised multiparty democracy. Rebels in all-terrain vehicles mounted with machine guns zoomed through the city today, spreading their control from key administrative buildings to working-class neighborhoods. After entering the capital, Deby said he wanted to end the civil strife that has ravaged Chad for the past decade and declared that he would institute a democracy. ``My worry is not to be president of the republic,'' he said. ``This country must become democratic, pluralist. The moment has come to lay down our arms.'' Earlier this year, Habre organized the country's first contested election in its 30 years as an independent state, but candidates were limited to independents and members of his ruling party. He was re-elected to a seven-year term. Deby urged reconciliation with Goukouni Oueddei, the president he and Habre toppled in 1982. Goukouni is exiled in Libya. Three companies of Foreign Legion soldiers landed Sunday in N'Djamena to reinforce France's total troop strength in its former colony to 1,800 men. The capital was pillaged Saturday after Habre and his troops fled. The legionnaires organized the evacuation of 948 foreigners to Paris on two flights Sunday. Most of the evacuees were French, but about 50 American dependents were on the flights. France has deployed soldiers in Chad under a defense treaty. They have taken no part in the fighting, which Paris views as a Chadian affair. On Saturday, the legionnaires organized the remaining Chadian government troops to impose an overnight curfew and disarm looters, mainly renegades or civilians who had picked up weapons thrown down by army deserters. There were no immediate reports of deaths in the rebel takeover, but the French relief agency Doctors Without Borders said it treated 120 people hurt in rioting. About 1,000 civilians cheered Deby as his Mercedes-led motorcade pulled into the Place des Martyrs, the central square in the city of 400,000 people. Others waved and cried out from the streets. No details were disclosed, but the talks were presumed to concern a handover of power in this North African country of about 5.2 million people. There were conflicting reports about the fate of Habre and his Cabinet. The Libyan news agency JANA said he was killed near the Sudanese border, but diplomats and other sources said Habre and his family flew in a military plane early Saturday to Maroua, Cameroon, about 185 miles west of N'Djamena. Neither report could be independently verified. Libya, which occupied two-thirds of Chad in 1980 and occupied parts of the north before being driven out in 1987, denied any involvement in Deby's offensive. But JANA called Habre a ``brigand'' and hailed the victory of the rebels. ``Habre was an obstacle in the way of national reconciliation between Chadians and an obstacle to good neighborliness and the bonds of history and common suffering between Libyans and Chadians,'' JANA said in the commentary. Deby, a brilliant military tactician, broke the morale of government troops in a three-week campaign that culminated Thursday when the rebels captured Abeche, a town of 30,000 people about 500 miles east of N'Djamena.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Compromise Clears Way for Alaskan Oilfield Project
DOC.TEXT: The federal government and oil producers have resolved an environmental dispute that had stalled production at part of a vast Alaskan oilfield near Prudhoe Bay. The Army Corps of Engineers, the main opponent of the project, agreed Friday to a plan in which Arco, BP Exploration and Exxon would spend an estimated $50 million in the drilling area to ease fish migration in the Beaufort Sea. The agreement clears the way for production to begin within two years at the Point McIntyre field, where the oil companies own rights to an estimated 300 million barrels. Production from Point McIntyre and the nearby Lisburne field could reach 100,000 barrels a day by 1994, said Al Greenstein, a spokesman at Arco's headquarters in Los Angeles. ``Our agreement recognizes that environmental quality and economic reality are both important in North Slope oil and gas decisions,'' said Col. William W. Kakel, Alaska district engineer for the Corps. Officials from the Energy Department helped mediate the dispute in an effort to increase domestic oil output to help make up for the loss of 200,000 barrels a day of Kuwaiti oil following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion. Production had been delayed because of concerns that existing gravel causeways that extended from land into the Beaufort Sea threatened fish that migrate in the coastal waters of northern Alaska. The roadbeds were built for exploration drilling at the Point McIntyre field and the nearby Endicott field. Federal officials said the causeways appeared to raise salt concentrations and the water temperature to levels that could be harmful to the Arctic char, broad whitefish and other fish relied upon by commercial fishermen. Oil industry officials have said years of monitoring programs on the causeways did not indicate any adverse effects to the fish. But they agreed to spend $50 million to clear several water passages in the gravel roadbeds. The agreement calls for 650 additional feet of openings in the Prudhoe Bay West Dock and Endicott gravel causeways. The agreement enables oil companies to move ahead with production and avoids years of dispute and possible litigation, said Brian Davies, a vice president for development at BP. The causeway work could take as long as five years, said BP spokesman Paul Laird. Output at the Lisburne field, which is already in production, is 40,000 barrels a day. Greenstein said the combined output from the Lisburne and Point McIntyre fields will exceed 60,000 barrels a day when output from Point McIntyre begins by late summer in 1992, and could 100,000 barrels a day after a planned expansion in 1993. About 1.3 million barrels a day are produced each day from Prudhoe Bay fields.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Increased in October
DOC.TEXT: Record government spending pumped up the value of new construction projects 1.3 percent in October, despite the smallest outflow for residential housing in 4{ years, the government said Monday. ``The (private) building side is still very weak and still declining,'' said economist Daryl Delano of Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass. ``If not for government spending, we'd be talking about a very bleak picture.'' The Commerce Department said overall residential, non-residential and government spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $434.4 billion, up from $428.9 billion in September. Construction spending was unchanged in August at $441.2 billion. But 27 percent of the October total came from government funds, a 7.7 percent increase from September, to $117.8 billion. That broke a $115.8 billion record set last August. Much of the increase was due to spending on sewer systems, up 15.5 percent; schools, up 5.7 percent, and streets and highways, up 5.5 percent. Spending by the often-volatile government sector had fallen 5.5 percent in September after gaining 7.1 percent the previous month. But private spending continued its recent weakness. Residential construction dropped 0.9 percent to $179.5 billion, its seventh consecutive monthly decline and the lowest since spending totaled $177.4 billion in March 1986. Residential spending was off 2.5 percent in September. At the same time, spending on non-residential construction slid 0.8 percent to $102.0 billion, the smallest amount since $100.0 billion in new projects got under way last December. Overall, spending in October was just 1.2 percent above the $429.3 billion posted in the same month last year. Delano attributed much of the recent weakness in the private sector to the so-called ``credit crunch'' which both Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady have said is causing problems for many businesses. The credit problem is particularly acute in the private, non-residential sector where there ``is a lack of funding for projects, even those projects that make reasonably good business sense,'' Delano said. Some critics contend government officials are being overzealous in interpreting banking regulations in the wake of the savings and loan debacle. Brady has asked regulators not to be ``unrealistically negative'' in evaluating loans and urged bankers ``to keep lending to your good customers.'' Single-family spending fell 2.0 percent to $102.8 billion after a 3.1 percent drop in September despite a 1.0 percent increase, to $18.7 billion, in apartment construction. Non-residential spending slipped 0.8 percent to $102.0 billion following a 1.5 percent decline in September. ``Residential spending has been down for many, many months now,'' Delano said. ``Non-residential just started turning down a couple of months ago. Our forecast for all of the non-residential sectors shows weakness continuing into next year, beyond the middle of next year. It's pretty grim.''

DOC.HEAD: Speaker Foley Enters New Phase: How to Use New Strength
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf to include characterization of leadership elections, picks up 17th graf, ``New lawmakers...''
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: This is a golden time for Speaker Thomas S. Foley. He has led his Democrats from upheaval to unity, has President Bush courting on every issue, and his side will enjoy a big 100-vote majority beginning next month. But what is his mandate? The Washington Democrat became speaker last year after former Speaker Jim Wright resigned in an ethics storm. Foley's soothing, low-key style was good medicine for the institution and built him a huge reservoir of good will. Given the mess he inherited, he wasn't blamed for the slow pace of legislation last year, or the sloppy way things were done this year, and he won praise for what was accomplished in the end. The 102nd Congress, however, will be all his, starting with his uncontested renomination by the Democrats on Monday. ``Speaker Foley came during a difficult time and I think he's established a high level of confidence and trust. I think he has strong bipartisan support and is an excellent speaker.'' said Rep. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla. ``I think the issue is, how does he consolidate the gains he made,'' McCurdy added. In the last Congress, Foley proved a patient negotiator with an extraordinary talent for nurturing consensus. On issues ranging from flag burning, where he outlasted demands for a constitutional amendment, to the budget, where he and the Democrats stonewalled as Bush's tax pledge crumbled, he smartly waited for the consensus to move in his direction, and won. He seems to be utilizing those same skills as he fences with the White House over Bush's Middle East policy. A protege of the late Sen. Henry ``Scoop'' Jackson, Foley clearly understands that even if lawmakers doubt Bush, they can't let Republicans trap them into appearing weak on defense issues. His handling of the issue on behalf of the Democrats could help set the tone for the new Congress. But the next Congress will test not only whether Foley can lead the Democrats through the political mine fields. He'll be expected to put new ideas for the nation's needs before his colleagues and the nation. McCurdy and others say Foley needs to develop legislative initiatives for the House that also will serve the party well in the 1992 presidential election. So far, Foley has enunciated an agenda that only repeats his desire for some of the unfinished items from the last Congress, including campaign reform and civil rights legislation. Democratic leaders also intend to keep pushing the economic ``fairness'' issue they believe served the party well in the closing weeks of the last Congress. Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., a member of the Democratic leadership, expressed confidence Foley will step out in front. The speaker toughened politically, he said, when Foley's initial budget deal with Bush was defeated. ``I think Foley became a better poker player with the help of his Democratic colleagues when they rejected the budget agreement they were dealt and asked for a new hand,'' he said. Foley's position will be stronger also because of changes he can now make in the House leadership structure, which he couldn't make midstream. Murky to the outside world, they are nonetheless important. New lawmakers will be beholden to him for their committee assignments, the new Democratic campaign chief is his pick, and he gets to replace Wright holdovers and appoint a big portion of the party's policy-making committee in the House. Foley's toughest challenge may be to temper his natural tendency to let issues come to him, since there's no way to make sure the most vocal message-carriers represent the party's best interests. The left-wing ``screamers'' and the one-issue Democrats need to let Foley steer a mainstream course, and to ``let Foley be Foley,'' said McCurdy, who promised he and other moderates would make sure they were in Foley's face as often as the others were. No one expects Foley to change stripes, to be anything but his cautious, compromising, intellectual self. The real question is whether he will be expansive, whether he will go beyond sorting through competing suggestions for curing the nation's ills and develop them and push them to fruition. With world and domestic events moving so quickly, he'll start providing answers soon after the new Congress begins on Jan. 3. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Former East German Leader Says He Committed No Wrongdoing
With AM-Germany-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former East German leader Erich Honecker insists he is not guilty of charges that he issued shoot-to-kill orders at the Berlin Wall, his lawyer said Monday. For the third straight day, Soviet officials blocked the arrest of Honecker, who has taken refuge at a Soviet military hospital in the woods south of Berlin. Soviet doctors believe he is seriously ill, an interpreter said. Berlin justice officials issued an arrest warrant Friday, two days before a united Germany held its first free elections in 58 years. They said they based the warrant on new documents recently uncovered that incriminate Honecker. Honecker faces charges that he signed shoot-to-kill orders at the Berlin Wall, the border between former East and West Germany. But German police cannot arrest Honecker without Soviet permission to enter the hospital, which is guarded by armed soldiers. The Soviets have indicated they are holding their former ally on humanitarian grounds. In Moscow, Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin told a news conference, ``Nobody knows what will happen with Honecker and how the situation will be resolved.'' ``The decision to get Mr. Honecker to a Soviet hospital had to do with his state of health and we would like to believe that the German side ... will also be guided first of all by principles of humanism,'' Churkin said. The warrant specifically links Honecker to the deaths of four people killed while trying to flee his repressive regime before it was toppled in last year's peaceful revolution. About 200 people died trying to escape from East Germany during the 28-year existence of the Berlin Wall. Wolfgang Ziegler, one of Honecker's defense lawyers, told the ADN news agency that his client insisted he was not guilty. The agency said Ziegler had lodged a protest against the arrest warrant on grounds that Honecker cannot be punished for alleged crimes committed under East German laws. The East German legal system ceased to exist when the former Communist state acceded to West Germany on Oct. 3 and West German laws took effect. Honecker, 78, was transferred earlier Monday to a cardiology unit at the Soviet military hospital in Beelitz, 20 miles south of Berlin. He took refuge there in April. ADN quoted a Soviet interpreter as saying Red Army doctors considered Honecker's condition ``serious.'' One doctor diagnosed Honecker as having high blood pressure, the agency quoted Igor Molotkin, the interpreter, as saying. Honecker's lawyers maintain that he is too sick to stand trial. German justice officials say they have no way of verifying Honecker's state of health until the Soviets let them into the hospital. An official at the Soviet Embassy in Bonn on Monday refused to comment on a report that talks were under way between German and Soviet officials on handing over Honecker, whose testimony could be potentially damaging to Moscow. Honecker, in coments published in November by The European, a British weekly newspaper, complained that he was brought down from power by ``intriguers.'' Later the same month, he said he was toppled on Oct. 18, 1989, because of a Soviet conspiracy, according to a report published in the Berlin Wochenpost weekly newspaper. The Soviet Union and the other three victorious World War II powers relinquished special rights over the two German states in agreements that restored German sovereignty. But the Oct. 12 German-Soviet agreement on the withdrawal of Red Army forces stationed in eastern Germany assures the Soviets control of their military bases.

DOC.HEAD: Portuguese Surrealist Painter Antonio Dacosta Dies
DOC.TEXT: Painter and art critic Antonio Dacosta, who introduced surrealism to Portugal and became one of the country's leading artists, has died. He was 76. Dacosta died Sunday in a hospital in Paris, where he had lived intermittently since 1947. The cause of death was not given. President Mario Soares on Monday called Dacosta ``a personality without equal in Portuguese culture. A painter of extraordinary resources and a most fine sensibility.'' Born in the Azores island town of Angra do Heroismo in 1914, Dacosta moved to Lisbon at 21 to study art. He was inspired by French and Spanish surrealists, especially the Spanish artist Salvador Dali. Dacosta held the first surrealist exhibition in Portugal in 1940. In 1949, he abandoned painting to work as a journalist and art critic in Paris for Portuguese and Brazilian newspapers. Dacosta returned to painting in 1975. His early works showed a dramatic, fluid use of forms and colors. Later works were more abstract with gentler color use, influenced by the rural landscapes of the Azores. A major retrospective of his work was held to critical acclaim at Lisbon's Calouste Gulbenkian Museum in 1988. Dacosta is survived by his wife, Miriam, and their two children. Funeral plans were not immediately announced.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Congratulates Kohl
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and congratulated him on his election victory, calling it a historic step for his united country, the White House said Monday. ``It is the first election in a unified Germany and underscores the growing importance and partnership of a united Germany in Europe's future,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. He said Bush called Kohl late Sunday afternoon before leaving Washington for a week-long tour to Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina, Chile and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: `Consumer Reports' Asks FDA To Halt Sale
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of Consumer Reports is urging the Food and Drug Administration to halt the sale of milk from cows being treated with a genetically engineered growth hormone. Critics have repeatedly raised questions about possible health risks associated with milk containing the hormone, but the FDA and many others have argued that bovine growth hormone, as it's called, has no effect on human health. The hormone is given to cows to boost milk production. Some critics have argued that it could have a harmful economic effect by boosting milk production at a time when there is no shortage of milk. It has not yet been approved by the FDA. But in 1985 the agency ruled that milk from cows treated with the hormone could be sold.
