Consumers Union, which publishes the magazine, called on the FDA to reopen its investigation of the human safety of the hormone while it pursues its review of the hormone's effects on animal health. ``We see virtually no benefits to the average consumer from the use of this drug,'' Michael K. Hansen, the report's author said. ``Its use is unlikely to result in lower milk prices to consumers. In fact, its use may cost consumers tax dollars that the federal government must spend to buy up dairy surpluses.'' Four companies produce growth hormone: American Cyanamid, Eli Lilly, Monsanto and Upjohn. In August, the FDA released a review of more than 120 studies to support its contention that the hormone is safe for human consumption. A week earlier, an article in the Journal of the American Medical Association also found the hormone to be safe. Yet critics have continued to raise questions. Last week, Jeremy Rifkin, one of the most outspoken critics, sued the National Dairy Board for what he said was illegal promotion of the hormone before it has been approved by the FDA. He also petitioned the agency to ``immediately halt any promotion of this product by FDA officials and to immediately rescind the use of this product in the marketplace until it is approved.'' On Monday, he filed another petition asking the agency to halt sales, recall milk produced by hormone-treated cows and establish a long-term independent research program on the hormone's safety. William Grigg, and FDA spokesman, said the agency has determined that the hormone is not active in humans and occurs normally in milk in amounts comparable to those found in milk from treated cows.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Rule on Searches of Containers Inside Cars
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Monday it will decide whether police who have an owner's permission to search a car must get a court warrant before opening any containers inside the vehicle. The justices agreed to review a Florida Supreme Court ruling that court warrants are needed before police open containers found in the car's interior other than in the trunk. In a 1982 decision, the nation's highest court ruled that police can search even closed containers within a car's trunk any time an officer has ``reasonable cause'' to believe the car contains drugs, weapons or other contraband. No warrant is needed for such searches of containers found in the trunk, the court said in 1982. The justices now must decide, probably by July, whether that ruling applies to consentual searches conducted inside that part of the car where the driver and passengers sit. The Florida court said the 1982 ruling did not apply. The state court's ruling barred prosecutors from using as trial evidence cocaine found by a Miami policeman in a car owned by Enio and Luz Jimeno during a 1989 search. Officer Frank Trujillo became suspicious of the car driven by Enio Jimeno and followed it until it made an illegal turn. Trujillo then stopped the car and asked to search the inside for drugs. Jimeno consented, and Trujillo's search turned up a brown paper bag on the floor on the front passenger side. Trujillo did not ask for permission to open the bag before doing so, and found cocaine inside. A state trial judge granted the Jimenos' request to exclude the cocaine as evidence against them, and the Florida Supreme Court upheld that ruling. Attorney General Robert Butterworth then appealed, contending that police authority to conduct warrantless car searches when given consent is ``just as broad as a search based on warrant or probable cause.'' Lawyers for the Jimenos had urged the justices to reject Butterworth's appeal. The case is Florida vs. Jimeno, 90-622.

DOC.HEAD: California College Loses Supreme Court Appeal
With AM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A California community college accused of unlawful censorship for blocking the on-campus performance of a racially charged play lost a Supreme Court appeal Monday. The justices, without comment, rejected arguments by the college officials that the lawsuit should be killed. The case raises the question of whether college administrators have the same broad power as public high school officials to limit freedom of speech in school-sponsored activities. The California dispute began in June 1986 when Alan DiBona, a drama teacher at San Diego Commmunity College, planned a class production of ``Split Second.'' The play is about a black New York City police officer who fatally shoots a white suspect after the suspect has taunted him with racial slurs and epithets. The officer, following his split-second loss of control, places a knife in the victim's hand to make the shooting look like self-defense. DiBona planned to have the play performed at the Educational Cultural Complex, a branch of the San Diego college. Students auditioning for parts in the play were to receive course credit. Robert Matthews, president of the branch college, and James Hardison, dean of arts and sciences there, opposed the performance. They said community church leaders who learned about the planned performance were upset. The college officials also expressed concern over profane language used in the play, saying it could inflame racial tensions already sparked by a local murder case in which a young black man was accused of shooting two police officers. When DiBona refused to change his plans, the college cancelled his class. He and his students performed ``Split Second'' off campus. None of the students received course credit for the performance, and DiBona was not paid by the college. DiBona and a student, Scott Gundlach, sued Matthews and Hardison for allegedly violating their free-speech rights. A judge threw out the suit. But it was reinstated in July by a state appeals court, which ordered a trial. The appeals court noted that the Supreme Court in 1988 upheld the power of a high school principal to remove two controversial articles from a student newspaper. But college students are adults, the appeals court said, adding, ``Where children are concerned the legitimate role of the government in regulating speech is substantially broader.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Impose Curfews on Black Townships After Weekend Violence
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers and heavily armed police moved into black townships Monday and more than a half-million blacks were under curfew after at least 78 people died in factional fighting over the weekend. The worst violence was in Tokoza outside Johannesburg, where bodies lay in the mud outside burned-out homes. Police Capt. Ida van Zweel said 52 victims had been found there by Monday afternoon. It was one of the most severe cases of township fighting since mid-August, when violence between supporters of the African National Congress and Inkatha Freedom Party broke out in the Johannesburg area. The leader of the South African Communist Party, Joe Slovo, said Monday that if President F.W. de Klerk did not act to stop the violence, talks between the government and ANC could be ruined. He accused government security forces of instigating the unrest to disrupt the talks. ``There's no way we can talk peace if people continue to be killed,'' Slovo said in an interview. The Communist Party, which is allied with the ANC, demanded the resignation of Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok and Defense Minister Magnus Malan. Vlok late Monday declared Tokoza an unrest area and imposed a 9 p.m.-to-4 a.m. curfew. Curfews also were imposed in the nearby townships of Katlehong, Vosloorus and Bekkersdal. Police reported 71 deaths in the Johannesburg area since Sunday night: 52 in Tokoza, eight in Tembisa, six in Katlehong, and five in Sebokeng. Another seven people died in weekend fighting in Natal Province. No new deaths were reported in Vosloorus or Bekkersdal, but clashes occurred in those townships last week. Police and soldiers in armored vehicles were deployed in the townships to enforce the curfews, which affected about 650,000 people. About 1,000 blacks have been killed in factional fighting in Johannesburg townships since August. Thousands more have died in Natal Province, where the battles have raged since 1985. The fighting involves supporters of the Inkatha Freedom Party, who are mostly Zulus, and Xhosas and other blacks who back the ANC. Both groups oppose apartheid but differ on tactics for fighting it. Inkatha favors a more conservative approach than the ANC. Several homes in Tokoza were attacked and burned during the factional battles, their inhabitants hacked to death with knives and clubs. Hundreds of men, women and children fled their homes in terror. ``The Zulus came in the night,'' said one frightened Xhosa, standing in the rain and holding a club. ``They killed our people. We don't know why.'' Both sides blamed the other for starting the fighting. Some residents of Tokoza claimed Zulus were being aided by armed whites, but they gave no evidence. Zulu leaders, meanwhile, said several of their followers had been shot by police for no apparent reason. Police said all but one of the victims were black. All were hacked, shot, or burned to death by having flaming tires thrown around their necks. A white security guard was killed in Katlehong, police said. He was one of the few white people to die in the factional fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Alleges NIMH Discriminates Against Female Researchers
DOC.TEXT: A female psychiatrist alleged Monday that national health officials, criticized in the past for not including more women in government studies, are now discriminating against women researchers. Dr. Margaret Jensvold, a former medical staff fellow at the National Institute of Mental Health, filed a federal lawsuit contending that a male superior harassed her because she was female and fired her in 1989 before she could complete the third year of a fellowship program. The suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Maryland, also alleged that Jensvold was denied opportunities for research and writing provided to male medical fellows and that a male superior tried to destroy her academic career. A spokeswoman for NIMH said officials had not seen the suit and would have no immediate comment. The suit said that when Jensvold worked in the Menstrually Related Mood Disorder Clinic at NIMH, she was the only woman physician in the program set up to study premenstrual syndrome. ``I was never accepted by the male physicians who were in charge of my program,'' Jensvold said in a statement. She said male physicians ``constantly denigrated'' women who had preceded her, saying they did not deserve any credit for work they had done and that they had been pushed out because they could not get along with male colleagues. Earlier this year, a study by the General Accounting Office, Congress' investigative arm, found that the National Institutes of Health has had little success with its four-year effort to include more women in government research of diseases and their treatments. ``NIH and NIMH have recently come under serious criticism for failing to includ women as research subjects,'' Jensvold said. ``Now it is clear that they are also excluding women as researchers. The effect of these two things on women's health is very destructive.'' The lawsuit named as defendant Louis Sullivan, secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services. It seeks to have Jensvold reinstated as a third-year medical fellow and awarded back pay, benefits and other damages of at least $100,000.

DOC.HEAD: High-Tech Equipment On Bush Trip Highlights Brazilian Restrictions ^By BRUCE HANDLER ^Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: As President Bush on Monday was telling South Americans to push for free trade and open up their economies, hundreds of U.S. journalists covered him using equipment that - technically - could have been seized by Brazil's federal police. A special press room set up here by the U.S. Embassy was a glaring contrast to the restrictions, barriers and bureaucracy that inhibit the use of up-to-date conveniences in Brazil and much of South America. American reporters wrote their Bush stories on lightweight lap-top computers. They filed them on portable fax machines or over high-speed data channels, using special telephone lines connected directly to the United States. American broadcast networks, thanks to a huge, imported dish antenna set up in the hotel parking lot, beamed reports directly to U.S. satellites. Brazil, obviously, made a special exception for the Washington press. But under normal circumstances here, computers and faxes and high-speed communications equipment are on a list of totally prohibited imports. The idea behind the law was to prevent ``foreign imperialists'' from controlling Brazil's sophisticated technology. Many other South American countries have similar restrictions to protect their high-tech industries. Brazil, it is true, today has a $6 billion-a-year market in computers and related equipment. And Brazilians who a decade ago knew nothing about this field now in fact turn out sophisticated machinery. But Brazilian-made computer components always seem to be a step behind the ``state of the art'' in the United States, Japan and Europe. And Brazilian high-tech equipment costs an outrageous fortune. A year ago a Brazilian fax cost $8,000. Now you might find one on special for $1,500, but most remain in the $2,500-$3,000 range. In the United States they cost less than $500. A 14-inch color monitor for a home computer, made in Brazil and thus for sale legally, costs $2,800. The U.S. price is $650. Brazil's top-of-the-line laser printer costs $20,000. A U.S. model with the same features sells for $3,500. ---= President Bush's team of senior advisers all passed up the opportunity to travel with him on his five-nation South American trip. So did his wife, Barbara, complaining of a sinus infection aggravated b flying around on planes. Secretary of State James A. Baker III stayed behind to testify before Congress on the Persian Gulf crisis. John Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security adviser, also remained at home and sent deputies in their place. There was no official explanation for the absence of Sununu and Scowcroft. One senior official, though, suggested that some of Bush's advisers are becoming exhausted by his near non-stop travel, which in recent days has included treks through Europe, the Middle East and Mexico. ---= Tropical Brazil is not known as great wine country. The little wine that it produces is mostly grown and drunk by ethnic Italians in southern Brazil. Other wines are exported to Europe for mixture in popular, low-priced brands there. Bush avoided the Brazilian grape when he threw a luncheon for business leaders. Instead, he reached 4,300 miles back to Virginia to serve wines from Meredyth Vineyards: a Seyval Blanc 89 and Vallard Noir 85. The rest of the menu: shrimp and avocado en beurre blanc, supreme of chicken with cheese and herbs, almond and raisin rice, green beans, lemon and rum mousse.

DOC.HEAD: Realtor Survey Finds Housing More Affordable
DOC.TEXT: The typical American family's ability to buy an existing home increased in October to its highest level in more than two years, a real estate trade group said Monday. But despite falling home prices, lower mortgage interest rates and rising family incomes, existing home sales fell 4.7 percent in October, according the National Association of Realtors. ``The missing link is consumer confidence - the housing affordability index indicates that conditions are better than they've been in over two years,'' said Realtors president Harley E. Rouda. The Realtors group said its housing affordability index rose to 113.4 in October from 110.8 the previous month. That meant a family with a median income of $35,353 had 113.4 percent of the income needed to qualify for conventional financing to buy a median-priced home costing $92,800. The median is the point at which half of the families earned more and half earned less, and half of the homes cost more and half less. The median income rose $114 in October while the median price fell $1,600. The monthly mortgage payment for the median-priced home decreased $14 to $649. The index was at its highest point since it reached 113.5 in September 1988. Buying conditions varied according to region, said John A. Tuccillo, the Realtors' chief economist. In the Northeast and the West, for instance, the typical family lacked the income necessary to buy the median-priced home. In the Northeast, a family earning the median income of $41,376 had 90.1 percent of the income needed to buy a median-priced home costing $136,200. In the West, a family with a median income of $37,631 had 80.8 percent of the income needed to buy a median-priced home costing $140,600. Families generally had more income than necessary to buy homes in the Midwest and South where housing typically is lower-priced. In the Midwest, a family earning $36,127 had 147.9 percent of the income needed to buy a $72,100 home, while a family living in the South earning $31,795 had 112.7 percent of the income needed to buy an $83,400 home. Also affecting the affordability index was a drop in the interest rate from 10 percent in September to 9.96 percent in October. The rate is a composite of closing rates for both fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages on existing homes as reported by the Federal Housing Finance Board. When the index measures 100, the median family income equals exactly the amount needed to purchase a median-priced home, using conventional financing and making a 20 percent down payment.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Burt Lancaster in Serious Condition Following Stroke
DOC.TEXT: Actor Burt Lancaster remained hospitalized Monday for a stroke and his agent said he was in good spirits. The 77-year-old film star was in serious condition at Los Alamitos Medical Center, said agent Ben Benjamin. Lancaster has some weakness on his right side and some slight difficulty speaking. ``But he's a fighter, as his daughter (Joanna Mari) says, and the family has every good hope that he's going to recover,'' Benjamin said. Doctors were expected to submit a full report on Lancaster's condition on Tuesday or Wednesday, said Benjamin. Lancaster starred in more than 70 motion pictures and won an Academy Award in 1960 for his portrayal of an evangelist in ``Elmer Gantry.'' More recently he appeared in the film ``Field of Dreams.'' He sued Columbia Pictures in 1988 after the studio, citing health insurance problems, replaced him with Gregory Peck in the film ``The Old Gringo.'' Lancaster was visiting a friend at the John Douglas French Center for Alzheimer's Disease when he collapsed in a chair Friday and was taken to the hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Military Insurection Is Fourth Since 1987
With AM-Argentina, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The military rebellion that erupted Monday is the fourth since 1987 staged by dissident soldiers. The others were: -In April 1987, about 130 officers and non-commissioned officers led by former Lt. Col. Aldo Rico, a commando and Falklands veteran, holed up at an infantry school in suburban Buenos Aires. Rico sought amnesty for officers accused of human rights abuse during the 1976-83 military regime. President Raul Alfonsin secured Rico's surrender, and later pushed a law through congress that absolved most officers below the rank of general of rights violations charges. Rico was placed under house arrest. There were no deaths or serious injuries in the uprising. -In January 1988, Rico fled house arrest and flew to an infantry garrison about 440 miles north of Buenos Aires. Joined by about 200 supporters, he accused the government of failing to fully meet demands made during his first rebellion. Loyal forces surrounded the garrison and Rico surrendered. He was imprisoned and cashiered. Several army generals retired and military pay was increased. In that uprising, two loyalist soldiers were wounded when their truck ran over a mine. -In December 1988, Col. Mohamed Ali Seineldin, also a commando and Falklands veteran, took over an army arsenal in Buenos Aires, demanding that the government recognize the army's role in ending leftist terrorism and fighting the Falklands war. Surrounded by loyalist forces, Seineldin and his men surrendered. One civilian was killed and several wounded when fired on during a demonstration outside the occupied arsenal. President Carlos Menem, who took office on July 8, 1989, pardoned Seineldin and other uprising participants. Seineldin was forced to retire. He currently is serving a 60-day jail sentence, ordered after he wrote a letter to Menem, outside the chain of command, criticizing army leaders for failing to live up to promises made following previous rebellions. Rico, released from prison, began forming a right-wing nationalist political organization and said he planned to seek public office.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Spar On Ousting Iraq From Kuwait, Iraq Says Palestine Comes First
LaserPhoto DHR1
DOC.TEXT: As the U.S. defense secretary sparred Monday with the chairman of the Senate Armed Service Committee over how best to drive Iraq from Kuwait, Iraq insisted a Palestinian homeland was the issue to be decided first. President Bush, meanwhile, departed from a prepared text to assail Saddam Hussein. ``I realize the sacrifces that Saddam (Hussein's) brutality has caused this nation,'' Bush told lawmakers in Brazil on Monday. He estimated high oil prices resulting from the Persian Gulf crisis are costing Brazil $5 billion annually - a figure local experts said seemed excessive. Bush, after winning U.N. authorization last week for a military strike against Iraq unless it quits Kuwait by Jan. 15, offered to send his secretary of state to Baghdad to negotiate. Iraq agreed to talk. But Monday, Iraq again insisted the Palestinian people must have a homeland in the West Bank and Gaza, with Jerusalem as its capital, before any other Middle East peace questions can be dealt with. ``The first question is Palestine,'' Iraqi delegate Adnan Malik told the U.N. General Assembly. ``Palestine comes first, Palestine comes second and Palestine comes third.'' The United States has rejected any linkage of the Palestine issue to Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. Israel has occupied the West Bank and Gaza Strip since seizing control of the territories in the 1967 Middle East war. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told the Senate committee on Monday the administration was pessimistic about economic sanctions bringing an end to Iraq's 4-month-old occupation of Kuwait. ``Given the nature of the regime, given Saddam Hussein's brutality to his own people, his very tight control of that society, his ability to allocate resources for the military, their ability to produce their own food ... he can ride them out,'' Cheney said. ``It is far better for us to deal with him now ... than it will be for us to deal with him five or 10 years from now, when ... Saddam has become an even better armed and more threatening regional superpower than he is at present,'' the defense secretary said. He said he saw no indication Saddam was willing to settle the dispute. Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., questioned the Bush administration's attitude toward economic sanctions. ``If we have a war, we're never going to know whether they would have worked, would we?'' he asked Cheney. ``That's the major point here. The way you find out if sanctions are going to work is to give them enough time to work,'' Nunn said. In Saudi Arabia, some U.S. forces reportedly were on heightened alert. Some troops donned gas masks and protective gloves against a possible chemical weapons strike at the same time Iraq test-fired missiles on Sunday, a correspondent with the NBC Radio network said. The heightened alert reportedly went into effect early Thursday and was the highest alert since Iraq seized Kuwait on Aug. 2. But it was not a war alert, U.S. military officers said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Iraq test-fired Soviet-type Scud missiles - which could be used to carry chemical weapons - on Sunday, the U.S. military said. The military said the flight path was away from the U.S.-led multinational force in eastern Saudi Arabia. A jetliner carrying boxing great Muhammad Ali and some former American and Canadian hostages returned to the Jordanian capital Monday shortly after taking off for New York. The plane turned around because of minor technical problems but resumed its flight about seven hours later, officials said. Also Monday, the British Foreign Office reported Iraq has detained four more British men who had been in hiding in Kuwait. The Foreign Office said there were 440 Britons hiding in Kuwait and an estimated 740 Britons in Iraq. Saddam has prevented many foreigners from leaving both countries and says he will use detained Westerners as ``human shields'' against attack from the multinational force massed in the gulf. He has been freeing the hostages affew at a time. In other developments: -Oil industry sources said war in the gulf would cause production engineers to flee, causing Saudi oil production to plummet by as much as 2 million barrels a day. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the United States would make up the shortfall from its strategic petroleum reserves. Analysts have said the price of crude oil, which has fluctuated widely since Iraq seized Kuwait, could top $65 a barrel in the event of war. -A small fire bomb exploded and another device was dismantled Monday on Dutch rail lines used to transport U.S. military equipment bound for the gulf, police said. Dutch opponents of the military buildup in the gulf reportedly claimed responsibility. The explosion set fire to trackside electric installations outside Boxtel, the Netherlands, causing delays in service, police said. No one was injured, and there were no U.S. military trains in the area at the time. Explosives experts later found a similar device at Boxtel rail station, again disrupting rail service.

DOC.HEAD: Ricks: America Is Headed For Brain Drain
DOC.TEXT: An American brain drain is in the making because of a poor atmosphere for creative technology and an aggressive engineer recruiting program by foreign companies, a NASA advisory committee was told Monday. ``Our members are asking themselves what future is there for the American aerospace worker,'' Leonard Ricks testified. ``Unfortunately, many of our colleagues are concluding that there is no future and are leaving.'' He spoke at the sixth and last hearing of the Advisory Committee on the Future of the U.S. Space Program, which is preparing to issue a final report on Dec. 17. The committee was set up in July by NASA administrator Richard Truly. Ricks, executive director for the Council of Engineers and Scientists Organizations, said American engineering journals now contain ads ``by foreign countries who will steal American technology by importing its creator.'' He said public policy has focused on the management of the nation's space program but not the creators of technology and said focus on NASA's problems has created a witchhunt atmosphere. ``Today there is a feeding frenzy over many of the technical difficulties that naturally occur in any complex scientific endeavor,'' he said. ``Both the print and electronic media have appeared jubilant over flaws in the Hubble (Space Telescope) mirror, fuel leaks and other technical problems.'' That, in turn, has produced an enormous morale problem in the aerospace workforce, said Ricks, whose organization represents more than 100,000 engineers. ``We are increasingly made to feel embarrassed by public policy makers who see our programs as wasting money that could be spent in meeting social needs. We are humiliated by the media's presentation of our products as inferior and flawed.'' America's space program, he said, is best characterized by the word instability and cannot be otherwise without long-term commitment. ``We need to think about the workforce of tomorrow,'' Ricks said. ``Are we to condemn our young people to a future of employment in fast food chains? If so, they do not need an education to operate the foreign made computers that show the pictures of burgers, fries and milkshakes, eliminating the need for employees who read.''

DOC.HEAD: Global Trade Talks Open With Protests and Tough Talk
LaserPhoto BRU2
DOC.TEXT: Negotiations to complete an unprecedented global free trade pact opened in turmoil on Monday. Delegates inside the hall clashed on farm issues, while police outside battled angry demonstrators. Almost 30,000 farmers marched through the cobblestoned streets of this European capital to protest a U.S.-backed proposal aimed at trimming billions of dollars in trade-distorting agricultural subsidies. At one point, police used tear gas and water cannon when demonstrators tried to storm the European Parliament building. Organizers hoped the protest would send a blunt message to delegates who have gathered for the concluding session of a four-year effort to overhaul the world trading system. The talks are known as the Uruguay Round for the nation where they began in 1986. They involve 107 member nations in an effort to rewrite the constitution of world trade, a document known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT. The United States, hoping to reduce trade deficits still running at close to $100 billion, is aggressively pushing a package of proposals aimed at expanding export opportunities for American farmers and businesses. In addition to trimming farm subsidies, the U.S. agenda included efforts to crack down on the piracy of U.S. products, estimated to cost American businesses $60 billion annually, and to expand GATT rules to cover the fast-growing service industries, such as banking and insurance. But officials of the 12-nation European Community, noting the number of protesters, maintained that adoption of the U.S. farm proposal would represent political suicide. They insisted that they had no latitude to go beyond an offer for a 30 percent cut in internal farm supports. ``The only flexibility I have is in explaining in detail the impact which the reduction in internal supports will have,'' said Ray MacSharry, the European Community's agriculture chief. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills told delegates in an opening speech that the EC proposal was totally inadequate. The United States is demanding 90 percent cuts in export subsidies, used as incentives to promote overseas sales, and 75 percent reductions in internal supports and market barriers. ``Only one thing stands between us and the triggering of a worldwide economic renaissance - the stalemate over agriculture,'' she said. The United States believes that without a commitment to reduce farm subsidies, Third World countries will walk away from the negotiations, dooming any chances to get new trade rules to cover service industries and copyright theft. Negotiators went into closed-door sessions late Monday on the farm issue, but with time running short there was growing concern that the talks could well end in failure. The only hopeful sign on Monday came in negotiations over efforts to draft rules covering financial services, such as banking. Canada, Japan, Sweden and Switzerland introduced a proposal that U.S. negotiators said could represent a breakthrough in this area. However, officials of Third World nations did not rush to embrace the measure. Their support is considered crucial since banks from America and other devoped countries see the Third World as the primary area for expansion opportunities. Many delegates from Third World countries complained that their needs were being ignored by the wealthy nations. They maintained that no overall GATT agreement was possible without an end to the costly farm subsidy battle, which steals potential markets from their farmers. ``When I talk about agriculture, I am talking about human decency itself,'' said Amaret Sila-on, minister of commerce for Thailand. ``I am talking about 30 million human beings in my country whose lives have been in abject poverty, generation after generation, significantly as a result of agricultural practices and polices of some countries in the developed world.'' Pakistani Commerce Minister Malik Muhammad Naaem Khan said his country was disappointed not only by the lack of movement in agriculture but also by a failure to reach agreement to lower barriers in textile trade, another item high on the agenda of Third World nations. ``We have borne the burden of these restraints,'' he said. ``The Uruguay Round is our hope.'' But farmers, particularly the 10 million in the European Community, viewed the trade talks as a threat to their livelihoods. ``We are all small farmers. We would have to leave the land,'' said Irish farmer Michael Murphy, one of those taking part in the demonstrations.

DOC.HEAD: Issues to be Resolved at GATT Talks
With AM-Trade Talks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of the most contentious issues to be resolved at the trade talks in Brussels: - Agriculture: The linchpin of the talks. Declared aim: ``Substantial progressive reductions in agricultural support and protection over a sustained period of time.'' The United States wants cuts of 75 percent in internal supports and import barriers and 90 percent in export subsidies over ten years. The 12-nation European Community has offered a 30 percent cut in internal supports by 1995. No negotiating text has been sent to Brussels. - Services: Aim is to set up a General Agreement on Trade in Services, to liberalize trade in the $680 billion sector just as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has opened markets in goods. The United States wants a new agreement to allow the continuation of bilateral accords. Most others say benefits granted to one country must apply to all countries. The negotiating text is littered with brackets, and an annex on financial services is left blank. - Market Access: Aim is to reduce overall import tariffs by at least one- third. Many countries have been slow in making offers, leading to U.S. threats to withdraw some cuts it has proposed. Washington offered cuts averaging 43 percent, leaving high tariffs on textiles and other sensitive products. The EC proposed flat-rate cuts, excluding agricultural products. The text is awaiting the outcome of bilateral talks. Many negotiators say the issue is as difficult as agriculture and services. - Anti-dumping: Aim is to revise the existing GATT anti-dumping code, which authorizes duties against ``dumping'' goods on world markets at artificially low prices. Japan and Southeast Asian countries want tighter restrictions to prevent the West from using such duties merely to protect inefficient industries. The West wants new measures against the evasion of duties. There is no agreed negotiating text. - Trade Related Investment Measures: Aim is to draw up rules on measures that governments apply to investors such as the insistence on use of local materials. The United States considers that all such measures distort trade and should be controlled or banned. The Third World says they are part of national development policies and should not be regulated by GATT. There is no agreed negotiating text. - Subsidies: Aim is to draw up rules governing both state aids to industry and measures to counter exports subsidized in this manner. Washington wants tough rules against subsidies. Countries such as Canada and Southeast Asian nations say there should be more restrictions on counterveiling duties - 90 percent of which are imposed by the United States. The chairman of the group has drafted a text but the it has not been officially accepted. - Trade Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights: Aim is to agree on new rules on copyright, trademarks, patents etc. There are divisions among industrialized nations on patent standards. Talks also are marked by a North-South split on whether pharmaceutical products should be exempt from patent rules to enable continued cheap access for the Third World. There is no agreement on how any new rules should be enforced. - Textiles: Aim is to phase out the 16-year-old international Multi-Fiber Arrangement - which restricts exports through bilateral agreements - and bring it within GATT rules. There are differences between Third World exporters, which want swift liberalization, and industrialized countries with their own textile industries. Outstanding issues include the scope of products to be covered, the length of any phaseout, and whether or not to implement safeguard measures against a sudden surge of imports during the transition.

DOC.HEAD: New York, California Legislators Face Unpopular Budget Cuts
DOC.TEXT: New York and California legislators went back to work Monday each facing $1 billion in politically unpopular spending cuts. New York's Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo proposed the cuts to avoid a projected $1 billion budget deficit for the fiscal year ending March 31. California Gov. George Deukmejian, a Republican leaving office in January, says his cuts would allow the nation's largest state to finish its fiscal year June 30 with a balanced budget or just a small deficit. Cuomo has recommended state worker layoffs, mandatory and unpaid employee furloughs and cuts in state spending on education and health care. But he proposed no new taxes and has said that this deficit, unlike ones in the past, would not be wiped out by raiding reserve funds and borrowing. It's the third consecutive year of budget deficits in New York and next year appears no better. State Comptroller Edward Regan has predicted a potential $3 billion deficit for the new fiscal year. Cuomo has said that cutting back spending was the only way to solve New York's persistent fiscal problems. ``I frankly don't believe there are a whole lot of other alternatives,'' Cuomo has said. ``There is no painless way out of this recession.'' Legislative leaders had been indicating they might be willing to leave Cuomo's proposals largely intact. But as rank-and-file legislators returned Monday, there were rumblings that negotiations had stalled over the weekend. ``Let's put it this way - we're not at impasse,'' said Geoffrey Taylor, spokesman for Democratic Assembly Speaker Mel Miller. Lawmakers, who recessed in midsummer, were meeting privately Monday and a vote was not expected until Tuesday, at the earliest. In California, Deukmejian's plan would cut $600 million in public school funding and $200 million from an income tax credit for renters, as well as freeze state hiring and purchases in a $75 billion budget. Deukmejian says his budget cuts would give California a cushion against worsening tax revenues. Deukmejian said he would like California legislators to approve his plan before he leaves office in January. Many legislators, particularly majority Democrats, would rather wait until Republican Gov.-elect Pete Wilson takes office Jan. 7. New York and California have suffered sharp declines in tax revenues and Cuomo has blamed his state's problems on a struggling national economy. California had a $1.3 billion reserve that Deukmejian expects to be depleted by the end of the budget year. New York has no such reserve and the Cuomo administration has been trying to slow down spending for months.

DOC.HEAD: Small Farmers Leave Land to Protest Trade Proposals
With AM-Trade Talks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Don Vig left his land to the North Dakotan frost, and Tom Britbach's nephews are tending his cattle in Montana. On Monday, the two joined about 30,000 fellow farmers from around the world in protest. Small-farm owners say a U.S.-backed proposal under consideration at trade talks here - aimed at trimming billions of dollars in agricultural subsidies - could cost them their livelihood. The American farmers said they found that European and Asian family farmers have the same fears they do. They worry that small farms will disappear, leaving only big agriculture conglomerates concerned with the bottom line. ``We will not sacrifice the lives and livelihoods of Japanese farmers for the grain traders and other multinational corporations,'' said Mitsugu Horiuchi, chairman of the Zenchu farm lobby, which represents 5 million Japanese small-family farmers. ``Even if we are an ocean apart, we share the same values,'' said Vig, 39, who grows wheat and barley on his 1,400-acre farm in Valley City, N.D. ``We are all fighting for a fair return on our costs.'' Vig says he cannot make enough of a profit to replace his aging equipment. Britbach's farm in Circle, Mont., was tended by his father, and his father before him. But he says he wonders if family farmers have a chance. ``The big companies will eventually have absolute control,'' said Britbach, 62. About 400,000 American rural families gave up farming between 1985 and 1989 alone, said Randolph Nodland, president of the National Family Farm Coalition. Proponents of industrial agriculture say that bigger farm operations are more efficient and competitive in global markets. Farm issues, including subsidies, are the main point of contention at the talks in Brussels. The United States and the 12-nation European Community are at odds over the question. But Vig said he found common ground among farmers when he visited farms in the Netherlands, France, Czechoslovakia, Germany and Poland in the last two weeks. The European Community is preparing programs to help the small family farmer survive subsidy cuts and other changes. The American small farmer is still largely unprotected, the National Family Farm Coalition says. ``Some family farmers think they are so key to the American spirit that Americans would never let them disappear,'' said coalition spokesman Brian Ahlberg. But Vig and Britbach say they're not sure that's the case.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Cautious on Rebel Leader in Chad
DOC.TEXT: The State Department reacted cautiously Monday to the overthrow of the Chadian government by a rebel leader U.S. officials say is supplied by Libya. ``The embassy is instructed to conduct normal contacts and monitor the situation closely to determine whether a new regime has effective control over the country,'' department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. She said that U.S. Ambassador Richard Bogosian would met with rebel leader Idriss Deby to find out what his policies are and discuss future U.S.-Chadian relations. ``It appears that the forces of Mr. Deby are in effective control'' of the Chadian capital of N'Djamena, she said. Asked if the United States would recognize the Deby government, she responded: ``The issue of recognition is de-emphasized'' until after a thorough diplomatic review. Tutwiler repeated the U.S. position that Deby, 38, a former military aide to ousted President Hissene Habre was funded by Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. ``I can tell you that the United States stands by the statement of last week,'' she said. The department said then that Deby's forces ``are armed and supplied by Libya.'' Officials said then that Deby's attacks on Habre ``represent the latest example of Libya's ongoing efforts to destabilize legitimate governments.'' Deby has promised to rule democratically. One of his first acts in power was to free some 400 Libyan prisoners in Chad. Libya fought a series of wars with Habre's government before being driven off Chadian territory in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Wins Elections; Must Form Coalition, Tackle Vast Problems
LaserPhotosBON3,7,11
DOC.TEXT: One day after triumphing in all-German elections, Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Monday began talks with coalition allies on forming a new government and prepared to tackle enormous problems facing the new Germany. His center-right coalition swept to victory in Sunday's parliamentary balloting, the first in a united Germany since 1932, but Kohl had little time to bask in the glory. On Monday, the chancellor began talks with his Christian Democratic Union's current governing partners - their Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union, and the centrist Free Democrats. He was hit by an ultimatum from the Free Democrats, which made more gains in the elections than any other party. They said they would re-enter the coalition only if Kohl agreed that companies in former East Germany should pay lower taxes than those in former West Germany. ``No low-tax area, no vote for the chancellor,'' said Otto Lambsdorff, chairman of the Free Democrats, arguing that would be an important move toward encouraging badly needed investment in eastern Germany. Kohl has said he opposes such a move, contending it is unnecessary. On Monday, he refused to discuss the issue in public and suggested his coalition partners do the same. ``I am of the old school that believes in talking first and going public later,'' Kohl said. He also said he would ``not be put under time pressure by anyone'' in forming a new Cabinet. He said he couldn't promise the coalition negotiations would be concluded before Christmas. Kohl's day began with an announcement from Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann, who said he was quitting the Cabinet amid what German television claimed was growing criticism over his handling of the economy. Haussmann was a major force in putting together the economic and monetary union of West and East Germany in July, a crucial step toward full unification on Oct. 3. He gave no reason for quitting. Later, the head of Germany's poerful central bank slammed Kohl's plans to borrow $100 billion next year to finance unification. In an interview with Stern magazine, Karl Otto Poehl said the proposed sum was ``too high'' and demanded instead greater spending cuts. Later, Kohl's Christian Democrats met to discuss coalition negotiations and the vast problems the new government must tackle. At a press conference, Kohl counted off some of those issues. He said ``important decisions'' needed to be made on ways to slash government spending and raise further revenues to rebuild eastern Germany. The chancellor has insisted he will not increase taxes to come up with extra revenues for the massive reconstruction job, but he has not disclosed just where the money will come from. Kohl could run up against opposition from his coalition partners over such issues. The chancellor also said his government faces the huge task of cleaning up former East Germany, which has severe pollution problems. ``The legacy'' of East Germany's deposed Communist government ``is especially grave in this area,'' Kohl said. Germany will also have to take on new global responsibilities that befit what is seen as its growing political and economic stature on the world stage, Kohl said. But he indicated Germany will not likely be able to quickly make the constitutional changes necessary to allow the deployment of German troops in the Persian Gulf or elsewhere outside NATO areas. ``We will discuss this within the coalition and with the (opposition) Social Democrats,'' he said. Many Social Democrats oppose constitutional changes. Kohl came under sharp international criticism in August when he declined to send German troops to the gulf. But under Germany's constitution, German troops cannot be deployed in non-NATO areas. Kohl has since said he favors the appropriate constitutional amendment. The big losers in Sunday's elections were the Social Democrats - the main opposition party - and the Greens. Both leftist parties had criticized Kohl's swift pace of unification and accused his Christian Democrats of underplaying the cost of bringing the east up to the standard of the west. The Social Democrats gained 13 parliamentary seats, finishing with 239. Western Germany's Greens, Europe's most-established ecology movement, were voted out of Parliament. Their sister branch in former East Germany snared only eight seats. Kohl's Christiahristian Social Union alliance increased its strength from 305 to 313 seats in the 656-member n Democrat and CParliament. However, they failed to attain the absolute majority that would have allowed them to govern without the Free Democrats, which increased their seats in Parliament from 57 to 79.

DOC.HEAD: Consumers Scaling Back Borrowing
DOC.TEXT: Consumers continued to pay their bills in the July-September quarter but were scaling back borrowing as the economy headed into what many analysts say is a recession, a banking group said Monday. The percentage of consumer loans 30 or more days delinquent was a seasonally adjusted 2.56 percenc U.S., will be chairman of North American Chemical. Former employees of Kerr-McGee Chemical will transfer to North American Chemical, Harris said. Harris and Associates is a buyout group that specializes in the chemicals and related process industries. It formed the North American Salt Co. earlier this year, combining acquisitions in the Midwest and Canada to form the nation's third-largest salt company. Kerr-McGee Corp., meanwhile, said earlier it was completing its withdrawal from the domestic offshore contract drilling business by agreeing to sell its fleet to Noble Drilling Corp. of Houston for $75 million. Included are 12 rigs, buildings and real estate.

DOC.HEAD: Greens Show Despair After Big Election Loss
With AM-Germany-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kerin Trepke began working for the Greens seven years ago, eager to assist a party that championed the environment and the underprivileged. She didn't know her destiny was the unemployment line. The Greens, which have brought together ecologists, women's rights activists, peace activists and others under one banner, will nearly vanish from the federal legislature as a result of Sunday's elections. They will continue to exist as a political party and lobby group, but with far less clout. On Monday, the party's headquarters was full of despair. Leaders worried about the party's political future, and hundreds of staff workers worried about their jobs. ``I guess all of us who work here will be seeing each other at the unemployment office,''said Ms. Trepke. ``Unfortunately, having worked for the Greens isn't exactly the best basis from which to launch a job hunt.'' The Greens' election losses turned years of politicking into concern that the party's days might be numbered. They still hold seats in some state parliaments and city councils, but far below the numbers held before the all-German balloting. The Greens' pioneering West German branch, which astonished the world by winning parliamentary seats seven years ago, was voted out of office on Sunday. The party was rescued from parliamentary obliteration by a coalition consisting of their East German branch and a group of activists who helped topple East Germany's Communist government last fall. Still, the Greens were reduced from 48 deputies in the federal parliament to only eight. Their losses resulted from an often shrill opposition to Chancellor Helmut Kohl's unification plans, and mainstream parties' success in encroaching on Greens political turf with promises to clean up the environment. ``Green arguments simply found no interest among the voters because of the German euphoria kindled by Kohl,'' said party spokeswoman Renate Dumas. In addition, deep ideological divisions within the party made the Greens even more vulnerable. On Monday, party leaders surveyed the scene and decided they should craft a new ``political concept'' at a congress early next year, said spokesman Christian Stroebele. ``We have been given something very painful to think about,'' he said. Ms. Trepke, a 46-year-old single mother of two and Greens researcher on women's rights issues, said she feared years of work would go down the drain because of the election results. ``This is a catastrophe, just horrible,'' she said. ``Policies on minorities, on women's rights, everything that we've done here could all fall flat.'' A throng of party workers held an emergency meeting at Greens headquarters to discuss their future. The current Greens lawmakers have a support staff of 266, and most will probably soon be out of work, Ms. Trepke said. The Greens' spacious offices will be replaced by smaller quarters for the new lawmakers from eastern Germany, she said. ``It's all over for us,'' Ms. Trepke said. ``We assume the new group will bring their own people.'' Wolfram Grueber, a 39-year-old Greens specialist on the homeless, said he had no idea what he would do if he lost his job. ``My work has been like a never-ending road race, and I had little time to consider what I would do instead,'' he said. He said he wasn't optimistic about finding a job with another political group. ``We've made ourselves unloved to the established parties. But that's all right. That was our function.''

DOC.HEAD: Interior Secretary's Son Formally Charged
DOC.TEXT: The son of Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan was formally charged Monday with raping a woman who lived in the same apartment building as he and his parents, authorities said. Robert Jeffrey Lujan, 28, was indicted on one count each of burglary, rape, sodomy and use of a firearm during the commission of a crime, according to Commonwealth's Attorney John Kloch. If convicted, Lujan, who lived with his parents, could face a maximum of three life prison terms, plus two years, in prison. Lujan has been held without bail in the city jail, after a judge said he posed ``an unreasonable danger'' to the community. During a court hearing, an Alexandria woman testified that the younger Lujan broke into her apartment, spoke with her for two hours, then led her up five flights of stairs and back to her apartment before forcing her to have sex with him early on the morning of Nov. 11. Lujan's attorney, Robert Powell, said during the hearing that his client spent several hours in the woman's apartment, but maintained he was invited and that sexual relations were by mutual consent. Robert Lujan was arrested four days after the alleged incident. The Interior Secretary said after the arrest that his son had a severe drinking problem.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Cite Overpackaged Holiday Products
DOC.TEXT: Holiday giftgivers should avoid buying toys, cosmetics and ornaments that come wrapped in excessive plastic and cardboard, an environmental coalition said Monday. The third set of ``Wastemaker'' awards handed out by Rep. Frank Pallone Jr., D-N.J., and the Wastewatch coalition of environmental groups was meant to encourage shoppers to think environmentally. ``As with all Wastemaker products, it is the consumer and the taxpayer who pay the price,'' Pallone said. He said special packaging costs more at purchase time and increases taxes for solid waste disposal. U.S. Public Interest Research Group and Clean Water Action joined Pallone and Environmental Action at a news conference to cite nine products that should be avoided. The products, purchased in the last three weeks at Washington area stores, include: - Tiny model cars called ``Matchbox Super Color Changers'' made by a New Jersey toymaker. According to Wastewatch, they are packaged in form-fitting plastic, glued to a cardboard display card accompanied by a small sponge and disposable plastic tub for color changes. ``The product that's been cited is not in the line and hasn't been for the last year,'' said Michele Litzky, spokeswoman for Matchbox Toys USA Ltd., of Moonachie, N.J. - A trophy figure and a scorecard for the popular Nintendo video game. The accessory was cited for an oversized cardboard package and plastic window. ``It's a little surprising they selected a product that hasn't been sold since 1988,'' said Wayne Charness, vice president of Hasbro, Inc., in Pawtucket, R.I. He said 90 percent of Hasbro's packaging is recycled fiber and the company has been increasing its use of recycled materials. - Sears, Roebuck and Co.'s four trumpet-shaped Christmas ornaments enclosed in a heavy plastic tray, cardboard box and clear plastic lid. Wastewatch said Sears offered a round tree ornament packaged in environmentally preferable recyclable cardboard. ``Our first concern is that the product is packaged so that when the customer opens it at home, the product is not broken, dented, bent or scratched,'' said Gordon Jones, a spokesman for the Chicago retailer. However, he said the company was working with suppliers to develop environmentally sound packages and had eliminated plastic foam from many of its holiday light sets. - A Drakkar Noir cosmetics gift set, a product of Cosmair Inc. Two small bottles are encased in a heavy cardboard box with plastic inserts. Cecilia Noguera, a spokeswoman for Cosmair's fragrance division in New York City, declined to comment. Other products cited were Saranac football gloves made by the Saranac Glove Co. in Green Bay, Wis.; Smooshees Smugglers hair accessories from Fisher Price in East Aurora, N.Y.; Holiday Enchantment cassette tape set from Moose Records, Tapes and CDs in San Francisco; Calvin Klein ``Obsession'' gift set from Calvin Klein Cosmetics Corp. in New York City; and Carlton Cards wrap and trim ensemble from American Greetings Corp. of Cleveland.

DOC.HEAD: Music World Mourns Death of Composer Aaron Copland at 90
LaserPhotos NY10,11
With AM-Copland-List
DOC.TEXT: The music world Monday mourned the death of composer Aaron Copland, the son of immigrants whose genius earned him the title ``Dean of American Music.'' Copland died Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown of respiratory failure brought on by pneumonia. He was 90. He had recently suffered two strokes. ``He created the American sound in symphonic music,'' said composer William Schuman. ``Copland believed in the validity of American music, that we were not inferior to our European cousins,'' Schuman said. ``He wrote music only an American could have written.'' Copland was being cremated and the funeral service was private, said his attorney, Ellis Freedman. A public musical tribute is planned, he said. Copland was known for his plain-spoken compositions such as ``Appalachian Spring,'' ``Rodeo,'' and ``Billy the Kid.'' The Brooklyn-born son of Jewish immigrants from East Europe was remembered in death as the prototypical American composer. ``He had a uniquely American voice and was able to express in his music particularly American sensibilities using substantially the language of European serious music,'' said Kenneth Haas, managing director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Copland's composing career gave the world such popular pieces as ``Fanfare for the Common Man,'' an orchestral composition the late Leonard Bernstein once called ``the all-time top of the hit parade in American music.'' Copland won the 1944 Pulitzer Prize for Composition for ``Appalachian Spring,'' which was commissioned by choreographer Martha Graham; an Oscar for his musical score of ``The Heiress'' in 1948; and the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1964. Graham, on retreat in Hawaii after completing a six-week Far East tour, called Copland ``a very dear friend and a very great artist.'' ``Aaron and I and `Appalachian Spring' have had such a long journey together,'' she said in a statement released by her Manhattan-based dance company. ``It is very difficult for me to accept that he is gone.'' Another dance great, Agnes DeMille, also mourned Copland's death. But, outspoken as always, DeMille said she did not think of Copland as a ``world-class'' composer. ``He was a very great composer; the finest we had. He's not by any means in a world class. ... But I liked him awfully,'' she said. ``He was wonderful to work with, charming to be with, an expert worker.'' DeMille recalled when Copland told her he had started conducting and mentioned how much he enjoyed it. ``By the way, he was a bad conductor,'' she interjected, and continued: ``He then said, `Agnes, have you ever conducted?' and I said, `Of all the damn fool questions you ever asked me, Aaron, that one takes the cake.''' The anecdote shows the simple side of Copland, a man who many described as a down-to-earth, uncomplicated genius. ``Usually geniuses are self-centered, and I thought, `How can a man be a genius and still be so nice?''' recalled Pulitzer Prize-winning composer David Del Tredici, who claims Copland as his mentor. Copland quit composing in the early 1970s and swore he didn't miss it. ``You'd think if you had spent 50 years at it you'd have the feeling that something was missing, and I really don't,'' he told an interviewer. ``I must have expressed myself sufficiently. I certainly don't feel tortured or bitter, only lucky to have been given so long to be creative. And resigned to the fact that it appears to be over.'' At his birthday celebration two weeks ago, Copland ate apple pie, which he preferred to cake. Surrounded by longtime friends, he read messages from young fans. ``He was not the least pretentious,'' said Schuman. ``If you didn't know he was one of the greatest artists of the century, you would never suspect it.'' Copland taught at the Boston Symphony's Tanglewood music school in Lenox, Mass., for 25 years and was head of the faculty there when he stepped down in 1970. His students included Bernstein and composer Lukas Foss. ``He lived a very productive 90 years,'' Haas said. ``Happily, we will have his music to appreciate even though we don't have him any more.'' Copland, a lifelong bachelor, is survived by a niece, Felice Marlin of Manhattan; and two nephews, Ralph Marcus of Stuart, Fla., and Burton Marcus of Woodmere.

DOC.HEAD: Angola Prepares Political, Economic Changes
DOC.TEXT: After 15 years of civil war, Marxist-inspired one-party rule, foreign invasion and economic crisis, Angola's leaders begin a new strugle on Tuesday - to radically change the nature of their country. President Jose Eduardo dos Santos's party is to debate plans at a congress being held to introduce multiparty democracy and a free market economy and to discuss peace terms with the U.S.-backed UNITA guerrilla movement. In preparing to emulate his allies in the Soviet Union, dos Santos faces a challenge from hard-liners within his Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, or MPLA. They have yet to follow him in dropping Marxist rhetoric and embracing his ``new option'' of democratic socialism. In 11 years as party leader and president of the war-torn southern African nation, dos Santos has survived the jockeying for power within the MPLA. He has given strong signals in recent months, however, that he plans to abandon the communist model and open the political system to opposition forces, including UNITA - the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola. Jonas Savimbi's UNITA rebels have been fighting the MPLA since Angola gaindd independence from Portugal in 1975. The two sides opened peace talks in Portugal last April to end their war, which has devastated what is potentially one of the richest countries in Africa. At the fifth round of talks last month, Portuguese officials mediating the negotiations said a cease-fire was in sight. A truce must be followed by political changes allowing UNITA a stake in Angola's future. This week's congress is to discuss major constitutional reforms aimed at removing the ruling party's position as the guiding force in society, legalizing opposition groups and preparing for general elections. Dos Santos says a multiparty system can be implemented early next year. To ensure support for the changes, he is expected to remove at least five longtime members from the 13-member Politburo and officially shed the party's Marxist ideology. Sub-Saharan Africa's second-largaest nation, Angola is rich in oil, diamonds and other minerals. It has an abundance of arable land and well-stocked Atlantic fishing grounds. Its deep-water ports at Luanda and Lobito could be a key economic outlet for other southern African nations. But fighting has crippled economic activity and cut communications. Only exports from the heavily guarded northwestern oil fields have kept the economy afloat. Also, an estimated 2 million of Angola's 10 million people face famine after a four-year drought. Dos Santos concedes that war was not the only cause of Angola's economic woes. He admitted in a recent address before 700 businessmen in Luanda that the centralized system adopted by all of Portugal's African colonies after independence resulted in many errors. The most important, dos Santos said, was not understanding the role of private enterprise in Angola's economic recovery. He promised reforms that would aid small-business owners and encourage foreign investment. A long-awaited devaluation of the kwanza was introduced in September as part of an austerity program. The government and UNITA remain divided on such issues as the timing of elections, integration of the two armed forces and the composition of an international force to verify a cease-fire. While both sides have expressed cautious optimism after last month's talks, fighting has flared since. UNITA commandos conducted daring raids on economic targets in the Luanda area last week, blowing up bridges, water pipes and electricity lines. They damaged the Luanda oil refinery, leaving the capital facing energy and gas shortages. A Cuban officer and two soldiers were killed in the attacks. Cuba maintains about 10,000 soldiers here from the estimated 50,000 stationed in Angola since the late-1970s. In a 1988 agreement with South Africa, which had made incursions into Angola, Cuba said it would withdraw its force and South Africa pledged to halt its aid to UNITA. The United States has said it will not stop helping UNITA until the government guarantees the rebels a role in a mulitparty society.

DOC.HEAD: Hanford Whistle-Blower Complains of Harassment
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Department of Energy said Monday it is investigating an engineer's complaint she was harassed after warning that emptying two tanks at the Hanford nuclear reservation could cause an explosion. Her warning was later vindicated by a General Accounting Office report that said too little was known about the explosive potential of the tanks. Engineer Inez Austin contends employer Westinghouse Hanford Co. is destroying her career because of her alert. Ken Morgan of the Department of Energy's Richland office said Monday that the agency takes harassment of whistle-blowers seriously. ``We do not have much first-hand information about'' Ms. Austin's case, he said. A Hanford watchdog group said the incident was the latest in a pattern of harassment against whistle-blowers on the reservation in south-central Washington. Hanford for decades produced plutonium for nuclear weapons, but now is largely focusing on cleaning up years of contamination at the federal site. ``The harassment of whistle-blowers who are trying to protect the public from extremely dangerous waste tanks is rampant,'' said Gerald Pollet of Heart of America Northwest. Six weeks ago, Energy Secretary James Watkins toured Hanford and promised whistle-blowers would be protected and rewarded. Last month, Westinghouse Hanford issued guidelines for protecting whistle-blowers. Ms. Austin, who made her concerns public Saturday, said, ``We've always been told if there is a problem go to your manager and if there is a safety concern they will listen. It is a blow to find out it is not true.'' Last June, Ms. Austin contends, she demanded a delay in the pumping of radioactive liquids from two waste storage tanks that the company did not want to grant. The pumping was canceled anyway after the GAO report. The tanks contained ferrocyanide, which could explode if internal tank temperatures top 400 degrees Fahrenheit. The chemical was added in the 1950s to concentrate the tank liquids. Ms. Austin, who had served on a panel that analyzed the safety of pumping 22 tanks containing ferrocyanide, had been asked to approve the emptying of two tanks. She refused, saying that removing liquids could cause the internal temperatures to rise, possibly to dangerous levels, said Tom Carpenter, an attorney for the private Government Accountability Project. The next day she argued with her supervisor and another engineer over the refusal, Carpenter said. Westinghouse spokesman John Burk said the technology did not allow enough of the liquid to be removed from the sludge at the bottom of the tank to raise internal temperatures. He also said 15 of the frrocyanide tanks had been pumped in the past without incident. Ms. Austin, a Westinghouse employee since 1979, contends she has since suffered a reduction of duties, a poor job evaluation, failure to receive mail, and even constant temperature fluctuations in her office. She said the actions were designed to make her quit, which she has not done. She said she has filed a complaint with the U.S. Department of Labor. After the argument Ms. Austin took the rest of the day and the next day as vacation days, Carpenter said. Burk said Westinghouse employees are not allowed to take vacation days on such short notice. ``Her manager gave her a letter of reprimand,'' said Burk, adding that the company has since rescinded the letter. He said Westinghouse Hanford President Roger Nichols is personally investigating some of her allegations.

DOC.HEAD: Short-term Interest Rate Changes Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Changes in interest rates on short-term Treasury securities were mixed in Monday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $10.0 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.06 percent, up from 7.02 percent last week. Another $10.0 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 6.96 percent, unchanged from last week. The three-month bill rate was the highest since 7.08 percent on Nov. 19. The six-month bill rate was the lowest since it averaged 6.71 percent on July 5, 1988. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.29 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,821.50 and 7.31 percent for six-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,648.10. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 7.30 percent last week, up from 7.29 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Civilian Employee Who Criticized Army Copters Assigned to New Job
With AM-Hanford Whistle-Blower
DOC.TEXT: A whistle-blower who contended that Army helicopters in the Persian Gulf were operating without proper protection against heat-seeking missiles began a new job Monday. Calvin J. Weber, 48, of Arnold, has criticized the defensive capabilities of some Huey and Blackhawk helicopters being used in the Desert Shield operation against Iraq. Weber, a civilian Army employee, was removed in handcuffs Oct. 25 from the Army Aviation Systems Command after he refused to leave. He was placed on administrative leave with pay while authorities investigated the incident. In his new job, Weber will inspect construction projects and check utility costs. He was ordered to report for work at the Melvin Price Support Center in Granite City, Ill., until his present extension from being fired expires Jan. 11. An Army memo at the time of Weber's removal from the AVSCOM building said he had been asking about ``sensitive information and intimating'' that he would disclose it publicly. Disclosure ``could be highly detrimental to the security of the United States,'' the memo said. Since then, the inspector general of the Pentagon has decided t investigate efforts to fire Weber, in response to a request from Sen. William V. Roth, R-Del. In addition, Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., has asked Army Secretary Michael Stone to look into the action against Weber. Conyers heads an oversight subcommittee of the House Government Operations Committee. ``It appears there may have been an attempt to silence and discredit an Army employee,'' Conyers wrote. ``One senior Army official has stated that the Army doesn't disagree with what he (Weber) is saying, just in who he is saying it to.'' AVSCOM spokesman Robert E. Hunt said he could not speculate what will happen to Weber after Jan. 11, because he has been given several extensions since he got his termination notice.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Planes Collide On Ground At Detroit Airport; At Least 19 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with quote from passenger on 727; CORRECT number ofppeople on burned plane to 43 sted 44, reflecting official change. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `Tony Dresden...'. SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT that airport was closed briefly.
DOC.TEXT: Two jets taxiing for takeoff at the Detroit airport collided in fog today and one of them, a DC-9 with 43 aboard, burned to a blackened hulk. At least 19 people were killed, officials said. The two Northwest Airlines planes were the DC-9, bound for Pittsburgh with 39 passengers and four crew members, and a Boeing 727-200 headed for Memphis with 146 passengers and 10 crew member aboard, the airline said. Alan Muncaster, Northwest's vice president of communication in Egan, Minn., confirmed the 19 fatalities. An undetermined number of persons were injured, some with severe burns, authorities said. All the severe injuries and deaths were believed to be among people on the Pittsburgh-bound plane, authorities said. ``As soon as I heard the thump we came to an abrupt stop,'' said Robert Karp, a passenger on the 727. ``I remember looking at the other plane and seeing smoke rolling out.'' Muncaster said that apparently the the right wing of the 727 hit the aft section, the engine, of the DC9, taking the engine off, Muncaster said. ``That resulted in the fire,'' he said. ``That at this point is all we know.'' He said that at the time of the 1:45 p.m. crash, the airport had been closed to inbound traffic because of fog but they were allowing planes to take off. A winter storm had moved through the area earlier in the day. Passengers from the 727 walked off the plane, down the stairs, said Karp, 60, a college professor from Jackson, Miss. When the impact occurred, he said, ``I thought the tire had blown out. The front end of the plane had begun to lift off. I don't think the back wheels were off the ground yet.'' Passengers were shook up but unhurt, he said. The wing appeared to be torn from the plane, 727 passenger Edward Duda said. Tony Dresden, a spokesman for the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, said according to preliminary reports from the scene, ``The DC-9 pilot became lost on the runways.'' ``The pilot gave the ground controller erroneous information about his position and turned right onto the runway where the 727 was taxiing,'' he said. ``The DC-9 pilot discovered at the very last moment where he was, and so the ground controller told him to immediately get off that runway, but it was too late,'' Dresden said, stressing that the description of the accident was preliminary. Edward McNamara, Wayne County executive, said there were at least some survivors on the DC-9 and that the only injuries on the Boeing were those that occurred during the evacuation of the plane. Linda Kalinsky, Taylor Ambulance Co., said, ``We were told that there were 50 or 60 injuries'' including some burn victims. Originally, the Federal Aviation Administration said the planes' wingtips struck. Later, Northwest said the wing of the 727hit the rear section of the DC9. After the accident, one of the planes could be seen surrounded by emergency vehicles, smoke pouring from what appeared to be a burned fuselage, tail blackened by fire. The fuselage appeared to be hollowed out as if by flames. By an hour after the accident, the fire was apparently out, McNamara said. As dusk settled in around 4 p.m., a stand of huge lights were wheeled into place near the cockpit of the DC-9 on Runway 3C to allow firefighters and investigators to see. At the time of the crash, weather was foggy, and the ground was wet from a morning snow and sleet storm that delayed flights at the airport. At least 11 people were brought or en route to Annapolis Hospital in Wayne, said spokeswoman Pat O'Dowd, and at least one was in critical condition. Two of the victims at that hospital were transferred to the University of Michigan Medical Center Burn Center at Ann Arbor. Romulus, where Detroit Metropolitan Airport is located, is some 10 miles west of Detroit. It was the site of the second worst air crash in U.S. history, the Aug. 16, 1987, crash of a Northwest MD-80, on takeoff in which 156 people were killed. The airport was closed briefly after the accident and later reopened. Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board were being dispatched to the scene to begin a probe aimed at determining the cause of the accident, a safety board spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Ed Department Seeks to Clean Up Loan Program
DOC.TEXT: The Education Department will ask Congress to toughen the Higher Education Act to cut down on defaults in the federal student loan program, an official said Monday. Leonard L. Haynes III, assistant secretary for post-secondary education, told a banking convention that student loan defaults are costing the nation nearly $2 billion a year. He said the figure is ``simply unacceptable'' although it may pale against other federal agency debts. To reduce the default rates, Haynes said, the department will seek to toughen major provisions in the Higher Education Act when it comes up for reauthorization next year. The law is the statutory authority for about 60 higher education programs. Haynes said the department may require stringent performance standards of both students, colleges, universities and trade schools before they are allowed to join student loan programs. There also may be greater scrutiny of administrative and financial abilities of schools, as well as the quality of education offered, he said. ``We will not reinvent the wheel, but we believe we must create a more efficient, fairer, and less confusing student aid delivery system, while continuing to maximize postsecondary access and choice for needy students,'' he said. Haynes, speaking at a Consumer Bankers Association conference, stressed that ``we are committed to taking the lead on reforming student financial aid and other higher education programs.'' ``What we have in place is not serving us well,'' said Haynes. ``But the question is how good is better.'' The total of student loan defaults is $7.8 billion. An estimated $12 billion will be loaned to some 5 million students during fiscal 1990. This year the Education Department has come under harsh criticisms by members of Congress for lax oversight of the federal student loan program. A report by investigators for the Senate Government Affairs subcommittee on investigations faulted the department for ``very minimal, if any, oversight over the accrediting bodies.'' The department, the report added, granted schools eligibility in the student loan program without verifying that they were licensed and accredited. ``The department will place a greater emphasis on performance standards and outcomes measures in the areas of school accreditation, eligibility, licensing, and student success,'' Haynes said. Haynes said performance standards might focus on an institution's ability to keep and graduate students once enrolled, as well as dropout and pass-fail ratios, and placement rates. Although the department cannot assess curriculum, Haynes said, it may ``use the outcomes of the educational program to determine its quality.'' In addition, Haynes said ``we hope to eliminate unscrupulous recruiting techniques and weak admissions standards that often have misled students into poor quality schools and defaults on loans.''

DOC.HEAD: Wintry Storm Sweeps Through Midwest
