Baggage handlers at London's Heathrow Airport have testified that bags from the connecting Pan American World Airlines flights, including the Frankfurt flight, were not physically checked. The inquiry is expected to last into the new year.

DOC.HEAD: 17th Game of Chess Championship Postponed at Kasparov's Request
DOC.TEXT: The 17th game of the World Chess Championship between Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov has been postponed from Monday to Wednesday at Kasparov's request. The two Soviet grandmasters still are scheduled to resume their incomplete 16th game on Tuesday. That game was adjourned after five hours Saturday and then again Sunday after nearly six more hours without a result after 88 moves. Through the 15 completed games, they are tied with 7.5 points each. They have had three draws in the French portion of the championship. They had 10 draws in the 12 games played in New York between Oct. 8 and Nov. 7. The first player to reach 12.5 points wins the championship, but Kasparov would retain the title in the event of a draw. Each player is allowed to request up to three postponements during the championship. The postponement requested by Kasparov on Monday was his second, while Karpov has used one timeout.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Leaves Intact Settlement in Illinois Abortion Case
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pro-choice activists hailed a U.S. Supreme Court decision Monday upholding a legal settlement that eased restrictions on Illinois abortion clinics, but anti-abortion forces vowed to pursue the case in lower court. The Supreme Court left intact a lawsuit settlement that rolled back restrictions on abortion clinics. Without comment, the court rejected an appeal that contended the settlement does not adequately protect women or fetuses. ``I think we anticipated that they would not hear it. From a practical standpoint, it was a good settlement,'' said clinic owner Dr. Richard Ragsdale of Rockford, who sued the state to overturn regulations he said were unnecessary for abortions before 18 weeks. The rejection is the latest setback to anti-abortion activists who had hoped the court would use the Ragsdale lawsuit to further tighten federal restrictions on abortion, legalized in 1973 by the court's Roe vs. Wade decision. Craig Greenwood, an attorney who represented the two nurses who filed the appeal, said they had also filed the appeal in the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and would pursue that challenge. ``It was a remote shot, but this is an issue that has divided the country for a number of years,'' Greenwood said. ``We wanted the court to have an opportunity to show decisive leadership if it chose to.'' Ragsdale sued in 1985, challenging restrictions he said were unnecessary medically and, in effect, forced abortion clinic operators to build the equivalent of small hospitals or go out of business. In 1985, a U.S. District Court suspended the regulations. The court's suspension was upheld by the 7th Circuit appellate court in 1987, and state Attorney General Neil Hartigan appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court. The justices last year agreed to hear the case. But as they were about to hear arguments, the dispute was settled by an agreement between Hartigan and the American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois, which represented Ragsdale. U.S. District Judge John Nordberg in Chicago approved the settlement in March. The settlement established separate rules for two distinct kinds of abortion facility. For women under 18 weeks pregnant, abortions can be performed in clinic settings. The state's original regulations requiring full-service surgical facilities still apply in pregnancies of more than 18 weeks. A coalition of anti-abortion groups opposed the settlement, leading to the appeal acted on Monday by the high court. The appeal was filed by Ritaellen Murphy and Penny Greenwood, two nurses who said the settlement does not adequately protect the health of expectant mothers. ACLU attorney Colleen Connell, a member of the team that hammered out the 1989 agreement, said oral arguments were scheduled for Tuesday in the nurses' appeal to the 7th Circuit appellate court. ``We were not surprised that the court rejected this attempt to bypass the court of appeals, and their petition was totally without merit,'' Connell said. Joseph Scheidler, executive director of the Pro-Life Action League, said his organization would try to persuade legislators to introduce new abortion restrictions when the state General Assembly convenes next year.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Federation Votes to Allow Farmers to Own Land
DOC.TEXT: Farmers in the Russian republic may own land for the first time in more than 60 years but must wait a decade to sell it under a measure passed Monday by the Russian parliament. ``Farmers will be free now. They will be free in choosing the ways and methods of their work and property,'' Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin told a news conference after what he called an ``historic vote.'' Yeltsin said farmers told him that allowing private ownership would boost production ``in a year or two.'' This winter, however, the Soviet Union must rely in part on food purchased or donated abroad. After four days of acrimonious debate, a hush fell over the Russian Congress of Peoples' Deputies as lawmakers voted 863-90, with 40 abstentions, to reverse a land policy in effect since dictator Josef Stalin carried out a bloody collectivization of land between 1929 and 1932. Millions died in the resulting famine, and Soviet agriculture took decades to regain earlier production levels. Legislators cheered when the bill passed, and Yeltsin said later that ``euphoria is natural when people have waited so long.'' Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has recommended a nationwide referendum on reversing collectivization. But Yeltsin said the solid majority in the Russian parliament showed wide backing for the move. Many opponents of the measure doubt whether farmers would buy land. They say that even before collectivization, many small landholders in the Russian republic worked under a communal system of land ownership. Private land ownership by small landholders was more common in other republics. The national legislature has yet to approve the sale of farmland. It was not clear whether passage of the measure by the parliament of the Russian Federation - by far the largest of the 15 Soviet republics - would force the Kremlin's hand or spark a constitutional battle. The three Baltic Republics, which declared independence earlier this year, have also passed laws allowing private land ownership, although the process is bogged down in disputes over property rights. The newly elected non-Communist parliament of Georgia is expected to pass a law soon allowing private farmland. Yeltsin said the measure passed Monday ``will revive hundreds of thousands of Russian villages'' that are being abandoned by farmers who find it impossible to earn a decent living on state-owned land, selling at state-set prices to a state distribution system. Although private holdings will be allowed, he said, ``collective farm and other types of ownership will remain in existence ... competing for their place in the market. All forms of ownership are equal and protected by law.'' Under the terms of the four-point resolution, the Russian legislature will enact laws specifying how to break up collective farms. Local legislative councils will have the final say on whether to decollectivize. The resale of land would be blocked for 10 years, and then it could be sold back only to the state. Parliament may decide to allow outright sale of land ``before the 10 years are over ... if we see that these processes are going smoothly,'' Yeltsin said. Russian farmers, he said, ``are set against buying or selling land because they are afraid land will be an object of speculation.'' The original proposal would have allowed the resale of land after five years. ``Russian peasants are not used to selling land, the land which is called Mother,'' said Yeltsin. ``Some lawmakers have been saying that, ``A Mother is not for sale.''' Yeltsin also stressed the need to monitor shipments of foreign food into the Soviet Union over the next three or four months. ``In this mess ... the Mafia can make great use of this, and sell it on the side,'' he said. Soviet crop yields were high this year, but much was lost due to poor transportation and storage facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Guerrilla Killed After Boat Forced Onto Beach
DOC.TEXT: A fishing boat suspected of carrying guerrillas was grounded Monday by Israeli forces, which shot and killed one person aboard the vessel and arrested three others, the military command said. The boat was spotted by an Israeli navy patrol craft off the Gaza Strip and ordered to halt. It tried to head out to sea, but the navy ship, assisted by air force helicopters, forced the boat to land on a beach near the Deir el-Balah refugee camp, the army said. Soldiers waiting on the beach killed one man when he tried to escape, the army said. The army said it was checking alleged connections between the suspects and recent guerrilla activity in the area. Meanwhile in the occupied West Bank, masked Palestinian activists shot a suspected Israeli informant in the head and hanged him from a telephone pole in a village square, Arab reports said. They said Saeed Abdul Rahman Jbur, 60, had been kidnapped earlier from his home in Araba in the northern West Bank. A group calling itself The Black Panthers claimed responsibility for the killing. The army said it was checking the report. Jbur's death raised to 311 the number of Palestinians killed by Arabs on suspicion of assisting Israel during the nearly 3-year-old uprising against Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 776 Arabs, including Monday's victim, have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the revolt, and 53 Israelis have died in the violence. The suspected collaborators included some prostitutes and drug dealers, seen by activists as corrupting the morale of the revolt. Also Monday, a military court sentenced 12 Palestinian guerrillas each to 30 years in prison for an aborted seaborne attack six months ago aimed at the U.S. Embassy and Israeli ivilians. The attempted raid on May 30 was claimed by the Palestine Liberation Front, a Palestine Liberation Organization faction headed by Mohammed Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas. The action prompted Washington to break off an 18-month dialogue with the PLO.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Official: Vote in U.N. Won't Hurt Efforts to Improve Ties
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Qian Qichen said Tuesday that China's refusal to support a military threat against Iraq disappointed U.S. officials, but won't derail Chinese efforts to improve foreign relations. ``This visit to Washington was very successful and I'm very satisfied with it,'' Qian said upon returning from the first official Chinese visit to Washington since China's military violently suppressed the pro-democracy movement in June 1989. Qian hedged when asked if he considered U.S.-China relations normalized following his talks with President Bush and other U.S. Officials. ``Both sides agreed to increase our contacts and exchanges so as to increase our mutual understanding,'' Qian said. China gained considerable international goodwill by supporting the first 11 U.N. Security Council resolutions aimed at forcing Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait. But China refused to support the measure passed Thursday that clears the way for a military strike against Iraq if its occupying army remains in Kuwait after Jan. 15. The Security Council approved the resolution 12-2, with China abstaining. China, as one of the five permanent Security Council members, could have vetoed the measure. The United States lobbied intensely for the resolution, hoping to marshal universal support to show Iraq the international community opposes its occupation of Kuwait. Qian said the abstention would not hurt China's efforts to improve foreign relations. China drew widespread condemnation after its army opened fire on student-led demonstrators urging democratic reforms. Hundreds of people were killed. ``China decides on its voting based on its own position and I think all countries understand that,'' Qian said. ``The Americans expressed a certain disappointment, but they also expressed a certain understanding.'' Qian also said he welcomed Bush's decision to send U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III on a peace mission to Baghdad. ``It has always been our position there should be some dialogue,'' Qian said. Western countries and Japan have gradually lifted sanctions imposed against China to protest the military crackdown. Western diplomats have acknowledged China's improved international standing resulted in part from its cooperation during the gulf crisis. Japan sent its education minister to Beijing in September and resumed low-interest loans to China. The European Community voted in October to lift all sanctions except the ban on arms sales and defense cooperation. The United States had tried to downplay Qian's visit to Washington, saying it didn't violate a U.S. sanction against high-level exchanges. The U.S. State Department said the ban remains in place, but applies only to ``exchanges of a formal and ceremonial nature.'' Bush made an exception to the ban when he sent National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft to China in December 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Magellan Finds Evidence Venus Still Has Active Volcanoes
DOC.TEXT: Pictures taken by the Magellan spacecraft suggest that volcanoes still spew Australia-sized lava floods on Venus, and the planet didn't abruptly shut down after a global-sized eruption 400 million years ago. ``Venus is not dead,'' Southern Methodist University scientist Roger Phillips said Monday during the American Geophysical Union's fall meeting. Magellan hasn't yet found direct proof that volcanoes are erupting today on the planet, but ``it seems likely Venus is still (volcanically) active today,'' said Steve Saunders, Magellan's chief scientist at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena. The spacecraft's latest radar pictures of cloud-covered Venus show there are absolutely no meteorite impact craters in an Australia-sized portion of the planet's Sappho region, just north of the Venusian equator, Phillips said. That means the huge area is covered by lava that was deposited in a massive flood-like eruption sometime within the last tens of millions of years - very young in geological terms, Phillips said. ``It raises the likelihood Venus is still active,'' the Dallas researcher added. Venus ``has to be volcanically active, but demonstrating it is going to be hard,'' said Brown University geologist Jim Head, a member of the Magellan science team. To show conclusively that volcanoes now erupt on Venus, Magellan must fly over the same parts of the planet twice and look for differences caused by active lava flows. That won't happen until next spring. Saunders said last month that most of the meteorite impact craters on Venus appeared relatively young and fresh. He said that suggested older impact craters were obliterated by gargantuan floods of lava. At the time, Saunders said that either lava gushed from numerous cracks in the surface to flood 60 percent of Venus during a single catastrophe about 400 million years ago, or that a series of somewhat smaller but still giant lava floods inundate various regions of Venus during different times. The evidence Phillips presented Monday supports the second theory. If a single global lava flood created most of Venus' lowland plains 400 million years ago, meteorite impact craters should appear across much of the planet's landscape. But the pictures showing the uncratered region of Sappho suggest that huge, but not global, lava floods occur on different parts of the planet at different times, Phillips said. That, in turn, indicates massive volcanic flooding is an ongoing process of Venus, the second planet from the sun. Magellan was launched from space shuttle Atlantis in May 1989, went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10 and formally started making maps and pictures of the planet on Sept. 15. As of Monday, Magellan had orbited Venus 847 times, bouncing radar off Magellan's surface to make maps and pictures during more than 450 of the orbits, said Magellan experiment representative Steve Wall. NASA engineers reported Monday that Magellan was unable to map Venus during 3{ orbits of the planet Saturday and obtained only poor-quality pictures during two other orbits. A device that locates stars to help point Magellan picked the wrong star because of electronic static. That meant the spacecraft's main antenna was unable to point properly and collect radar echoes used to make pictures. Engineers fixed the problem Saturday night by sending new computer commands to Magellan.

DOC.HEAD: Strikes End at Paris Opera Houses
DOC.TEXT: A weeklong strike by musicians at the Opera-Bastille and the Palais Garnier ended Monday, opera officials said. The strike, which forced the cancellation of several performances last week, was resolved when musicians agreed to open negotiations with opera administrators. Productions of ``Othello'' on Tuesday and Saturday at the Opera-Bastille and a dance premiere at the Palais Garnier on Thursday will go on as planned.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Jaruzelski Received Order for Martial Law on Train
DOC.TEXT: A spokesman for Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski on Monday denied a newspaper report that quotes Jaruzelski as saying he was secretly whisked to the Soviet Union in 1981 and ordered to crush the Solidarity movement. ``Gen. Jaruzelski did not say this,'' said spokesman Wlodzimierz Lozinski. ``There was no trip, no plane.'' The former Communist leader, who will be replaced after Sunday's presidential runoff, repeated in an interview with the Turin-based daily La Stampa his contention he imposed martial law in order to avoid a Soviet invasion. He was quoted in Sunday's editions of the paper as saying he set out one evening for what he thought was a meeting in southwestern Poland with the Soviet officer in charge of Warsaw Pact forces. But the Soviet plane instead took him to a Soviet military base just across the border in Brest, the newspaper quotes him as saying. From there, Jaruzelski was taken to an empty train in a nearby station, La Stampa quotes him as saying. On entering, he found then-Soviet KGB chief Yuri Andropov, and the chief Soviet ideologist and Politburo member, Mikhail Suslov, waiting for him in one car. ```Try to get out of this by yourself' was the gist of their conversation,'' La Stampa quoted Jaruzelski as saying. ``We don't want to be forced to help you, but we certainly can't allow a change of system in Poland,'' Jaruzelski quoted them as saying. Shortly thereafter, in December 1981, Jaruzelski declared martial law. Both Andropov and Suslov have since died, Andropov after a short-lived tenure as Soviet leader. In Warsaw, Lozinski said the general ``had a lot of conversations with Andropov and Suslov, but it was the author (from La Stampa) who imagined that it happened in such circumstances.'' ``The sentence used by Mr. Suslov is quite probable ... these are obvious things, except for the description of a nighttime trip to southwestern Poland,'' said Lozinski, who said he was present with Jaruzelski during the interview with La Stampa.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Study Criticizes Handling of Gander Crash
DOC.TEXT: The United States was ``grossly negligent'' in rubber-stamping a Canadian report on a 1985 plane crash that killed 256 Americans and both governments failed to investigate the possibility that terrorism was involved, according to a congressional study. The National Transportation Safety Board should not have uncritically accepted Canada's finding that ice on the wings caused the crash in Gander, Newfoundland, says the staff report prepared for the House Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on crime. ``We found no evidence that there was an investigation of possible terrorism'' by the Canadians or the Americans, said the report, which was obtained by The Associated Press on Monday. Subcommittee members have not yet adopted the report. It will provide the basis for a hearing Tuesday into the Dec. 12, 1985 crash which occurred less than 30 seconds after liftoff from the airport at Gander, Newfoundland. U.S. Rep. Robin Tallon, D-S.C., says the crash could be connected to the Iran-Contra scandal. He suggests the plane may have been the target of a terrorist attack as a reprisal stemming from Iran's unhappiness with a weapons shipment authorized by the Reagan administration. Shortly after the plane went down in Gander, an anonymous caller said that Islamic Jihad, a pro-Iranian terrorist group, had put a bomb on the plane. ``No one in the United States Government had detailed information on what was done by the Canadians, or by the United States government itself, to determine that terrorism was not the cause,'' said the congressional report. It appears that FBI agents sent to Gander the day of the crash ``waited in a ... motel for whatever reports or conclusions Canadian authorities saw fit to share with them,'' said the report, which has not yet been voted on by the subcommittee members. ``After a mere 36 hours, they accepted a declaration that `terrorism was not involved' and returned home,'' apparently without getting any evidence to bolster that conclusion, it added. Spokesmen for both the NTSB and FBI declined comment. Both agencies will send representatives to testify at the hearing. The chartered military flight operated by Miami-based Arrow Air carried soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division coming home from peacekeeping duties in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula. Less than three weeks before the crash, CIA proprietary aircraft flew 18 Hawk missiles from Tel Aviv to Iran as part of the Reagan administration's secret attempt to free U.S. hostages held in Lebanon. The delivery of Hawks wasn't acceptable to the Iranians, who wanted a more powerful version of the Hawk and felt they had been duped. White House aide Oliver North used the Iranians' unhappiness to urge further shipments. ``We stand a good chance'' of condemning U.S. hostages held in Lebanon to death as well as a ``renewed wave of Islamic Jihad terrorism'' if the Iran initiative is discontinued, North said in a Dec. 4, 1985 computer message to his boss, national security adviser John Poindexter.

DOC.HEAD: Passengers: `My God, We've Hit Another Plane
With AM-Planes Collide, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: James Izzo's eyes had closed and he was drifting into sleep as Northwest Flight 1482 taxied toward the runway at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. Izzo, a nuclear engineer, was on his way home to Pittsburgh. The next thing he knew, ``I heard a bang, felt a thud, and then all of a sudden, there was a blast.'' Flight 1482 - a Northwest Airlines DC-9 - had been hit by the wing of another jet and was on fire. Izzo jumped from a window, over the left wing and onto the runway, slippery with slush. ``I just watched the fire spread across the plane and engulf the entire fuselage,'' he said. Izzo was among the lucky ones Monday, one of those who escaped unhurt from the inferno that engulfed Flight 1482. Within an hour of his escape, a charred hulk was all that remained of the jet, its ceiling open to the sky. It was not immediately clear how or why it happened, or how many people had died. This much appeared certain: Another Northwest jet, a Boeing 727 departing for Memphis, clipped the DC-9 on the taxiway, setting it on fire. The wing of the 727 was badly damaged, but the rest of the plane was intact and its 146 passengers were able to escape without serious injury. Passengers on the Memphis-bound plane, Flight 299, said the collision felt like a heavy, dull thud. ``I thought the tire had blown out,'' said Robert Karp, 60, of Jackson, Miss. ``The front end of the plane had begun to lift off. I don't think the back wheels were off the ground yet.'' Karp, a professor at Jackson State University who was sitting on the plane's left side, said people on the other side of the plane yelled: ``Oh my God, our entire wing is gone.'' As passengers left through the rear of the plane, they saw the wreckage of the DC-9 just 300 feet away. ``That's when it really hit me, when I saw the other plane at the end of the runway. I thought `My God, how close were we to a broadside collision?''' Karp said. Another Flight 299 passenger, Madana Mohan Kunjapur, 29, of Florence, Ala., said ``we were just about to take off from the ground when we hit the other plane, just like a heavy car tire hitting. We knew either something had hit the wings or one of our tires blew.'' ``I saw a blur and heard a thump,'' said Edward Duda, 55, of Plymouth, Mich., a materials engineer with Ford Motor Co. ``I saw a lot of fuel pouring out of the plane. That's really what concerned me. After I felt the impact, I thought it was a tire blow-out.'' Passengers on Flight 299 ``generally were calm, but I was pretty scared,'' Duda said.

DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Lawmaker To Propose National Version of LBJ Bill
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn., said Monday presidentially inclined members of Congress should be able to pursue their ambitions without risking their political hides. Gejdenson said he was introducing a bill to let House members and senators run for president and still appear on the ballot in their home state for their legislative jobs. The bill adopt nationally the essence of a Texas law designed for Lyndon Johnson and used by Lloyd Bentsen in 1988 to ensure he could run for vice president without giving up his Senate seat. Texas is the only state with such a law, Gejdenson said. ``It shouldn't just be Texans who have the opportunity to run for re-election and president simultaneously,'' Gejdenson said. ``And hhe country shouldn't be put in the position where a person of that experience should either remove himself from office or stay as majority leader or minority leader or committee chairman.'' Republicans viewed the legislation as a thinly veiled bid to widen the field of possible challengers against President Bush in 1992. ``It's nonsense,'' said Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., a close friend of the president. ``If the states want to do it, let them do it. ... If legislators are not serious enough about the presidency to be willing to give up a Senate seat or a House seat, then they're not serious about being president.'' Gejdenson said there is a crisis in a political system when seasoned elected officials stay out of the presidential fray because the odds are so long compared to the security of a powerful post on Capitol Hill. Political science Professor Larry Sabato of the University of Virginia said the GOP ``would be crazy'' to go along with Gejdenson's proposal. ``They'd just be encouraging opposition to George Bush,'' Sabato said. The Texas law allowing a candidate to appear on the state ballot for two different offices was tailor-made in 1959 for Sen. Lyndon B. Johnson, the Texas Democrat who ran for president the next year. He lost the nomination to Sen. John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts, but was on the successful national ticket as Kennedy's running mate. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Tex., used the law to his advantage in 1988 when he ran for re-election while joining Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in the presidential race. The move backfired for Dukakis, though. Instead of helping Dukakis carry Texas, many voters in the Lone Star State supported Bentsen for Senate and then voted for Bush for president. ``It was `Vote twice for Texas!''' Sabato said, ``so it actually ended up hurting the Democrats.'' Bush, of course, claims Texas as his home state. The LBJ law also cost Texas Democrats in 1960. For while Johnson became vice president, Republicans won his Senate seat and have held it ever since. Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif, incoming chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said that while he thinks the plan has merit, voters would have ``very little sympathy'' for it. ``Their current mood is for us not to run at all,'' Fazio said.

DOC.HEAD: At Least Four Earthquakes Occur; None Along New Madrid Fault
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to CORRECT that quakes were moderate sted major; SUBS grafs 11-12 pvs, `Between midnight...,' with 4 grafs to ADD fourth 5-magnitude quake, explain that such quakes aren't considered serious in unpopulated areas; ADD explanation of Richter scale. Pick up 12th graf pvs, `The severity...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Quake Projection, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: At least four moderate earthquakes rattled parts of the world, but there was nary a tremor Monday along the New Madrid Fault, where a scientist said a earthquake was likely to occur. ``This is just a normal day,'' said Waverly Person, chief of the U.S. Geological Survey's National Earthquake Information Center. ``We're not backing the prediction at all.'' Along the New Madrid Fault, some schools were canceled and residents purchased earthquake emergency kits and others left town, just in case climatologist Iben Browning was right. Browning said there was a 50-50 chance for a major earthquake early this week along the fault, which stretches from Marked Tree, Ark., northeast through New Marid, Mo., to Cairo, Ill. He believes tidal forces can trigger earthquakes, a theory most scientists reject. ``There's just no way to predict an earthquake precisely,'' said Person, who has been with the U.S. Geological Survey for more than 25 years. ``There are no two earthquakes alike.'' The center received more than 50 calls about the New Madrid forecast Monday morning and hundreds last week, said Person, who began doing interviews for radio and television stations just after midnight. As Person talked, 24 seismographs etched out activity recorded by monitoring equipment in different parts of the United States, ranging from Alaska to Tennessee. A needle jumped a few inches across the seismograph connected to monitoring equipment in Tonopah, Nev. Person scanned the chart and called to a colleague, ``It may be a nuclear test. That's where they conduct those tests.'' A few minutes later, the needle jumped again. ``That's not a test,'' he said. ``That's a quake.'' With a measured eye, he estimated the quake was magnitude 2.5 to 3.0 on the Richter scale. Quick calculations showed the quake was magnitude 3.5, centered about 30 miles southwest of Ely, Nev. Between midnight and evening, four moderate quakes were recorded at Golden. Three were in the South Pacific, a 5.9-magnitude shaker near New Caledonia, and quakes of 5.1 and 5.0 in the area of Tonga. The fourth was a 5.9-magnitude temblor in northern Colombia. A quake of that size can cause considerable damage in a populated area, but aren't considered serious in remote spots. About 800 quakes between magnitudes 5.0 and 5.9 are recorded each year, said USGS spokesman Don Finley in Washington. The Richter scale gauges the amount of energy released by an earthquake. A quake of magnitude 2 is about the smallest felt by humans. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage; 8 is a ``great'' quake, capable of tremendous damage. The big San Francisco Bay area quake last year registered 7.1 on the Richter scale. In 1989, the earthquake center recorded 14,604 earthquakes, with a magnitude 1 or higher, Person said. An average of 30 a day are recorded. This fall, there have been two in the New Madrid Fault area, magnitude 4.6 on Sept. 26 and magnitude 3.5 on Nov. 9, which ``is not unusual,'' he said. Although earthquakes can be tracked historically, forecasting them is difficult, if not impossible, Person said. Some people watch precursor activity, but that doesn't always lead to an earthquake. Other quakes occur in a swarm over a period of time, he said. Over the years, he has heard countless earthquake predictions. One woman called daily, alerting Person that an earthquake was about to occur, based on the number of birds that crossed her windshield as she drove down the street. The job, he confesses, ``is never boring.''

DOC.HEAD: India's Farmers Hold Protest Over Amusement Park
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of farmers held a rally in the capital Monday to protest the proposed setting up of an amusement park, news reports said. The farmers said the amusement park, which newspapers have labeled ``India's Disneyland,'' will render hundreds of acres of fertile land useless for agriculture, Press Trust of India reported. The government of Haryana state, which is adjacent to New Delhi, announced earlier this year that land around 38 villages will be bought by the government to set up the park. Landowners have protested, claiming the government will pay arbitrarily fixed prices that will be below the going rate for their properties.

DOC.HEAD: Politically Polarized Berlin May Get Left-Right Government
DOC.TEXT: Berlin, a city that once symbolized a divided world, is so united these days that two bitterly opposed political parties are talking about running the city together. The conservative Christian Democrats defeated the left-leaning Social Democrats in Sunday's city council race, just as they won the national German elections held the same day. However, Christian Democrat leader Eberhard Diepgen, a former West Berlin mayor and the united city's new mayor-elect, immediately asked the Social Democrats to think about joining his government. Both parties said Monday they would begin talks on putting together a broad, left-to-right coalition for a city that is without a doubt the most politically polarized municipality in Germany. ``What Berlin now needs is responsible government,'' said Klaus Landowsky, general secretary of the Berlin Christian Democrats. He called a merger with the Social Democrats ``mathematically thinkable.'' Politically unthinkable, however, is forming a coalition with the third-largest party - the former Communists who used to run East Germany. The Christian Democrats won 40.3 percent of the vote, the Social Democrats 30.5 percent and the former Communists, now called the Party for Democratic Socialism, finished with 9.2 percent. Traditionally, if no party captures a majority, the first place finisher would try to form a coalition with the third-place party. Because of the stigma of East Germany's Communist past, however, no mainstream German party wants to form an alliance with the former Communists at any level of government. Sunday's election was the first time in 44 years that eastern and western Berliners - once divided physically, ideologically and psychologically by the Berlin Wall - could vote for the same government. Diepgen, a West Berliner, will be the mayor and have to put together a cabinet. He will answer to a 240-member legislature. He will inherit a troubled city. Western Berlin is a modern, attractive metropolis faced with a housing crunch, a violent radical leftist fringe and serious overcrowding. West Berlin always has been a state of perpetual bailout. It spent much more than it took in annually because of huge subsidies from the former West German government, which sought to keep afloat an island of democracy in a sea of Stalinism. With Germany likely to face a cash crunch next year as the cost of unification, some lawmakers may question whether Berlin should continue to get a disproportionate share of federal money. Eastern Berlin, despite being the showplace of the former Communist nation, is beset with environmental problems, rising unemployment, bad roads and worse housing. It is also a stronghold of the former Communists.

DOC.HEAD: Little Town in Spotlight for `Quake'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS first two grafs, SUBS 7th graf pvs pvs, `The quake commotion...,' to CLARIFY that quake prediction was for 48 hours on either side of Dec. 3.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XSIK2
DOC.TEXT: Tavern owners opened their doors early, the governor paid a reassuring visit and reporters lurked at every corner Monday, drawn by an earthquake forecast. The prediction was dismissed by mainstream scientists, but it certainly put this Missippi River town of 3,200 in the spotlight. ``It's a zoo out there all right,'' said Eugenia Halterman, head teller at the Bank of New Madrid on Main Street. She said the goings-on were making the usually hectic first Monday of the month even more frazzling. Rose Townsend, the town's postmaster, agreed. She was handling a stack of postcards and envelopes that came in with requests for a ``Dec. 3, New Madrid'' postmark when Marilyn Rhodes, of Ruston, La., stopped in seeking a postmark for her husband, a stamp collector. ``This will be a surprise, an early Christmas present,'' she said. The quake commotion was caused by Iben Browning, a climatologist, who said the chances were 50-50 that a major quake would hit the New Madrid Fault zone in the 48 hours before or after Dec. 3. The fault runs from Marked Tree, Ark., to Cairo, Ill. Browning based his projection on tidal forces, which on Sunday were at their highest level in 60 years. He also mentioned several other locations including Tokyo and the Middle East for possible quakes. Browning, who lives in Tijeras, N.M., was on vacation and unavailable for comment, said his daughter, Evelyn Browning Garriss. Earthquake experts and local seismologists have called Browning's theory unscientific and said his projection is worthless, but that didn't stop some schools from canceling classes and the sale of earthquake kits. Missouri Gov. John Ashcroft toured New Madrid and several other small towns Monday to make sure everyone knew that there was no cause for alarm. New Madrid was the site of what are considered to be two of the nation's strongest quakes, in 1811 and 1812. The last major earthquake on the fault occurred in 1895. ``Panic is inconsistent with the appropriate response to living in an earthquake-prone area,'' Ashcroft said during a visit to the home of an elementary school principal, whose school was closed. At least four counties in southeast Missouri closed their courthouses just in case Browning was right. Some schools that stayed open reported higher than usual absences - 34 percent in one southern Indiana district. In Franklin, Tenn., 30 miles west of Nashville, teachers let young students bring teddy bears and favorite toys to school for extra comfort. In St. Louis and Memphis, Tenn., the two largest cities closest to the fault zone, the projection didn't have much of an impact on the usual back-to-work rush. ``It's just been another regular day,'' said Memphis police Capt. Chuck Ewerling. Radio commercials urged St. Louisians to buy a device called ``Quake Awake,'' which is a sort of earthquake alarm clock that will sound when the ground moves. The cost was $39.95 and next-day delivery was available. In New Madrid, at Hap's Bar and Grill, owner Jack Hailey had his hands full serving the media and his regular customers who came in after shifts at nearby aluminum and power plants. He had opened his ``Shake, Rattle and Roll'' party at 6 a.m. to accommodate a radio station from St. Louis that was broadcasting live from his tavern. But some local business owners said all the hoopla about earthquakes would be bad for the already depressed local economy and other residents weren't too happy with the portraits being painted by journalists. ``I think we're being portrayed as a little backwards,'' said Sandra Dial, a postal worker who was tired of seeing farmers in overalls and folks sitting on bar stools as spokespeople for her town. Police Chief Jim Helms said things were going smoothly. ``So far we haven't had a bit of trouble,'' he said. ``I kind of figured we'd have some small problems, not with the news media, but with some of the clowns around town.'' A few people missed out on the excitement. Jennine Steward, an insurance office worker, was busy weeks ago with a deluge of phone calls from clients checking on earthquake insurance. ``Today has been real quiet. We've had no phone calls. It's just been very quiet,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Residents of Guatemalan Massacre Village Ask for Military Base
DOC.TEXT: Residents of the lakeside village of Santiago Atitlan, where soldiers killed 12 people and wounded 21 last weekend, on Monday asked President Vinicio Cerezo to relocate the military base in nearby Panabaj. Ramiro de Leon Carpio, Guatemala's attorney general for human rights, promised a full probe of Sunday's incident and said he received a petition from the village with more than 15,000 signatures saying the village had constant problems with the military. ``There are various versions both from the authorities in the area and the residents, but what is sure is that there are innocent victims, and this must be cleared up with the search for the truth about what really happened and putting those responsible in court,'' he said. Santiago Atitlan, whose population is nearly 100 percent indigenous, is in an area of Guatemala where the country's 30-year-old guerrilla movement has long been active. According to one version, the shooting started after men in civilian clothes identified as army troops tried to take a resident from his house without a warrant. Another version blamed it on disorderly troops who were drunk and firing their weapons. There is agreement that villagers, led by town officials, were headed toward the military base when the shooting began in the early hours of Sunday. The morning newspaper El Grafico quoted one of the injured, Estaban Diaman Coo, as saying ``it was the army that opened fire at the people led by their mayor.'' Another resident, Nicolas Raxtun Sapuli, said: ``First the mayor tried to talk with the soldiers, but unfortunately a rain of bullets came and we heard someone yell to get on the ground.'' Antonio Rianda Coche said he hit the ground wounded, and two dead people fell on top of him before emergency workers took him to the hospital. The soldiers in the military zone were replaced Sunday night. The army issued a bulletin Sunday confirming the deaths and offered to investigate. More than 100,000 Guatemalans have died the past 30 years because of the civil war. The army, which has used ruthless tactics in the mountainous, heavily indigenous areas of the southwest where Sunday's killings took place, is frequently criticized for rights abuses.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-President Reagan Arrives for British Visit; To Meet Thatcher
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan and his wife Nancy arrived at London's Heathrow airport Monday night for a five-day visit to Britain that will include a meeting with Margaret Thatcher. Reagan is scheduled to have lunch on Thursday with Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace and meet with Mrs. Thatcher, the former prime minister, later the same day. Mrs. Thatcher on Nov. 22 announced her decision to resign as prime minister after Conservative Party elders told her she could not win a party leadership contest and formally quit on Nov. 28. Mrs. Thatcher, 65, who came to power in 1979, and 79-year-old Reagan, who was president from 1981-88, were close political allies when in power. Reagan did not speak to reporters at Heathrow. He and his wife were driven away by car, flanked by U.S. security officers and British police.

DOC.HEAD: Unofficial New York Murder Toll Passes 2,000 for Year, Another Record
DOC.TEXT: More than 2,000 people were murdered in New York during the first 11 months of 1990, making the year the city's bloodiest ever, according to unofficial police statistics released Monday. New York City rang out 1989 with 1,905 murders, also a record high. The city's 1990 homicide rate continued to increase, as six people were murdered during the period from Sunday night to Monday morning, police said. The year's record murder rate was partially attributed to the proliferation of handguns on the city's streets, as well as a rising tendency toward violence, said Deputy Inspector Thomas V. Connolly of the department's Office of Management Analysis & Planning, which tracks crime statistics. Of the 1,461 people murdered in the city during the first eight months of the year, 65 percent were killed by guns, according to the department's official figures, which lag as much as four months behind the unofficial figures. The homicide figures are subject to change because some deaths originally listed as murder could be reclassified later. Officials expect the number of killings to surpass 2,000, because December traditionally has a high number of murders. ``We've never seen as many guns as we've had this year, we've never confiscated as many, never had as many arrests for weapons,'' Connolly said. He said 9,410 guns were taken off the streets through the first six months of this year. The motives of many of the killings were not known, but Connolly said many of the murders began as disputes or robberies and escalated because a weapon was used. Seventy-three percent of the homicide victims were known to the people who killed them, Connolly said. Most of the murders - 57 percent - occurred on the street. Almost a quarter - 24 percent - happened during the commission of another crime, most often robbery. The exact date isn't known, but the city's homicide rate passed the 2,000 mark sometime during the last two weeks of November, said department spokesman Sgt. Peter Sweeney.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Walesa Hecklers Disrupt Tyminski Rally in Warsaw
DOC.TEXT: About 250 noisy supporters of Lech Walesa disrupted a presidential campaign rally for dark-horse challenger Stanislaw Tyminski on Monday with shouts of ``KGB!'' ``Get Out of Warsaw!'' and ``Go To Peru!'' They threw a tomato and handful of change, some of which struck the wealthy businessman without hurting him. Tyminski, who returned to Poland in September after 21 years in Peru and Canada and decided to run for president, drew cheers from his 1,000 adherents in the hall by defying the hecklers and pledging to stay. ``I represent the hopes of millions of people,'' he said. Tyminski came from obscurity to place second Nov. 25 in the first round of Poland's first popular presidential elections. He faces Walesa in the runoff Sunday. Latest surveys have him trailing the Solidarity leader by a 2-1 margin. Hecklers on Monday homed in on accusations that Tyminski is a stalking horse for the former Communist system with chants like ``Ubek!'' - slang for secret policeman. He denied any connection with the party. Walesa did not campaign Monday but used his allotted television time to publicize Tyminski's connections to former party members.

DOC.HEAD: 3,000 Homeless After Earthquake in Kirgizia
DOC.TEXT: At least 3,000 people are homeless following a weekend earthquake in the Central Asian republic of Kirgizia, Tass reported Monday. No one was killed, the official Soviet news agency said. Saturday's quake registered 6.5 on the Soviet 12-point scale, Tass said. It did not give a Richter scale reading and the Soviet scale does not convert to the Richter scale. Tass said the quake was centered 12 miles east of Uzgen in the Osh region where ethnic fighting has claimed more than 210 lives. It said 940 homes and public buildings were destroyed in Kyzyl Charba, Salam Alik and Ak Terek villages. A state of emergency declared after ethnic violence flared in Osh in June was lifted only last month. Ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks, both mostly Sunni Moslems who speak Turkish dialects, are engaged in a dispute over the allocation of land.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Soviet Hot Line Upgraded
DOC.TEXT: The Washington-Moscow hot line, a Cold War tool set up in the 1960s to prevent an accidental war, will more likely be used in the 1990s for disarmament talks, the Army said Monday. Contrary to popular belief, the hot line is not a pair of red phones, one in the Oval Office, the other in the Kremlin. It's a complex web of technology enabling the heads of state in both countries to exchange written messages directly, by teletype and fax. ``I suspect the future of this facility will be focused more on the remaining nuclear force reduction efforts, verification and other issues that I suspect only our imaginations can address,'' said Lt. Gen. Jerome B. Hilmes, director of information systems for the Secretary of the Army. The hotline is maintained at Fort Detrick, about 50 miles northwest of Washington. Hilmes was at the base to announce completion of a $4.7 million renovation of the emergency communications link. The improvements included new transmitters and receivers, control consoles and a new pair of 60-foot satellite dishes. The hot line was established in 1963, 11 months after tensions rose between the United States and the Soviet Union during the Cuban missile crisis. In that verbal altercation, President Kennedy forced the Soviets to dismantle their missile bases in Cuba. The hot line has been used more than 15 times since then. One of the most notable uses was during the six-day Arab-Israeli war in 1967. President Johnson advised the Soviet Union of U.S. ship and aircraft movements in the Mediterranean Sea after an Israeli attack on the USS Liberty. Though seldom used for its intended purpose, the line is tested several times a day by technicians at both ends to ensure it works. As the cold war ebbs, routine, maintenance-related dispatches on the presidential hot line are becoming more informal, said Tom Brothers, manager of the Fort Detrick earth station. American technicians and linguists have detected a freer flow of words in messages they exchange hourly with their Soviet counterparts. ``Could we ask an unofficial question about basketball?'' Brothers said the Soviets asked last February. ``Could you please tell us how our Kurtinaitis performed against your snipers?'' - an apparent translation of long-range basketball shooters. The Soviets were referring to Rimas Kurtinaitis, a 6-foot-5 basketball star from Lithuania. The NBA had invited Kurtinaitis to challenge eight of the NBA's best long-distance shooters in a 3-point contest in Houston. ``We'd like to know how he feels in the NBA,'' the Soviets said, according to Brothers. He said the U.S. hot line workers replied, ``Friends, in the local newspaper it says that Kurtinaitis is feeling fine, but there are no results from the competition. They'll probably be in tomorrow's paper.'' Such informality was unknown several years ago, Brothers said. The first hot line, a trans-Atlantic teletype cable, was prone to interruptions. A Finnish farmer cut a hot-line cable with his plow in 1963. In the 1970s, a manhole fire north of Baltimore severed the cable's primary circuit. About the same time, American telephone workers accidentally cut the cables to the hot line. Today, each hot line message goes to the Soviet Union three ways - by land cable and two satellite systems. The duplication is necessary to ensure messages get through during a crisis, Brothers said. Any message Bush might send to Gorbachev is encoded and taken to a terminal in Washington. The message is transmitted to Fort Detrick, where the signal is enhanced and relayed to two Soviet satellites. The Soviet satellites, 22,300 miles above the equator, beam the message to antennae south of Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Baltics Warned on Secession; Russia Seeks Economic Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with Yeltsin's comments, CORRECT date of Soviet Union document to 1922 sted 1924. Picks up 16th graf pvs, `Marshal Sergei...'
DOC.TEXT: Even if the Baltic republics refuse to sign a new Union Treaty, they will remain part of the Soviet Union unless they follow constitutional procedures for secession, a top Soviet legislator said Monday. Rafik Nishanov, chairman of the Council of Nationalities, one of two chambers in the Supreme Soviet legislature, issued the warning to the Baltics as he formally submitted the treaty to lawmakers. Another challenge to the treaty came from Russian President Boris Yeltsin, who said the giant republic would not sign until Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev recognizes the republic's right to control its own economy. Gorbachev has been pushing hard for adoption of the treaty to hold the 15 Soviet republics together. It would replace the 1922 document that formally created the Soviet Union and would give the restive republics more economic and political autonomy. But a strong central government in Moscow would retain control over defense, foreign policy, taxation, monetary policy, electric power and transportation. Nishanov's speech indicated that the Gorbachev government is maintaining a hard line on the issue of secession. Gorbachev sat on the rostrum during the legislative session but did not speak. As expected, the 542-member Supreme Soviet formally referred the Union Treaty to its parent body, the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies, which meets Dec. 17. If the congress approves the document, it will go to the 15 republics for ratification. The Baltic rpublics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia refused to participate in drafting the document and have said they will not sign it. ``If the Baltic republics don't accept such a treaty, in my opinion, they will remain in the Soviet Union on the basis of the documents with which they joined the union,'' Nishanov told the legislature. He added that under the Soviet constitution, the Baltic republics have a right to secede, but only if they first hold referendums and then follow rules established by the national legislature. Those procedures could entail a waiting period of five years, repayment for Soviet investments and resettlement of Russian-speaking people now living in the Baltics. Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia were occupied by the Soviet army at the start of World War II and were annexed in 1945. The Kremlin has refused to recognize their declarations of independence this year, saying they violate the Soviet constitution. The Baltic republics contend that they were occupied by force and that their annexation was invalid. The parliaments of all three republics, meeting in joint session in Vilnius last week, demanded the removal of Soviet ``occupation'' forces and international recognition of their independence. In addition to the Baltic republics, Armenia, Georgia and the Ukraine have said they will not sign the Union Treaty in its current form. Georgia's parliament has declared that it wants full independence, and there are also strong independence movements in Armenia and the Ukraine. Without mentioning Yeltsin by name, Nishanov attacked Yeltsin's proposal for bilateral treaties between republics. Forming ``a union without a center ... would be a step backwards,'' he said. But Yeltsin said he would sign the treaty ``only ... when the declaration of Russian sovereignty is recognized, when the budget is separated, when property is divided, hard currency, gold, oil, gas, and so forth'' are transferred from Soviet to Russian control. ``I will not compromise at the expense of Russia's sovereignty,'' said Yeltsin, who has advocated greater Russian control over its politics and economy since he was elected last May. Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, the Soviet Army chief of staff, told the legislature that defense had to remain a function of the central government. He noted that defense installations and academies were spread across the country, and he said nuclear weapons should remain under the control of only a few top officials. ``No other way (of handling nuclear weapons) is possible,'' Akhromeyev said. ``That's how it's done both here and in the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: Polish Presidential Candidate Said to Have Taken Hallucinogens
With AM-Poland-Candidate
DOC.TEXT: Polish presidential candidate Stanislaw Tyminski used hallucinogenic drugs when he lived in the Peruvian jungle town of Iquitos in the early 1980s, according to a Lima television news program. Tyminski took a deep interest in folk healing rituals while living in the Amazon river town, 620 miles northeast of Lima, Channel 4's news program En Persona said in a special report Sunday night. Iquitos folk healer Francisco del Castillo said in a taped interview that Tyminski used the hallucinogenic drug ayahuasca on several occasions. The program also detailed Tyminski's legal clashes over two of his Iquitos businesses - PetroRapido, a gasoline distribution network, and TVS-Iquitos, a cable TV channel. In April, the Supreme Court ruled Peruvian law was not violated in the business ventures. Friends described Tyminski as energetic, a man always on the lookout for business opportunities. ``Everything was a business to him,'' the Rev. Jose Maria, a friend in Iquitos, said. Tyminski faces Solidarity leader Lech Walesa in a runoff for the Polish presidency on Dec. 9.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Shrugs Off Argentine Revolt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush shrugged off a military revolt in Argentina and proclaimed ``a new era of hope'' in newly democratic South America as he opened a five-nation tour Monday. Bush vowed not to skip a visit to Buenos Aires and, indeed, the uprising there collapsed by day's end. The administration had expressed confidence the rebellion would be quelled quickly but also had left room for a late change in Bush's plans. ``If the situation became such that there was a real danger to his security, I'm sure we'd take another look at it,'' said Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger. The Argentine crisis threw a cloud over Bush's week-long mission, intended to celebrate the sweep of democracy throughout the hemisphere. It also obscured Bush's message that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was driving up oil prices and forcing poor countries to pay high fuel bills that they could ill afford. In Argentina, the government put down the last remnants of the uprising, the fourth of its kind in less than four years, by bombing rebel tanks. The government news agency said the last of several hundred rebels had surrendered. Nine people were reported killed. Francisco Rezek, foreign minister of Brazil, called the revolt in Argentina ``a step backward for democracy in Latin America.'' The Bush administration took another view. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater told reporters Monday evening that the situation in Buenos Aires ``does appear to be improving'' and that Argentine President Carlos Menem was in control. ``It is not a large-scale uprising,'' Fitzwater said. ``My argument would be that fundamentally democracy in Argentina is working and when this is over it will demonstrate the roots of democracy in Argentina are fairly deep.'' Bush said he would not abandon a planned stop Wednesday in Buenos Aires, where Menem declared a state of siege, suspending constitutional guarantees, after the fourth military uprising in four years. ``I have great confidence in the security there,'' Bush said. Administration officials accompanying Bush talked throughout the day with U.S. Embassy officials in Buenos Aires. The rebellious soldiers said they were not trying to overthrow the government but wanted to force changes in the way the military is run. There also was violence in Chile, another stop on Bush's trip, as bombs exploded in a chapel and in the offices of two right-wing political parties. There were no injuries. An anonymous caller said the blasts were a protest of Bush's visit. Bush arrived in Brasilia at dawn after an overnight flight from Washington, accompanied by a mostly junior staff. He was greeted by a 21-gun salute and military pageantry at the pillared Planalto Palace, the workplace of President Fernando Collor de Mello. The day ended with announcement of approval by Bush to license the sale of a high-performance computer sought by Brazil for more than two years. The step was taken to reward Brazil for agreeing, along with Argentina, to renounce any intention to proceed with nuclear programs with a military dimension. Secretary of State James A. Baker III remained in Washington to testify before Congress on the Persian Gulf. White House chief of staff John Sununu and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft also stayed home. While celebrating the rebirth of democracy in South America, Bush put a strong emphasis on the Persian Gulf crisis and Iraq's takeover of Kuwait. Bush said Czechoslovakia, where he visited last month, is paying $1.5 billion in additional fuel costs because of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's refusal to retreat. Collor, during a picture-taking session with Bush, said Brazil is paying $5 billion more for oil. Bush responded, ``That's why, (when) people say to me, `Well, this can go on and on and on,' I say, `No,''' Bush said. Bush raised the gulf crisis again during a speech to the Brazilian Congress. ``I realize the sacrifices that Saddam's brutality has caused this nation and its people, has caused many nations around the world.'' He mentioned the fuel estimates for Czechoslovakia and Brazil and said it was the direct result of ``the brutality and the aggression of Saddam Hussein.'' The military trouble in Argentina put a cloud over Bush's tribute to the sweep of democracy in the Western Hemisphere. Administration officials played down the problem. One official referred to it as ``an inter-military squabble.'' Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson said, ``There's a small group in the military that has certain grievances and every once in a while something like this happens.'' Fitzwater said the incident apparently was intended to embarrass Menem before Bush's visit. ``The president wants to express his confidence in President Menem and his support for democracy in Argentina,'' Fitzwater said. In an interview with Cable News Network, Collor said Menem called him and said the uprising was ``the responsibility of a minority group and a very localized event with no practical consequence for democracy in Argentina.'' The past decade has seen a resurgence of democracy across Latin America. Four of the five countries on Bush's itinerary - Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina and Chile - emerged from military dictatorships in the past decade. Venezuela turned to democracy in 1958. Bush's trip comes at a time of unusual harmony in U.S.-Latin American relations, and there were no burning issues on the agenda. An administration official said ``it's an old-fashioned question'' to be asking about possible U.S. aid for Latin America, which suffered through soaring inflation and falling living standards during the 1980s. Bush told the Brazilian Congress, ``All of us have been galvanized by a new era of hope and opportunity throughout the Americas, especially here in Brazil.'' He hailed the ``extraordinary political and economic change that is transforming the face of this hemisphere'' and described Brazil as a leader in this effort. In particular, Bush cited Collor's efforts at reducing the size of the state, privatizing enterprises, combating inflation and liberalizing trade. These steps, he said, ``are the keys to growth and prosperity in the global economy of the 21st century.'' Collor put in place a Draconian austerity plan which froze most bank accounts for 18 months and suspended automatic wage increases. With inflation creeping back up and a string of industrial bankruptcies, Collor's popularity has dropped sharply and his reform plan is in danger. The centerpiece of Bush's policy toward Latin America is the Enterprise for the Americas Initiative, which is designed to achieve economic growth through expanded trade and investment and reduced debt. Brazil's foreign debt is $112 billion, the largest in any developing country. The country is almost $10 billion in arrears on debt repayments and is negotiating a new repayment schedule with creditors. ``Brazil intends to reach an agreement that it can honor,'' Collor said Monday night, speaking at a dinner for Bush. ``We seek to reach a serious commitment with our creditors.'' Collor also said his country is determined to protect the Amazon environment and be ``the leader of a crusade to harmonize the ends of economic development with the respect for the environment.'' In his toast, Bush said: ``I believe we've just begun to tap the true potentials of the Americas and it is within our power to bring a new dawn to the new world. ... Together our opportunities are boundless. And so let us forge a closer and more vital partnership to esnure lasting prosperity for all our people.''

DOC.HEAD: Drug Agents Kill Six Passersby During Failed Raid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 5 grafs with dismissal, charges against officers
DOC.TEXT: Federal drug agents in the northern state of Sinaloa shot to death six passersby during a failed raid on a smuggling plane, officials said Monday. The incident took place in the pre-dawn hours Sunday, said Angelica Gil, a spokeswoman for the federal attorney general's office in Mexico City. She said the agents went to a remote airstrip, hoping to intercept a shipment of cocaine. They arrived too late, she said, and found the plane had been unloaded and abandoned. In the ``darkness and confusion,'' the agents opened fire on a passing vehicle, killing four adults and two minors, she said. ``Unfortunately they weren't involved. They were innocent Mexicans,'' Gil said. Assistant Attorney General Jorge Carrillo went to Sinaloa state Monday to investigate the incident, she said. Gil said no further details were immediately available. The incident came to light through a telephone call to The Associated Press from a ham radio operator in the United States. The caller said he had monitored what appeared to be transmissions from U.S. agents tracking the drug plane from South America up the west coast of Mexico. U.S. Embassy spokesman Steve Telkins in Mexico City said no U.S. government agents were involved in the shootout. He was not able to confirm whether U.S. agents had tracked the smuggling plane. The United States has an intelligence team its embassy in Mexico City that passes air surveillance information to Mexican authorities. In a related development, 12 officers and 23 agents of the Federal Judicial Police were dismissed Monday and charged with abuse of authority and other crimes, the official news agency Notimex reported. Notimex quoted Carrillo as saying five of the dismissed officers and all the agents were serving in the northern state of Chihuahua. The other seven officers were from Mexico City. The agency did not go into details concerning the accusations. The Federal Judicial Police, which is under the Attorney General's Office, has widely been accused of abusing its authority in its fight against drug trafficking. Dozens of complaints recently were filed in Chihuahua state and in Mexico City against the organization.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Surrender in Argentina to End Day-old Uprising, 13 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `The right-wing' to CLARIFY Bush in Brazil on first leg of South American visit, picks up 3rd, `The uprising...' SUBS grafs 26-28, `In April ...,' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with casualties from previous uprisings. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BAI1-4,7,8
DOC.TEXT: The military crushed a daylong uprising Monday by hundreds of rebels demanding a shake-up in the army high command. At least 13 people were killed. The right-wing insurrection occurred two days before President Bush, in Brasilia on the first leg of a South American trip, was to visit. U.S. officials who closely monitored the situation to the south said Bush will arrive as scheduled Wednesday. The uprising was the fourth and bloodiest in less than four years in Argentina, where democracy was restored in 1983 after nearly eight years of harsh military rule. The rebellion collapsed Monday night after tanks surrounded army headquarters, the one remaining rebel stronghold, and the last mutineers surrendered. Warplanes earlier bombed two columns of rebel tanks. ``The triumph of the armed forces was absolute,'' President Carlos Menem told a news conference. ``The surrender was unconditional.'' About 420 rebels - soldiers and civilians - surrendered, army officials said. Others were being sought. Rebel leader Col. Enrique Baraldini was among those arrested. Monday's rebel leaders may face the death penalty. ``The military code of justice contemplates that possibility,'' Menem said. ``The full measure of law will be applied.'' Before dawn, hundreds of mutineers and armed civilians took over army headquarters in downtown Buenos Aires, two blocks from Government House; the Palermo infantry base 5 miles to the north; the Boulogne tank factory 16 miles northwest; and at least two other installations. In contrast to three previous insurrections dating to April 1987, during Raul Alfonsin's presidency, Menem - in his 16th month of power - refused to negotiate. ``This is an attempted coup d'etat and will be treated as such,'' he said after declaring a state of siege. White House spoksman Marlin Fitzwater said in Brasilia, the capital of Brazil, it seemed likely the incident was intended to embarrass Menem before Bush's visit. ``It's also the reason we want to make clear our support for democracy and President Menem,'' Fitzwater said. Firefights raged all day in and near this capital of 11 million residents, capped just before nightfall by air force planes bombing rebel tanks on public roads. At least seven soldiers, one rebel and five civilians died before order was restored, the government news agency Telam reported. The civilians were in a bus hit by a tank. Twenty people were injured in that crash, Telam reported. At least 11 soldiers and one rebel were shot and wounded, the army said, along with at least 10 civilians, local news agencies reported. Menem said banks and foreign exchange houses would reopen Tuesday following the bank holiday declared Monday by the Economy Ministry. Jorge Newbery metropolitan airport was reopened Monday night. The state of siege, suspending constitutional guarantees, will be lifted by week's end, Menem said. The insurrection, broadcast live on television and radio, disrupted Buenos Aires. Banks were ordered closed at 1:30 p.m. Federal employees sent home two hours later. The stock exchange closed early. Federal police barred public gatherings. Key roads were blocked off to protect civilians and give priority to military traffic. Security at Congress and Government House, where Menem has his office, was reinforced. Bullets lodged in Government House and the Economy Ministry. Vice President Eduardo Duhalde's helicopter was hit by gunfire as it landed at Government House, but Duhalde was unhurt. The uprising began at about 3:30 a.m. when rebels, their faces blackened commando-style, appeared at army headquarters and took over several floors. About the same time, other rebels seized the Palermo infantry base and Boulogne tank factory. They insisted they were not out to overthrow the government. ``This is not a coup,'' a spokesman told reporters. ``We recognize the authority of President Menem as commander-in-chief.'' Asked their motives, the unidentified lieutenant replied, ``The same as during the Holy Week uprising: Our generals don't represent the sentiment nor the thought of our army.'' In April 1987 and January 1988, then Lt. Col. Aldo Rico led barracks revolts to halt trials of officers accused of human rights abuses during the 1976-83 dictatorship, force generals to retire and the government to increase the military budget. There were no deaths reported in the first uprising, and two loyalist soldiers were wounded when their truck ran over a mine in January 1988. Rico was imprisoned and cashiered, but most trials were halted after those uprisings, military pay was increased and a number of generals retired. Col. Mohamed Ali Seineldin's insurrection in December 1988 had similar motives and results. One civilian was killed and several wounded when fired on during a demonstration outside the occupied arsenal.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says Homeland for Palestinians is First Item on Peace Agenda
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with U.N. allows food for Soviets in Kuwait, CORRECTS that Kuwait made appeal in letter, not speech, ``grace'' to ``grave.'' No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said Monday that the Palestinian people must have a homeland in the West Bank and Gaza before any other Mideast peace questions can be dealt with. ``The first question is Palestine,'' Iraqi delegate Adnan Malik told the General Assembly. ``Palestine comes first, Palestine comes second and Palestine comes third.'' The United States has refused to link the Palestine issue to Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has said the Palestinian problem must be on the agenda in any dialogue with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. A General Assembly subcommittee meanwhile voted 132-1 to condemn Iraq for purported human rights violations in Kuwait. Iraq voted against the recommendation by the Third Committee, which deals with social affairs. Zambia abstained. The committee sent a draft resolution to the General Assembly denouncing ``the continued and increasing acts of torture, arrests, summary executions, disappearances and abduction'' in Kuwait by Iraqi forces. It criticized Baghdad's refusal to let the Red Cross into Kuwait and expressed ``grave concern'' over deteriorating living conditions under Iraqi occupation. In a letter to the Security Council, Ambassador Mohammad Abulhasan of Kuwait charged Iraq with ruining his homeland's agriculture since seizing the emirate on Aug. 2. With food shortages setting in, said Abulhasan, ``Kuwaitis who refuse to acquire Iraqi identity documents are unable to obtain food or fuel.'' He accused Iraq of looting Kuwait of at least 2,000 Arabian horses, 20,000 cattle and all the zoo animals, and of converting parks into military camps. The Security Council's committee on sanctions decided Monday to allow a food shipment to Soviets trapped in Iraq, but deferred action on a similar request for Palestinians in Kuwait. A diplomat who attended the private meeting said the committee approved a ``one shot'' delivery of food for Soviets outside Baghdad, whose diet is limited by rationing and available food supplies. The Soviet Red Cross will supervise distribution of food, the diplomat said. About 3,500 Soviets are still in Iraq. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Soviets did not specify how many were in Baghdad, and how many were in rural areas. At U.S. insistence, the committee deferred until its next meeting action on a similar request for food for Palestinians living in Kuwait. The diplomat quoted Abulhasan as having said the Iraqis treat Palestinians in Kuwait better than Kuwaitis. Malik said ``a radical solution to the question of Palestine, which guarantees an end to Zionist occupation, which guarantees the exercise by the Palestinian people of their inalienable rights, foremost of which is its right to self-determination and the establishment of its independent state with its capital Al-Quds el-Sharif (Jerusalem) - this is the only way to solve the crisis in the region.'' Israel has occupied the West Bank and Gaza Strip and controlled all of Jerusalem since the 1967 Middle East war. Most residents of the occupied territories are Palestinians. Malik portrayed Iraq as the hero of the Palestines. ``The United States of America and Israel refuse recognition to the Palestinian people, among all peoples of the world, the right to self-determination,'' he said. ``We must unmask the great gap between their claim to defend international legitimacy and the new international order, on the one hand, and their silence, indeed their support, for the crimes of the Zionist entity.'' To curb Israel, Malik said, Iraq had created ``a preventive Arab force ... capable of achieving a measure of balance to deter the Zionist terrorists and put an end to their expansionist, aggressive policies at the expense of Palestinian people and the Arab nation. ``That has made Iraq a major target in the Zionist-American plots.'' He said America's true objective in the gulf crisis is ``control of the oil wealth in the region.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Project Severe Earthquake in Los Angeles Basin
DOC.TEXT: The earthquake that rocked the Los Angeles Basin and caused $12 million in damage in February may only be the prelude to a nastier jolt to come, scientists said Monday. The Upland earthquake Feb. 28, which measured 5.2 on the Richter scale, failed to relieve stress on the San Jose Fault, said Egill Hauksson, a seismologist at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy an earthquake releases, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. As a result of that unspent stress, the San Jose fault may produce a quake measuring 6 to 6.5 on the Richter scale, Hauksson said during the American Geophysical Union's fall meeting. Scientists couldn't say when that might be, he said. The last quake of that size in the Los Angeles Basin was the Feb. 9, 1971, San Fernando-Sylmar quake, which had a magnitude of 6.4. It killed 65 people and injured 2,000 more as it collapsed freeway overpasses and caused $511 million in damage. The new study of the San Jose fault's potential for disaster was conducted by Hauksson and his wife, U.S. Geological Survey seismologist Lucy Jones. Roughly 11 miles long, the San Jose Fault starts near the base of the San Gabriel Mountains north of Upland and runs southwest near Claremont and Pomona. The Feb. 28 quake was centered 3 miles northwest of Upland, a community 40 miles east of downtown Los Angeles. It shook much of the Los Angeles Basin, causing minor injuries and $11.8 million in damage. The quake ruptured the fault's northeastern 2{ miles. The other 8{-mile section hasn't broken in any recent earthquake. Hauksson said he and Jones analyzed the type of faulting caused by the aftershocks in a quake in 1988 and the one in February. They concluded the two quakes failed to relieve stress on the rest of the San Jose Fault, which by its length could produce a jolt of 6 to 6.5 magnitude. ``There are still forces stored up in the region that could produce another earthquake as large or larger than what we've already had,'' Jones said. But far worse has been projected for Southern California - the so-called ``big one'' on the San Andreas Fault that scientists say will measure 7.5 to 8 or more in magnitude. A 1988 Geological Survey report said such an event quake is at least 60 percent likely by the year 2018. An earlier federal report said it could kill up to 14,000 people, hospitalize 55,000 and cause $17 billion in damage. But scientists believe the region will be shaken more often by smaller but still deadly quakes on other faults, including the San Jacinto Fault, the Elysian Park Fault and the Newport-Inglewood Fault.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Gets United Nations to Water Down Human Rights Resolution
DOC.TEXT: Iran persuaded the General Assembly on Monday to delete all references to``executions, ill-treatment and torture'' from a draft resolution on human rights violations in Iran. To avoid a divisive vote, sponsors removed language Iran found offensive. In return, Iran pledged to continue cooperating with U.N. human rights investigations and to allow the Red Cross to visit its prisons. A General Assembly subcommittee on Tuesday will recommend adoption by consensus of the toned-down resolution. A vote on the original draft would have been a humiliating public rebuke to Iran, which then would have barred future visits by rights experts. Tehran radio, monitored in Cyprus, called the original draft a ``lever'' to pressure Iran into dropping its opposition to multinational forces, posted in Saudi Arabia.
