DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Nov. 26-Dec. 3:
DOC.HEAD: Daily News Files RICO Suit Against Union Group, Drivers
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News has filed a $150 million civil racketeering lawsuit against union groups and drivers for allegedly conspiring to force the News to either accept wasteful contracts or sell the paper to them. More incidents of violence or threats of violence were reported in the 6-week-old strike against the newspaper. On Dec. 2, two replacement drivers were charged with possessing an unlicensed gun, a pipe bomb was found near the paper's Brooklyn plant and a striker was charged with assaulting a News hawker. On another front, the Daily News obtained a court order permitting hawkers to sell the paper on subway platforms and at railroad stops after the Metropolitan Transportation Authority canceled permits. The transportation agency said it acted because of concerns that strikers would set up picket lines that would be honored by transit workers, creating a work slowdown that might halt operations. On Dec. 3, first day of the transit sales, there were no reports of problems with Daily News hawkers at subway stations. Transit officials had no count of how many hawkers were selling at 60 approved sites around the city, but Caren Gardner of the TA said, ``There doesn't appear to be many out there.'' The newspaper's civil lawsuit against the unions was filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan on Nov. 29 and alleges violations of the Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO. The suit claims that a conspiracy exists involving attempted murder, coercion, arson and robbery. Named are the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity, the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella group representing the nine striking unions, and 23 drivers, some of whom have been arrested during the strike. The lawsuit claims the groups want to force the paper to accept a settlement that contains abuses the News has tried to end in 10 months of negotiations. The News also claimed that through violence the unions hoped to implement a buyout plan organized by Theodore Kheel, the unions' unpaid legal adviser. Kheel is not being sued. A 6-inch pipe bomb was found Dec. 2 near a parking area at the company's Brooklyn printing plant, police said. Nearby were two unexploded, M-80 firecrackers taped to boxes of nails. Police had gone there to investigate 12 explosions, apparently caused by firecrackers. Sgt. Peter Sweeney, a police spokesman, said one man was arrested for throwing a bottle that hit an officer. Four demonstrators were also arrested for disorderly conduct. In separate incidents the same day, police said two News replacement drivers were charged with weapons possession after a loaded .25-caliber handgun was found in the front seat of their truck, and a striking pressman was charged in the assault of a Daily News hawker. The strike by about 2,100 workers began Oct. 25.
DOC.HEAD: Murdoch Hopes To Reach Debt Agreement by Early January
DOC.TEXT: Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. says it hopes to reach an agreement with bankers by early January on a new financing plan that would defer repayment on about $5 billion in debt for the next three years. The Australian-based company has amassed a large debt by aggressively expanding into newspapers, book publishing, movie and TV production, television stations and magazines. But unexpectedly slow assets sales, economic weakness in Britain and Australia and a sluggish advertising market in the United States have made it tough to keep up with debt payments. Murdoch has met over the past few weeks with groups of bankers in Australia, Europe and the United States to outline a proposal to consolidate about $6.5 billion in bank loans otherwise due by mid-1993. An executive source close to the News Corp. chief executive but speaking on condition of anonymity said Nov. 29 that Murdoch made the proposal because principal payments are coming due that the company would have trouble paying. Under terms of the proposed package, only $1.4 billion in bank loans would have to be repaid by December 1993, the executive said. The company would then hope to renegotiate the remainder by early 1994, he said. In exchange for permitting the debt deferral, the bankers would get higher rates of interest and other fees. The company has also told the bankers it plans to sell about $1 billion in assets over the next two years. As part of the refinancing proposal, News Corp. would get a $600 million bridge loan that would have to be repaid in mid-1992. The bridge loan would give the company the ability to make interest payments, meet business expenses and allow extra time to arrange asset sales. News Corp. purchased the book publisher Harper & Row, 20th Century Fox Film Corp., several television stations and Triangle Publications, the owner of TV Guide and The Daily Racing Form, in the past few years. Under its existing loan agreemnt, News Corp. would have had to pay back $2.4 billion in both bank loans and public debt by next June, another $1.4 billion by June 1992 and $3 billion by June 1993. The new agreement would require no repayments by next June, $1.2 billion including the bridge loan by June 1992 and another $800 million by June 1993 with the chance for delaying the final payment until December 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Renfrew Leaving Reuters After 10 Years as Chief Executive
DOC.TEXT: Glen Renfrew, who guided Reuters through a decade of strong profit growth, will step down as chief executive in March, the company announced Nov. 29. He will be replaced by Peter Job, a 49-year-old Reuters veteran who started as a journalist before moving up the management ladder to his current post as managing director for Reuters in Asia. The announcement comes during a bumpy but still profitable year for Reuters which, Renfrew said, included a high number of cancellations of the company's financial services. Earlier in November the company said it would cut 300 jobs from its work force of 10,500 and delay the launch of a new automatic foreign exchange dealing system because of unsettled market conditions. Reuters Chairman Sir Christopher Hogg told a news conference that Renfrew's departure had nothing to do with the company's performance this year. The agency said it still would have record pre-tax profits of about $627 million, even after absorbing severance pay worth $19.6 million. Hogg said Renfrew, 62, had informed the board 15 months ago of his decision to retire after a successor had been picked. ``The whole process has been a planned one,'' said Hogg, who paid tribute to Renfrew for leading Reuters through ``a period of quite outstanding growth and prosperity'' as chief executive and managing director. Hogg said Renfrew had already stayed two years beyond the normal pensionable age for senior Reuters executives. Mandatory retirement is at 65. Neil Blackley, a media analyst at the brokerage James Capel and Co., also said it would be wrong to link Reuters' recent difficulties with Renfrew's leaving next March. ``He had a decade of meteoric profit growth but the last nine months have been difficult,'' Blackley said. ``It's a shame he has to end on that note.'' Blackley said he was pleased with the appointment of Job, whom he described as very talented. Job, a graduate of Oxford University, served as a foreign correspondent and news executive in India, Malaysia, Indonesia, Britain and Latin America before moving into business management in 1974. He has been head of Reuters Asia since 1988. Renfrew, an Australian, joined Reuters in London in 1952 after graduating from Sydney University. He was in charge of Reuters' North American operations from 1971 until his promotion to chief executive in 1981. When he took over as CEO, Reuters was owned by a publishers' association representing newspapers in Britian, Ireland, Australia and New Zealand. It had 2,700 employees then. Renfrew guided Reuters through a complicated transformation into a public company, Reuters Holdings PLC, in 1984. In the past five years pre-tax profits have risen steadily, with each year setting a new record. Renfrew sold 20 percent of his personal holdings in the company last August for about $3.37 million. That left him with 849,378 shares, worth $10.55 million the day his departure was announced.
DOC.HEAD: FNN Owner Expects To Report $72.5 Million Loss for Fiscal 1990
DOC.TEXT: Financial News Network Inc. said Nov. 29 it expects to report a $72.5 million loss for fiscal 1990. The company, whose biggest shareholder is the owner of the United Press International wire service, also said it expects to report a loss of $25 million for the first quarter of its current fiscal year. The company has been unable to report its financial results for the fiscal year ended June 30 because it replaced its auditing firm in a controversy over how FNN was reporting a $28 million investment in a new service. The auditors Deloitte & Touche contended the investment should have been deducted from quarterly earnings while FNN wanted to spread the costs over a few years. Deloitte left as FNN's auditor in October and the firm Coopers & Lybrand was brought in to study the FNN annual financial statements. FNN said that its new auditors had ``substantially completed their examination'' and said it expects to file its audited financial statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission in early December. FNN said the anticipated net loss for he year would leave it with a ``shareholders' deficit of approximately $33.5 million at June 30.'' The shareholders' deficit represents an excess of liabilities over assets. The company said it would probably file amended quarterly reports for the first nine months of fiscal 1990 to reflect ``material changes deemed appropriate as a result of the audit.'' In addition, it said it expects to report within a few weeks a $25 million loss for the first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30. FNN said that more than half of the anticipated losses for the year and the first quarter involves elimination of revenues derived from affiliated businesses. The company did not identify the affiliates, but it is 46 percent owned by Infotechnology Inc., which owns UPI and an assortment of other media and technology companies. It was disclosed last month that the SEC is investigating Infotechnology for undisclosed reasons. Infotechnology and FNN have each said they do not have enough cash flow to cover operating expenses, and are negotiating with those to whom they owe money. In late October, Alan J. Hirschfield and Allan R. Tessler were brought in to succeed Earl Brian as interim co-chief executives at both Infotechnology and Financial News Network. In early November, they said they were putting the companies' principal operations up for sale, including the FNN cable network and UPI. In the Nov. 29 announcement, Hirschfield and Tessler said FNN's investment banker, Wertheim & Schroder & Co. Inc., is beginning the sale process for FNN. ``A substantial number of inquires have been received from a broad representation of media-related companies and others concerning the proposed sale of FNN,'' the statement said. Infotechnology spokeswoman Amber Gordon said she could not identify who was interested or how many inquiries had been received. She said the company hopes to conclude negotiations of the contracts for the sales by the end of the year. FNN provides stock quotes, business and financial news and sports information on a cable TV network to more than 35 million homes served by 3,500 cable systems in the United States and Canada. It also operates a business radio network and, with Infotechnology, owns 51 percent of The Learning Channel cable network.

DOC.HEAD: AP Members Should Re-Examine Their Use of Resources, Daniels Says
DOC.TEXT: Members of The Associated Press need to reassess how they use their resources and consider reaffirming their commitment to the news cooperative, the chairman-elect of AP's board of directors said Dec. 2. Members of the AP tend to spend a great deal of money sending their own reporters to cover major news events rather than use the AP's coverage, said Frank A. Daniels Jr., president and publisher of The News & Observer of Raleigh, N.C. ``The instinct that so many of us have is that if we don't cover it ourselves, it isn't as well-done (and) that our readers expect us to staff certain events,'' Daniels told the Missouri and Kansas AP publishers and editors at their annual meeting. ``There's a lot of merit in that,'' he said. ``But every time we staff an event we have to forego another event. Or we give up a position on the copy desk that might have been able to rewrite a story and present more information more clearly by better editing.'' Daniels also urged the group to critique the AP report daily and call local bureaus with requests and complaints. ``The AP is only as good as you want it to be,'' he said. ``Let's work harder at using our cooperative, complementary skills so that our readers benefit from additional news. ``No one newspaper or group of newspapers is as strong as the cooperative AP. None has the financial resources to be devoted to gathering news and disseminating it, tapping into the creative productivity of 1,500 newspapers, each of which shares its reporting through the AP.''
DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Claims Reporter Fired From UPI for Being Lesbian
DOC.TEXT: A former United Press International reporter claims in a $12.75 million lawsuit that she was fired because she is a lesbian and wrote a free-lance story for a gay publication. Julie Brienza's lawsuit was filed Nov. 29 in U.S. District Court. UPI and Wisconsin Voice of Christian Youth, a Milwaukee-based religious group, were named as defendants. Brienza, who was UPI's Supreme Court reporter, alleged that she was dismissed under pressure from Vic Eliason, the religious group's executive director. In the suit, Brienza contends that Eliason began a campaign to have her fired after she interviewed him on April 10 for a free-lance article she was writing about the influence of the ``religious right'' on broadcasting. The suit alleges that Eliason buys news from UPI, and that he contacted UPI management to complain about Brienza writing for The Washington Blade, a news weekly. He then urged listeners to his radio network to jam UPI's telephone lines demanding her dismissal, the suit said. On April 27, UPI fired her, accusing her of violating free-lancing rules. ``UPI terminated Brienza's employment because of her sexual orientation, and because she was writing a free-lance article for a gay and lesbian newspaper,'' the suit contends. UPI spokesman Milt Capps said Nov. 29 he could not comment on the suit until he had seen it. But earlier, Capps had denied that Brienza's firing was due to pressure from religious broadcasters and said it was based on violations of UPI work rules. Officials at Wisconsin Voice of Christian Youth Inc. in Milwaukee did not immediately return a call seeking comment. The suit seeks $750,000 in general damages, plus $12 million in punitive damages - $10 million from Eliason and $2 million from UPI. It claims violation of privacy, loss of income and violation of a District of Columbia law that prohibits discrimination in employment based on a person's sexual orientation. The suit contends Wisconsin's ``hate crime'' law also was violated. Besides the $12.75 million, the suit seeks return of Brienza's job, back pay, and a retraction from Eliason and his group. The suit acknowledges that Brienza used UPI's internal message system to retrieve information on Eliason from the news agency's Milwaukee bureau and that she made two long-distance phone calls for the story from UPI's Washington office. UPI rules, according to the suit, prohibit employees from free-lancing on company time, doing outside work that could compete with UPI or writing articles that take an advocacy position. But Brienza said at a news conference that her use of company facilities was minimal and that other UPI employees routinely did the same for personal reasons or for outside work. She said The Blade is not an advocacy publication and that she had gotten permission from UPI management prior to working on the article. She said UPI's actions were out of proportion to the offense and that the issue in her firing really was her sexual orientation.
DOC.HEAD: First Journalist Travels Into Space Aboard Soviet Rocket
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese television reporter became the first journalist in space Dec. 2, riding a column of fire into orbit aboard a Soviet rocket. Journalist Toyohiro Akiyama, 48, joined Soviet cosmonauts Viktor Afanasyev and Musa Manarov in the Soyuz TM-11 space capsule. Akiyama was a passenger under a $12 million contract between the Soviet Union and Japan's biggest private television company, TBS. Underscoring the commercial nature of the mission, the Soviet rocket even had advertising slogans for TBS and other Japanese companies emblazoned on its sides. ``I feel fine,'' Akiyama said minutes before the liftoff. During the eight-day mission, he will document the experience on radio and television for TBS. The Japanese television company is spending $37 million on the entire venture to mark its 40th year on the air, according to network president Izumi Tanaka. More than 120 TBS reporters, cameramen and technicians scurried about the launch control center and reviewing stand to cover the launch, even sacrificing a remote-control camera next to the rocket to watch the flames close-up before it burned. Akiyama, a TBS news director who quit a four-pack-a-day cigarette habit during the training, was asked before liftoff what he looked forward to most on his return from the first trip into space by a Japanese citizen. ``I can't wait to have a smoke,'' he said. Akiyama, for whom TBS bought a $2.2 million life insurance policy, carried stationery, a picture of his family and three Japanese good-luck charms into space.
DOC.HEAD: Plain Dealer To Begin New Plant Construction
DOC.TEXT: The Plain Dealer will build a $210 million printing and distribution plant in suburban Brooklyn, just south of the city, Publisher Alex Machaskee announced. Construction at the 84-acre site will begin in about a month and is expected to take three years. The project will include a $70 million building, plus $140 million worth of printing presses and other production and distribution equipment. The Austin Co. of Cleveland will design, engineer and construct the facility. Machaskee said The Plain Dealer would have preferred to expand at its Superior Avenue site in Cleveland, but ``we determined that we simply did not have the room to expand our building to accommodate new printing and distribution equipment while we produced a daily newspaper.''
DOC.HEAD: Donrey Buys Paper; Sells Interest in Another
DOC.TEXT: The Donrey Media Group has bought the Oroville (Calif.) Mercury-Register from Buckner News Alliance and sold Buckner a half-interest in the Minot (N.D.) Daily News. The Minot newspaper has a circulation of about 28,000. The Mercury-Register's circulation is about 9,000. ``Oroville is in the heart of a fast-growing market where Donrey already owns two daily newspapers, and the Mercury-Register will fit our business and reader service plans very well,'' said Donrey President Fred Smith in a Nov. 30 news release. Margaret Wade, publisher in Oroville, and John Fenrich, publisher in Minot, will switch jobs.

DOC.HEAD: NFL: Players Did Act Nasty, Team Slow To Investigate
DOC.TEXT: The National Football League commissioner vindicated sports writer Lisa Olson by imposing $22,500 in fines on three New England Patriots players she accused of sexually taunting her in the team locker room. Commissioner Paul Tagliabue on Nov. 27 also fined the team $50,000 for being slow to investigate allegations that Zeke Mowatt, Michael Timpson and Robert Perryman exposed themselves or made lewd comments to the Boston Herald reporter. Mowatt, who earlier was fined $2,000 by the team, was fined $12,500. Timpson and Perryman were fined $5,000 each. The fines are likely to hurt their reputations more than their bank accounts, but Olson said she accepted the penalties. ``My satisfaction with the investigation and subsequent sanctions is surpassed only by my wish the disgraceful incident had never occurred in the first place,'' she said in a statement. ``It was not my choice to have this matter decided in a public forum, and it is unfortunate that Patriot management forced this to happen by not dealing with the guilty persons swiftly and decisively.'' Tagliabue agreed, saying the team ``did not adequately investigate and resolve a serious incident of misconduct in the club's locker room and appeared to condone the misconduct of the Patriots' players.'' The commissioner levied the fines based on a 60-page report by Harvard law professor Philip Heymann on the Sept. 17 incident. The report by Heymann, as Tagliabue's special counsel, resulted from 107 interviews with 91 people. Heymann cited discrepancies between the accounts given by Olson and several players, but he said Mowatt's story was not credible and he concluded the reporter suffered sexual taunting by naked players. Tagliabue called the players' actions ``completely uncalled for and improper. Mowatt's conduct involved both verbal and demonstrative actions. Timpson and Perryman encouraged the misconduct.'' ``The decision has been rendered. Now it's time to get on with playing football,'' Patriots owner Victor Kiam said in a statement. The penalties are subject to appeal, but Kiam said the team will abide by the decision. There was no comment immediately afterward from Mowatt, Timpson or Perryman, who is now with the Dallas Cowboys after being cut by New England. In addition to a $25,000 fine for dragging its feet on the investigation, the club was ordered to pay another $25,000 to help pay for instructional materials for all 28 NFL teams on how to deal with the news media. The Patriots are 1-11 this season and have not won since the day before the incident. A few weeks afterward, Cincinnati Bengals coach Sam Wyche barred a woman reporter from the locker room. Tagliabue fined him more than $27,000.
DOC.HEAD: Connecticut City Bans News Racks
DOC.TEXT: Executives from the Record-Journal of Meriden, The Hartford Courant and the New Haven Register said they plan to fight on constitutional grounds a directive that bans news racks from city sidewalks. City officials began notifying area newspapers Nov. 29 that the vending machines had to be removed from sidewalks and certain other locations. A one-sentence section of a local zoning ordinance prohibits placement of vending machines between a city street and a property line, effectively banning them from city sidewalks. It also requires machines on private property to be a certain distance from the street, although that distance varies depending on the area's zone designation. But newspaper officials said numerous court cases, including a 1988 U.S. Supreme Court decision, have upheld newspapers' First Amendment right to maintain the machines. A letter mailed to the three newspapers said their machines have to be removed within 30 days. If they are not, cease-and-desist orders will be issued and the city will begin enforcement actions, City Planner Dominick J. Caruso said. He said the same letter will go out to other newspapers that own vending machines in the city. But City Manager Michael H. Aldi later said he believes the ordinance may be unconstitutional, and that intends to seek a legal opinion to resolve the issue. Caruso said the regulation has ``been on the books for a long time, it's just never been brought up before.'' Caruso said he was unaware of the law until recently when he received a complaint. Eliot C. White, publisher of the Record-Journal and president of the Record-Journal Publishing Co., said the matter revolves around ``an out-of-date ordinance that's never been enforced, as far as we know.'' The Record-Journal maintains 50 vending machines in the city. In a 1988 case, the Supreme Court ruled that a Lakewood, Ohio, official could not prevent a Cleveland newspaper from putting out news racks by denying them a permit to do so, according to Alice Neff Lucan, a Washington, D.C., attorney who has handled similar cases. ``It is extremely unlikely in my opinion that just by coloring this a vending machine issue, they can prevent newspapers from distributing,'' said Neff Lucan, who represents USA Today, which owns machines in the city. The distribution and publication of newspapers is protected by the free speech provisions of the First Amendment, she said. William J. Rush, chief executive officer of the New Haven Register, said he has seen municipalities try to outlaw news racks. ``It's always boiled down to our constitutional rights under the First Amendment,'' he said. ``We try to be good citizens ... but we intend to keep our boxes on the street and we intend to protect our constitutional rights.'' The Register has about 35 machines in Meriden. Raymond A. Jansen, publisher of The Hartford Courant, said his paper has ``encountered this a number of times over the years, and we typically try to work with city officials to position the machines where they'd like to see them. ``But if it comes down to not allowing them, we'd view that very seriously,'' Jansen said. ``We would seek legal advice as to how the law could be enforced in the face of the First Amendment.''
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Racks Return to Huntsville Mall
DOC.TEXT: The manager of a shopping mall that banned newspaper racks changed his mind Nov. 26 after hearing complaints from several publications, including a black weekly. Madison Square Mall manager Joe Black said the issue had been blown out of proportion. Editor William Smothers of the weekly Speakin' Out News, who complained that banning the racks amounted to censorship, speculated that the policy was reversed to protect the mall's image. Black said he became concerned about the number of newspaper racks and the lack of maintenance of them last year. He had some removed, and then all of them to avoid the appearance of favoritism. ``We thought this thing had been blown way out of proportion and it was not deserving,'' Black said after deciding to allow the racks back. ``We thought it was time for the community to focus on things more important to Huntsville.''

DOC.HEAD: New Bedford Newspaper Targets Drug Suspects With Published Photos
DOC.TEXT: The war on drugs has taken a new twist in nearby New Bedford. The local newspaper, teamed with the chief of police and a top judge, has begun printing the mug shots of every person arrested on drug charges. ``This newspaper has escalated the importance of crime news relating to drugs,'' Editor James Ragsdale wrote in The Standard-Times. ``We are now saying that photographing those accused of drug-related crime is as important as for homicides, manslaughter, arson and the rest.'' Although many newspapers run the names of people arrested for various crimes, and some print the names of men charged with hiring prostitutes, Ragsdale believes that publishing the pictures of drug suspects is entirely new. ``This is just one of the many things this newspaper is doing to raise public awareness that there is a drug problem,'' he said. Titled ``Drug Watch,'' the daily column begun Nov. 15 requires one staff photographer and up to 30 inches of newsprint. A recent edition carried photos of nine men, ranging in age from 17 to 39, arrested for possession of various drugs, possession with intent to distribute and conspiracy to violate drug laws. Mayor John Bullard praised the paper's efforts. He said New Bedford's drug problem and related crime are overwhelming. More than 2,000 drug arrests were made in New Bedford in the first 10 months of 1990. Bullard acknowledged that publishing photos may not prevent hard-core drug use. ``But for those people who buy drugs and think they can stay undercover, this should be a deterrent,'' he said Tuesday. Reaction to Drug Watch has been varied, with many local officials and residents applauding the attempt and some journalists and lawyers questioning the ethics involved. Sarah Wunsch, a lawyer for the Massachusetts Civil Liberties Union, called the policy sensationalistic. She and others said the publication of pictures threatens a defendant's right to a fair trial. Ragsdale said his newspaper will make every effort to print the outcome of each court hearing, even if that happens months or years after initial publication.
DOC.HEAD: Gov. Deukmejian Reads Column, Rejects Paper's Interview Request
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Deukmejian, angered at a column in the San Francisco Examiner, has rejected the paper's request for a one-on-one interview but granted personal interviews to other newspapers, including the Examiner's competitor. Bob Gore, a spokesman for the Republcan governor, acknowledged Nov. 27 that Deukmejian was angered by an Oct. 1 column by writer Bill Mandel, who criticized the governor's fiscal policies relating to health care and social programs. The column appeared under the headline, ``Hell is Too Good for Deukmejian.'' ``It went beyond fair comment,'' Gore said when asked why the interview request had been denied. ``I think if you read your editorial page lately you might figure out why you are in the second round of interviews.'' The Examiner has been offered a group interview with the governor, along with The Associated Press, Gannett News Service, the Political Pulse, a Sacramento-based political newsletter, and United Press International. Three newspapers have been given one-on-one interviews: The San Francisco Chronicle, the San Diego Tribune and the Los Angeles Times. ``Those represent the three major urban areas in the state,'' Gore said. Among those that were denied personal interviews were the San Jose Mercury News, the San Diego Union and The Sacramento Bee. Frank McCulloch, the Examiner's managing editor, said it appeared the governor had made a decision on access based upon a newspaper's editorial comment. The ``columns and editorials have nothing to do with the news columns. No one on the editorial page has any authority over the news columns,'' he said. McCulloch added that newspaper columnists ``are constrained only by their by broad good taste, which is pretty hard to measure anyway.'' The refusal to allow a one-on-one interview ``may not be all that serious but in this competitive world it's a disadvantage.''
DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Libel Judgment Against Kentucky Post
DOC.TEXT: The Kentucky Supreme Court has upheld a libel judgment against The Kentucky Post won by a prosecutor who claimed the newspaper defamed him. The court, in a unanimous ruling Nov. 29, also upheld the $175,000 jury award to Campbell Commonwealth's Attorney Louis A. Ball for compensatory damages from the newspaper, reporter Al Salvato and the E.W. Scripps Co., which owns the Post. No punitive damages were awarded. The newspaper published front-page stories on Nov. 17 and 19, 1984, titled ``Portrait of a Prosecutor'' outlining what the paper said was Ball's poor record as prosecutor. Included was a comment from a former narcotics officer who said criminals ``couldn't have a better friend'' than Ball. The court's ruling said there was ample evidence the newspaper printed erroneous material that it knew was wrong or made insufficient effort to determine if it was wrong. The circumstances surrounding the newspaper's reporting and publishing of the story all led to the conclusion the articles were printed maliciously, the court said. ``We include in the circumstances surrounding publication the way in which the articles were laid out, the evidence regarding malice ... and the failure to make any retraction,'' Justice Charles Leibson said in the opinion. Kentucky Post Editor Judith Clabes called the ruling ``gravely disappointing.'' ``It's an unbecoming decision from a political body that has demonstrated in a number of instances that, when it comes to the press, politics and emotions are more controlling than the law,'' she said. The court ``completely ignored the facts of the case and misrepresented the facts of the case,'' Clabes said.
DOC.HEAD: Everett Newspaper Switching to Morning
DOC.TEXT: The Herald newspaper said Nov. 28 it will begin morning publication next May. The afternoon paper, which is owned by The Washington Post, now publishes mornings on weekends and major holidays. Publisher Larry Hanson said the decision to switch was based on studies that show faster-growing circulation of morning newspapers, and a readership survey that showed growing preference for morning delivery. The Herald's circulation is 54,242 daily and 64,409 on Sunday.
DOC.HEAD: Tolland County Times Suspends Publication
DOC.TEXT: The weekly Tolland County Times said it has suspended publication because of the slumping newspaper market. Editor William A. Johnson said the 3,000-circulation tabloid would resume Jan. 10 after reorganizing to better serve readers and advertisers. Six full-time and nine part-time employees were laid off. The newspaper was initially mailed free to more than 21,500 people when it started in August 1989. Circulation fell sharply after Johnson began charging 50 cents per issue in September.

DOC.HEAD: Court: Hearings for Professionals Can Be Closed
DOC.TEXT: New York's top court ruled Nov. 27 that Regents' disciplinary hearings involving doctors and other professionals should be closed to the public unless those accused of misconduct want them open. The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously against the Johnson Newspaper Corp., publisher of the Watertown Daily Times, which had argued that hearings conducted by the state Board of Regents should be open. The state Board of Regents is responsible for disciplining 32 licensed professions, including doctors, nurses, architects and veteranarians. Traditionally, the Regents have kept their misconduct cases against professionals confidential until they decide a person's guilt or innocence, said Christopher Carpenter, state Education Department spokesman. The Daily Times in April 1988 sought access to a disciplinary hearing involving a Watertown dentist. That hearing has been held up pending determination of this case. The Court of Appeals said nothing in state law or tradition supports opening the hearings to the public.
DOC.HEAD: FOI Arguments Before South Carolina Supreme Court
DOC.TEXT: The state's open records law would be meaningless if it did not apply to a University of South Carolina foundation that has received and spent public money, two news organizations told the state Supreme Court Nov. 27. ``The decision of this court ... will determine whether this powerful law is really meaningful or whether this is a make-believe world of form over substance,'' said Wallace Lightsey, attorney for The Associated Press and The Greenville News. The Carolina Research and Development Foundation has appealed a lower court order to make the records public. Circuit Judge Carol Connor ruled in June 1989 that the foundation was subject to the Freedom of Information Act because it accepted and spent about $28 million in public money. Her order was set aside pending the outcome of the foundation's appeal to the Supreme Court. Foundation attorney Hoover Blanton said the FOI law should not apply to a private group unless a large amount of the group's budget came from public money. Attorneys did not expect a ruling until next year.
DOC.HEAD: Court Keeps Alive Fair-Housing Suit Over Condo Ads
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Nov. 26 refused to kill two fair-housing lawsuits stemming from newspaper real estate advertisements showing only white models posing as homeowners. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that forces developers of a Virginia condominium community to defend themselves in a jury trial against allegations they violated federal law. The suits center on ads that appeared in The Washington Post over a 17-month period beginning in 1985 for Colonial Village, a condo community in Arlington, just across the Potomac River from the District of Columbia. The suits were filed by Girardeau Spann, a black resident of Washington who is a professor at Georgetown University's law school, and two advocacy groups - the Metropolitan Washington Planning and Housing Association and the Fair Housing Council of Greater Washington. Named as defendants are Colonial Village Inc., and its parent firm, Mobil Land Development Corp., a subsidiary of the oil company. The lawsuits allege that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by featuring only white models in ads that appeared in the Post. The suits said the ads were racially preferential and discriminatory, and they sought an injunction and monetary damages. A federal trial judge in 1987 threw out the suits, ruling they had been filed too late. But the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here reinstated them last March 13, and sent the dispute back to U.S. District Judge Harold Greene for trial.
DOC.HEAD: Pulitzer Board Changes 2 Categories
DOC.TEXT: The Pulitzer Prize Board said Nov. 26 it has renamed and redefined two journalism categories. The category that had been General News Reporting has been renamed Spot News Reporting, and will be given for local reporting of spot news. It was formerly given for local reporting of spot news or consistent beat coverage. The category that had been Specialized Reporting has been renamed Beat Reporting. Its former definition was ``for reporting on such specialized subjects as sports, business, science, education or religion.'' Now, the category will cover ``any form of consistent, specialized reporting, from police beat coverage to religion writing,'' said Robert C. Christopher, board secretary and prize administrator. ``The board's intention was to give these two category definitions greater clarity and simplicity and eliminate any appearance of overlap between them,'' Christopher said in a statement. The deadline is Feb. 1 for submitting articles, photographs and cartoons published in daily or weekly U.S. newspapers during 1990. The winners will be announced April 9, 1991. The other journalism categories are: Public Service, Investigative Reporting, Explanatory Journalism, National Reporting, International Reporting, Feature Writing, Commentary, Criticism, Editorial Writing, Editorial Cartooning, Spot News Photography and Feature Photography.
DOC.HEAD: Sister of Duchess Awarded Defamation Damages
DOC.TEXT: The Duchess of York's sister, Jane Makim, was awarded $234,000 (U.S.) in damages Nov. 27 by a jury that ruled three newspapers defamed her in 1988. The jurors found that The Daily Telegraph, The Sunday Telegraph and The Australian implied Mrs. Makim had an affair with Argentine polo player Horatio Lanusse and wrongfully attempted or threatened to remove her two children from Australia. Mrs. Makim, the 33-year-old sister of the former Sarah Ferguson, now Britain's Duchess of York, said, ``My reputation has been totally vindicated.'' In addition to the award, Nationwide News, publisher of the three Sydney-based newspapers, must pay interest and Mrs. Makim's legal fees. Mrs. Makim was separated from her rancher husband, Alex Makim, 11 months ago. She wept as she told the jury she was ``embarrassed and humiliated'' by the articles. The publisher's attorney, Ian Callinan, argued she suffered no damage from the stories.
DOC.HEAD: Indonesia Warns Foreign Reporters
DOC.TEXT: Information Minister Harmoko was quoted Nov. 29 as defending government restrictions on foreign journalists, saying it will continue to ban those who offend Indonesia's leader. The comment followed government banning of a New York Times reporter who wrote an article saying President Suharto's children enjoy lucrative business ties to most major government projects. ``We will be consistent. I will blacklist such journalists,'' Harmoko said Nov. 28, according to news reports. He spoke after the intallation of Indonesian Press Council members. Harmoko said the policy applied only to foreign publications circulated in Indonesia.

DOC.HEAD: Britain's Sunday Correspondent Closes After 14 Months
DOC.TEXT: The Sunday Correspondent, a nationally distributed weekly newspaper launched last year, has closed after failing to meet circulation targets. The newspaper was started at a cost of $25.5 million and included the Chicago Tribune among its shareholders. Sales of the paper fell below the 350,000 figure needed to break even and last August shareholders pumped in another $19 million to keep it going. The paper's chief executive, Nick Shott, said Nov. 27 that its final circulation had fallen to 210,000. The closing leaves Britain with 10 national weekly Sunday newspapers. Like its competitors and TV and radio stations, the paper has been hit by falling advertising revenue in Britain's current economic recession. Shott said the closing will mean the loss of about 200 jobs.
DOC.HEAD: Report: CBS Considers Stock Buyback
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. is considering a share repurchase program, following the disclosure that it expects a fourth-quarter loss and lower earnings next year, a published report said. The media company's stock fell after the Nov. 19 earnings forecast, although it gained ground later along with other media stocks. The Wall Street Journal said Nov. 29 that people familiar with the proposal said CBS is considering a so-called Dutch auction as one share buyback option. In a Dutch auction, a company states the number of shares it wants to buy in a specified period and gives a price range within which shareholders may tender their shares. The company then selects a price in the range that will enable it to buy all the shares it needs. That might enable CBS to buy back part or all of the 8 percent stake held by the estate of the late CBS founder, William S. Paley. Paley's shares are to be divided among his six children but may have to be sold to cover tax obligations. CBS had no immediate comment on the report. In the earnings forecast, CBS said it expected to post a loss in the fourth quarter compared with earnings of about $60 million in the same period a year ago because of losses at its CBS Television Network. CBS has only posted one other quarterly loss from continuing operations in its history, and that was $20 million in the fourth quarter of 1986. The company also said it expects its earnings from continuing operations in 1991 will be down from this year because of a weak ad climate and rising costs for entertainment programs and sports rights.
DOC.HEAD: `60 Minutes' Target of Lawsuit, Letter Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Washington apple growers are suing CBS and an environmental group over a ``60 Minutes'' report they say damaged their livelihood by creating a scare about the growth chemical Alar. In a separate dispute in Youngstown, Ohio, college students and the head of a local public relations firm plan to send a form letter to newspapers across the country, claiming another segment on the show inaccurately portrayed their city. The Alar lawsuit, filed Nov. 28 in state court, seeks unspecified damages running to millions of dollars for losses it said were caused by the program's ``false, misleading, scientifically unreliable statements.'' The industry has estimated growers lost more than $100 million following the 1989 broadcast, which was based on a report by the Natural Resources Defense Council, a consumer group. ``We believe the broadcast highlighted an important public health matter,'' said Roy Brunett, spokesman for ``60 Minutes.'' ``It was well researched and well documented and we expect a lawsuit ... to be dismissed.'' The Washington, D.C.-based consumer group said it stood behind the report. The Youngstown dispute concerns a Nov. 11 segment featuring an interview with U.S. Rep. James Traficant, who expressed concern for the city's economy. Correspondent Morley Safer described the city as ``practically an industrial ghost town.'' Vic Rubenstein, president of the public relations firm, Rubenstein Associates, said the city's letter-writing campaign was intended to correct what he said was a misconception. The letter said Youngstown has made a comeback: ``Although there is still lingering pain caused by the closing of our steel mills, we have recovered far better than so many communities of like circumstances,'' it said. Rubenstein said the letters, signed by ``a dozen caring Youngstown State University students,'' should reach about 1,500 newspapers. Brunett said the segment was accurate and was not intended to insult anyone.
DOC.HEAD: MacNeil-Lehrer To Begin English-Spanish Broadcasts Next Year
DOC.TEXT: Public broadcasting's ``MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour'' will add simultaneous Spanish translations in January, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting said Nov. 28. The CPB, which is contributing $290,000 to fund a year of English-Spanish broadcasts, said ``MacNeil-Lehrer'' would be the first major nationally distributed news program to offer simultaneous second-language translation. Some TV stations provide bilingual broadcasts for local audiences.
DOC.HEAD: Jane Pauley, Tom Brokaw Get New Shows
DOC.TEXT: NBC is deploying Jane Pauley in the Sunday night ratings wars opposite ABC's top-rated ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' and CBS' durable ``Murder, She Wrote.'' The battles start Jan. 6 at 8 p.m. EST when Pauley's ``Real Life With Jane Pauley'' starts. It will be followed by another NBC News series, ``Expose,'' an investigative program with Tom Brokaw as anchorman. Each program will be a half-hour series for three Sundays each month. Pauley's show will get a full hour on the fourth Sunday and Brokaw's ``Expose'' will have the night off. The two programs will take over the time slot now occupied by the medical series ``Lifestories.''
DOC.HEAD: Whittle Says More Than 5,700 Schools Signed Up for Channel One
DOC.TEXT: Whittle Communications said Nov. 26 that more than 5,700 schools have signed contracts for its commercially sponsored Channel One news show for teens and that it expects to reach its goal of 8,600 schools by June. Chairman Christopher Whittle said all of the service's available commercial time has been either sold or optioned for sale to 13 different advertisers for the January-June period. Ed Winter, the Whittle executive overseeing Channel One, told reporters at a news briefing that Channel One should generate $65 million in gross revenue this school year. The Channel One service has been widely criticized by national education groups for bringing paid advertising into the classroom, when children are required by law to be in school and must sit and watch. Each 12-minute show includes two minutes of paid commercials for products such as breath mints, candy bars, movies and toothpaste.

DOC.HEAD: AP Bureau Chiefs Named in Atlanta, Detroit
DOC.TEXT: Henry Ackerman, chief of bureau for The Associated Press in Detroit since 1987, was named chief of bureau for Georgia and Alabama on Nov. 27. He will be succeeded in Michigan by Charles Hill, bureau chief in Minneapolis since 1984. The appointments were announced by AP President Louis D. Boccardi. In Atlanta, Ackerman succeeds Carl Bell, who is retiring Jan. 1. Ackerman, 48, began his AP career as a vacation-relief broadcast newsman in New York City in 1968 and started full-time service on the news cooperative's World Services Desk in 1972. A year later he was named news editor in Buenos Aires, Argentina. He was appointed chief of bureau in Lima, Peru, in 1975. In 1978 he was named bureau chief in Caracas, Venezuela. He returned to the United States in 1980 as Cleveland correspondent. Two years later he was selected as bureau chief for Louisiana and Mississippi, based in New Orleans. In 1987 Ackerman was appointed chief of bureau for Michigan. Hill, 37, began his AP career in his native Charlotte, N.C., in 1975 and took another temporary assignment later that year in Raleigh, N.C. In 1976, he moved to Hartford, Conn., as a probationary newsman. Two years later, Hill was appointed news editor for Connecticut. He transferred to Washington, D.C., as an editor in 1980. A year later, he moved to Dallas as a desk supervisor. In 1982, Hill was named correspondent in Houston and in 1983 he returned to Dallas as assistant chief of bureau for Texas. He was promoted a year later to bureau chief for Minnesota, North Dakota and South Dakota. In 1989, Hill directed the transition when the Dakotas were split off as a separate AP territory and Tena Haraldson was named the Dakotas' first chief of bureau, in Sioux Falls, S.D.
DOC.HEAD: Fischer to Vice President at Freedom
DOC.TEXT: Scott Fischer, publisher of The News Herald in Panama City since 1980, has been named senior vice president of Freedom Newspapers Inc., the company announced. He will be succeeded by Karen Hanes, 40, of the Lesher Newspaper organization in northern California. She has held several positions with Lesher, including general manager of the Valley Times in Pleasanton, Calif. Fischer, 45, will oversee Freedom's community newspapers west of the Mississippi River and will be responsible for capital budgeting for the company when he assumes his new duties in Orange County, Calif., in January.
DOC.HEAD: Executives Named at Two Kentucky Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: The American Publishing Co. announced the appointment of top executives at The Harlan Daily Enterprise and The Daily News of Middlesboro. Elaine Nelson, advertising director at the Enterprise, becomes publisher, succeeding Ewell Balltrip. Balltrip also was publisher at The Daily News, and that appointment went to James T. Hurst, an employee of the newspaper since 1954. Balltrip left to accept another publisher's position with The New York Times Co. It recently sold both newspapers and the Claiborne, Tenn., Progress to American Publishing. Nelson has been with the Harlan newspaper for four years. A native of Tullahoma, Tenn., she previously served as publisher and general manager for The Elk Valley Times in Fayetteville, Tenn., and advertising director for The Gallup, N.M., Independent. Hurst, who has extensive experience in the circulation, advertising and production departments, said the newspaper will immediately lower its newsstand price from 50 cents to 35 cents.
DOC.HEAD: Huddleson Named Alliance Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Tom Huddleson, editor of the weekly Geneva Signal, was named managing editor of the Alliance Times-Herald on Nov. 27. He succeeds Scott Smith. Publisher Fred Kuhlman said that Larry Hvranek, assistant managing editor of The Hastings Tribune, is acting managing editor until Huddleson joins the staff on Dec. 17. The Tribune and Times-Herald are Seaton Group newspapers.

Ruth Brummel Washington, publisher of the city's leading black newspaper, the Los Angeles Sentinel, died of cancer Nov. 30. She was 76. Mrs. Washington was the widow of Sentinel founder and civil rights activist Leon H. Washington. The paper was started in 1933 and reached a peak circulation of 56,000 in the 1960s. In recent years circulation has slipped to about 25,000. Mrs. Washington briefly took over the newspaper when her husband became ill in 1948, then served as business manager. She was named publisher after her husband died in 1974. Under her direction the Sentinel emphasized coverage of urban community issues and civil rights. Survivors include a sister, three nieces and four nephews.

Merrill Windsor, a former managing editor of Sunset magazine and an editor at National Geographic and Arizona Highways magazine, died Dec. 2 of cancer. He was 66. Windsor was editor of Arizona Highways from 1985 until his retirement in February. He also worked as a reporter at The Arizona Republic from 1951 to 1956. Survivors include his wife, three children, a brother, sister and seven grandchildren.

Kuwaiti college students are producing a weekly cable television show to publicize the plight of their country under Iraq's domination. ``Students for a Free Kuwait'' began Oct. 9 on Continental Cablevision in Pomona, Claremont, Ontario and Fullerton, Calif. ``This is part of fighting the Iraqis,'' said co-host Fahed Bouresli, 25. Producer and co-host Randa Milliron, a Chaffey College broadcasting instructor, agreed: ``We're calling it guerrilla television.''
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: President Bush opened a five-country South America visit today to show support for the historic shift to democratic rule and for policies aimed at ending long years of economic stagnation. Bush seemed in good spirits as he arrived at dawn at a military air base here. He smiled and shook hands as he was greeted by Foreign Minister Francisco Rezek and an air force honor guard. Bush was driven to the U.S. Embassy residence to await his formal welcoming ceremony with President Fernando Collor de Mello at Planalto Palace. Bush's plane arrived at dawn in the Brazilian capital of Brasilia, and the president was proceeding to talks with President Fernando Collor de Mello and a speech to a joint session of the Brazilian Congress. There are no urgent issues to be discussed, but Bush wants to associate himself with what he sees as a rare opportunity in hemispheric relations. The first four countries on Bush's itinerary - Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina and Chile - all were under military rule within the last few years and now have elected governments. The fifth country, Venezuela, has been democratic since 1958. Bush is making the trip at a time of unusual harmony in U.S.-Latin American relations. ---=

Saddam Hussein says he expects the Palestinian question to be on the agenda of talks with U.S. officials on preventing war, for which Iraq has shown itself to be preparing with the test-firing of medium-range missiles. The surface-to-surface missiles, with a range of 400 miles, were fired and landed Sunday within Iraqi territory. Iraq fitted similar weapons with conventional warheads during its eight-year war with Iran, but they could also be equipped with chemical weapons, Defense Secreatary Dick Cheney said in an interview on ABC-TV. The U.S. military refused to confirm or deny reports that allied forces in the Persian Gulf went on alert after detecting the missiles, presumably with spy satellites or AWACS airborne early-warning radar planes. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The Bush administration says Iraqi President Saddam Hussein poses a long-term threat to world peace and ``has to be dealt with'' even if he withdraws Iraqi troops from Kuwait and frees western hostages. In television appearances Sunday, administration officials promised Iraq a peaceful way to end its occupation of Kuwait but still branded the Iraqi leader as a dangerous man whose larger military ambitions must be checked. ``There's never been any suggestion that force would be used if the U.N. resolutions were fully complied with,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said on NBC-TV's ``Meet The Press.'' ``That would give some assurance, it seems to me, that if he complied with the resolutions, his reward for that would not be a military attack by the United States,'' Baker said. ---= BONN, Germany (AP) - Opposition parties who showed reluctance to jump on Chancellor Helmut Kohl's reunification steamroller were largely left by the wayside in the first free all-German elections in nearly 60 years. For the environmentalist Greens, Sunday's vote spelled disaster. Kohl's center-right governing coalition won 54.8 percent of the vote, compared to 335 percent for the main opposition Social Democrats, who were led by Oskar Lafontaine, according to nearly complete official results. The elections marked the first free balloting in a united Germany since Adolf Hitler's rise to power ended in the devastation of World War II. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - A published report today says the FBI is conducting a criminal investigation that could lead to charges against two of the so-called ``Keating Five'' senators. The Washington Times, quoting unidentified congressional and law enforcement sources, said the ``wide-ranging'' investigation involved allegations of vote trading and bribery against Sens. Alan Cranston and Dennis DeConcini. The report comes as the Senate Ethics Committee this week shifts the focus of its hearings into the matter to Cranston, the major beneficiary of $1.3 million in Senate campaign contributions from savings and loan owner Charles H. Keating Jr. The Times said also that an FBI source had confirmed for the newspaper that a federal grand jury sitting in California was reviewing evidence involving Cranston, D-Calif., and DeConcini, D-Ariz. The newspaper said it had no other details on that matter. ---= SPACE CENTER, Houston (AP) - Trouble with the $150 million Astro observatory today delayed Columbia astronauts' probe of some of the hottest spots in the universe. NASA officials had trouble calibrating the observatory's instrument pointing system - which affects all three telescopes - and also had problems with a computer that controls the movements of one telescope. Mission scientist Gene Urban at Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., remained confident. ``The mission is poised to do extremely good science. We are in an extremely good orbit and three of the experiments (telescopes) have been activated almost completely,'' he said early today. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Aaron Copland, the immigrants' son from Brooklyn who used jazz rhythms of the South, folk songs of Appalachia and cowboy tunes of the prairie to create classical music that was unmistakably American, has died at 90. The composer, who lived in Peekskill, died Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown of pneumonia. He had suffered two strokes recently. The ``dean of American music'' created such classics as ``Appalachian Spring,'' ``Rodeo,'' ``Billy the Kid'' and ``Lincoln Portrait.'' Leonard Bernstein once called Copland's 1942 orchestral composition ``Fanfare for the Common Man'' the ``all-time top of the hit parade in American music.'' The son of Eastern European immigrants, he strove to be more American than most Americans and sought to focus the international spotlight on his fellow American composers. ---= MARKED TREE, Ark. (AP) - Dozens of schools along the New Madrid Fault canceled classes today just in case the earth rumbles as forecast. And farm animals will decide whether classes should be held in one Illinois county. Judy Byrd of Evansville, Ind., gave in to her 11-year-old son's request to stay home even though she doesn't believe earthquakes can be forecast. ``At this age, they really worry about everything. War. An earthquake. Water. The environment,'' Mrs. Byrd said. ``I figured if he really was that worried about it, it should be up to him.'' The nervousness was prompted by New Mexico climatologist Iben Browning's forecast of a 50-50 chance for a major earthquake along the fault this week. ---= FREDERICK, Md. (AP) - The Russians asking questions about basketball over the Moscow-to-Washington hot line? The Cold War really must be over. Experts manning the hot line, which was to be rededicated today afeer a $4.7 million upgrade, see evidence of glasnost in test transmissions from the Soviets. Routine, maintenance-related dispatches have actually become chatty. ``Could we ask an unofficial question about basketball?'' the Soviets asked last February over the communications link set up after the Cuban missile crisis to avert the accidental outbreak of war. ``Could you please tell us how our Kurtinaitis performed against your snipers?'' The Soviets were referring to Rimas Kurtinaitis, a 6-foot-5 star from Lithuania. The National Basketball Association had invited Kurtinaitis to challenge eight NBA stars in a three-point shooting contest in Houston. ``Snipers'' apparently was the Soviets' translation of long-range basketball shooters.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Sunday, Dec. 9, the 343rd day of 1990. There are 22 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Dec. 9, 1907, Christmas seals went on sale for the first time, in the Wilmington, Del., post office. The proceeds went to fight tuberculosis. On this date: In 1608, English poet John Milton was born in London. In 1854, Alfred Lord Tennyson's famous poem, ``The Charge of the Light Brigade,'' was published in England. In 1884, Levant M. Richardson of Chicago received a patent for the ball-bearing roller skate. In 1940, 50 years ago, British troops opened their first major offensive in North Africa during World War II. In 1941, China declared war on Japan, Germany and Italy. In 1958, Robert H.W. Welch Jr. and 11 other men met in Indianapolis to form the anti-Communist John Birch Society. In 1965, 25 years ago, Nikolai V. Podgorny replaced Anastas I. Mikoyan as president of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet. In 1975, President Ford signed a $2.3 billion seasonal loan-authorization that officials of New York City and State said would prevent a city default. In 1979, Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen, the religious broadcaster, died in New York City at the age of 84. In 1982, Leon Jaworski, the Watergate special prosecutor who played a key role in forcing the resignation of President Nixon in 1974, died at his Wimberly, Texas, ranch at age 77. In 1984, the five-day-old hijacking of a Kuwaiti jetliner that claimed the lives of two Americans ended as Iranian security men seized control of the plane, which was parked at Tehran airport. Ten years ago: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that a law giving the federal government the authority to appeal a criminal sentence it felt was too lenient did not constitute ``double jeopardy'' under the Bill of Rights. Five years ago: Dale Burr, a Johnson County, Iowa, farmer suffering financial troubles, shot and killed his wife, a neighbor and the president of a local bank before taking his own life. In Argentina, five former military junta members received prison sentences for their roles in the so-called ``dirty war'' against subversives waged during the 1970's. One year ago: President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger began a surprise visit to Beijing, six months after China's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. Today's Birthdays: Actor Douglas Fairbanks Jr. is 81. Former House Speaker Thomas ``Tip'' O'Neill is 78. Actor Kirk Douglas is 74. Comedian Redd Foxx is 68. Actress Dina Merrill is 65. Actor Dick Van Patten is 62. Actor Beau Bridges is 49. Football Hall-of-Famer Dick Butkus is 48. Singer Joan Armatrading is 40. Actor John Malkovich is 37. Singer Donny Osmond is 33. Thought for Today: ``The well of Providence is deep. It's the buckets we bring to it that are small.'' - Mary Webb, Scottish religious leader (c.1881-1927).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Monday, Dec. 10, the 344th day of 1990. There are 21 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Dec. 10, 1906, President Theodore Roosevelt became the first American to be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, for helping to mediate an end to the Russo-Japanese War. On this date: In 1520, Martin Luther publicly burned the papal edict demanding that he recant, or face excommunication. In 1817, Mississippi was admitted to the Union as the 20th state. In 1830, poet Emily Dickinson was born in Amherst, Mass. In 1869, women were granted the right to vote in the Wyoming Territory. In 1898, a treaty was signed in Paris officially ending the Spanish-American War. In 1931, Jane Addams became a co-recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize, the first American woman so honored. In 1948, the United Nations General Assembly adopted its Universal Declaration on Human Rights. In 1950, Ralph J. Bunche was presented the Nobel Peace Prize, the first black American to receive the award. In 1958, the first domestic passenger jet flight took place in the U.S. as a National Airlines Boeing 707 flew 111 passengers from New York to Miami in about 2{ hours. In 1964, civil rights activist Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. received the Nobel Peace Prize during ceremonies in Oslo, Norway. In 1967, singer Otis Redding died in the crash of his private plane in Wisconsin. He was 26. In 1983, Raul Alfonsin was inaugurated as Argentina's first civilian president after nearly eight years of military rule. In 1984, South African Bishop Desmond Tutu received the Nobel Peace Prize. Ten years ago: Soviet President Leonid I. Brezhnev, on a visit to India, proposed a plan aimed at easing tensions in the Persian Gulf. Rep. John W. Jenrette, D-S.C., resigned to avoid being expelled from the House following his conviction on charges relating to the FBI's ``ABSCAM'' investigation. Five years ago: The Nobel Peace Prize was awarded in Oslo, Norway, to the American and Soviet co-founders of the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, an honor veiled in controversy because of the Soviet founder's ties to the Kremlin. One year ago: Czechoslovakia's president, Gustav Husak, resigned after swearing in a coalition cabinet in which Communists were relegated to a minority role. Today's Birthdays: Composer-conductor Morton Gould, the president of ASCAP, is 77. Actress Dorothy Lamour is 76. Actor Harold Gould is 67. The secretary of agriculture, Clayton Yeutter, is 60. Actress Susan Dey is 38. Thought for Today: ``The people who think they are happy should rummage through their dreams.'' - Edward Dahlberg, American author and critic (1900-1977).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Tuesday, Dec. 11, the 345th day of 1990. There are 20 days left in the year. Tonight marks the beginning of Hanukkah, the eight-day Jewish ``Feast of Lights.'' Today's Highlight in History: On Dec. 11, 1936, Britain's King Edward the Eighth abdicated in order to marry American divorcee Wallis Warfield Simpson. In a radio address, Edward said he ``would have found it impossible'' to carry out his duties as king ``without the help and support of the woman I love.'' On this date: In 1719, the first recorded sighting of the Aurora Borealis took place in New England. In 1792, France's King Louis XVI went on trial, accused of treason. (Convicted and condemned, Louis was sent to the guillotine the following January.) In 1816, Indiana became the 19th state of the union. In 1872, America's first black governor took office as Pinckney Benton Stewart Pinchback became acting governor of Louisiana. In 1882, Boston's Bijou Theatre, the first American playhouse to be lighted exclusively by electricity, gave its first performance, of Gilbert and Sullivan's ``Iolanthe.'' In 1928, police in Buenos Aires thwarted an attempt on the life of President-elect Hoover. In 1937, Italy withdrew from the League of Nations. In 1941, Germany and Italy declared war on the United States. In 1946, the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund (``UNICEF'') was established. In 1961, a U.S. aircraft carrier carrying Army helicopters arrived in Saigon - the first direct American military support for South Vietnam's battle against Communist guerrillas. In 1981, the U.N. Security Council chose Javier Perez de Cuellar of Peru to be the fifth secretary-general of the world body. Ten years ago: President Carter signed into a law legislation creating a $1.6 billion environmental superfund to pay for cleaning up chemical spills and toxic waste dumps. President-elect Reagan announced eight Cabinet appointments, including his choice of Donald T. Regan to be Treasury Secretary and Caspar Weinberger to be Defense Secretary. Five years ago: The U.S. House of Representatives joined the Senate in giving final congressional approval to the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law, intended to eliminate the federal government's red ink by fiscal 1991. One year ago: President Bush, facing criticism at home for sending two U.S. officials to China, defended the diplomatic overture despite the Beijing government's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators the previous June. Today's Birthdays: Producer Carlo Ponti is 77. Nobel Prize-winning author Alexander Solzhenitsyn is 72. Actress Betsy Blair is 67. Actor Jean-Louis Trintignant is 60. Actress Rita Moreno is 59. Actor Ron Carey is 55. California state assemblyman Tom Hayden is 51. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., is 49. Actress Donna Mills is 47. Singer Brenda Lee is 46. Actress Lynda Day George is 44. Movie director Susan Seidelman is 38. Actress Bess Armstrong is 37. Singer Jermaine Jackson is 36. Thought for Today: ``Better by far you should forget and smile Than that you should remember and be sad.'' - Christina Rosetti, British poet (1830-1874).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Wednesday, Dec. 12, the 346th day of 1990. There are 19 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Dec. 12, 1787, Pennsylvania became the second state to ratify the U.S. Constitution. On this date: In 1792, in Vienna, 22-year-old Ludwig van Beethoven received his first lesson in music composition from Franz Joseph Haydn. In 1870, Joseph H. Rainey of South Carolina became the first black sworn into the U.S. House of Representatives. In 1901, the first radio signal to cross the Atlantic was picked up near St. John's, Newfoundland, by inventor Guglielmo Marconi. (The signal was transmitted from a point some two-thousand miles away.) In 1913, authorities in Florence, Italy, announced that the ``Mona Lisa,'' stolen from the Louvre Museum in Paris in 1911, had been recovered. In 1917, Father Edward Flanagan founded Boys Town outside Omaha, Neb. In 1925, the first motel - the ``Motel Inn'' - opened in San Luis Obispo, California. In 1937, Japanese aircraft sank the U.S. gunboat ``Panay'' on China's Yangtze River. (Japan apologized for the attack and paid $2.2 million in reparations.) In 1946, a United Nations committee voted to accept a six-block tract of Manhattan real estate offered as a gift by John D. Rockefeller Jr. to be the site of U.N. headquarters. In 1947, the United Mine Workers union withdrew from the American Federation of Labor. In 1963, Kenya gained its independence from Britain. In 1975, Sara Jane Moore pleaded guilty to a charge of trying to kill President Ford in San Francisco the previous September. In 1979, in response to the Iran hostage crisis, the Carter administration ordered the removal of most Iranian diplomats in the United States. Ten years ago: NATO foreign ministers meeting in Brussels issued a communique warning the Soviet Union that military intervention in Poland would wreck East-West detente. Five years ago: 248 American soldiers and eight crew members were killed when an Arrow Air charter crashed after takeoff from the airport in Gander, Newfoundland. One year ago: Amid international criticism, Britain forcibly removed 51 Vietnamese from Hong Kong and returned them to their homeland. In New York, hotel queen Leona Helmsley was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $7.1 million for her conviction on 33 counts of tax evasion. (She remains free pending her appeal.) Today's Birthdays: Frank Sinatra is 75. TV host Bob Barker is 67. Former New York City Mayor Edward Koch is 66. Singer Connie Francis is 52. Singer Dionne Warwick is 49. Jazz musician Grover Washington Junior is 47. Gymnast-turned-actress Cathy Rigby is 38. Singer-musician Sheila E. is 31. Thought for Today: ``To escape criticism - do nothing, say nothing, be nothing.'' - Elbert Hubbard, American author and publisher (1856-1915).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Thursday, Dec. 13, the 347th day of 1990. There are 18 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Dec. 13, 1577, five ships commanded by Sir Francis Drake embarked on Drake's famous circumnavigation of the globe, a journey that took almost three years. On this date: In 1642, New Zealand was discovered by Dutch navigator Abel Tasman. In 1769, Dartmouth College, in New Hampshire, received its charter. In 1835, Phillips Brooks, the American Episcopal bishop who wrote the words to ``O Little Town of Bethlehem,'' was born in Boston. In 1862, Union forces suffered a major defeat at the hands of the Confederates at the Battle of Fredericksburg. In 1918, President Wilson arrived in France, becoming the first chief executive to visit a European country while in office. In 1928, George Gershwin's musical work ``An American in Paris'' had its premiere, at Carnegie Hall in New York. In 1944, during World War II, a Japanese ``kamikaze'' plane crashed into the U.S. cruiser ``Nashville,'' killing 138 crewmen. In 1964, in a ceremony in El Paso, Texas, President Lyndon B. Johnson and Mexican president Gustavo Diaz Ordaz set off an explosion that diverted the Rio Grande, reshaping the U.S.-Mexican border and ending a century-old dispute. In 1978, the Philadelphia Mint began stamping the Susan B. Anthony dollar, which went into circulation the following July. In 1981, authorities in Poland imposed martial law in a crackdown on the Solidarity labor movement. (Major provisions of the decree were lifted a year later; martial law was formally ended in 1983.) In 1983, Martha Layne Collins was inaugurated as Kentucky's first female governor. In 1988, PLO chairman Yasser Arafat addressed the U.N. General Assembly in Geneva, where it had reconvened after the U.S. refused to grant Arafat a visa to visit New York. Ten years ago: In El Salvador, Christian Democrat Jose Napoleon Duarte was named the president of the country's new government. Five years ago: Investigators were probing the crash of an Arrow Air DC-8 charter in Gander, Newfoundland, that had claimed the lives of 248 U.S. servicemen and eight American crew members the day before. One year ago: South African President F.W. de Klerk met for the first time with imprisoned African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, at de Klerk's office in Cape Town. Today's Birthdays: Former Secretary of State George P. Shultz is 70. Actor-comedian Dick Van Dyke is 65. Actor Christopher Plummer is 63. Singer John Davidson is 49. Singer Ted Nugent is 42. Thought for Today: ``To know how to say what others only know how to think is what makes men poets or sages; and to dare to say what others only dare to think makes men martyrs or reformers -- or both.'' -- Elizabeth Charles, British writer (1828-1896).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Saturday, Dec. 15, the 349th day of 1990. There are 16 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: One hundred years ago, on December 15th, 1890, Sioux Indian Chief Sitting Bull and 11 other tribe members were killed in Grand River, S.D., during a fracas with Indian police working for the U.S. government. (Other violence followed, included the massacre of some 300 Sioux Indians at Wounded Knee Creek.) On this date: In 1791, the first 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution - the Bill of Rights - went into effect following ratification by Virginia. In 1916, the French defeated the Germans in the World War I Battle of Verdun. In 1938, groundbreaking ceremonies for the Jefferson Memorial took place in Washington D.C., presided over by President Franklin D. Roosevelt. In 1939, ``Gone With the Wind,'' producer David O. Selznick's movie version of the Margaret Mitchell novel starring Vivien Leigh and Clark Gable, had its world premiere at Loew's Grand Theater in Atlanta. In 1944, a plane carrying bandleader Glenn Miller - a U.S. Army major - disappeared during a flight over the English Channel. In 1948, former State Department official Alger Hiss was indicted by a federal grand jury in New York on charges of perjury. (He was convicted in 1950.) In 1961, former Nazi official Adolf Eichmann was sentenced to death in Jerusalem. In 1964, Canada's House of Commons approved dropping the Canadian ``Red Ensign'' flag in favor of a new design. In 1965, 25 years ago, two U.S. manned spacecraft, Gemini VI and Gemini VII,'' rendezvoused in orbit, coming within 10 feet of each other. In 1966, movie producer Walt Disney died in Los Angeles. In 1978, President Carter announced he would grant diplomatic recognition to Communist China on New Year's Day and sever official relations with Taiwan. In 1979, the deposed Shah of Iran left the United States for Panama, the same day the International Court of Justice in The Hague ruled that Iran should release all its American hostages. In 1982, Paul ``Bear'' Bryant, one of the winningest coaches in college football, announced his retirement from the University of Alabama. (In a 38-year career, Bryant had a then-record of 322 wins, 85 losses and 17 ties.) Ten years ago: Ronald Reagan was elected President of the United States by the Electoral College, which cast 489 votes for the Republican nominee and 49 votes for President Carter. Five years ago: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, on a whirlwind tour of six European countries, met in Bucharest with Romanian President Nicolae Ceausescu to discuss Romania's human rights record. One year ago: A popular uprising that resulted in the downfall of Romania's Nicolae Ceausescu began as demonstrators gathered in Timisoara to prevent the arrest of the Reverend Laszlo Tokes, a dissident clergyman. Drug trafficker Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha was killed in northern Colombia following a shootout with police. Today's Birthdays: Actor-comedian Tim Conway is 57. Actor Don Johnson is 41. Thought for Today: ``We are all citizens of history.'' - Clifton Fadiman, American author, editor and radio personality (1904- ).
