DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - He was a farm boy from Kansas with his eyes on the skies, a tinkerer who could build telescopes but had never been to college. Then one day in 1930 Clyde Tombaugh spotted a dot in the heavens that would change his life forever, not to mention change the study of astronomy.

Sixty years ater he discovered the planet Pluto spinning three billion miles from Earth, Clyde Tombaugh can't keep his hands off telescopes. At age 84, Tombaugh is supposed to be retired, resting on his laurels as one of only four people ever to have discovered a planet. Instead, the snowy-haired astronomer is still crisscrossing the country, lecturing about Pluto to raise funds for post-doctoral astronomy students at New Mexico State University, where he taught for 12 years. And he's still building telescopes, which is how the former farm boy got started in astronomy in the first place. At the moment, he's working on one for his 16-year-old granddaughter. ``I'm going to have her do some of the polishing, and have her test the curve,'' he says. ``She's going to get a good introduction to it.'' Tombaugh has no hobbies that aren't related to astronomy, his lifelong love. ``I'm always interested in making telescopes, grinding mirrors and so on,'' he says. ``I love that.'' On a recent lecture stop in Spencerport, the planet hunter handled a throng of elementary school students with the experienced patter of a cornball comedian. ``That's a very good question!'' he told a girl who asked how Pluto got its name. The name was chosen by scientists at Lowell Observatory, where the planet was discovered, he says. Then, with his face crinkling into a wide grin, he adds: ``Some people think it's named after Pluto the Pup. Of course there's no connection. I think the planet came first - I'm not sure.'' ``How cold is Pluto?'' a student calls out. ``The air that you breathe - nitrogen and oxygen - would be frozen solid rock on Pluto,'' Tombaugh says. ``It'd be a little hard to breathe, wouldn't it?'' Tombaugh was just 24, fresh off his family's Kansas wheat farm with only a high school diploma to his name, when he discovered Pluto in 1930. Six decades later, the discovery remains his proudest achievement. Tombaugh got interested in astronomy in the sixth grade, when his favorite subject was geography. ``I wondered what the geography was like on other planets and I've been at it ever since,'' he says. In high school, Tombaugh built a telescope and spent long hours making careful drawings of Mars and Jupiter. He wanted to be an astronomer, he says, but his family didn't have the money to send him to college. In 1929, Tombaugh's drawings got him hired on a trial basis as an assistant at the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Ariz. He was to help search for a trans-Neptunian planet with the observatory's new 13-inch telescope. Of the nine planets now known to be circling the sun, six had been known since antiquity. The English astronomer William Herschel discovered the seventh, Uranus, in 1781. In 1846, two people are credited with the discovery of Neptune, the eighth, the English astronomer John C. Adams and the French mathematician Urbain J.J. Leverrier. The existence of a ninth planet was predicted in 1915 by Percival Lowell, who believed ``Planet X'' was causing deviations in the orbits of Uranus and Neptune. Tombaugh's job was to compare 14-by-17-inch-photographs of the night sky on a device called a blink-microscope-comparator, which rapidly switched between two images taken several days apart. If a planet were visible, it would have moved to a new position in the second photograph. In more crowded areas of the universe, such as the Milky Way, more than 2,000 stars filled every square inch of the photograph. Each had to be examined for even the most infinitesimal movement. ``It was tedious,'' Tombaugh says. ``But it was much more interesting work than farming, as far as I was concerned.'' On Feb. 18, 1930, Tombagh found what he was looking for. A tiny dot of light had moved an eighth of an inch. ``It electrified me,'' he says. ``In one split second, I realized I'd be world famous and turn the scientific world upside-down. It was a tremendous feeling. ``I was excited, but I didn't go around yelling. I figured it'd just alarm everybody. It alarmed them plenty when I told them I found a planet.'' As it turned out, Lowell's prediction of Planet X's location had just been lucky. Pluto - now estimated to have about two-tenths of a percent of Earth's mass - is much too small to cause irregularities in the other planets' orbits. For finding Pluto, the novice astronomer got a $10 raise and a nominal prize from the Royal Astronomical Society in Great Britain. Later, Tombaugh got a bachelor's and master's degree in astronomy from the University of Kansas and continued combing the skies - discovering a globular star cluster, a supercluster of galaxies, several lesser clusters, one comet and about 775 asteroids, one of which bears his name. Tombaugh lives in Las Cruces, N.M. with Patricia, his wife of 56 years, and a mostly black cat named Pluto. He wears a watch his son had made for him, which features Walt Disney's cartoon dog Pluto. Tombaugh doesn't put much stock in speculation that a 10th planet exists. It could be out there, but it would have to be very small or very far away for him to have missed seeing it on his plates, he says. ``It'd be interesting to see if they ever did find one, but it's going to be some hard digging,'' he says. ``Actually, I'm a little pessimistic about it.'' Tombaugh says he has looked at 45 million stars in his lifetime - more than two-thirds of the visible universe. He has seen more of the heavens' starry expanses than perhaps anyone else. ``I had a grand view of the universe,'' he says. ``I often wonder how people who never had any exposure to this view the world. ``They're not aware of all this universe around them - they think the Earth is it.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - Their names are Olivier and Redgrave and Cusack, three of the most famous names in the London theater. This season several members of those families are teaming up in the same plays, ``a sort of thinking man's Osmonds,'' as one newspaper columnist put it.

Despite some sniping that it smacks of gimmickry, the London theater is celebrating its English and Irish acting dynasties with three productions that are truly family affairs. On Dec. 5, Laurence Olivier's widow, Joan Plowright, opened at the Old Vic Theater in a revival of J.B. Priestley's ``Time and the Conways.'' The cast includes the two Olivier daughters, Tamsin and Julie-Kate, directed by their brother, Richard. One week later, Dec. 11, came the Redgrave sisters, Vanessa and Lynn, in Anton Chekhov's ``The Three Sisters.'' The opening at the Queen's Theater marks their first stage appearance together. The third sister is played by their 24-year-old niece, Jemma Redgrave, the daughter of their actor brother Corin. Jemma joins her cousins, Natasha and Joely Richardson, in the fifth generation of acting Redgraves. Chekhov's masterwork has already been seen in another family production in London this year. That sold-out production, which ended Sept. 29, starred Ireland's Cusack sisters - Sinead, Sorcha and Niamh Cusack - and their father, Cyril. While keenly aware that these ventures are vulnerable to charges of gimmickry, all three families found the blood ties invigorating. ``We were all very aware of the pitfalls,'' says Sorcha Cusack. ``That's why it took us so long to commit ourselves to doing it.'' Lynn Redgrave says, ``Whatever we did together, it had not to be a gimmick. It had to be something that in any legitimate production anywhere we would have been thought of for those parts.'' The productions have been warmly supported by audiences and critics, though not without dissent. ``Lack of box office bankability, singly, is bolstered by the sheer gimmickiness of having all the family work together - a sort of thinking man's Osmonds,'' snarled columnist Julie Burchill in The Mail, a Sunday newspaper. Most commentators, however, were enthusiastic about productions that bring a lifetime of intimacy to the theater. ``I just think that if you've got a vocabulary that goes back 40 years, as is the case with myself and Sorcha, there's no doubt at all that we have a given,'' says Sinead Cusack. ``It's there in our bloodstream, our very being, which is to do with our umbilical cords.'' Sinead, at age 42 the oldest Cusack sister, played Masha, the middle one of Chekhov's trio. Sorcha, 40, played the older Olga. Niamh, 30, played baby sister Irina in a production that looks likely to transfer to New York in the new year. Lynn Redgrave says her family's production resulted from a benefit performance on Dec. 10, 1989, in New York, where Vanessa was finishing her Broadway engagement in Tennessee Williams' ``Orpheus Descending.'' Vanessa was organizing a concert called ``The Wall Breaks'' to benefit victims of Stalin's repression. To conclude the first act, she asked Lynn, Sigourney Weaver and Christopher Reeve to join her in a condensed version of the final scene of ``The Three Sisters.'' ``I was full of nerves about it,'' recalls Lynn Redgrave, 47, the younger sister by six years. ``There was a real sort of quiet in the house, and one realized: Here we were walking forward for the first time.'' Before long, a project was born. ``The minute we did the concert, I knew this could work, which is why we so wholeheartedly went into it,'' she says. ``The Three Sisters'' is actually the second sisters' act for the Redgraves. Four days before rehearsals began, they completed a TV remake of the 1962 horror film, ``Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?'' It's due to be aired in the United States on ABC in February. Lynn inherits Bette Davis's role as the demented Baby Jane Hudson, with Vanessa filling Joan Crawford's shoes as her crippled sister. ``We haven't spent this much consecutive time together since we were children,'' laughs Lynn Redgrave, who, unlike Vanessa, has based most of her career in the United States. ``It's bringing back memories we haven't had in ages.'' But Lynn says there were times when sibling undercurrents left off and Chekhov's creations took over. ``We feel very much that we are these characters, or our version of these characters,'' she says. ``While we're actually playing it, the family links are a bit more amorphous.'' Sorcha Cusack had a similar experience: ``Obviously, when I'm working, I'm not thinking whether it's my sister or not my sister, but of course they are my sisters; that's something that's there for free. I don't think about it.'' In ``Time and the Conways,'' written in 1937, Joan Plowright plays the matriarch presiding over a brood of kids, two of whom are played by her and Lord Olivier's real-life daughters. ``It can help - well, it does help - a lot because you are dealing with people who are very close to you, and all that feeling of familiarity is there for you,'' says Tamsin Olivier, 27. But her 29-year-old brother Richard, the play's director, stresses that Priestley was writing about the Conways, not the Oliviers. ``I wouldn't want people to `family spot','' he says. ``Hopefully, they come to see the play primarily, and if they enjoy people's performances, then that's terrific.'' Next spring, Timothy West and Prunella Scales - husband and wife in real life - play the fraught Tyrones in Eugene O'Neill's ``Long Day's Journey into Night'' at the Royal National Theater. No word yet on whether their son, Sam West, an actor, will play one of the Tyrones' two sons. Other family connections have yet to be explored. Maggie Smith, the Tony-winning star of Broadway's ``Lettice and Lovage,'' has two sons in drama school. Rosemary Harris' daughter, Jennifer Ehle, is in her last year at London's Central School of Speech and Drama. Susannah York, Edward Woodward and Frank Finlay each have children who have decided to act. In the United States, if famous families appear together at all, it's usually on the screen: Henry and Jane Fonda in ``On Golden Pond,'' Beau and Jeff Bridges in ``The Fabulous Baker Boys,'' the Carradines, Quaids, Guests and Keaches in ``The Long Riders.''

DOC.TEXT: Bill Smitrovich says his portrayal of a ``working class guy'' on ABC's ``Life Goes On'' is patterned after a man who remains a symbol in his own life. ``I put a lot of my father into Drew Thatcher,'' he says. ``He's a throwback to a man who's lived through tough times. I draw the spirit of Drew from my father. They're from the same kind of hard-working background.'' ``Life Goes On'' is about a family facing a financial struggle and the challenge of a son with Downs syndrome. It also stars Patti LuPone as his wife, Libby, Chris Burke as Corky, their son, and Kellie Martin as Becca, their daughter. Smitrovich's father, William S. Smitrovich Sr., who died in 1965, moved his family from Connecticut to New Mexico to California in search of work as a tool and die maker. Bill, the actor, attended 12 different schools before the family returned to Connecticut. His father had asthma ``and often slept sitting up,'' he says. ``But at 6 a.m. every morning he was up and at 'em. He had a sense of duty, pride and workmanship.'' Smitrovich fulfilled his father's dream by getting a degree at the University of Bridgeport. It was in college that he discovered his love of acting. And he gave some of his time to a cause he believes helped him prepare for his role in ``Life Goes On.'' While in college he minored in special education and tutored children with Downs syndrome. After graduation he was a leader in a work shelter for children with Downs syndrome and cerebral palsy. ``Drew's a high-principled man who tries to live for his family,'' Smitrovich says. ``I think he feels that when Corky came into his life that was a message. He's a God-fearing man. Part of him would like to have a `normal' son. And he's a frustrated man because he's never gotten to fulfill some of his dreams. ``He went into construction work because he couldn't become an architect. Now he owns a restaurant because he wants to be his own boss. He's a hard-working, middle-class American who believes in the union and buying American. He believes in the American dream but has probably been burned by it a few times.'' On ``Life Goes On,'' the Thatchers will have another child at the end of the season. LuPone, who is pregnant, filmed her scenes for three shows in advance of her absence for maternity leave. She'll miss several episodes, but she will return afterward and wear a ``fat suit'' until the Thatcher baby is born. ``Life Goes On'' is the second series for Smitrovich, who was Sgt. Danny Krychek in NBC's ``Crime Story.'' He co-starred in ``Crazy People'' and has been in such movies as ``Without a Trace,'' ``Splash,'' ``Maria's Lovers,'' ``A Little Sex,'' ``Silver Bullet,'' ``Manhunter,'' ``Her Alibi'' and ``Renegades.'' In the ``Miami Vice'' pilot he was Sonny Crockett's partner who became corrupt to get money for his son who requires use of a wheelchair. Smitrovich is living in Southern California for the series, but also has a home in Connecticut. He's married to Shaw Purnell, an actress he met while doing a play in New York. She was his ex-wife in the play, ``Never Say Die.'' His son, Alexander John, called ``A.J.,'' was born in Nevada while he was working on ``Crime Story.'' ``I was creatively frustrated doing `Crime Story' because it was more style than substance,'' he says. ``It was set in the 1950s with the old cars and clothes, and I worked with a great bunch of guys. But I wished we'd stayed in Chicago with the show. It got too glitzy in Las Vegas. I was hoping we'd be like a grand opera comic book, but it never reached those heights.''

DOC.TEXT: The 16 musicals created by George and Ira Gershwin between 1921 and 1933 were not written for posterity. They only had a life expectancy of their original Broadway runs. When these shows closed after six months or sometimes a year, no one ever bothered to preserve all the material from them. Hit songs such as ``The Man I Love,'' ``I Got Rhythm,'' ``Someone To Watch over Me,'' ``S'Wonderful'' and others survived, but the musicals they were from often did not. There wasn't the sense that anyone would want to hear - some 50 or 60 years later - the entire score from ``Girl Crazy,'' ``Strike Up the Band,'' ``Treasure Girl,'' ``Funny Face,'' ``Lady, Be Good!'' and ``Tip-Toes.'' With the advent of the cast album in 1943 that changed. Audiences found a way to keep alive their memories of original performances. But George and Ira Gershwin had written their last Broadway show nearly a decade earlier. Now a major recording project is under way to document all the Gershwin theater works, including the shows lyricist Ira Gershwin wrote with other composers, such as Kurt Weill, Vernon Duke and Arthur Schwartz. The recordings will use scores carefully reconstructed from original manuscripts. The comprehensive effort has been financed by Leonore Gershwin, Ira's widow. Mrs. Gershwin, now 90, formed Roxbury Recordings, named after the stately drive in Beverly Hills where the couple lived and where she still lives. ``She has taken it as a mission in life to make sure that the works of her husband and his brother are preserved in the best possible way,'' says Michael Strunsky, Mrs. Gershwin's nephew who represents her on the project. ``My aunt wants people forever to hear what George and Ira really wrote, at a quality level they would be proud of.'' The company's first effort, released in December on Electra Nonesuch Records and done in collaboration with the Library of Congress, is ``Girl Crazy,'' a 1930 Gershwin musical trifle fashioned for Willie Howard, a big musical comedy star of the day. The original show also featured two teen-agers, one named Ethel Merman and the other Ginger Rogers. The new release, the first complete recording of the show, stars Lorna Luft in the Merman role, Judy Blazer singing Rogers' part, David Carroll and Frank Gorshin. ``In a sense, we are the show's original cast album,'' says Luft, who had the daunting task of singing ``I Got Rhythm'' and ``Boy! What Love Has Done to Me!'' - two songs closely associated with Merman throughout her career. ``There were no modern interpretations on the recording,'' Luft says. ``There is a tendency, of course, with songs like `I Got Rhythm' to use a more up-to-date vocal style. I had to not use it at all.'' ``You want to exude a sense of fun with this music,'' says John Mauceri, conductor of the new recording and a champion of restoring old Broadway musicals for stage and record. ``It should be quite contagious. ``Sometimes you'll hear a recent recording of an old show, and it sounds like an adult education course. And then when you listen to the original performers on old 78 records, you smile. One of the things I wanted to make sure was present in this music was its smile. `Girl Crazy' is one of the happiest scores George and Ira ever wrote.'' Listen to modern versions of ``I Got Rhythm,'' Mauceri says. Most singers seem to get the rhythm wrong. ``If you're doing it right, it's very entertaining,'' he says. ``The orchestrations and the arrangements really only work when you sing them in the right style.'' The problem is that most of those original orchestrations have long disappeared. Research was required to put the shows back into their original state. Restoration work on ``Girl Crazy'' was supervised by Tommy Krasker, producer of the recording series and archivist for the Gershwin estate. His task, which took about six months, was made easier because much of the show's original material, including orchestrations, was available. Krasker was not so lucky with ``Strike Up the Band,'' the second show in the project, which was recorded in early December with Mauceri again conducting. An extensive research effort had to be undertaken. At the Gershwin home in California, Krasker pored over musical manuscripts, lyric sheets and scrapbooks about the show. He scoured old reviews and other newspaper articles, listened to period recordings and studied photographs. ``Strike Up the Band,'' which originally had a book by George S. Kaufman, was one of the Gershwins' most interesting failures - and successes. A 1927 version of the show closed in Philadelphia and never made it to New York. A revised version became a hit three years later. Roxbury has recorded both versions and will release them next summer. The first version of ``Strike Up the Band'' was a dark comedy, an anti-war piece about the United States going to war with Swizterland to protest a tariff on Swiss cheese. The second, with a revised book by Morris Ryskind, softened the anti-war tone, turning the war into a dream sequence and the fight over cheese into a battle over chocolate. ```Strike Up the Band' certainly was ground-breaking in terms of subject matter, characterization, integration of script and score,'' Krasker says. The problem was that outside of piano-vocal material and lyric sheets, not much of the original remained. Out of some 40 songs in the two versions of the show, Krasker found orchestrations for only six. What he did was hire six of the theater's most accomplished orchestrators - Sid Ramin, Bill Brohn, Dick Hyman, Russell Warner, Larry Wilcox and Ralph Burns - to write orchestrations in the style of the period. All the lyrics for ``Strike Up the Band'' were found, and only one piece of music - the verse to a song called ``Meadow Serenade'' - was missing. Its refrain had been remembered by Kay Swift, a composer and good friend of George Gershwin. Krasker asked Burton Lane, composer of ``Finian's Rainbow'' and a one-time collaborator of Ira Gershwin, to write a new verse. ``A few days after I handed him the lyric, he came in with a tune that was absolutely wonderful,'' he says. ``It feels like it was all written in one stroke. Burton's verse and George's refrain complement each other beautifully. I have to think it's going to be one of the highlights of the recording.''

In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Guitar Music of Nicolo Paganini'' (Europa) - Frederic Zigante
Paganini, the demon of the violin who transformed the instrument's technique and turned himself into legend, was also an accomplished guitarist. That is no secret, nor the fact that he wrote numerous chamber works involving the guitar, usually with violin. But Paganini (1782-1840) also wrote an astonishingly vast - and until recently - unknown number of solo works for the instrument. A complete edition was not published until the mid-1980s, 150 years after they were written. Before then, only 26 of his guitar pieces were available, dating from a 1926 edition. Europa introduces most of this new richness of repertoire on four discs, beautifully played by Frederic Zigante. The pieces on the release break down into 40 sonatas, five sonatinas, 16 various one-movement works and 43 ghiribizzi, or popular song transcriptions from Mozart, Paganini himself and lesser composers of the day. According to Zigante's excellent notes, Paganini publicly never performed any of these, though he might have planned to publish some during his lifetime because a small number survive in neat copies apparently prepared for a printer. Paganini was also famously protective of his manuscripts. When concertizing around Europe, he would personally distribute and retrieve the orchestra parts to his concertos for fear of pirated editions. Because he rarely played the guitar in public, and because he learned it pretty much on his own, Paganini developed his own guitar technique. Zigante points out that he doesn't use the progression of positions of standard 19th-century technique, and writes music that is horizontal in nature - more like a violin, and less like vertical, chordal writing more typical of the instrument. Many of Paganini's violinistic tendencies can be heard - arpeggios beginning phrases, sudden register changes, leaps and fast scales. But more striking are the large number of simpler pieces with easy flowing melodies and natural-sounding accompaniment. Zigante's playing matches his scholarship. He has a warm sound and lyrical manner, and keeps an obvious affection for this music despite recording more than 100 pieces, totaling four hours and 20 minutes, by the same composer. It is a wealth of excellent music for classical guitar lovers and listeners partial to 19th-century Italian melody. One hopes it will spur interest in Paganini's guitar output and prompt more live performances of it by guitarists. - By Daniel Wakin, Associated Press Writer. --- ``Triple Threat'' (Alligator Records) - Lucky Peterson
A 20-plus-year career would denote senior status for many performers. Bluesman Lucky Peterson's 20-plus years of performing leave him in his mid-20s with 20-plus years to go. A musical prodigy at 3, Peterson is emerging as a young ambassador of the blues. Robert Cray may have the name recognition and the big record label contract, but Peterson is one to watch. ``Triple Threat,'' Peterson's second effort for Alligator Records and his fourth solo LP is an excellent showcase for the multitalented native of Buffalo, N.Y. Peterson massages the keyboards with the same soul that wells up out of his big voice. For proof, listen to ``I'm Free.'' You'll also hear the third of Peterson's triple threats, his fine guitar playing. Where Cray has shaped his earlier, raw sounds to draw more commercial appeal, Peterson still revels in the edginess of a tough, urban beat. But there's a healthy dose of soul running through the record. There's also great potential for Peterson to take his ambassadorship across the line of commercialism ala Cray and spread the word of the blues. Lyrics on ``Triple Threat'' don't grab hold of your short-term memory like more commercial music does. You're not likely to find yourself repeating ``Don't cloud up on me if you ain't going to rain'' in the shower. But for that weakness, the record is a great mix of funky soul and blues with a beat. - By James Reindl, Associated Press Writer.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: Longtime Partners Team With Superstars
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: For 30 years they have been an ideal combination of filmmakers: James Ivory, the aesthetic American director of a series of literate movies; Ismail Merchant, the well-named producer from India, the voluble moneyraiser for his partner's dreams. Actually it's a triumvirate. Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, German-born of Polish parents, educated in England and married to an Indian architect, has written most of the 15 Merchant-Ivory features. The trio combined again on their most ambitious venture yet: ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge,'' starring Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward. Most of the trio's films have literary beginnings: Henry James' ``The Europeans'' and ``The Bostonians'' and E.M. Forster's ``Room with a View'' and ``Maurice,'' for example. ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge'' stems from a pair of novels by Evan S. Connell. They trace 30 years of marriage of a well-to-do Kansas City couple. Ivory and Merchant sat down for a joint interview at the Beverly Hills Hotel. Ivory is a well-groomed, meticulous man, born in Berkeley, Calif., and educated at the University of Oregon and the University of Southern California film school. His fascination with India led him to make documentaries about Indian art and life in Delhi. In 1961 he joined with Merchant and Jhabvala in their first feature, ``The Householder.'' Born in Bombay, Merchant has lived and worked in Europe and America; he graduated in business from New York University. He became partners with Ivory when they met at the Cannes Film Festival. A born salesman, Merchant financed their early films with the frozen rupee funds of American distributors. Financing ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge'' was an easy sell, Merchant said. With Jhabvala's script and the Newmans' participation, he was able to make a deal with his first customer, Cineplex Odeon. The film cost $7.5 million, and all of it is visible on the screen, he insisted. He cited the cooperation of people in Kansas City, as well as New York suppliers. One of them contributed $250,000 worth of draperies and other materials. ``Let's not get lost here,'' snapped Ivory, ever the director. ``Why don't we start all over again. Let's not go into a thing about the draperies. Let that be a later question. ``Let's get on to the key source of our success: good script, good actors, good material. That's why we've gotten wherever we have gotten.'' Ivory also bristled at the suggestion that he was dealing with superstars for the first time in ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge'': ``It's not for the first time. It's the first time in the sense of working in the United States, yes, certainly. But I've worked with some superstars in Great Britain. Maggie Smith, James Mason, Vanessa Redgrave, all marvelous actors. In my mind, Paul and Joanne are in that league of great actors.'' The project grew out of a dinner conversation with Miss Woodward in New York. ``It was an accidental conversation,'' reported Merchant. ``We started talking about books, and Joanne said she had read this wonderful book, `Mrs. Bridge,' but not many people knew about it. Jim had found it 20 years ago in Calcutta in a small bookstore. He gave it to me and said, `It's a wonderful book, it could make a good movie.''' ``It was Joanne's project,'' continued Ivory. ``She wanted to make `Mrs. Bridge' for television, and she already had an arrangement with (producer) Robert Halmi. We talked them into combining the book with `Mr. Bridge.' Paul said if he liked the script, he would play Mr. Bridge. He did like the script, and that's how we got going.'' Both Newmans have been directors, but Ivory said that posed no problems. ``That just made it easier. We got over a lot of material fast that might have taken longer. He knows the problems of a relatively small production, having so recently done `The Glass Menagerie' (with Woodward as star). He knew that we had to move swiftly. There was a lot of hard work and long hours. They accepted that sort of thing very well.'' ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge'' was filmed in Paris, New York and Canada (for snow) as well as Kansas City. It was an amazing feat on a $7.5 million budget. Wouldn't it be easier for Merchant-Ivory to hook up with a major studio and let it worry about financing? ``We've also hooked up with major companies, and we've made exactly the film we wanted to make,'' said Ivory. ``And it was certainly less of a headache for Ismail.'' ``The important thing is to have one source of money, as we did on this picture,'' said Merchant. ``Today, Merchant-Ivory has made about 28 films (including TV). The negatives belong to us. If you have a studio deal, the negatives belong to the studio.'' Inevitably, there are clashes between art (Ivory) and commerce (Merchant). The director cited an instance on ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge.'' He wanted a period fire engine for a scene in which a car is burned. Such a machine was available in Kansas City, but Merchant didn't want to pay for it. ``I finally convinced him it was necessary,'' said Ivory. Would Merchant like to sit in the director's chair? ``Well, I'm a good entrepreneur and organizer, I like to take the challenge of producing the picture,'' he replied. ``I am going to direct a film which is set in India, `In Custody.' I did `The Courtesans of Bombay' some years ago and a short film, `Mahatma and the Bad Boy.' I must say I felt wonderful at the time, because someone is taking all your orders, doing all your things, and you are the boss.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: Cultural Artifacts From Alaska and Siberia
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A cultural thaw opened the way, but it took 10 years to put together a show of long stored masks, weapons and ceremonial clothes used by the peoples of the frigid lands on both sides of the Bering Strait. ``Crossroads of Continents: Cultures of Siberia and Alaska'' is a Smithsonian Institution traveling exhibit now at the Gene Autry Western Heritage Museum in Griffith Park. The idea for the exhibit of about 600 cultural artifacts arose as a bridge between the Soviet Union and the United States, but the project endured some chilly times before the recent dramatic improvement in relations. ``We were delayed because of political problems,'' the exhibit's curator, William W. Fitzhugh, said in an interview from his office in Washington. ``We were fighting against the image of `The Evil Empire.' We were the test wave of glasnost,'' said Fitzhugh, who is director of the Smithsonian's Center for Arctic Studies. Sergei Serov, Fitzhugh's Soviet counterpart and senior researcher with Leningrad's Institute of Ethnology, said the project went well at their level. ``We experienced no problems with cooperation between scholars,'' he said. The monumental task of uniting collections from the two countries started in 1978 when the Soviet Union became more receptive to scholarly exchanges, Fitzhugh said. ``If you take a project of this geographic scope, immensity, you need time just to get familiar with the objects,'' he said. ``Documentation takes many, many hours. And we had no funding from any American corporations.'' Fitzhugh and his team made several trips to the Soviet Union, and Russian researchers made similar trips here. In musty, dusty corners of museum warehouses, attics and basements, Fitzhugh found items he had only read about from the years before the United States bought Alaska from Russia in 1867. ``We were rediscovering collections that long had been in storage,'' he said. ``It is quite a task to pack, to mount, to dismount and check all the items and do condition checks and damage checks,'' said Serov. ``We have been lucky that nothing has been seriously damaged.'' Enthusiasts who attend the display of jewelry, ivory work, masks, religious costumes and everyday items like hunting and fishing tools walk into darkened rooms that create an arctic winter atmosphere. The lighting is subdued due to the fragility of the artifacts, some a century old. The pieces are sensitive to light and could be permanently damaged if exposed. ``The artifacts are made with vegetable and animal dyes and the peoples who created them were accustomed to throwing them away after they were used,'' Fitzhugh said. ``Things made for everyday use were expendable after a couple of months,'' he added. One example of the elaborate work is a Siberian bucket made from the jawbone of a whale. Using bentwood techniques, the jaw was soaked, bent, riveted and fastened to a wooden bottom. The ornamental trim decorated the handle of what was believed to be a chamber pot. The exhibit was unveiled in 1988 at the National Museum of Natural History in Washington. It also was displayed in Seattle and New York in 1989 and was shown earlier this year in Indianapolis. It will be at the Western Heritage Museum until Feb. 24. Then it will move on to the Anchorage Museum of History and Art in Alaska and the Canadian Museum of Civilization in Ottawa. In 1992, organizers hope to take the exhibit to the Soviet Union to cities including Moscow, Leningrad and Novosibirsk. Museum visitors who crave more Soviet art can view the work of eight Russian artists at the Lori Kaye Gallery in Garden Grove. The exhibit, which opened Nov. 29, includes 40 watercolors by Vasil Panikarov, most of them still lifes ``enabling him to escape the gloomy Russian everyday life.'' The exhibit also includes ``The Window'' by the late Alexander Freyidin, whose works are considered national treasures and restricted from leaving the country. The other artists with works in the show are Constantin Filatov, Victor Resovich, Lev Michaelovich Shmoys, Gavzdinskaya, Natalya Teodorvna Tchulvaloma and Vera Alexandra Tchiyka. Another Soviet exhibit, ``Keepers of the Flame,'' was organized by Selma Holo, director of the University of Southern California's Fisher Gallery. Open until Jan. 19, it will be taken to three other college campus galleries. ``Keepers of the Flame'' is a show of 25 unofficial or underground artists. Before the era of glasnost, artists who did not qualify to join the official artists union were not recognized and banned from public exhibit. In 1975, the KGB dismantled an outdoor show of such art. Lori Kaye said the Soviet artists' ``view of life is very different.'' Just getting art supplies in the Soviet Union is a test of an artist's commitment to the craft, she said. ``Paper is often crude and causes the watercolors to react very differently,'' she said. ``The paints themselves are difficult to find and often have to be made using old-fashioned techniques such as squeezing the oils from flower petals.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: Spies in the House of Was
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Success has (has not) been sweet for Was (Not Was). For years, they were a funny, funky Detroit band, with singers Sweet Pea Atkinson and Sir Harry Bowens, songwriters David and Don Was and a handful of listeners. Their first two albums bombed. They spent much of the 1980s bouncing around Europe. That made sense to David and Don, perpetual outsiders, pariahs with pride. They expected mistreatment at the hands of the record industry. They'd rather crash parties than be invited. But for the past two years, separately and together, the Wases couldn't lose. ``Walk the Dinosaur'' and ``Spy in the House of Love'' were hit singles. Their third album, ``What Up Dog?,'' went gold. Don Was topped that by producing platinum records for Bonne Raitt and the B-52's. Suddenly, everybody wanted to know about Was (Not Was), and when they got around to making their next record, ``Are You O.K?,'' they felt self-conscious, sensitive to the presence of spies in the house of Was. ``I actually feel this is a fine record,'' said David, interviewed with Don Was at a Manhattan hotel. ``But I'm glad we got rid of it. The follow-up to a hit - it's like having a genius kid and the next kid grows up and all you can see is the new kid in the image of the older one. I think the next one we'll lose the jitters, the pressure'll be off or something.'' ``We thought we had a soft image, nothing like we really were,'' Don added. ``We went in the studio and the album took on a life of its own. It was nothing like we planned.'' After ``Are You O.K?'' they may have to start crashing parties again; the album has quickly vanished from the charts. They knew they were in trouble from the first single. A British A&R (artist and repertoire) man urged the Wases to take advantage of their Motown roots and top-notch singers. Why not cover that old Temptations hit, ``Papa Was a Rollin' Stone''? They had performed the song in concert, with great success, so they gave it a shot in the studio, sticking closely to the original version. The single flopped. ``Don put a nice beat under it, but otherwise it was fruitless,'' David said. ``The singers are too close, they can `do' the Temptations practically. ``We liked the song. It was a chance to pay homage to our soul roots and it was a way of making a statement about today's problems. The only problem was having it represent us as the first single on the marketplace. Here's Was (Not Was) and their first single is a cover. Maybe it was ill-advised.'' If success has had an effect, it's made them more philosophical, more concerned about being taken seriously. The problem: They are funny, very funny. Who else but Was (Not Was) could get signed to their first contract with the help of a flattering letter from jazz critic David Weiss, a.k.a. David Was? Who else would come up with titles such as ``I Feel Better Than James Brown'' and ``Earth to Doris.'' And who else but David Was would let his young son pick out a Christmas tree and then help him steal it? Yet, listen to ``Love Can Be Bad Luck'' off ``What Up Dog?'' or ``How the Heart Behaves'' from the new record. In quieter moments, they're more likely to write lyrics such as these from ``Love Can Be Bad Luck'': ``When two cars crash, you just pull them apart. But when lovers come to together, they get tangled heart to heart.'' ``When we saw `Walk the Dinosaur' work, we saw what the world wanted us to and meant us to be: cartoonish, lovable, black and white, kind of a fun party band,'' David explained. ``We tried to resist that definition with all of our energy, but in a way I think we set ourselves up for it. In a way I'd like to have Peter Gabriel's audience: listening hard, committed.'' Don Fagenson and David Weiss grew up in suburban Detroit in the 1960s, their friendship sealed in eighth grade outside the principal's office; both were there on detention. Similar in their thinking, the Wases are easy to tell apart. Don's hair is dark - and wavy; David's is blond - and frizzy. Don wears shades; David doesn't. David's voice is lower, a stage whisper. ``It was a matter of finding a sensibility with someone,'' David said. ``Those were fairly strained times. Growing up bored in the suburbs. What do you do with yourself? ``We'd go on poetry writing missions, going to local shrines, to a water tower at the mall. This was our religious life. Then it burgeoned into full-blown productions when Don started experimenting with tape recorders.'' They formed the group in 1980, the name springing from the mouth of Don's 2-year-old son. Atkinson and Bowen, studio performers in Detroit, were recruited as singers. David, a history buff, thinks Was (Not Was) is going through its ``Baroque'' phase, a time of self-awareness, when every song carries the weight of songs written before. ``If this was our last record, I would say we went out with a whimper and not a bang,'' he said of ``Are You O.K?'' But he dismisses the lull as ``birth pangs,'' growing pains for a band with mixed feelings about growing up, a time when the only way to go forward might be to take a giant step back. ``I think, and I don't really care if our company (Chrysalis) reads this or not, we would be so much better off if they got sick of us and said goodbye,'' David said. ``It would be nice to make records that didn't reflect having to recoup such an enormous amount for a company. ... It would be nice if we could go back to the beginning and make a record for $18,000.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: The Capacity for Wonder
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: ``The Great Gatsby'' is still one of Geoffrey Wolff's favorite books, and narrator Nick Carraway's insistence that he is ``inclined to reserve all judgments'' still makes the author laugh. The novel is nothing but judgments, Wolff insists, a young man's moral education. Carraway never stops evaluating Gatsby or Daisy or Tom Buchanan - or himself. He has an opinion on everything, and his opinion is constantly shifting. But Wolff doesn't mean that as criticism. He considers Carraway the perfect writer, an inspiration for his own books, a man who both observes and participates. Making judgments, and then changing them, is part of the process, a moral education for an author who learns something new with every word. ``We're told, teachers tell us, `Show, don't tell, show, don't tell, show don't tell.' I don't feel comfortable only showing, I do want to tell when I have a judgment to sound off on,'' Wolff, author of ``The Duke of Deception: Memories of My Father,'' ``Providence'' and the new ``The Final Club,'' said in an interview. ``I think some things are right and some things are wrong. I like to say when I think this person shouldn't have done something, even at the old-fashioned primitive level that violates all the aesthetics. For better or worse, I feel that's something I've been doing.'' ``The Final Club'' (Alfred A. Knopf, $19.95) is narrated by Nathaniel Clay, a Princeton University student, class of '60, who leaves behind a troubled family life in Seattle. His education begins immediately, on the eastbound Empire Builder train, when he meets the beautiful Diana (pronounced Dee-ah-nah, she emphasizes) Carr, falling madly in love with a woman who either flirts with him or ignores him. This is straight out of F. Scott Fitzgerald, a relationship much like the one in the short story ``Winter Dreams,'' in which a caddy spots an 11-year-old girl on a golf course and never looks at life the same way again. Even when Nathaniel declares he will no longer pursue Diana, he admits he will always hold her up as some kind of ideal, remembering her the night she showed up 42 minutes late for a meeting under the giant clock at Manhattan's Grand Central Station. --- ``Nathaniel was past answering Diana's questions. She had asked at least one question too many. But he'd never forget the way she smelled, and years later he'd ask the snit behind the perfume counter at Bendel's to spray his palm with this scent and that scent, hoping to find that smell, and give it to the woman he was about to marry, so that his wife would smell just as Diana smelled tonight.'' --- ``I'm interested in moments that change lives,'' Wolff explained. ``It's like that extraordinary ending to Frank O'Connor's short story `Guests of a Nation.' The last lines of the story are something like, `Anything that happened afterwards, I never felt the same about it again.' I want to write narratives in which that happens. The world is one way before and one way after.'' Wolff was born in Los Angeles in 1937 and, like Nathaniel, traveled East. But this was not by choice. As the author notes in ``Duke of Deception,'' his father was a notorious con man, racing from city to city just out of reach of angry creditors. By the time Wolff was old enough to go to college, Princeton, he had lived all over the country and was estranged from his mother - his parents had separated - and his younger brother, Toby (author Tobias Wolff, who wrote of his own childhood in ``This Boy's Life''). In 1968, Geoffrey Wolff wrote his first novel, ``Bad Debts,'' a story based on the relationship with his father, who died in 1970 after spending his final years in a sanitarium. Besides ``Duke of Deception,'' Wolff has since written four novels and ``The Black Sun,'' a bleak study of poet Harry Crosby. ``The Final Club'' takes Nathaniel through his years at Princeton, offering judgments on fraternities, writers and the elitist student body, and into a troubled marriage. The origin of the book's title keeps shifting. At first, it's an alternative club Nathaniel forms with his Princeton friends, the name coming from a card game in which you can be defeated by holding the final club. But the world changes and the title eventually means something much deeper. ``That was the final club,'' Nathaniel thinks when he learns of a death in his family. ``Everyone was a member, not exclusive in the least, all comers were goers.'' The book ends at the beginning, with Nathaniel looking ahead to the next time he can ponder ``The Final Club.'' He's a middle-aged man who knows his life will never be the same, so all he can do is what Wolff aims for himself, behave well to others and try to maintain his capacity for wonder. ``He has, to a degree, an obsession about time passing,'' Wolff said. ``It's like that wonderful line Burt Lancaster delivers in `Atlantic City.' He looks out over the boardwalk and says, `When I was a boy, there was a real ocean.' It's a line that breaks your heart.''

DOC.HEAD: Nashville Sound: An Uncluttered Singer
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In a genre of music replete with songs about rebellious drinking and infidelity, Don Williams is downright counterculture. His songs are positive love ballads that also often glorify home and family. So it's no surprise that Don Williams' new album is titled ``True Love,'' and it's the typical Williams form: soothing, uncluttered, restrained. The LP maintains Williams' 15-year tradition as something of a country music paradox. He sings uplifting love songs, such as ``I Believe in You,'' ``You're My Best Friend'' and ``We Should Be Together.'' But don't expect him to play the new LP at his home on a 90-acre ranch in neighboring Cheatham County where he lives quietly and reclusively with his wife of 30 years. The 51-year-old Williams has a detached attitude toward his music once it's recorded, rarely listening to his songs. ``I think I've got a pretty good idea of what I've done after I've finished it,'' he said in a rare interview. ``I'm so critical of what I do that it's just never been a part of the picture to sit around and relax with what I've done. ``I don't watch the (music popularity) charts. Unless someone tells me what the sales are, I don't know. Because that's history. I've done that. I'm always thinking more about what I'm going to do than what I've done.'' He doesn't even know if his LP ``I Believe in You'' was a million seller. And there's also no need for adulation from fans. ``I don't think I'm the kind of person who'd go nuts if I didn't have another standing ovation or wasn't on stage to hear that applause,'' he said. ``The thing I've constantly been concerned about is I don't want to whip a dead horse. I'm more than willing to step aside if the folks out there reach a point where they've had enough of me. ``As long as they want me to do it, I'll do it. But I don't want to force the issue.'' About his only concession to the country music lifestyle is a weather-beaten cowboy hat, one of four he owns, that's constantly perched on his head. ``I kid about it turning into a growth,'' he said. Williams has had five gold albums (sales of 500,000 each): ``Greatest Hits Volume 1,'' ``Expressions,'' ``The Best of Don Williams Volume 11,'' ``Portraits'' and ``I Believe in You.'' He has had concerts at Carnegie Hall in New York City, Royal Albert Hall in London and the Sporting Club in Monte Carlo among others. He has made international appearances in Belgium, Monaco, Germany, Spain, Wales, Scotland, Ireland, France, Sweden, England, Holland and Finland. He credits his popularity overseas to the universality of his music. ``It's universal as to how we feel about each other and what our needs in life are. Most of what I talk about is people and how they react to people,'' he said. Williams also had a brief motion picture career in the 1970s, appearing in two Burt Reynolds' films: ``W.W. & the Dixie Dancekings'' and ``Smokey & the Bandit II.'' He'd like to do more film work. Williams, a member of the Pozo Seco Singers pop-folk trio in the 1960s, has never been involved in even a whisper of controversy despite his high visibility as one of country music's top performers since the mid-1970s. ``I'm so bland I'm amazed people want to do interviews with me,'' he said. ``We live a pretty simple life. And that's our preference. We don't do a whole lot. We go to church and we were involved in school activities when our kids were in school.'' The first single released from ``True Love'' is ``Back in My Younger Days,'' an uptempo song about the joy of getting older. Another cut, ``Lord Have Mercy on a Country Boy,'' is a nostalgic piece about yearning to return to the dirt-road life of hunting wild turkeys and fishing. In the song, Williams laments that a former meadow is now a parking lot. For him, it's a rare reflection on a topical issue such as the environment. ``I haven't been given too much to that - the political, the religious. But I do have very strong feelings about it.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Add Barbara Hershey's voice to the growing chorus of actresses who support Meryl Streep's attack on sex discrimination in the movie business. Streep launched the campaign in August when she addressed the first women's conference sponsored by the Screen Actors Guild. She assailed movie moguls who produce a preponderance of male-oriented films and pay actresses far less than actors. ``Meryl has come out with a lot of frightening statistics, such as 23 percent of womens' roles vs. 79 percent for men,'' said Hershey. ``When (women) hit 40, it's 6 percent. Those are pretty scary - unhealthy - statistics. Certainly unfriendly. ``And the money factor: Men get twice as much as women. That's a little more nebulous because in an acting career it' very hard to measure someone's worth.'' Hershey said that she didn't work as much as she would like. ``It's the quality. There are just so few quality pieces to work on. And you have to be lucky to get one.'' ---= NIWOT, Colo. (AP) - William Randolph Hearst, Jr., editor in chief of the Hearst newspapers, is the first member in the century-old media history of his family to write a revealing insider's account of the colorful, often controversial, Hearst dynasty. ``The Hearsts: Father and Son,'' will be published by Roberts Rinehart, Inc., on Aug. 14, 1991, to coincide with the 40th anniversary of his father's death. Ranging from the remarkable rags-to-riches story of the author's grandparents to the building of the Hearst publishing empire by his father and the future of the Hearst Corporation t`e 90's, ``The Hearst's: Father and Son'' is an intimate portrayal of an extraordinary American family. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Hugh Masekela, musician, composer and human rights activist, leads a celebration for the 45th Anniversary of the United Nations on Dec. 10 at the UN Delegate's Dining Room. Masekela and his African Orchestra will be sharing their high-spirited music at the gala benefit sponsored by The Friends of the UN, a non-profit, non-governmental organization, in honor of the 45 years of service that the United Nations has provided on behalf of peace, justice and the environment. Masekela began his career over 30 years ago when he became a member of the seminal South African band ``The Jazz Epistles,'' the first black jazz band to record an LP in South Africa. Dec. 10 is also United Nations Human Rights Day, and the event will mark the announcement of the recent UN convention regarding the Rights of the Child. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Dolly Parton heads ``Home for Christmas'' with her first full album of Christmas music of the same name. ``Home for Christmas'' is Parton's second release on Columbia-Nashville, following her successful ``White Limozeen.'' ``Home for Christmas'' contains such timeless classics as ``Joy to the World'' and ``The First Noel,'' for which Parton headed down to East Tennessee to record the two tracks with the congregation of the New Salem Methodist Church and the Christ Church Pentecostal Choir. Other cuts feature the Bobby Jones gospel choir and Parton's own children's choir, called Our Kids.

Stock and bond prices climbed steeply and oil prices plummeted after comments by President Bush led to renewed hope of a peaceful end to the Iraqi stalemate. Oil plunged more than $4 per barrel Friday in its second-largest one-day move since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The biggest was a $5.41 drop Oct. 22, when traders sold on a rumor that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had a dream in which a prophet told him his missiles were pointed the wrong way. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The government's economic forecasting gauge belatedly signaled the likelihood of a recession that most economists believe already has begun. The Commerce Department said Friday that its Index of Leading Economic Indicators plunged 1.2 percent in October on top of three previous monthly declines including July, when the index was first reported to have been flat. --- BOCA RATON, Fla. (AP) - Top officials from both the Bush administration and Wall Street declared that major surgery is needed to treat the ills of the nation's banking and financial system. And they stepped up their calls for action by Congress to deal with financial problems they say go beyond the current slump in the economy and the savings and loan crisis. ``The legal and regulatory structure of our financial system is outmoded, burdensome and inefficient,'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said Friday at the annual convention of the Securities Industry Association, Wall Street's main trade group. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady acknowledged Friday that the fund insuring commercial bank deposits may need a cash infusion, but pledged the money will come from the industry, not taxpayers. Separately, Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chairman L. William Seidman on Friday outlined some of the options under consideration: raising the deposit insurance premiums banks pay to the fund, imposing a one-time assessment on all banks, and requiring banks to purchase preferred stock from the FDIC. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Orin E. Atkins, former chairman of Ashland Oil Inc., was sentenced to probation and community service for trying to sell confidential company documents to Iran. U.S. District Judge Charles S. Haight of Manhattan said Friday that although he felt Atkins had committed a serious crime, he decided prison time was not warranted because Atkins cooperated with prosecutors and agreed to pay restitution to Ashland. --- DETROIT (AP) - Other automakers may not match General Motors Corp.'s gloomy proclamation of potential fourth-quarter losses, but the Big Three will keep inventories slim as the economy stumbles, analysts and the companies say. GM officials predicted the first quarterly red ink on operations at the world's largest manufacturer since the 1981 recession. Chairman Robert Stempel said Thursday night that the company would cut fourth-quarter car and truck production by 111,000, to a total of 1.07 million vehicles for the period. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Prices farmers get for raw products declined 0.7 percent from October to November, leaving the overall index below a year earlier for the first time in 14 months, the Agriculture Department said. The USDA on Friday reported lower prices were reported for hogs, milk, soybeans and corn, although higher prices for oranges, lettuce and strawberries helped soften the decline of the other commodities. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Standard & Poor's Corp., raising further doubts about the financial stability of R.H. Macy & Co. Inc., said it was re-evaluating ratings on $2.5 billion of the retailer's bonds. The move Thursday came a day after published reports said Macy's losses in its first fiscal quarter had nearly doubled to $66 million. --- PHOENIX (AP) - A federal judge said he will approve a plan to liquidate the assets of Charles Keating Jr.'s American Continental Corp., the former parent company of Lincoln Savings and Loan. Under the plan approved Friday, American Continental's assets would be sold over three years to provide partial payment to the company's 25,000 creditors, who are owed $365 million. ---

Stock prices rose Friday as oil prices tumbled in the wake of President Bush's offer to seek a diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 40.84 to close at 2,559.65, bringing its gain for the week to 32.42 points. Bond prices rose sharply on Bush's comments. The dollar and gold prices fell. Wheat futures prices surged after Bush said he would consider offering food export credits to the Soviet Union, cattle futures retreated and pork futures wre mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Temp Agency's Survey Predicts Big Decline In Hiring Plans
DOC.TEXT: Hiring plans of U.S. companies will drop steeply to recession levels in the first quarter of 1991, particularly in the economically battered Northeast, the world's largest temporary help firm says it found in a srvey. Manpower Inc. said Sunday its sampling of more than 15,000 American businesses showed that 15 percent plan to increase hiring while 16 percent plan to reduce their workforces, for a net hiring drop of 1 percent. The firm said the net drop is the first shown by the survey since the first quarter of 1983, when the nation was still emerging from the last recession. Manpower said the 15 percent of firms intending to hire compares with 20 percent for the same period in 1990. The 16 percent planning work force cuts compares with 12 percent year earlier. The survey substantiated a number of other recently released private and government statistical evidence that suggests the nation is sliding into a recession or already is immersed in one. Mitchell Fromstein, Manpower president, said the survey figures clearly show hiring activity is reaching recession depths in all regions except the Midwest and is reflected in all business categories. Although the first quarter of any year historically is a time of low hiring activity, Fromstein said that even on a seasonally adjusted basis the hiring predicions for the quarter are down sharply. The survey showed the deterioration to be most evident in the Northeast, where symptoms of recession have grown since the stock market crash of 1987. The net hiring prediction for the area showed a net drop of 9 percent, vs. a 3 percent advance a year earlier. It is the lowest in the 15 year history of the survey and well below the recession levels of 1982-83. By industry, the survey showed the steepest declines in hiring plans were in the construction and retail trade sectors. The survey showed a 9 percent advance in hiring plans in the service category, which suggested service jobs will account for much of the total U.S. job increase activity through early next year. Manpower, based in Milwaukee, is the leading supplier of temporary help to businesses worldwide, providing jobs to nearly 1.5 million people annually through more than 1,600 offices in 34 countries. It conducts the employment outlook survey on a quarterly basis, measuring employer intentions to increase or decrease the permanent workforce.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Agents Seize Airline's Maintenance Records
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents have seized records of Eastern Airlines as part of an investigation into allegations that the troubled carrier failed to adequately inspect its airplanes for safety as recently as early November, according to a published report. Thirty federal agents entered Eastern's Miami headquarters on Saturday after lawyers for Eastern unsuccessfully tried to block the raid, Newsday reported Sunday. The seizure of hundreds of safety logs is tied to indictments against Eastern handed down last July by a federal grand jury in Brooklyn, the newspaper reported. The charges allege that the airline and nine of its former and current managers participated in a money-making scheme that allowed unsafe planes to fly. The grand jury has received evidence that Eastern failed to perform safety inspections properly as recently as early last month, Newsday said, citing unidentified sources. An Eastern spokeswoman, Karen Ceremsak, said there have been allegations about the airline's safety inspections in the past and ``none of those have ever borne out.'' ``The fact the (search) warrant was so broad indicates to us that they're simply on a fishing expedition, that they're not seeking records that relate to specific allegations,'' she added. The indictments were based on testimony from informants. The raid was the first seizure of documents under search warrants authorities obtained for Eastern's records, Newsday said. Newsday said U.S. Attorney Andrew J. Maloney, who is heading the investigation, declined to comment on the report of the raid. Eastern attorneys who had somehow learned of the impending raid went before U.S. District Judge I. Leo Glasser in Brooklyn late Friday asking him to stay the seizure. Glasser agreed to seal the affidavits supporting the government's plans for one week, but let the raid go forward, Newsday said. Eastern has been operating under protection of U.S. bankruptcy laws since last March. It received a temporary reprieve last week when the bankruptcy judge overseeing the case agreed to the airline's request to use up to $135 million from an escrow fund to keep flying through the winter.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Talks Open With Growing Pressure To End Farm Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with U.S. warning on tariffs, Indonesian, Japanese comment. No pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: World trade officials opened a final round of global trade talks today with a blunt reminder that the economic health of millions was riding on the outcome of their bargaining. ``The world is expecting a great deal of you,'' Belgian Prime Minister Wilfried Martens told the delegates from nations attending the negotiating session of the 107-nation Uruguay Round, the most ambitious trade talks ever. ``Failure would deal world trade stability a nasty blow and would seriously harm the world economy,'' he said at the Heysel Palaces exhibition complex on the outskirts of the Belgian capital. Trade officials said 1,650 officials from 96 nations were in attendance to launch the week of bargaining, which has been threatened with failure by an acrimonious fight over cuts in government payments to farmers. The dispute has pitted the European Community and Japan against the United States, Australia, and others. Today, the United States formally warned it may impose ``prohibitive'' tariffs on some imports from the European Community unless the EC agrees to renew an accord on compensation for potential losses of U.S. farm exports to Spain and Portugal. U.S. trade officials said the move could cost the 12-nation community almost $420 million in exports. Thousands of farmers, mostly Europeans, marched through Brussels to show their opposition to any move to trim their support payments. The negotiations, which began in 1986 in the Uruguayan resort of Punta del Este, are designed to lower barriers to trade in 15 areas, including agriculture, textiles, manufactured goods and services, such as banking, transportation, telecommunications and construction. Indonesia's trade minister, Arifin Siregar, complained today that rich nations were hindering work on an overall agreement. ``With a few days left in the Uruguay Round, we are being confronted with a crisis situation, mainly attributed to roadblocks put up by the majors,'' he told the opening session. He said if the problems were not solved quickly, ``It would not be an exaggeration to say that the decay of the multilateral trading system has begun.'' Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, whose nation is being pressed by the United States and others to lift its ban on rice imports, called for a ``realistic solution'' to agricultural disputes. Japan argues that its ban on rice imports is essential to give the country self-sufficiency in its staple food. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter met Sunday with trade officials from the European Community and Japan but reported no progress. On on the eve of the talks, officials stressed repeatedly that ending the fight over agriculture was key to a successful conclusion of the round. ``The impasse there is poisoning other parts of the round,'' said Australian Trade Minister Neal Blewett, chairman of the Cairns Group of 14 farm-exporting nations. The Bush administration, backed by Australia, Argentina, Brazil and others, wants the European Community to snip away much of its costly farm support system, making cuts ranging from 75 percent to 90 percent. But the Europeans have refused to budge from a 30 percent cut in limited areas. Ray MacSharry, the EC's top farm official, however, told reporters that ``there is substantial common ground'' in some areas of negotiation. France and Germany have been the community's main opponents to further reductions. But there is speculation that the Germans, who had been anxious about the farm vote prior to Sunday's elections, might give in some now that the balloting is over. Blewett predicted the farm issue would ``come to a head'' in the first two days of the conference. On another dispute, officials reported some progress in an effort to write new rules for trade in various service industries such as banking and insurance. Canadian Trade Minister John Crosbie said his country, with the support of several other nations, was expected to offer a proposal for removing barriers to trade in financial services. He said the measure has the support of the United States and the Common Market. The Uruguay Round is the eighth in a series of negotiating sessions designed to reduce tariffs and lower barriers to global trade. The negotiations are sponsored by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which was created in 1947 as a forum and an agreement to freer world trade.

DOC.HEAD: Two Airlines Expand Links By Taking Stakes In Each Other
DOC.TEXT: Swissair and Singapore Airlines are buying equity stakes in each other effective next June as part of a program to expand their existing links, the Swiss carrier said Monday. The two airlines established an alliance last December that allows cross-stakes of up to 5 percent by each carrier. Swissair, Switzerland's shareholder-owned national airline, will buy an initial 0.62 percent stake in Singapore Airlines, while Singapore will obtain a 2.77 percent holding in Swissair.

DOC.HEAD: EEOC To Accept `Tester' Complaints of Job Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: The federal government will begin prosecuting job discrimination cases in which individuals used as ``testers'' by civil rights groups charge they have been illegally denied employment, an official says. The new policy extends the use of testers - long a tactic in housing discrimination complaints - to the federal employment bias arena for the first time. ``It's used in housing cases and used by other state agencies, and I couldn't see why it couldn't be used by the commission,'' Evan J. Kemp Jr., chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, said in a telephone interview Sunday. ``Testers'' - or individuals from minority and women's groups who historically have been victims of discrimination - have posed as renters or home buyers to win housing discrimination suits. The Supreme Court in 1982 said such activities were legal even if the testers did not intend to rent or buy. However, the government never has used the testimony of testers to prosecute job discrimination cases. Kemp said the new commission policy, announced Friday, would address one of the ``weaknesses'' of the EEOC system. ``People that apply for a job in answer to a newspaper ad can be discriminated against and they won't know it,'' under current circumstances, Kemp said. The EEOC chairman said he was confident his agency has the legal authority to bring the cases because the ``courts address this all the time and make a determination whether an employer has discriminated or not.'' Representatives of the business community could not be reached for comment Sunday on the new policy. But Stephen Bokat of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce told The Washington Post that ``proving the case'' of job bias against an employment tester would be ``infinitely more difficult than it is in the housing context.''

DOC.HEAD: Cash Market Only On Brussels Stock Exchange
DOC.TEXT: Brussels Stock Exchange officials said only the cash market will operate Monday following last week's fire that badly damaged the exchange's computerized trading system. Bond trading is expected to resume on Wednesday, they said. Stock Exchange President Jean Peterbroeck said it is too early to estimate the damage caused by Friday's fire. The exchange's computerized forward trading system, known as CATS, suffered serious damage due to the high level of humidity during the blaze.

DOC.HEAD: Wright Investors Forms New Data Information Venture
DOC.TEXT: Wright Investors' Service and Disclosure Inc. have formed a joint venture to permit almost instantaneous access to financial data on more than 5,500 corporations in 25 countries. Peter Donovan, Wright president, said the arrangement will make information and analysis on foreign companies as readily available as it is for domestic concerns. Under the arrangement, which Donovan said was a combination of cash and assets, Wright's corporate research center in Shannon, Ireland, will provide material for marketing by Disclosure, a Bethesda, Md. data distributor. Steven Goldspiel, Disclosure president and chief executive officer, said the addition of Wright's Worldscope database would make it the largest single-source provider of domestic and international corporate information. He said the easier access to foreign financial information and analysis was essential to chief executives and investment advisers who increasingly are operating in an international business and economic environment. The new product, called Worldscope-Disclosure, will be available immediately through online information systems, compact discs, magnetic tapes and published periodicals. The Worldscope database is the information source for Wright's financial services business, which includes 28 domestic and international mutual funds, the administration of 40 bank trust departments, and various advisory products and services. It has about $3.5 billion under management worldwide. In 1988, the company established its Shannon-based global research center to gather, translate and analyze corporate financial information. The center is staffed with more than 60 international analysts.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, with no major developments influencing supply and demand. Wheat futures were slightly higher, soybeans fractionally lower and corn futures narrowly mixed. Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said supportive factors included expectations that the Bush administration will announce a package of food export credits for the Soviet Union on Thursday. Lespinasse said a turn to colder conditions in the Midwest could result in stronger demand for livestock feed, a bullish development for the corn and soybean meal markets. On the bearish side were perceptions that world trade talks in Belgium will break down, possibly leading to a U.S.-European trade war that could include grain, he said. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent to 2\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.46 a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to 1{ cents higher with December at $2.29\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to 1 cent higher with December at $1.13 a bushel; soybeans were \ cent to 4 cents lower with January at $5.89\ a bushel. Cattle futures were mixed and pork futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .05 cent to .20 cent higher with December at 78.72 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to .20 cent higher with January at 87.45 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent lower to .35 cent higher with December at 51.25 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .10 cent to 1.20 cents higher with February at 66.80 cents a pound.
