DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Holds Steady After Recent Rebound
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States remained unchanged this week at 1,175, following a healthy rebound the week before, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. The number of rigs had plummeted by 41 in late November, following heavy rains in Oklahoma, then rebounded last week by 72 as weather improved and the end-of-year seasonal upturn began. A year ago this week, the number of working rigs was 1,062. Decreases in the previous weeks followed a milestone earlier in the month when the number of working rigs reached 1,144 - a figure not seen since Dec. 28, 1987. Baker Hughes has kept track of the rig count - the widely watched index of drilling activity - since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Oklahoma led the major oil producing states for the week, adding 13 rigs to the count, followed by Pennsylvania, which added six; Michigan, which added 2; and North Dakota and Ohio, which each added one. Louisiana led the states reporting losses for the week, with nine fewer working rigs. Louisiana was followed by Texas, whose count dropped by 8; Wyoming and Colorado, which each lost two rigs; and California and Kansas, whose counts each dropped by one. New Mexico's count remained unchanged for the week.

DOC.HEAD: Visa Imposes Moratorium
DOC.TEXT: Visa U.S.A. has imposed a moratorium on issuing memberships to new applicants from non-banking companies. Visa said the six-month moratorium was a ``prudent measure'' while it reviews Visa membership eligibility in general. Institutions not eligible to join Visa directly would not be allowed to join indirectly by merging or acquiring a member company without the approval of Visa's board, the company said. The membership freeze, annouced on Friday, is Visa's latest step to soothe bankers disturbed by the success of their non-bank rivals in winning part of the valuable credit-card market, particularly the success of American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s Universal card. Visa in October announced tight rules on so-called affinity programs. Under those programs, non-financial organizations can issue cards under contract with a financial institution. The Universal card is sold under a relationship with Universal Bank in Atlanta. Under the new rules, affinity cards cannot be used to access any account that isn't maintained by a financial institution that issues Visa cards.

DOC.HEAD: Patent Office Grants Trademark to Scent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 2 grafs with Clarke quotes
DOC.TEXT: The Patent and Trademark Office today recognized an aroma as a subject for trademark registration for the first time. It granted a trademark to the scent of a line of embroidery yarns and threads. The office approved registration of a scent described by its developer, Celia Clarke of Goleta, Calif., as ``a high-impact, fresh floral fragrance reminiscent of plumeria blossoms.'' Ms. Clarke's application was initially turned down on grounds the product's fragrance did not qualify for a trademark. The ruling was overturned on Sept. 19 by the Trademark Trial and Appeal Board. ``This marks the first time in the history of trademarks that a fragrance has been approved for registration,'' said Jeffrey M. Samuels, assistant commissioner for trademarks. ``We are all familiar with what trademarks look like. Now we'll see what they smell like.'' Approval of the registration was published in today's Trademark Official Gazette. Members of the public have 30 days in which to oppose registration. If no opposition is filed, the registration will be issued on Feb. 26. More than one million trademarks have been registered since the first trademark law was passed in 1870. About 600,000 of them are still in use. A trademark registration lasts 10 years and can be renewed indefinitely. David Sams, chairman of the Trademark Trial and Appeal Board, said Ms. Clarke and her associates maintained that the fragrance ``was in fact the trademark by which their product could be distinguished from other people's thread and yarn.'' Sams said the board's reasoning in granting the application was that there was no natural fragrance to yarn and no evidence that ``it was a common practice or a practice of anybody else at all in the industry, to make their yarn scented so that it stood out and was distinctive to this particular producer of yarn.'' He said the board said in a footnote to its decision that it was not passing any judgment on ``registerability of a scent or fragrance on products which are noted for those features, like perfumes and household products. We left for another day whether a party could register a particular scent for a product sold for its scent.'' ``We are here talking about an unusual application of a scent to a product,'' Sams said. Ms. Clarke, reached by telephone in Goleta, said the firm, a manufacturer of punch embroidery needles, has been in business 15 years. She said the application for trademark was submitted about two years ago, when the company began producing the scented yarn. ``We are a small company, so we haven't done a big lot with it, although we do intend to,'' she said. ``I think we will really push it now and show it more,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Ask For Total Ban on Tobacco Ads; Reject Milder Measure
DOC.TEXT: The European Community Commission, at the request of several member states, will soon propose a total ban on tobacco ads on billboards and in the print media, officials said Monday. The request for a total ban came after the 12 EC health ministers, at a meeting here, rejected a proposal to toughen curbs on tobacco ads in nations with relatively lax rules on such advertising. Sources said Germany, Britain and the Netherlands argued the proposal would not harmonize tobacco advertising rules across the EC as France, Italy and Spain already have complete bans. ``The current proposal has lived its day and died,'' said Italian Health Minister Franco De Lorenzo, who chaired the meeting. ``This will not be reanimated.'' The measure that was rejected envisaged strict controls on the content of tobacco ads in the print media and on billboards and offered a choice of 14 specific health warnings. All EC nations ban tobacco commercials on television and three ban tobacco ads from the print media. ``All delegations agree that it is necessary to take measures to reduce tobacco consumption,'' De Lorenzo told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Soars, Gold falls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout, includes midday New York rates. AMs planned by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The dollar soared against other major currencies in Europe today, boosted by a Japanese news report of a planned financial summit about the American currency, and later by comments from the U.S. Treasury Department. Gold prices fell. The Treasury's comments, included in its twice-yearly report to Congress on international economic and exchange rate policy, stressed the government's desire to see the U.S. trade deficit improved by fundamental economic factors rather than through a weak dollar. Dealers said the statement refocused attention on growing speculation that the so-called Group of Seven industrialized democracies might reaffirm their commitment to maintaining a stable dollar. The G-7 nations are the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Italy and Canada. The Kyodo News Agency report, quoting unidentified Japanese sources, said a G-7 meeting was planned in January, and sparked a flurry of buying. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9205 from $1.9400 late Friday. Later in New York trading, the pound fetched $1.9163. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.25 yen to a closing 133.00 yen. DOC.HEAD: Judge Tightens Bail Conditions to Avoid `Phone Tag' with Prosecutors
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Monday tightened the terms of bail for indicted financier Charles H. Keating Jr., after prosecutors complained that the former Lincoln Savings and Loan owner couldn't be found over the Thanksgiving weekend. Superior Court Judge Lance Ito ordered the district attorney's office and Keating's attorneys to set up a schedule specifying the day and hour at which Keating can be reached by telephone each week. The order differs from one set earlier by a federal judge by establishing the specific time for a call. ``That way you don't have to play phone tag with each other,'' Ito said. Keating, free on $300,000 bail, is charged with 46 counts of fraud alleging he misled investors into believing that high-yield, high-risk bonds issued by the Lincoln parent American Continental Corp. were safe. The indictment says buyers, many of them elderly people investing their life savings, lost some $200 million. The bonds became worthless in April 1989, when American Continental sought bankruptcy protection. Lincoln was seized the following day by federal regulators. Experts say its failure will cost taxpayers $2 billion, the largest savings and loan bailout to date. Ito postponed until Jan. 11 discussion of an amended indictment that revises 20 of 42 original counts against Keating and adds four counts. The case is scheduled to go to trial Feb. 3, but Deputy District Attorney William Hodgman said that date probably would be postponed until spring. In documents filed Friday, Keating's attorneys said their client could not be located during the Thanksgiving weekend because he had changed his home phone number in the Phoenix area to an unlisted number. Conditions of bail set by U.S. District Judge John Davies required Keating to be available for a weekly phone call from the district attorney's office, but did not set a specific time. Hodgman said Keating violated the orders of bail by not advising his office of the new number. ``We want to know where Mr. Keating is,'' Hodgman said. ``Mr. Keating's got to play by the same rules as any other defendant.'' Keating appeared for the hearing but declined to talk to reporters. His attorney, Stephen Neal, criticized the Senate Ethics Committee, which has been conducting hearings into the relationship between Keating and five senators, for declining to grant Keating immunity in exchange for testimony. Neal said it was impossible for the committee to learn the truth without hearing from Keating. ``It is far more important that the committee gets to the bottom of what is going on with campaign contributions than the ability or inability of the federal government to prosecute anybody,'' Neal said.

DOC.NOTE: For release Sunday, Dec. 9, and thereafter
Eds: Also contained in AP Newsfeatures
DOC.HEAD: Mailed print subscribers get 2 b&w photos and 1 illustration.)
DOC.TEXT: Shopping mall patrons across the land are screaming the same question: Do the kids think they own the place? Well, among those teen-age hordes, some in fact do. Kicking them out, though, has proved a dubious solution. There's money in those jeans. ---

With Christmas shoppers breathing down their necks, the people who run the nation's almost 35,000 shopping centers have an eye out these days for the droves of teen-agers whose high jinks sometimes explode in violence and whose presence sometimes intimidates other shoppers. About a dozen shopping centers and malls have gone so far as to ban teen-agers entirely at critical hours. And even those that haven't are looking for ways to cope with youngsters who have adopted the comfortable and elegant mall surroundings as second homes. At its fall meeting in Kansas City, Mo., the International Council of Shopping Centers held a seminar titled ``Hanging Out: Whose Shopping Mall Is It Anyway?'' At McKinley Mall in Hamburg, N.Y., 15 miles from Buffalo, no one under 20 is allowed inside between 6 p.m. and 10 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays, unless they are reporting for work or are accompanied by an adult. The mall took the action after an estimated 600 teens inundated the mall's food court one Friday night and a fight in the parking lot spilled over into the common area. At the Randall Park Mall in North Randall, Ohio, the operators don't allow unescorted teens at any hour. Even teen-agers going to the theater must be brought and picked up. Omaha's Park Fair has banned people under 18. Beyond those shopping centers which have banned teens, far more have reported trouble controlling teen crowds that clog common areas, block store entrances and generally, if inadvertently, intimidate customers. But banning teens has also posed an ironic conflict. Teens are good customers. They spend a lot of money. Mall operators say the problems stem from changes in the community, a growing number of two-income latchkey families and the cuts made in school budgets, leaving the teens no place to go when the closing bell rings. They are a new kind of temporarily homeless, and the mall is a haven. The scene at Aurora Mall, outside Denver, Colo., this Christmas is a study in contrast to a year ago. This year there are teen-age advisory boards at all eight high schools in the mall's neighborhood, and each of these sends a representative to a super advisory board that meets once a month at the mall. These youngsters, with adult advisors drawn from the community, help devise programs that can help revise adult perceptions about teen-agers. So this Christmas they will field Customer Service Ambassadors, drawn from the high schools, who will help adult customers with their parcels, with directions to shops, and try to change adult attitudes to the teen-age presence. There will also be teen-agers available at the mall to wrap Christmas presents for customers. Consider last year. Mall operators began to notice a growing number of youngsters in the spring of 1989. Susan Keene, general manager, says they were congregating in large groups, ``acting out in loud fashion'' and otherwise horsing around. ``We started receiving complaints from our adult shoppers'' on Mondays following the weekends. ``So in order to get rid of the problem and get rid of it fast, we instituted a get-tough policy in the fall of 1989. It was a kind of steamroller approach.'' Youngsters were handed wallet-sized cards with rules of behavior on them - no behavior likely to cause a disturbance, no sitting on planter walls, no alcoholic beverages, no blocking store entrances. After two weeks notice, they were given one warning and then photographed and banned. Recalcitrants were arrested by local police and charged with trespass. The mall was banning 10 to 15 youngsters every Saturday. But it didn't work. There was no decrease in teen-agers coming to the mall. Harassment was not the answer. Furthermore, the mall became the target of a boycott and pickets from the black community, which perceived the tactic as being aimed at their children. ``While only about 20 percent of Aurora Mall shoppers were African-American,'' says manager Keene, ``about 75 percent of the kids who come to the mall are African-American.'' Clearly something else had to be done. The mall began with a marketing survey, intercepting youngsters and holding discussion groups to find out just who they were. What they found was something of a surprise.

DOC.NOTE: For release Sunday, Dec. 9, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: a surprise.
DOC.TEXT: The teens and their parents, they discovered, had a sense of ownership of the mall, even though it was private property. They felt it was their right to congregate there, not just to shop. The youngsters came to be with their friends, to make dates, to find out where the parties were, all of this in lieu of a school environment which had suffered from budget cuts. The mall offered an elegant and inexpensive focus for the youngsters, and in some cases a place they perceived as being safer than their own neighborhoods. The youngsters, concerned about gang activity in the community, saw the mall as safe haven. Stephen Huber, of a Cleveland firm that manages a number of malls, says that on one occasion three teen gang members were standing at an entrance to the mall when four members of a rival gang drove by. The four turned the car around, got a running start, jumped the curb and crashed into the entrance in an attempt to run down their rivals. Oddly, gang activity is easier to deal with than the teen problem, shopping center operators say, because the police know who they are and what to do about them. Not so the average teens. The market survey showed that the teens visited the Aurora Mall one to three times a week, visited an average of 10 stores and spent an average of $64 a visit. Most of them had sincere career aspirations, and in spite of their bizarre dress and behavior were basically ``good kids.'' So the mall operators set about changing their own mind-set, and that of security people. Just because kids had intimidating appearances and numbers, it didn't mean they were bad or that they were any more bizarre than previous generations. The mall also hired a customer service director whose job is more public relations than security, which also comes under his purview. The accent is on politeness, requests to move on, or please don't block the store front. It seems to be working. And the city of Aurora put a highly visible police mini-station in the heart of the mall. There was a similar impasse at the Columbia Mall in Columbia, S.C., where a heavy-handed approach eventually yielded to gentler means. Without knowing it, the mall operator had used a strong but old South Carolina law that permits the banning of people from private property for six months under penalty of law. They used the law frequently, but then discovered it had been passed as a tool for segregationists. There was a community uproar. Now the mall has a polite Customer Service Corps, neatly dressed people in blazers and carrying radios and directories of stores. They help customers with parcels, give directions, and act as new sets of eyes and ears as they roam around the mall. The emergence of the mall as a prime community focal point has been growing throughout the nation each year. The number of malls and floor space has been growing about 7 percent a year, drawing 172.4 million adults, 70 percent of the population. Malls and shopping centers now number 34,683, and more than 1,500 new ones were started in 1989. One near Minneapolis plans to house about 600 stores. So the teen problem can be expected to grow. Most expect teen banning to abate, however. Teens are a growing $56 billion market, and this has not passed unnoticed. Bans quite naturally have alienated teens. At the McKinley Mall in Hamburg, N.Y., 15-year-old Jan Harris says, ``A lot of kids who are here are straight. The reason they turn away people is that they're different.'' She was banned from the mall when she sat on a bench to rest. ``Is that a valid reason to kick someone out?'' she asked. By and large, McKinley merchants say, the ban has not affected business as much as they feared. Ron Jefferson, who runs the Singing River Mall in Gautier, Miss., which attracts as many as 200 teens on a weekend, has put in an outside entrance to the game rooms to divert traffic. He has also put in extra security and more phones at the theaters. On visits to local schools he reminds teens that they are potential mall employees as well as patrons. Malls have been havens for teen-agers almost from the beginning. In fact mall owners took pains to attract them with movie theaters, game rooms, record stores. The difference today is their sheer numbers. Managers are trying innovations to attract teens. One offers vacant space to a church group, which has set up drop-in counseling. Another features fashion shows with high school students as models. Says one manager, ``When I was a kid, I didn't have an American Express card, but these kids do. They spend a lot of money here.''

DOC.HEAD: Steel Importers Lash out Against ``Dumping'' Accusations
DOC.TEXT: Steel importers have taken a bad rap for ``dumping'' products in the United States when the real culprit is volatility in world currency markets, a trade group said Monday. The American Institute for Imported Steel contended that the price discrepancies often seen in foreign steel are in many instances due to unpredictable changes in the dollar's value against foreign currencies. In recent months the dollar has fluctuated dramatically on world currenyy markets amid a weakening of the U.S economy and the growing potential for war in the Persian Gulf. ``Under present anti-dumping rules throughout the world, international traders can become targets of expensive litigation for reasons entirely beyond their control,'' said John Griffin, the institute's president, at a news conference in New York, where the group was holding an annual meeting. ``Dumping'' is the practice of selling foreign goods at unfairly low prices in order to grab a bigger share of the market. It is considered a violation of import rules in the United States and many other countries. There has been widespread concern in the steel industry about what domestic producers call foreign dumping of steel in the United States, once one of the world's mightiest steelmakers but now a major importer. To remedy what it called a potentially serious problem, the steel-import institute proposed an agreement under which governments apply a 10-year average to exchange rates to be used in calculating costs and prices. The proposal, an amendment to existing anti-dumping rules, would ``strengthen the law by sharpening focus on truly predatory acts of international price discrimination unrelated to shifting exchange rates,'' said Griffin. It was unclear if the proposal would win the necessary international support. Backers hope to introduce it in negotiations next year. Institute members said dumping accusations were worsening with the dollar's recent plunge in value, which were increasing imported steel's dollar value but not giving the price charged in the United States enough time to catch up. As a result, steel importers are being accused of ``technical'' dumping in cases brought against them by U.S. steel manufacturers, group members said. American companies brought roughly 395 cases against importers between 1980 and 1989, a dramatic increase from earlier years, said Kermit Almstedt, an attorney representing the trade group. Almstedt said he did not know how many of those lawsuits were prompted by ``technical'' dumping but added, ``one of the reasons you're seeing a lot of cases against the Japanese is a result of the exchange rates.'' Importers found charging unfairly low prices for their products can be slapped with a tarrif equal to the difference between what they charged and the product's perceived fair market price, Almstedt said. Steel importers fear a big litigation problem in 1992 with President Bush's planned lifting of the system of Voluntary Restraint Agreements which for the past five years has curbed imports of steel from most major supplying countries into the United States. The potential for a subsequent flood of steel imports into the United States could prompt a backlash from domestic steel manufacturers, members said.

DOC.HEAD: Powerful Central Bank Warns on Government Borrowing Plans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to RECAST lead to emphasize call for spending cuts, moves to 3rd graf quote from Poehl; no pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: In a post-election warning, the president of Germany's powerful central bank said Monday that drastsic government spending cuts are needed to offset the costs of unification. Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl said in a magazine interview that the government plans to borrow too much money to rebuild the crippled eastern part of the newly united nation. Poehl, whose comments were confirmed by the bank's press department, said ``far reaching and drastic'' government spending cuts were needed to offset the borrowing. Johann Wilhelm Gaddum, a director of the bank, also criticized the government's plans. With Chancellor Helmut Kohl's election victory now history, from bars to boardrooms Germans are returning to a main topic of conversation: How much will it cost to bail out economically backward eastern Germany? Among the possible ways to pay the massive bill are cutting government spending or going further into debt. Neither is popular, and either could eventually lead Kohl into trouble despite his Sunday re-election. The influential news magazine Der Spiegel said the total government debt could reach $860 billion by next year, leading to worries that today's unification joy will become tomorrow's debts for future generations. Estimates of how much it will cost to give eastern Germans a Western standard of living reach into the hundreds of billions of dollars. Eastern workers are anxious to have their salaries brought up to Western levels, and a recent railroad strike could be a sign of trouble to come. For now, Kohl's government plans to run up the national debt to pay for unification bills. That decision drew Poehl's remarks. The central bank president told Stern magazine that the government's plan to borrow between $93 billion and $100 billion in 1991 ``was too high.'' The growing deficit is driving up interest rates and thus borrowing costs for ordinary Germans who want loans for cars, homes and other items. Chancellor Kohl needs Poehl's backing to complete a full and swift merger of capitalist western Germany with the formerly Communist eastern part of the country. The Bundesbank president is probably the single most important figure in guiding the economy in this nation of 78 million people. During the summer, Poehl expressed reservations about Kohl's plans to exchange much of East Germany's virtually worthless money into West German marks at a 1-to-1 rate. Poehl later went along, despite his misgivings. The Bundesbank is especially vigilant in monitoring German monetary policy, keeping a special watch out for economic moves that could drive up inflation. Gaddum, the Bundesbank director responsible for eastern Germany, said Monday that officials don't understand repeated warnings about the dangers of high government borrowing. ``When I look at the planned growth rates of the public budgets for 1991, I have doubts whether the message has been understood,'' the director said in an interview on Germany's ARD television network. The comments from the two Bundesbank officials could cause trouble for Kohl, under increasing criticism for planning to borrow too much. Finance Minister Theo Waigel has said the borrowing will be raised only to the point justifiable by German unification. ``Then, in the course of medium-term financial planning we have to reduce the debt again, so that the repayment of interest and principal don't become too great later on,'' Waigel said on election night. Oskar Lafontaine, the unsuccessful candidate for chancellor from the Social Democratic Party, has repeatedly accused Kohl of slipshod financial planning for the Oct. 3 German merger.

DOC.HEAD: Passengers Unfazed, Employees Don't Say Much
DOC.TEXT: Employees were low-key and passengers seemed mostly oblivious Monday after the parent of Continental Airlines filed for protection under federal bankruptcy laws for the second time in seven years. ``I'm not worried as long as I can get home today,'' Gwendolyn Currie, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said. Her flight to New Orleans was detoured to Houston because of bad weather and she was among the crowd waiting for Continental flights at Houston Intercontinental Airport's Terminal C, the Houston-based airline's main hub. ``I just hope to get out of here today,'' she said. ``I hope I still have a way to get back,'' said Frank Dow, who was heading to Lafayette, La., from Houston. Some Continental employees were handed a printed message about the filing when they reported to work Monday morning and a text of the announcement was made availabletto others on computer monitors at passenger check-in gates. Passenger reaction to the announcement was minimal, gate attendants said, probably because so few people knew of it. The airline company said it intended to run normally despite the Chapter 11 filing in a federal bankruptcy court in Delaware, where Continental is incorporated. ``The impact is zero,'' said one flight officer, who declined to be identified, saying employees are told to not speak with reporters. ``It's business as usual. ``Look around,'' he said, pointing to aircraft taxiing and passengers boarding. ``I don't have any anxiety.'' ``This is something external, with the fuel prices,'' a flight attendant with him said. ``It's all out of our control and there's very little I can do. I think it's important the public recognizes this is an administrative action. That's what's important. If you didn't watch the news, you would never know.'' The flight officer, who said he went through the 1983 bankruptcy filing when flights were halted, employees laid off and passengers stranded, noted the chaos of that time was absent on Monday. ``It's very relaxed,'' he said. ``This was a whole different background.'' Capt. Robert Finley, a senior pilot at Continental, said he was among four top pilots to meet with airline chairman and president Hollis Harris on Thursday to discuss the situation. ``Continental Airlines is going to wind up surviving and being a leader in the industry,'' Finley said. ``Mr. Harris is a very positive, people-oriented person which is something we haven't known a lot of around Continental for awhile. ``It seems like a breath of fresh air to see a man like him in that job. If anyone can pull us through these difficult times - where fuel costs are skyrocketing and all costs are elevating at an enormous rate while the fares are still being depressed and the fare wars are going on - I think Mr. Harris is the guy who can do it.'' Finley said he was not nervous about his future. ``I went through the last one,'' he said. ``That one made me nervous. But this I feel is necessary and is a positive move to strengthen the company so we can move forward.'' ``If I was an employee, I'd really be concerned,'' passenger Robert Cloud of Houston said. Cloud was a reluctant Continental passenger and was sent to the airline on Monday by United Airlines when his United flight was canceled. ``I had heard they were having problems,'' he said while waiting to fly to San Francisco and then Bangkok. ``It's one of those hazards.'' ``I can just go to another airline,'' said Archie Buchanan, flying to Phoenix. ``Filing Chapter 11 doesn't normally mean you're going to quit flying - at least for the short term.'' ``I think we're too tired right now to worry,'' Beverly Zigal, of Austin, who was heading for Belize, Central America. ``Hopefully, we'll get back. It'll be interesting to see what transpires in the next few days. I hope it hits the newspapers down there but we'll be off on some remote island fishing.'' ``As long as we get there, we'll probably get back,'' added her companion, Jane Bessent. ``I've been through it three times before with other carriers,'' said one Continental flight officer, who refused to provide his name but said he was based in Newark. `You position yourself. It's a little bit of a surprise and it's kind of strange to hear this from a reporter.''

DOC.HEAD: Retiring NYSE Chairman Joins Merrill Lynch Board
DOC.TEXT: The retiring chairman and chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, John J. Phelan Jr., will join the board of brokerage giant Merrill Lynch & Co. on Jan. 1, the investment firm announced Monday. Phelan announced earlier this year he would step down at the end of the year after 6{ years in the top post at the NYSE, guiding it through its most tumultuous period that included the market crash in 1987. He is being succeeded at the NYSE by William H. Donaldson. Before being elected chairman and chief executive at the NYSE in May 1984, Phelan was its president and chief operating officer from 1980 to 1984. Phelan has been associated with the securities industry for 35 years. He becomes the 17th member on the Merrill Lynch board. Merrill Lynch is the nation's biggest brokerage company with $14 billion in annual revenue and 10,500 brokers.

DOC.HEAD: Surging Soybeans Boost Crop Futures
DOC.TEXT: A strong rally in the soybean and soybean product markets helped lift grain futures prices to a higher close Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The surge began in the soybean oil pit after a large number of delivery notices were cancelled, indicating soybean oil supplies for delivery against the December contract may be tighter than previously thought. Steve Freed, grains analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago, said the soybean complex also may have been boosted by reports that Germany plans to sell at least some of its excess soybean crushing capacity to the Soviet Union. Such an increase in European crushing activity would likely translate into increased demand for U.S. soybeans because the Europeans must import all the beans they use. ``We know Brazil is basically out and the Argentinias are running out, so the only store left in town would be the United States,'' Freed said. At the close, wheat futures were } cent to 2{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.47{ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 2} cents higher with December at $2.30{ a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to 1} cents higher with December at $1.13} a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 11{ cents higher with January at $6 a bushel.

The stock market edged higher today, extending the previou session's advance in moderate dealings. The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 40.84 points on Friday, was up 5.45 points at 2,565.10 with one hour left in the session. It had been up by about 16 points near the opening, but later gave back nearly all the gains. Advancing issues were ahead of decliners by a margin of 3 to 2, with 929 up, 603 down and 451 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume totaled 142.82 million shares as of 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said the market opened strongly in the wake of gains on overseas markets and in bond futures trading overnight. There was continuing hope that the Bush administration's offer to discuss the Middle East crisis with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein might avert a war. The rise in the Dow Jones average was held in check by AT&T, which fell 2[ to 30 after offering to acquire NCR Corp. in a $6 billion stock swap. AT&T was the most-actively traded issue on the NYSE. NCR was the second most active, surging 26{ to 82\. The AT&T offer was $90 a share, but NCR indicated it wanted to remain independent. Elsewhere in the technology sector, Digital Equipment was up 3[ at 54~, IBM was up [ at 113}, Hewlett Packard was up 1{ at 31{ and Honeywell was up 1[ at 91\. There was mixed evidence today on the state of the economy. The National Association of Purchasing Management said its purchasing managers index, a closely-followed economic indicator, tumbled to 41.3 percent in November from 43.4 percent in October. The decline indicated a further weakening in manufacturing and the overall economy. But the government said construction spending increased 1.3 percent in October, the first gain in three months. The advance was due in large part to new school and sewer projects as spending on residential and non-residential buildings continued to fall. Among active issues on the NYSE, Pepsico was up { at 26[, Philip Morris was up \ at 48~, Limited was up 1\ at 17 and General Electric was up { to 54|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed stocks rose 0.95 to 177.01. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 0.37 to 302.16.

The stock market posted small gains today, helped by lower interest rates and stability in oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial issues was up 4.71 at 2,564.36 with five minutes to go before the close. Advancing issues outpaced declines by a margin of 3 to 2 among issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with 933 issues up, 646 down and 435 unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Plus, Visa Systems Exchange ATM Cardholder Privileges
DOC.TEXT: Plus System Inc. and Visa USA agreed Monday on a program providing their cardholders with access to all U.S.-based automated teller machines in the Plus and Visa networks. Over the next two years, the move will add 14,000 domestic locations to the Visa network, and 6,000 locations to the Plus network. Wesley C. Tallman, Visa's executive vice president for debit systems, estimated that financial institutions will see increased ATM volume from the 410 million cards from both networks. Only small technical changes will be required in the respective machines to permit the added access, executives said. Customers will know they can take advantage of the added-access machines when they see the Plus or Visa decals installed on their ATMs. The announcement was made at the Bank Administration Institute's Retail Delivery Systems Conference. Plus is based in Denver, Colo., and Visa headquarters are in San Mateo, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Arco Suits Seek to Force Insurers to Cover Toxic Waste Cleanup Costs
DOC.TEXT: Atlantic Richfield Co. sued more than 70 insurance carriers for reimbursement of the huge costs of restoring 50 hazardous waste sites polluted over six decades, company officials said Monday. Experts said the case will help set precedents for insurers and companies nationwide. It stems from a California Supreme Court ruling two weeks ago that the cost of cleaning up toxic pollution is part of the damages to be paid by insurers under standard comprehensive general liability policies. Arco, the big Los Angeles-based oil company, also is asking to have the duties and liabilities of both companies and insurers clarified under the state Supreme Court ruling. ``Arco believes that this action will bring the questions of insurance coverage and compensation before a single forum for orderly and efficient resolution and administration,'' Arco said in a statement. Supreme courts in Massachusetts, Minnesota, Washington and North Carolina have made similar rulings in recent months. Thecase decided Nov. 15 said insurance companies that provide property coverage must pay their policyholders' costs of cleaning up toxic waste at government order. The case was brought against AIU Insurance Co. and other insurers after FMC, A Chicago-based chemical and weapons company, was sued by federal and local agencies for allegedly polluting land and water at 79 sites in a number of states. The unanimous state Supreme Court ruling was broad but not all-inclusive. Carriers have legal defenses that include gross negligence or willful misconduct by the insured. Many recent policies also exclude all but ``sudden and accidental'' instances of pollution. Companies affected by Superfund legislation all over the nation are checking old policies to see if they can escape liability for increasingly expensive toxic cleanup work, said Joel Moskowitz, a partner specializing in environmental law with the Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher firm in Los Angeles. Steve Wasdick, a spokesman for Aetna Casualty and Surety Co. of America, said suits over toxic waste liability have frequently wound up in court, and often turn on the language of the policy. By the early 1970s, many carriers included ``pollution exclusion'' clauses to avoid liability except when an incident was sudden and accidental. ``There have been a good number that have gone the insurers' way too,'' Wasdick said. Among the carriers named as defendants in Arco's lawsuit are Aetna, Fireman's Fund Insurance, Travelers Insurance, Lloyd's of London and more than 20 other foreign companies. The defendants issued policies as far back as the 1930s to Arco and its predecessor companies: Anaconda Co., Richfield Oil Corp., Sinclair Oil Corp. and Atlantic Refining Co. Arco spokesman Albert Greenstein said it's too early to predict the effect of the company's suit, filed Nov. 23, because the Supreme Court ruling opened new ground. Greenstein also said it's too early to tell the total costs of the cleanups. ``It goes back so far and involves so many cases that it's impossible to say,'' he said. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency estimates the average costs of cleaning up a Superfund site has grown from $9 million to $25 million during the past five years. However, a recent study by the Rand Corp. think tank in Santa Monica found that the vast majority cost far less than that.

DOC.HEAD: How Sweet It Is: A Scented Trademark
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS first two grafs; INSERTS new 17th graf, Oscar Mastin, specifying legal protections for perfumes. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A smell can be registered as a trademark just as a word, name, symbol, color or sound can be, the Patent and Trademark Office said in a ground-breaking decision Monday. The office approved registration of the scent of a type of embroidery yarn and sewing thread produced by Clarke's OSEWEZ (pronounced ``Oh Sew Easy'') of Goleta, Calif. According to an exhibit in the case, the yarn can be used to make, among other things, a scented skunk. If nobody objects within 30 days, the registration will be issued on Feb. 26. A trademark is defined by law as any word, name, symbol or device, or any combination of such things, that is used to distinguish a product from the products sold or manufactured by others. In an earlier case, the color pink was recognized as a trademark for a type of fiberglass insulation. The trademark was granted in the mid-1980s to the Owens-Corning Corp., whose Fiberglas product is pink. Sound marks, such as the NBC chimes, also have been registered. There had not previously been a case, however, in which a trademark was granted for an aroma. ``We are all familiar with what trademarks look like,'' said Jeffrey M. Samuels, assistant commissioner for trademarks. ``Now we'll see what they smell like.'' What this one smells like, said Celia Clarke of Clarke's OSEWEZ, is `` a high impact, fresh, floral fragrance reminiscent of plumeria blossoms.'' Trademark Examining Attorney David Cline had refused the registration on grounds that consumers were likely to regard the scent as just a pleasant feature of the yarn and not an indication of its origin. Ms. Clarke argued that customers, dealers and distributors throughout the embroidery field recognized the firm as the source of scented embroidery yarn and thread. She submitted as part of the record a kit containing yarn and thread for making a scented skunk. The Trademark Trial and Appeal Board, in a decision handed down Sept. 19, said Ms. Clarke was the only person who had marketed yarns and threads with a fragrance. ``Under the circumstances of this case, we see no reason why a fragrance is not capable of serving as a trademark to identify and distinguish a certain kind of product,'' the board said. ``It should be noted that we are not here talking about the registrability of scents or fragrances of products which are noted for those features, such as perfumes, colognes or scented household products,'' it added in a footnote. Oscar Mastin, a spokesman for the Patent and Trademark Office, said perfumes can be patented and their names registered as trademarks. J. David Sams, chairman of the board, said the case was the first in which copyright registration had been sought for a scent. The company advertises its product as ``Clarke's Distinctive Sof-Scented Yarns.'' They are of the type known in the trade as Russian embroidery or punch embroidery. Ms. Clarke, reached by telephone in Goleta, said the firm, a manufacturer of punch embroidery needles, has been in business 15 years. She said the application for trademark was submitted about two years ago, when the company began producing the scented yarn. ``We are a small company, so we haven't done a big lot with it, although we do intend to,'' she said. ``I think we will really push it now and show it more.'' More than 1 million trademarks have been registered since the first trademark law was passed in 1870. About 600,000 of them are still in use. A trademark registration lasts 10 years and can be renewed indefinitely.

DOC.HEAD: Lightning Rod Lorenzo Gone, But Company He Led Is Dogged By His Legacy
With AM-Continental Airlines, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Frank Lorenzo is no longer boss at Continental Airlines, but the carrier he shaped is following a road he traveled in the early 1980s when Continental first sought refuge under federal bankruptcy laws. On Monday, Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. filed for protection for a second time, blaming the move on the recent runup in fuel costs and heavy debts accrued in the 1980s. Lorenzo, the 50-year-old entrepreneur who came to symbolize a tumultuous decade of airline deregulation, announced in August he was selling off most of his stake in Continental to Scandinavian Airlines System. He also resigned as chairman and chief executive at Continental, replaced by Hollis Harris, a respected manager lured from rival Delta Air Lines Inc. Just two weeks ago, in his first public remarks since departing Continental, Lorenzo warned that the troubles in the airline industry could leave just three or four major airlines within three years. ``And if you don't like air fares today ... just hold on to your hats - you may not have seen anything yet in terms of air fare price increases,'' he said. The predecessor to Continental Holdings was Texas Air Corp., which Lorenzo built into the nation's largest airline operator, parenting Continental and Eastern Airlines. The growth of Texas Air began in 1966 when Lorenzo and Harvard University classmate Robert Carney formed a financial advisory firm. Even before that, in 1963, Lorenzo's first professional job was in the industry, when he was hired by Trans World Airlines as a financial analyst. Within two years, he was manager of the financial analysis department at Eastern. In 1968, the Lorenzo-Carney duo created Jet Capital Corp., which bought a controlling interest in Texas International Airlines in 1972. Lorenzo, then 32, a Harvard MBA and son of Spanish immigrants from Queens, N.Y., was the carrier's youngest president. In 1981, Lorenzo merged Texas International with Continental after a bitter takeover battle. His image as a union buster began when he fought organized labor at Continental and won. The image grew in 1983 when he put Continental, then the nation's eighth-largest airline, under bankruptcy protection, scrapped labor contracts and hired strike replacements at lower pay. Lorenzo subsequently acquired New York Air, People Express and Frontier airlines, which were merged into Continental. He didn't face another labor fight until he acquired Eastern in 1986, where his relationship with unions was acrimonious and a strike against the airline made him the target of union members' hatred. Using billions of dollars in borrowed money and cheap fares, Continental and Eastern, once high-cost airlines, helped Texas Air become the nation's largest airline operator, capturing about 20 percent of the domestic market. But with bitter resistance from the unions, particularly at Eastern, both airlines came under extreme financial pressure and there were doubts about Eastern's ability to survive. After the strike hamstrung Eastern in 1989, Eastern sought bankruptcy court protection and is still operating under the supervision of a court trustee who replaced Lorenzo in April. It was then that Continental began a quiet hunt for a new leader, a search that resulted in the hiring of Harris. ``It's been perfectly obvious to me that I personally have become a lightning rod for many of the attacks that the company has taken,'' Lorenzo said in announcing his departure.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Stop Sliding; Up 30 Cents a Barrel
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices see-sawed but finished slightly higher Monday as traders saw dimmed peace hopes in the Persian Gulf. Light sweet crude oil settled at $29.15 per barrel, up 30 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange on contracts for January delivery. Price tumbled $4.06 a barrel Friday, when President Bush proposed face-to-face discussions with ranking Iraqi officials. ``It was coming back from a bit of an overreaction on Friday,'' said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Speculation of a possible diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf crisis pushed crude futures to their second sharpest drop since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August. Crude fell Monday on hints of peace and rose on hints of war, but stayed slightly higher all day. It rose as much as $1.63 per barrel, but near the end of trading, crude was only 20 cents higher. ``We had selling, as it appeared the peace winds were blowing,'' said analyst Bob Baker at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Prices fell after the State Department said only U.S. and Iraqi officials would participate in the proposed talks later this month, which traders interpreted as a sign of progress toward peace. But crude began rising again after Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said sanctions against Iraq might not be sufficient to get Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. War in the Middle East would threaten crucial world oil supplies, making crude more expensive. Crude for delivery in later months fell as those contracts moved to catch up with the losses suffered by January crude. On Friday, later months had been held back by daily decline limits intended to lessen risks faced by oil traders. Futures for refined petroleum products kept falling on Monday in a move to catch up with Friday's crude losses. Unleaded gasoline settled at 73.52 cents per gallon, down 5.40 cents, on contracts for January delivery. Home heating oil settled at 84.67 cents a gallon, down 3.75 cents, on contracts for January delivery. Later contract months were down for both products. Some analysts were surprised that unleaded gasoline showed more weakeness than home heating oil. Baker suggested traders might have been responding belatedly to higher federal gasoline taxes imposed over the weekend. Natural gas prices, which are not affected by the Mideast standoff since it does not threaten supplies, were higher Monday. Contracts for January delivery rose 3 cents to $2.475 per 1,000 cubic feet. Later contracts rose moderately.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Slide Persists, Purchasing Managers Say
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Business continued to slow at the nation's industrial firms in November, extending a decline that is likely to continue for some time, the National Association of Purchasing Management said Monday. Private economists, agreeing with the trade group's assessment, predicted the downturn will continue until interest rates come down and the Middle East crisis is resolved. The purchasing managers said production and new orders both dropped, pushing the group's index of economic activity down to 41.3 percent from 43.4 percent in October. The latest monthly decline was the fifth in a row, sending the index to its lowest point since November 1982, during the last recession. When the index registers below 50 percent, it indicates the manufacturing economy is declining, and when it drops below 44 percent, it points to a shrinking of the overall economy. The survey results substantiated other statistical evidence that the economy's health has worsened, including a Commerce Department report Monday on construction spending. The department said spending for new building rose 1.3 percent in October, the first gain in three months. But the advance was largely due to new school and sewer projects. Spending on residential and non-residential buildings continued to fall. Overall residential, non-residential and government spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $434.4 billion, up from $428.9 billion in September. Alan Levinson, an economist with Wefa Group, a private economic forecasting service based in Bala Cynwd, Pa., said the purchasing managers results ``confirm the fact that we are slipping deeper into recession.'' Robert Chandross, chief economist with Lloyds Bank PLC in New York, called the survey figures ``unambiguously weak'' with employment particularly hard-hit. Thirty-three percent of the purchasing managers questioned said employment was down at their companies, while 62 percent said it was the same and 5 percent said hiring was up. In October, 28 percent said employment was down, 63 percent said it was the same and 9 percent said it was higher. The purchasing managers said many companies reported layoffs, hiring freezes, plant closings and other steps to bring staffing levels in line with business activity. Employment s tied directly to production and new orders, both of which declined. Forty-three percent of the purchasing managers surveyed said their firms had fewer new orders in November, while 39 percent said orders were the same and only 18 percent said they had more orders. It was the fifth consecutive monthly decline for new orders, dropping them to to their lowest point since May 1982. In October, 34 percent reported fewer orders, 47 percent were the same and 19 percent were up. Robert Bretz, chairman of the trade group, said the decline in orders was an ominous sign for the economy. ``It appears likely the negative trend will continue for some time,'' Bretz said in a statement. Production levels fell for the fourth straight month in November. Thirty-five percent of those surveyed said production at their firms was down, 49 percent said it was the same and 16 percent said it was up. In October, 31 percent reported lower production, 52 percent said it was the same and 17 percent said it was up. The survey also found that deliveries to the companies from suppliers were faster than the previous month. This is yet another negative economic signal, because it means companies have fewer orders to fill and therefore can deliver their goods faster. Inflation, accelerated by the surge in oil prices since the Middle East crisis began in August, continued to put a bite on industrial firms. Most reported they were again paying higher prices for raw materials, although the rate of increase was down from September and October. Chandross said the economy would begin to turn around if the Federal Reserve eases credit. ``The weaker the economy looks, the more aggressively the Federal Reserve will have to lower interest rates,'' to stimulate business activity, he said. Both he and Levinson said, however, that the Middle East crisis, which has sent oil prices sharply higher, stands in the way of an economic recovery. ``Hopefully, in the early part of next year, some kind of resolution to the Persian Gulf crisis will allow business and individuals to go forward with a little more certainty,'' Levinson said. The National Association of Purchasing Management is a trade group of purchasing executives at industrial companies across the country. Its monthly survey questions purchasing managers at 300 firms.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Post Small Gains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices posted modest gains Monday, as oil prices appeared to stabilize at lower levels and interest rates slipped. But more evidence of a weakening economy and a decline in American Telephone & Telegraph stock in the wake of its $6 billion stock offer for NCR Corp. limited the gains. The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 40.84 points on Friday, added another 5.94 points to close at 2,565.59. It had been up by about 16 points near the opening, but quickly gave up most of those gains. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 964 up, 612 down and 444 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 177.01 million shares, compared with 192.35 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 211.46 million shares. Analysts said the market opened strongly in the wake of gains on overseas markets and a strong performance in the bond futures market overnight. There was continuing hope that the Bush administration's offer to discuss the Middle East crisis with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein might avert a war. That development had sparked a big drop in oil prices on Friday and prices recovered only a fraction of that ground on Monday. The January contract for light, sweet crude oil, which lost $4.06 a barrel on Friday, edged up 30 cents Monday to settle at $29.15 a barrel. Bond prices, meanwhile, advanced and pushed yields on 30-year bonds down toward 8.35 percent from 8.39 percent at the end of last week. Tempering the stock market's advance were signs of more economic weakness. The National Association of Purchasing Management said its purchasing managers index, a closely-followed economic indicator, tumbled to 41.3 percent in November from 43.4 percent in October in another sign of weakening in manufacturing and the overall economy. ``People are realizing the main factor in the stock market is the economy and these figures are still painting a dismal picture of the economy,'' said Newton Zinder, a veteran market watcher at Shearson Lehman Bros. The government reported construction spending increased 1.3 percent in October, but much of that was due to new school and sewer projects. Spending on residential and non-residential buildings continued to fall. The rise in the Dow Jones average was constrained by AT&T, which fell 2 to 30[ after offering to acquire NCR in a $6 billion stock swap. AT&T was the most-actively traded issue on the NYSE with nearly 8.5 million shares traded. NCR was the second most active, surging 24} to 81{. The AT&T offer was $90 a share, but NCR indicated it wanted to remain independent. Elsewhere in the technology sector, Digital Equipment rose 2} to 54{, Hewlett Packard gained } to 30} and Honeywell rose } to 90~. IBM lost \ to 113], however. Continental Airlines Holdings dropped 2 to 1] after it filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws. But some of the big airline companies rose, reflecting expectations of lower fuel prices and speculation they could benefit from the problems affecting airlines like Continental. UAL climbed 1~ to 99], Delta Airlines rose 1} to 58{ and AMR Corp., the parent of American Airlines, gained 1\ to 48{. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $17.83 billion, or 0.59 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.01 to 177.07. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 2.13 to 380.05, and S&P's 500-stock composite index gained 1.88 to 324.10. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 2.26 to 361.32. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 302.60, up 0.81.

DOC.HEAD: Court Shields Businesses from Some Suits in Pension Case
DOC.TEXT: Businesses facing lawsuits over pensions received some protection from the Supreme Court Monday as the justices ruled workers cannot sue in state courts on grounds they were fired so their employers would not have to pay pension benefits. The court ruled unanimously that state suits are pre-empted by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, which is aimed at assuring that workers get their retirement pay. State lawsuits had loomed as potentially far more lucrative because fired employees could win punitive damages that greatly exceed lost pay. In other cases affecting businesses, the Supreme Court on Monday: -Left intact an Iowa Supreme Court ruling that forced four Omaha, Neb., automobile dealerships to defend themselves in Iowa courts in lawsuits brought under that state's consumer fraud laws. The dealerships had argued that Iowa's courts have no authority over them. -Ruled that a federal anti-counterfeiting law may be used to crack down on the sale of used cars with phony mileage readings. Writing in the pension case, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said Congress clearly intended to preclude state lawsuits over firings motivated by efforts to avoid paying pension benefits. ``The goal was to minimize the administrative and financial burden of complying with conflicting directives among states or between states and the federal government,'' O'Connor said. The decision is a victory for the Ingersoll-Rand Co., which was sued by Perry McClendon after it fired him in 1982. McClendon had been transferred by the company from San Antonio to Dallas in 1979 to develop a sales market for construction equipment there. He was fired four months before his 10th anniversary with the company. A worker with 10 years experience is entitled to have his pension vested, which meant Ingersoll-Rand would have to contribute to McClendon's retirement benefits. McClendon sued in Texas state courts, accusing his former employer of firing him to avoid paying pension benefits. The company said he was fired to reduce the workforce and save money. McClendon did not sue for lost pension benefits. In fact, shortly after he sued the company agreed to vest his pension. Instead, McClendon's suit sought a potentially big-money judgment for lost wages, mental anguish and punitive damages.

DOC.HEAD: Government Hopes to Halve State Ownership by 1994
DOC.TEXT: The government said Monday it hopes to halve state ownership of businesses in the next few years as it replaces the Marxist economic model of past Communist rulers with one where private ownership dominates. ``We may succeed in reducing the share of state ownership to 50 percent or less in the coming three to four years,'' government official Lajos Csepi told reporters. Csepi is managing director of the State Property Agency, set up in March as Hungary prepared for the first democratic elections in four decades, to oversee the sale of state-owned assets. He spoke on the eve of a scheduled national address by Premier Jozsef Antall expected to deal primarily with the dismal state of the economy. The 1991 budget, to be presented in Parliament next week, envisages a deficit of 78 billion forints, or $1.3 billion. As in other East European countries liberated from Communist domination this year, initial euphoria among the population has been replaced by gloom over the economic picture as the nation struggles to correct past mistakes. Inflation is at 35 percent. The foreign debt has reached $20 billion, the highest per capita among former Soviet bloc nations. Unemployment, officially unknown under the Communist leadership, is now at 70,000 and is expected to balloon to 200,000 of the 4.5 million work force by next year. Poverty is growing. The state MTI news agency cited statistics indicating that at least 60 percent of families are drawing on savings just to make ends meet, compared to 40 percent last year. Growing frustration peaked late last month in a three-day national blockade of main streets and highways by truckers and cabbies irate over a planned 65-percent gasoline price hike. Most of the population supported the unprecedented protest, forcing Antall's conservative government coalition to back down and agree to lesser price increases. The decision to increase gasoline prices was due in part to shortfalls in promised Soviet oil deliveries and to the rising price of crude on the world market because of the Gulf crisis. Janos Martonyi, state secretary of the Ministry of International Economic Relations, recently estimated economic damage from the Gulf crisis at $200 million, including the cancellation of trade with Iraq under terms of a U.N. embargo. Worsening economic conditions have taken their toll on government popularity, with Hungarians increasingly agreeing with opposition charges that the return to a capitalist economy is being mismanaged and is taking too long. The criticism has exacerbated internal government differences. Finance Minister Ferenc Rabar announced Oct. 10 that he planned to resign after passage of the budget, following months of dispute with Gyoergy Matolcsi, state secretary of the Prime Minister's Office and a key economic aide, over responsibility for long-term economic plans.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Bound to 5-Week High on Bullish Supply-Demand Outlook
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices bounded to five-week highs Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a late rally fueled by signs of tight supplies and prospects for stronger export demand. Most grain futures also advanced. On other commodity markets, most energy futures fell sharply; gold futures retreated while silver advanced; cattle futures were mixed; and pork futures were lower. Soybean futures settled 4\ cents to 11} cents higher in Chicago with the contract for delivery in January at $6.01\ a bushel, the first daily close above $6 for a near-term contract since Oct. 25. Wheat finished 1{ cents to 2{ cents higher with December at $2.47{ a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to 2{ cents higher with December at $2.30\ a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to 1} cents higher with December at $1.13} a bushel. The surge began in the soybean oil pit after a large number of oil delivery notices were cancelled, indicating soybean oil supplies for delivery against the December contract may be tighter than previously thought, according to analysts. Steve Freed, grains analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago, said the soybean complex also was boosted by reports that Germany is considering selling at least some of its excess soybean crushing capacity to the Soviet Union. He said such an increase in European crushing activity probably would result in stronger demand for U.S. soybeans since the Europeans must import all the beans they use. ``We know Brazil is basically out and the Argentinians are running out so the only store left in town would be the United States,'' Freed said. William Biedermann, research director for the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc., said U.S. farmers have been reluctant to sell their soybeans at the recent low prices, which bottomed out at $5.52 a bushel on Nov. 14. The limited availability of new-crop beans has contributed to the rise in prices, he said. Biedermann said tax considerations will prevent many farmers from selling new-crop commodities until the new year, leading to further supply tightness. ``You can figure that from now until the end of the year the bin door is locked up,'' he said. Near-term crude oil rose slightly but other petroleum futures fell sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting lower fears of war in the Persian Gulf. The decline extended the steep losses that were posted Friday in reaction to President Bush's new push for a negotiated settlement in the U.S.-Iraqi standoff over Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. ``The story supporting a negotiated solution is still fresh in everybody's mind,'' said Ray Mazzeo, energy futures specialist with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Light sweet crude oil futures settled $1.97 lower to 30 cents higher with January at $29.15 a barrel; heating oil was 2.29 cents to 3.89 cents lower with January at 84.67 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 3.1 cents to 5.4 cents lower with January at 73.52 cents a gallon; natural gas was 0.1 cent to 3.5 cents higher with January at $2.475 per 1,000 cubic feet. Gold futures fell sharply on New York's Commodity Exchange in line with the drop in energy prices and a stronger dollar. Silver edged higher. Gold settled $6.70 to $7.70 lower with December at $376.60 a troy ounce; silver was 1 cent to 1.6 cents higher with December at $4.138 a troy ounce. Cattle futures finished narrowly mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade. Pork futures retreated amid profit-taking after rallying early in the session on perceptions that hog marketings in the Midwest would be slowed by wintry weather. Live cattle finished .20 cent lower to .30 cent higher with December at 78.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to .10 cent higher with January at 87.60 a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .33 cent lower with December at 50.62 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .75 cents to 1.1 cents lower with February at 65.90 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Soars, Gold falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed sharply higher Monday, spurred by reports that the big industrial nations will step in to halt the U.S. currency's recent slide. Gold prices skidded, tumbling more than $6 a troy ounce in New York, in response to the dollar's advance. Analysts said the dollar was boosted by reports that the Group of Seven industrial nations would meet in January to discuss stabilizing the U.S. currency. The G-7 nations, the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Italy and Canada, have said little as the dollar plunged in recent months. Their reticence contributed to the U.S. currency's slide as traders believed the countries wanted a lower dollar, so speculation that the G-7 was about to take a stand sent the dollar higher Monday. Kevin Lawrie, senior foreign exchange manager with the Bank of Boston, said the Persian Gulf crisis continued to affect dollar trading, with rumors alternately sparking buying and selling. The dollar is seen as a relatively safe investment in times of international strife. ``We're all looking over our shoulder,'' he said. ``It's very volatile and confusing.'' Oveaseas traders said the dollar was also supported by the Treasury's twice-yearly report to Congress on international economic and exchange rate policy. The report stressed the government's desire to see the U.S. trade deficit improved by fundamental economic factors rather than by a weak dollar. Lawrie said the dollar also rose on technical buying by investors adding to their portfolios before the end of the year. The dollar surged against the British pound. Sterling fell to $1.9180 in New York from late Friday's $1.9430. In London earlier, the British pound fell to $1.9205 from $1.9400 late Friday. The U.S. currency also jumped against the Japanese yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 134.735 yen, up from 132.50 late Friday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose 0.25 yen to a closing 133.00 yen, and it was quoted later in London at 134.35 yen. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.51395 German marks, up from 1.5020; 1.2935 Swiss francs, up from 1.2770; 5.1135 French francs, up from 5.0580; 1,138.00 Italian lire, up from 1,125.25; and 1.16625 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16475. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late Friday, included: 1.5125 German marks, up from 1.4990; 1.2915 Swiss francs, up from 1.2760; 5.1113 French francs, up from 5.0630; 1.7055 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6910; 1,137.00 Italian lire, up from 1,122.00; 1.1655 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1640. Gold prices fell as the dollar advanced and amid some optimism that the Middle East crisis might be resolved without military action. In New York, a troy ounce of gold closed at $376.60 on the Commodity Exchange, down $6.70. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $375.50, down $6.50. Gold fell earlier in London to a late bid price of $380.50 a troy ounce from $382.25 late Friday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $380.85, down from $385.00 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold fell $4.95 to close at a bid $380.06. Silver prices advanced. In New York, silver rose 1.6 cents to close at $4.138 on the Commodity Exchange. In London earlier, silver rose to a late bid price of $4.16 a troy ounce from Friday's $4.11.

DOC.HEAD: Documents Show Industry Lobbied Hard To Sway EPA on Smoking Reports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Rosenberg's area to ``air and radiation,'' sted ``aid and radiation,'' in graf 16, The industry's. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: For three years, the tobacco industry and its Congressional allies have lobbied the Environmental Protection Agency to soften or delay its three draft reports on second-hand cigarette smoke, documents show. Industry representatives sent the EPA a mountain of technical information that dwarfs the EPA's reports and met repeatedly with agency officials to press their concerns, according to documents obtained by The Associated Press under the Freedom of Information Act. ``They clearly were privy to stuff that was going on that we had no idea about,'' said Mark Pertschuk, executive director of Americans for Nonsmokers' Rights in Berkeley, Calif. The EPA at the industry's request twice extended the time allowed for outside comment on draft reports. ``No one else was as active in conveying their concerns and interests,'' said Robert Axelrad, director of the EPA's indoor air division. He said the agency received ``boxloads'' of material from the industry. The next step in the preparation of the reports occurs Tuesday and Wednesday in Washington. An advisory panel chosen by the agency will meet to consider the reports and hear testimony from interested parties, including a dozen tobacco industry representatives. Two of the three reports will be considered: a report assessing the lung cancer risks associated with passive smoking, and a workplace policy guide on environmental tobacco smoke. The risk assessment recommends that environmental tobacco smoke be declared a class A carcinogen - a known cause of human cancer. A third EPA report, a compendium of related technical information on passive smoking, is undergoing revision. Two Republicans from the tobacco state of Virginia - U.S. Rep. Thomas Bliley and Sen. John Warner - have written to the EPA expressing concerns shared by the industry. Bliley has repeatedly sought clarification of EPA procedures and protested the agency's reliance on certain scientists whose work has found large risks associated with passive smoking. Brennan Dawson, a spokeswoman for the Tobacco Institute, said passive smoking is important to the industry and ``we've let the EPA know.'' ``What we have tried to do is stay in the process and do it appropriately and through conversations with EPA staff,'' she said. ``There has been a lot of involvement by the anti-smoking community that we don't think should be there. If you're going to pursue science, it ought to be without advocacy. ... ``The outcome certainly has not been entirely to our satisfaction.'' Most of the EPA's correspondence with industry representatives makes clear the industry's comments are welcome. In a June 30, 1989, letter, however, an assistant administrator of the EPA criticized the industry for its continued refusal to admit that smoking causes cancer and other diseases in smokers. The industry's argument that passive smoking is not a proven danger ``would be more credible if it were not so similar to the tobacco industry's position on direct smoking, despite the estimated 50,000 studies linking smoking with disease in humans,'' wrote William Rosenberg, the EPA's assistant administrator for air and radiation. The industry has been lobbying outside the EPA, too. The Tobacco Institute and the two largest tobacco companies, Philip Morris and R.J. Reynolds, have formed a ``media subcommittee'' to get their message to the media. Three R.J. Reynolds scientists, a company spokeswoman and an adviser from PR firm Hill and Knowlton have been on the road nearly full-time since Labor Day talking to reporters and newspaper editorial boards about the EPA reports, said Betsy Annese of R.J. Reynolds. Anti-smoking groups were critical of the apparent access granted the tobacco companies by the EPA. ``They basically have no business being in there at all,'' said Richard Daynard, an attorney and the chairman of the Tobacco Products Liability Group in Boston. ``Nobody's talking in these proceedings about regulating the tobacco industry. They're talking about regulating individual behavior.'' ``As I look at the intense pressure that the tobacco industry placed on EPA staff, I see that they had a tremendous amount of information about the process,'' said Pertschuk.

DOC.HEAD: Investors Partnership Calls for Avon Stock Buyback
DOC.TEXT: A group of powerful investors increased its pressure on Avon Products Inc. management Monday, calling for the cosmetics company to repurchase $500 million of its own shares. In a letter to Avon Chairman James E. Preston, Chartwell Associates said the move would ``enhance value for all shareholders.'' Chartwell conceded in the letter that such a move ``will require debt restructuring.'' The letter was disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In New York, where Avon is based, Avon spokesman John Cox said there was nothing new in the recommendation. ``Chartwell's letter, in effect, endorses several of the many proposals that have been placed on the table during the last few months,'' he said. ``A special committee of the board of directors is studying all of these proposals with its independent adviser, James D. Wolfensohn & Co., which will present its recommendations to the board in January,'' Cox said, adding, ``Further comment of the merits of the specific proposals would be premature.'' Chartwell, a limited partnership that includes oil heir Gordon P. Getty's Family Trust, controls about 19.9 percent of Avon's stock. The partnership has been wrangling with Avon since last year when Chartwell started buying large blocks of Avon stock and sought seats on the board of directors. The letter to Peterson listed other recommendations proposed by Chartwell's investment bankers, Lehman Brothers. Those recommendations included trying to sell the Giorgio subsidiary, and reappraising the decision to sell a portion of Avon Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Hearings Begin on Trump Taj Mahal Financial Stability
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort got off to a shaky start but a proposed restructuring of $675 million in debt will give it time to recover, casino officials testified Monday. ``The anticipation and expectation was perhaps way too high, knowing what we know today,'' said Ed Tracy, president of Trump's Atlantic City holdings. He and Trump Organization chief financial officer Stephen Bollenbach blamed the casino's problems on the recession in the Northeast and on its failure to capture enough of the lucrative slot machine market. But both said conservative projections for the coming year leave the property poised to recover. ``When times get good again, we'll have a wonderful property,'' Bollenbach told the state Casino Control Commission during a special hearing into the Taj Mahal's financial stability. Trump did not attend the hearing, but his associates said they expected to finish details of the restructuring within a week and file it with the Securities and Exchange Commission Dec. 17. The casino commission said it would hold hearings Dec. 12aand Dec. 19 as details of the restructuring plan are finalized. A ruling would come after Dec. 19, said chairman Steve Perskie. Under state law, the commission is responsible for ensuring that each casino licensee remains financially stable and has the power to revoke a license. One day after missing a $47.3 million bond payment due investors in the Taj Mahal, Trump reached a restructuring deal on Nov. 16 that reduces the interest rate on the notes from 14 percent to 12 percent. The agreement also spreads the repayment date over 10 years to the year 2000 instead of 1998, and gives bondholders half ownership in the Taj Mahal. Trump can recover up to 30 percent of the ownership if he can repay the bonds at rates above 12 percent. The casino plans to enter into a ``prepackaged'' bankruptcy agreed to by bondholders and emerge by the spring, Bollenbach said. State gaming regulators, however, said the plan fails to cut the Taj Mahal's debt significantly.
