They said it was still too early to assess the deal's prospects. ``Regrettably, future stability cannot be adequately judged now but must await an assessment of the final resolution between the Taj Mahal and its bondholders,'' said Deputy Attorney General Thomas Auriemma. ``Nevertheless, to the extent that the crisis which has developed has forced this company to rethink its entire capital structure, there may be long-term positive benefits for this licensee,'' he said. Trump executives continued to play up the agreement. ``The really important element is ... that it reduces the interest rate,'' Bollenbach said. ``A 12 percent rate would be a very competitive rate.'' Another key aspect of the deal would allow the casino to borrow up to $50 million to meet debt service, with bondholders agreeing to relinquish their claim to the new lender, he said. That means the new lender would have first claim if any action is taken against the Taj Mahal. Tracy and Bollenbach noted the Taj Mahal has cut operating costs, with a 29 percent cut in payroll.

DOC.HEAD: Dixon Says He Advised Execs to Have Attorneys to Check Contributions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with late testimony. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Former Vernon Savings Association owner Don R. Dixon, on trial for bank fraud, testified Monday that he told executives of the thrift to check with attorneys before reimbursing themselves for political contributions. Dixon spent all day in the witness chair, his second day of testimony. Prosecutors and defense attorney Billy Ravkind said Dixon would finish testifying Tuesday and the jury is expected to get the case on Wednesday. Some of the 38 bank fraud and conspiracy charges against Dixon accuse him of making illegal political donations with Vernon funds. Former Vernon officers have testified that Dixon encouraged them to donate money to certain candidates and reimburse themselves through falsified company expense accounts. Dixon, responding to Ravkind, said he encouraged political donations to ``try to maintain the environment we were prospering in.'' But he said some officers complained the donations were a hardship. ``If it's that hard on you, you can expense it on our expense account if you can clear it with our attorneys,'' Dixon said he told one Vernon official. He said he didn't authorize any Vernon officer to cheat on expense accounts. He is also accused of using Vernon funds personally for prostitutes, trips and beach houses in California. If convicted on all counts, Dixon could be sentenced to up to 190 years in prison and be fined as much as $9.5 million. During cross-examination, prosecutors focused on an agreement between Dixon and developer Jim Atkinson, who paid for a beach house near San Diego that Vernon and Dixon used. Dixon testified he and Atkinson, a Vernon borrower, had agreed ``on a handshake'' that Atkinson could use the house half the time and receive a share of the proceeds of its sale in return for paying its lease. He said there were no written documents of the agreement for thrift regulators to inspect. Under Ravkind's questioning, Dixon said Vernon needed the $1 million house to boost its image while moving into the southern California real estate market. ``For a little savings and loan from Vernon, Texas, to go to the shores of southern California and attract any type of quality builder-investors, we felt we had to be part of the community,'' Dixon said. He said the house was remodeled to include three master bedrooms and three smaller bedrooms so that it could be used by the thrift's executives while visiting their California operations. He said the thrift had planned to sell the beach house after establishing a permanent office in the San Diego area, which he originally thought would take three years. Vernon was still making payments on the house in 1986, previous witnesses have said. The thrift opened an office in San Diego in 1983, but it did not have facilities for executives, such as a conference room, Dixon said. Dixon also provided details of trips to Kansas and California he took with Linton Bowman, former commissioner of the Texas Savings and Loan Department. The trips were paid for by Vernon. He testified their expense was not harmful to the savings and loan. The California trips were made, Dixon said, so Bowman would ``get comfortable with the rapid growth of Vernon in southern California.'' Dixon also wanted Bowman to check out some car dealership investments he was considering and a computer system developed by a southern California thrift consultant. Dixon said he helped arrange for a female Vernon employee to be a date for Bowman on one those trips. Providing a date was ``probably inappropriate, but at the time I did not think so,'' Dixon testified. He said it was not a ``regular business practice'' for Vernon to provide escorts at social functions and said the thrift never paid women for sex. Dixon said he had no recollection of ``anything off-color'' ever occurring during parties the thrift hosted, as other witnesses have testified. Dixon testified he became concerned about Vernon's financial condition in the mid-1980s when he heard rumors Congress might change tax laws and thrift regulators might step up their efforts. Dixon said regulators, lawmakers and thrift leaders, including himself, should all be faulted for the savings and loan crisis. ``We should all share in the blame,'' he said. Vernon failed in 1987 at an estimated cost to taxpayers of more than $1.2 billion. Dixon, who developed condominiums before purchasing Vernon in 1981, increased the thrift's assets tenfold through speculative real estate and construction deals.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Oilman, Unions to Investigate Foreign Investment
DOC.TEXT: Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens and building trade unions from Ohio and Kentucky said Monday they are starting a research organization to investigate foreign investment in a six-state region. Jerry Hammond, executive secretary-treasurer of the Kentucky State Building & Construction Trades Council, said the study will focus first on Japanese investment in the region's auto industry because of the investments by Toyota, Nissan, Mazda, Mitsubishi, Honda and Subaru-Isuzu. He said the study is likely to expand to Japanese investment in the steel business, Australian regional investments and Italian contractors. Pickens has become a leading critic of Japan's business practices because of his frustrated attempts to get a board seat on a Japanese company he's invested in. He said the Japanese, who are among the biggest foreign investors in this country, are unfairly preventing American entry into Japanese corporate management. He attended a luncheon to give a $5,000 check for the Mid-America Project. The building trade councils of Cincinnati and central Kentucky are joining in the project. Jerry Monahan, executive secretary of the Cincinnati council, estimated the unions would provide about $25,000 in financing. Pickens said he is confident the study will find evidence that Japanese keiretsus - cartel-like organizations of interlocking companies - are operating in the United States to the detriment of outside competitors. Pickens noted that the Federal Trade Commission, at the urging of Congress, is investigating to determine whether Japan is exporting its corporate cartels in violation of U.S. antitrust laws. ``There's no doubt in my mind that the Mid-America Project is going to find that the keiretsu system is being exported to the U.S. and is more damaging than anyone ever figured,'' Pickens said. Union leaders said they want to compile a computerized information database of foreign investment in Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Michigan, Kentucky and Tennessee. They expect the first data by late spring and will use it to assess job prospects and employment practices, and to better understand the objectives of foreign investors, Hammond said the unions intend to be fair to the Japanese in the study. They will gather information from published studies and public information, including corporate filings and courthouse records. ``We see new neighbors we don't know. We hear languages we don't understand,'' Hammond told the union members. ``We don't fear change. ... Change and ignorance is a dangerous combination.'' Union leaders said they contacted Pickens to initiate the research project because they support Pickens' drive for American access to Japanese markets equal to what Japanese companies are granted in the United States. Pickens, founder of Dallas-based Mesa Petroleum, says the management of Japan's Koito Manufacturing Co., supplier of lighting systems for Toyota vehicles, has denied him seats on the company's board and access to its financial documents even though Pickens' Boone Co. investment firm owns 26 percent of Koito. ``All I want is a chance. American shareholders must have the same investment rights in Japan that Japanese investors have in the United States,'' Pickens said. He said 850 of 900 U.S. companies with Japanese investors have Japanese board members. Nori Shikata, press attache at the Japanese embassy in Washington, responded: ``We are not sure how applicable his own specific case is to when he describes the total Japanese environment.'' Shikata said the Cincinnati-based Procter & Gamble Co. is among U.S. companies that have penetrated the Japanese market. ``The people who are not successful tend to complain,'' Shikata said. Koito Manufacturing Co. said through a press statement that Pickens has been harassing Koito in a ``greenmail raid.'' ``Pickens has cynically poisoned Japanese-American trade relations in an effort to advance his own personal financial interests,'' Koito said.

DOC.HEAD: Strikes Idle Ports in Philadelphia, Baltimore
DOC.TEXT: More than 2,000 dockworkers in and around Philadelphia and in Baltimore stayed off the job Monday as strikes prevented ships from loading or unloading during the ports' busiest season. ``We're not going to handle anything without a contract,'' said Dan Duffy, a longshoreman in Philadelphia, where a strike entered its third day. The walkout involves eight locals of the International Longshoremen's Association representing about 2,000 dockworkers at Delaware River ports in Philadelphia, southern New Jersey and Wilmington, Del. The workers went on strike Saturday after rejecting an offer for a new contract by the Philadelphia Marine Trade Association, an employers' group. In Baltimore, business at the waterfront was at a near-standstill after 415 cargo clerks began a walkout Monday after contract talks collapsed over pension and benefit fund contributions. Without cargo clerks to process documents, most ships were not being loaded or unloaded in Baltimore. The strikes coincide with the ports' busiest season, when imported fruit keeps the docks bustling. The Philadelphia-area ports are to receive 22 ships by Wednesday, said Susan Howland, a spokeswoman for the Philadelphia Maritime Exchange. She said five ships already have been diverted to posts in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Virginia. Negotiators for the workers and the Philadelphia-area ports met Monday and were to resume talks Tuesday. The union struck after the dockworkers' 14-month contract extension expired at midnight Friday. The union and the employers could not agree on the terms of a new three-year, 10-month contract. Union and port officials said the stumbling blocks included work rules and employer contributions to welfare and benefit funds. The strike by Local 953 of the ILA in Baltimore was surprising because a tentative agreement was reached Friday with locals representing most of the Port of Baltimore's 2,000 union members. It was not clear whether other locals would honor the cargo clerks' walkout. Baltimore officials had hoped to get some cargo diverted from Philadelphia because of the strike there. Richard Trainor, chairman of the Maryland Port Commission, said the port generates $7.6 million in business a day and can expect to lose $2.5 million each day of the strike.

DOC.HEAD: Union Criticizes Company's Retraining Offer
DOC.TEXT: BASF Corp. said Monday it would spend $400,000 to retrain workers left unemployed by an explosion that damaged one of the company's chemical plants, but a union criticized the offer as a publicity stunt. ``We're all about 50. We have high blood pressure and other ailments. Who's going to hire us?'' said John Littlejohn, vice president of Chemical Workers Local 417. ``We're too old for school.'' Littlejohn said the local's members want the $400,000 divided among the 96 workers who lost their jobs after the July 19 explosion. BASF said it would pay for tuition at vocational schools, books and living expenses. The blast, blamed on explosive fumes from a cleaning solvent, destroyed much of the plant, which made chemicals to coat paper cups and food cans. The explosion killed two people and injured about 80 others. The federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration fined the company $1.6 million in November, citing more than 100 safety violations at the plant. ``While our actions can in no way make up for the hardships caused by the accident, we have tried to do as much as we can, and we will continue to do so,'' said J. Larry Jameson, president of BASF's coatings and colorings division. A three-member panel including an administrator from the University of Cincinnati is to supervise a trust fund to pay for the workers' training, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Hoge Determined News Will Survive Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT typo in `abuses'; SUBS 12th graf, `Hoge estimated ...' to CORRECT that $30-35 million loss figure did not come from Hoge; SUBS grafs 15-16, `The paper ...' to DELETE reference to recruiting homeless and to change subways to subway platforms; SUBS penultimate graf, `Hoge said ...' to recast; picks up last graf, ``I do ...'
DOC.TEXT: Publisher James Hoge said Monday he is determined to lure advertisers and readers back to the strike-hampered Daily News and expects the tabloid to survive and thrive. ``Absolutely. No question about it,'' Hoge said in an interview. ``We will prevail. We hope through settlement, but if not, without it.'' The man at the center of the 5{-week-old strike by 2,100 unionized employees said he is exploring options to take the paper in new directions once the work force is stabilized. Before new plans can be carried out, he said, the strike must end, profits must begin, and the work abuses the News has alleged must be eliminated. As he sat in his eighth-floor office in midtown Manhattan, Hoge spoke as if addressing the picketers on the sidewalk below: ``Fellows, get rid of the inefficiencies with us so we can build a secure future for the next century.'' The News recently spent $3 million to $4 million to select new technology and design new printing plants to be built on land bought in New Jersey and Long Island before the strike, the publisher said. He said expansion options being weighed include creating either an afternoon edition, a satellite-produced national edition or a school edition. At least one was discussed at a Monday morning meeting, he said, but he gave no further details. ``I wouldn't want to put a time on it now,'' Hoge said. ``We have been chomping at the bit to be innovative and try to do things when we think it's practical to do so and that includes variations on what we do today.'' The strike by nine unions, which began Oct. 25, has cost the paper untold millions of dollars. It has been marked by incidents of vandalism against News trucks and against news dealers who carry the paper. The unions say the News engaged in unfair labor practices, which the paper denies, and the News' parent, the Tribune Co. of Chicago, is trying to break the unions, a charge Hoge denied Monday. Major advertisers have deserted the pages of what was, before the strike, the nation's third-largest metropolitan daily, and have fattened the pages of its tabloid rivals. Hoge estimated the paper's losses would total $200 million from 1979 to the end of this year, but he would not specify how much the strike is costing. The News' vice president for human resources, John T. Sloan, has said the paper expects to lose $30 million to $35 million in this quarter. The paper has published every day during the strike, using management, replacement workers and employees who crossed the picket line. But circulation, which was 1.09 million on weekdays before the strike, has dropped drastically. The News filed a civil racketeering suit against the striking unions last week, claiming a pattern of orchestrated violence had blocked the paper's distribution. The paper has used a system of hawkers, numbering more than 1,000, to help sell the paper. Under an agreement reached with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and enforced by court order, hawkers appeared Monday on subway platforms and at commuter rail stations. Transit police said there were no violent incidents. Hoge said the hawkers each day are given their 200,000 papers free and are making 100 percent profit. That helps bring current circulation to 525,000, Hoge said. ``Here it is a question of building back arduously piece by piece the distribution system, and we are doing it,'' Hoge said. ``We went from about 400 sales outlets in the first 72 hours after the strike to well over 4,000 now. We added over 900 last week. We'll add more this week.'' Hoge said he wants to get all parties to the negotiating table and is willing to offer job buyouts if the unions are interested. However, he reiterated the News' demand for an end to what it sees as featherbedding and other labor abuses. ``I do not regret at all that we have in this generation faced up to the issue that you have got to reform the contracts ... because if we did not, the paper could not survive,'' Hoge said.
